1541111.content:
“I’m glad you asked!” Bernie sniggered, dumping out the contents of the sacks onto the floor. “Reclaiming the property of stupid businessmen never felt so good!”

The bags were emptied and its contents spread out on the living room floor of the house. Even though it was pitch black inside, a candlelight cast a flickering glow over the room. Most of the items were standard things one would expect from robbing a research facility. Scattered on the floor were office supplies, tin cases of parts, wires, medical supplies, blueprints and schematics of machines, a few thumb drives, bricks of shiny metals, laboratory equipment, and one bag even contained a thick wad of cash!

“Nice haul, boys.” Amie smiled, sifting through the stolen goods. “I’ll find a buyer for some of these things and – who took these bags of fucking potato chips?” She picked up a dozen small bags of chips and set them aside. Alex chuckled, his deep voice booming, “What? There was a vending machine. I was hungry.” “Who steals potato chips at a laboratory?” Amie cracked a smile, shaking her head in amused disbelief.

“Hey, what’s that?” Bernie asked, pointing to a large metal box.

“That was the thing in the display case.” Alex answered, grabbing it and bringing it closer. “It looked important, so I took it.”

The metal box had no labels, inscriptions, tags, or anything that could describe the thing it held inside. It was a luminescent white helmet. The helmet seemed to glow by itself in the dark room, giving off an effervescent shine the moment Alex took it out of the metallic box. It had a glass visor extending over the front, a few plugins in the back, metal plating surrounding the exterior, and looked like something out of a cheesy 1980s futuristic film. Included in the box were plastic cables, spare plates, electric wiring, and a small paperback manual.

“Fuck that!” Bernie exclaimed, tossing the manual aside and holding the helmet in his outstretched arms. “Oh my god, is this the VirtuSim 3000?”

“That thing the news was talking about?” Alex mumbled, his neanderthallic eyes lighting up.

“It’s still in the prototype stage,” Bernie explained to your group. “Not scheduled for a commercial release for another 5 years at least. The Virtual Reality Simulator, or VirtuSim, is a technological breakthrough. It’s like how the computer was forty years ago. It will change everything!” He proclaimed dramatically. You all hushed him again, and Alex cuffed him in the back of the head again.

He added that the helmet would allow the wearer to experience reality from a different perspective. Although the exact working of the device was lost on a bunch of high school dropout thieves, Amie skimmed through the manual and understood it best.

"Wow," She said, adjusting her flashlight to flip through the pages of the manual.

"Wow what?" Bernie asked impatiently. "How much shit is this worth? I'm guessing thousands, we'll be rich!" You rolled your eyes, but nevertheless hoped that the stolen items would more than compensate the group for taking that risky heist.

"Does it work?" Alex cleared his throat.

"Don't know yet." Amie replied, setting down the manual and picking up the helmet. Rotating it in her hands, she added, "The manual only instructs on how to plug it in, establish a connection, and moderate its power usage. There's nothing here indicating how to use the helmet once you're wearing it. That's why the VirtuSim 3000 is still in the experimental stage. Still just a prototype."

"Well, what are we waiting for?" Bernie said. "Somebody try it out!"

Alex cuffed Bernie on the head again. You sighed, "We're in a shithole of a house with no electricity. We can't leave with the helmet without risking somebody seeing us. And since the heist just literally happened, we need to lie low for a while. Technology like this isn't missed for long."

"I agree with Jake." Amie said. "Let's stash the helmet under the floorboards of this house, then pick it up a week later and move it to someone's place. Not my own, just in case Olivia decides to interfere and fuck things up." She explained, while the boys silently agreed.

"Fine..." Bernie relented. "One week. We meet back here. Then the fun starts!"

15411112.content:
True to your words, the four of you split up for the next week. During the daytime, and on nights when you aren't planning or executing crimes, you four don't see each other much. Amie has her secretary job, you do menial work and short-term projects that you find on Craigslist, Alex hangs out at the public library, and Bernie is... Bernie.

To your satisfaction, the morning news caught wind of last night's heist:

"Early this morning, the Imaginetech research facility, located on 13th and Barstrode Place, was raided. Julia Sanchez is reporting live at the scene."

"Thanks Marcus. Broken windows, lost supplies, and many questions leave authorities searching for clues. At 12:34 am this morning, security cameras picked up footage of two hooded figures entering the research facility and leaving just 6 minutes afterwards, with bags full of Imaginetech items. The company has declined to provide details as to the items in question, but corporate spokesperson Jessica Keene is remaining positive.

"If anything, this crime reminds us to be on the lookout, both inside and outside our organization." Keene said to PRFZ news this morning. "Imaginetech produces some of the most innovative and advanced security systems in the world. We have reason to believe that these criminals had received help from one of our employees in getting into the facility. We are currently investigating the issue."

"Composite rendering from security camera footage suggests that the two criminals are most likely young men, between the ages of 16 and 24. If you have any information that could help authorities resolve this case, please call your silent witness program immediately."

News of the heist also hit newspapers, but thankfully it was buried beneath larger, more controversial stories. It was a hot news cycle, which meant that the public was distracted on other things. Law enforcement was another matter, but you felt confident in your group's safety for the time being.

----------------------------------------

Over the following few weeks, Amie managed to sell off most of the pieces of junk and items for a nice profit. Anything that bore the Imaginetech logo was melted down; Alex converted all metallic items into bars and alloys, to be sold to contractors and industrial parks looking for cheap scrap with no questions asked. This was the procedure, and the four of you had become efficient in both dispersing and disbursing. It paid the bills.

The only thing bothering you was Olivia, Amie's ex-girlfriend. You hadn't heard any updates since the initial news coverage, so whatever happened next was kept pretty quiet. Doubtless, a security company suffering from a security breach would want to sweep a story like this under the rug, no matter how they could spin it. Why were they producing a reality-changing helmet? Why was it so easy to break in to their facility that night? What if Amie's assessment of Olivia was wrong, and she turns you all in? These questions nagged at your brain for each of the next seven days, but there wasn't much you could do about it. Time passed slowly, yet the same questions remained.

As the week drew to a close, you had heard nothing from your comrades and were beginning to feel paranoid. You had also begun to experience very weird dreams, which partially fueled the paranoia.

Every night, the dreams were the same. In a fog, you recall waking up in a bright, sanitized room. It wasn't a hospital, but it looked like... the inside of the Imaginetech facility. You recall feeling very weak and your head feeling heavy in the dream, with shadowy visions of people looming above you, mumbling in and out of earshot. Every night, this dream began the same.

Finally, it was the end of the week. Time to regroup with your buddies and find out more about the news, the heist, the helmet, and anything else you had missed.
You glanced around yourself at the empty street before you; it was night time again, and the milk-yellow streetlights showed nobody else around. You entered the abandoned house and were greeted by Amie, Bernie, and Alex, who were already there and retrieving the helmet.

"Hey, Jake. How was your week?" Amie asked nonchalantly, taking out a wad of cash and extending it out to you. You took the bills and replied, "Lousy. Wondered if you all were alright."

"Alright? I'm better than alright!" Bernie exclaimed, turning around to reveal a brand new smartphone in his hand. "I don't normally approve of consumerism, but I had to splurge. This thing is sweet!"

"You know that phone can track your location, right?" You said. "What's the matter with you? Do you want the police to come snooping around here, catching us in the dark with our pants down like this?"

"That's paranoid." Alex said simply, holding the shiny helmet in his brutish hands. "Don't worry about it, Jake."

"I'm not paranoid!" You retorted. "Can we please get out of here and go somewhere low-key? How about your flat, Alex?"

"Sounds good." He answered. "Let's go."

154111121.content:
Alex's flat, like Alex himself, was of a simple and Spartan design. There was a table, two beds (one for Bernie), a refrigerator, and the bathroom. That was it. If you asked Bernie, he's say nothing more was needed. Alex would agree, albeit for entirely different reasons. Their flat was located about 10 minutes away by car, the same rusted junkpile you used for the heist in fact. After parking in the lot, Alex and Bernie examined their surroundings before giving you and Amie the go-ahead to bring in the Imaginetech materials. Amie carried the wires, plugs, and electric cables in a small cardboard box; you carried the VirtuSim 3000 helmet in its metallic case.

Walking up the stairs to Alex's flat, you laid the case down on the bed and sat down. There was a question you had been meaning to ask the two burglars, which was bothering you lately.

"Hey Bernie, Alex, can I ask you guys a quick question?" You said, while Amie was unwrapping the cables and inserting them into the VirtuSim 3000. "Alex, when you were breaking into the display case holding the VirtuSim 3000, did you notice a bright room anywhere on the floor?"

Alex rubbed his beard for a moment. "Yeah, there was a room like that. It was --"

"Next to a framed poster showing a world map?" You interrupted him. Bernie spun around. Even Amie took her eyes off the helmet and raised her eyebrows at the comment.

"Yeah, there was a map. How did you know?" Bernie answered quietly.

"Did the map say, 'Future Locations of Imaginetech, 2035?' And was there a water cooler on the opposite side of the map, inside the bright room?" You continued, a chill running down your spine.

"What the fuck," Bernie muttered. "I-I-I don't know. Maybe there was a water cooler. I honestly can't remember."

"What's the deal, Jake?" Amie said, her voice emitting equal parts curiosity and concern. "How are you --"

"I can't explain," You interrupted again. "Somehow, the dream that I have been experiencing all week is giving me insight into the layout of the Imaginetech facility. I don't know how this started, or why. But I'm certain that if I go to sleep again tonight, I'll have the same dream again."

A pause filled the room with silence. Alex shrugged his immense shoulders. "You're just feeling paranoid."

"Y-yeah," Bernie agreed, "I mean, every office has a water cooler, right? It's probably just a coincidence. The map thing could be your overactive imagination. It's nothing to stress about, Jake. Just shut your damn mouth and don't lose your head over the heist. That's all."

"Well said." Amie nodded conclusively, although you weren't sure that she sounded as confident as Bernie or Alex. "In the meantime, I've got this VirtuSim 3000 powered up and working. I know how to work the controls. Who wants to go first? I mean, who wants to try out the helmet first?"

"Uh, you can Ames." Alex said. "You know how to use it."

"Alright, but I get to use it second! What do you plan on simulating for yourself, Ames? I'm going to be, like, a movie star or a political revolutionary! Or a motherfuckin' astronaut, with lasers and..." Bernie prattled away, Alex telling him to shut up all the while.

"I think..." Amie glanced downward, her eyes deep in concentration. "I think... I want to be a boy. Just for the simulation."

"A boy?" Bernie squawked. "A boy! That's a dumb idea. Guys are awesome, don't get me wrong, but this is the VirtuSim 3000 here. Think outside the box a little! You could try out all kinds of things, like ......"

Bernie's voice trailed off as he saw the finality in Amie's eyes. This was something more than a gag for her; all her life Amie had imagined what being a boy was like. Now, with this device, a simulated reality like that could be possible. If the helmet delivered on its promises, it could give Amie an opportunity that good looks and a cunning mastermind brain could not give her. Bernie saw this, and despite being a low-life criminal thug, he respected her wishes.

"Fine, but I got next turn." He said.

"How about you go third, and I'll go next?" You said.

"What? Aww, fine, I'll go third." Bernie folded his arms petulantly. "If this thing works."

1541111211.content:
Amie took a deep breath. "Okay, here goes nothing." The helmet gave off a spectacular bright shining, followed by a low humming. Amie tucked in her hair, lowered the helmet over her head, and laid down on the bed. The glass visor slid over her face and she closed her eyes. For a long while, she laid still on the bed, her chest rising and falling slowly with each breath taken. The only sound was the low humming of the machine, its many cords and cables sticking out the back of the helmet and leading into the electrical socket on the wall.

You, Bernie, and Alex took turns looking out the window, patrolling the apartment complex, and generally staving off the impending sense of boredom. There was no way to communicate with Amie while she was experiencing the simulation, which meant there was no way to know if she was doing well or not. In fact, the manual did not describe how to operate the simulation itself, just how to set up the conditions to start the simulation. You were unsure how long a simulation was supposed to last. Would Amie remain there, lying paralyzed on the bed, for hours? Days? Longer than that? There was no way to know for sure.

At some point, you had fallen asleep. The dream you had was much like the others this week. It began with a bright, sanitized room. Your head felt heavy and groggy, and unidentifiable figures hovered over you. They mumbled to themselves. You think you saw an outline of a clipboard at one point. Against the wall was that water cooler, and somehow you knew that outside the room was that framed map.

It was a dream where sensory perceptions were all foggy and distorted, yet you could remember them even after waking up. It was like seeing and not seeing at the same time. Hearing and not hearing. Shadows, ghosts of the dream lingering with you beyond waking up from that dream. It was surreal, even though it was only a dream.

"That's bullshit," You retorted. "I have entire memories of my life. My family, my history, my friends--"

Your exaggerated motion also drew plenty of attention to the plunging neckline and the canyon of cleavage exposed by it. It wouldn’t do to rush in though, better to let some bait out and see if there were any nibbles.

You didn’t notice someone coming up behind you till you heard, “Hey there, good looking.”

Looking back over your shoulder, you saw that it was one of those that had caught your eye. It was…

“Not to your taste?” you asked, extending a finger towards the petplay Raven.

You couldn’t respond to that with more than some rapid blinking for a bit. It seemed like this cow was looking better and better with every passing moment. Turning your gaze back, you saw the submissive Raven lying down at her master’s feet as he got up close and personal with a She-Hulk.

“How about you?” she asked out of the blue, making you return your attention to her luminous eyes.

Shaking your head to get back in gear, “How about me what?”

Despite yourself, you gulped loud enough that you were sure she could hear it. You could feel a blush spreading up your neck as well. You hoped that she wouldn’t be able to see it due to the lighting.

Her drink arrived, putting a hold on any further insight into her mind. Rather than sipping, she gulped down almost half of the glass in a single go. She swallowed her hasty drink before turning to you. “How do you suppose we solve this little impasse?”

“What do you mean?” you asked.

Before you had even finished, you felt her hand gliding up across your thigh before curling up to cup the bottom of your breast,

“Please, it’s so obvious that you want me just as much as I want you. But there can be only one master in this relationship, so again: how do you suppose we solve this little impasse?” She stared right into your eyes, swirling the rest of her drink around the glass with a casual grace.

You could feel your blush blazing ever brighter across your neck and cheeks. Without taking her eyes off of yours, she upended her glass and drained the other half as fast as the first.

“We could make it a game,” you suggested, matching her steady gaze.

The cow snorted, “What, Monopoly or something? That’s how you want to decide which of us becomes the slave?”

It was your turn to shake your head. “Not exactly. I was thinking of something more like…maybe whichever of the two of us was better at guessing personal info about the other.”

She cocked her head, still swirling her drink. “That’s not a bad idea, I suppose. But are you sure that you want to risk yourself on something like that?”

You nodded, and responded with a bit of wit. “I’m sure I’ll have some fun either way,” grinning.

She returned the grin with a sly twist, “You aren’t wrong there. All right, if you’re sure.” She gulped down the rest of her drink, setting the glass down on the bar. “This place even provides something that I think will work just fine…” she said, swiping a finger across the bar.

Soon a digital panel appeared from thin air. Looking it over, you saw that it was a form contract, one dealing with setting the terms for a master-slave relationship. The bovine slipped her finger down across the panel and new text appeared, filling gaps in the contract. Soon, there was only one blank left.

“How long do you want this little wager to be good for?” she asked, turning her gaze back up to you.

You turned away, as if you were thinking about it, even though you already knew for sure what you wanted. You spent several moments watching the petplay Raven, her master, and the She-Hulk al retreated towards the private rooms in the back of the club. The She-Hulk was already acting subservient to him, looking to be well on her way to being another conquest.

As the trio left the main room, you turned back to the bovine. “How about we make it permanent?”

Her eyes went wide for a moment, “Are you sure…absolutely sure that you want to do that?”

You nodded, and she rocked her head back and forth for a bit.

“Oh come on, now you’re getting cold feed…Just imagine the possibilities…” you whispered after leaning close and putting your mouth next to her ear. Meanwhile, you slide your hand down her back, stopping with your fingertips sneaking into the waistband of her shorts.

She bit her lip and screwed her eyes shut, then swiped her finger across the last blank so that it was filled in. You gave her one last teasing huff of breath down her neck before backing off a bit. The two of you then pressed your thumbs to the bottom of the completed contract. The panel warmed beneath your touch before chiming softly and vanishing in a flurry of bits that circled the two of you before vanishing.

“All right, let’s get this started. I have big things planed for you,” she said, a bit of her bravado returning.

154232131111111.content:
As agreed, the two of you brought up data screens about yourselves with the information blanked out. As the two of you made guesses, the other person would reveal each piece if it was true.

The bovine surprised you by being rather astute and made far more correct guesses than you had been expecting. She did make a few wrong guesses though, more than she knew in fact because you let her have some of them. It was simple enough to alter your data screen to show that she had been correct even if she hadn’t in truth. It was just as simple to have all the information about her be displayed on a screen that only you could see and use that to make rather more educated guesses.

Despite having the information at hand, you threw out some guesses you knew to be incorrect to help give her a false sense of success. It worked better than you hoped. Before long, she was all but on the edge of her seat, licking her lips in anticipation of what she was going to do with you. It was time to go for the kill and crush her.

“I’m impressed. I never would have thought that you would be able to get my real age correct,” you said while altering the data to show the number she had guessed.

“What can I say, you’re easy to read,” the bovine said, sipping at another drink. You lost count of how many she had had, but it was enough that she was starting to look a bit tipsy.

“Oh is that so?” you said, and then adding dramatic flair, “We’ll see how easy you are to read.”

You then propped your head in your hand, drumming your fingers on your chin, staring at her.

“Well come on with it,” she said after a few seconds, a frown curling her lips.

“Fine, fine,” you said, consulting your hidden data screen. You then blurted out, “How’s your sister?”

She was good, you had to admit that. She gave almost no sign that what you asked had hit the mark, but it wasn’t enough.

She tried to bluster through. “Oh, so sorry, I don’t have a sister. That means that is your final incorrect guess, so you lo—“

You couldn’t help but let the corners of your mouth turn up a bit. “I mean the one that became part of your family when your father remarried.”

There was a slight tremor of her lips and her eyes went wide for a moment. “What? How could you—?”

“Know that?” you finished for her. “You’re easy to read,” echoing her words from just a little bit ago. “It’s a shame that she didn’t want to be part of your life. It seems that she’s doing rather well for herself in that small town even still though.”

Her face paled and her mouth dropped open. Then she looked rather like a fish with her mouth opening and closing like that. All signs of her slight intoxication fled as her gaze continued to bore into you. You kept a placid smile on your face up till the point where – without another word – she hopped to her feet and started to walk off.

You caught her arm and pulled her close. She struggled until you whispered “Now where do you think you’re going?” into her ear.

“Away from you,” she snapped back. “I don’t know how you knew that, but however it was, I want nothing more to do with you.”

“Oh, that’s too bad. There is the little matter of our contract though.” You kept a hold on her arm while extending your other hand with a flick. The contract appeared in a whorl of light.

“That…that…I…” she started, her mouth again going like a fish gasping for breath. Then screwing her eyes shut, she muttered, “Shit.” Taking a deep breath and holding it for a moment, she then said, “Fine.”

“Really? I hope you remember our little talk about the fight making the prize sweeter,” you said, releasing her arm to sweep your hand across her stomach and up to heft one of her impressive breasts. The soft warmth yielded so deliciously to your hand.

Through her fur, you could see a blush creeping up her neck and into her cheeks. She reached up to try to push your hand away, but it was half-hearted at best.

“I haven’t forgotten,” she muttered.

“Good,” you purred back.

With another flick of your wrist, the contract broke into many little glowing shards. The pieces then reassembled into an intricate and well decorated metal choker.

“Wha–? How…?” the cow muttered.

“A little secret to create something to help you remember,” you responded. A flick of your finger sent the collar whirling through the air till it snapped around her lovely neck. Numb with shock, she didn’t seem to respond at all as you took a tender hold on her arm and started her walking towards the door again. “As you said before ‘I’ve big things planed for you’,” you added with a devious grin.

It was child’s play to alter the door to connect to your home for a brief time instead of the outside of the club. Stepping through with your new pet, you showed her her new home.

1542321311131.content:
Smooth gray skin shined under the pulsing lighting of the club, contrasting with the vibrant violet hue of her hair and eyes. Those eyes all but glittered as she looked at you, nibbling on her lip.

Her companion nudged her in the back and muttered, “Go on, say something.”

The Raven looked close to hyperventilating, but after screwing her eyes shut and concentrating on her breathing, seemed to calm down a bit.

“We saw you come in here,” she sputtered, clearly not as calmed down as you had thought.

“So did most of the people in here,” you noted. Your drink was sat down beside your elbow, and you took a sip.

“No, but—yes.” She huffed and balled up her fists. “What I mean, is that we think you’re exactly who we’ve been looking for.”

“Oh?” arching an eyebrow.

“Oh, come on, Rose, are you sure that this is the one you want?” the Starfire grumbled.

“Shush, Suki. Don’t blow this,” Rose snapped back before turning to you again with a smile, though her lips were pressed into the thinnest of lines. “We” though Suki rolled her emerald eyes at that, “would like to become your slaves.”

You rolled your drink around without taking your eyes off of either of them. “Is that so?” you responded with a casual air.

The darker of the pair nodded with a hopeful air about her, while Suki acted much more aloof. The differences between them extended even further. Rose’s digital form was taller than average with a curvy frame. Her outfit was rather fitting as well with the sleeveless leotard and hooded cloak spilling from her shoulders. Suki the Starfire on the other hand was even taller, almost as much as you were, and her body was limber with a hint of muscle showing through. Her outfit was much more typical and revealing with a tube top and microskirt. Both also wore the simple leather collars provided by the club for those that wished to be dominated.

“What brought you to me then? It looks like you’ve got plenty of other possibilities. Look, that wolf seems to have his eye on you right now.”

Rose looked back over her shoulder with narrowed eyes, “He’s…not really our…type.” Turning back to you with that same hope in her eyes, “You are though! So will you do it, please?” She was all but groveling on her knees at this point. Suki looked on with a frown and wrinkled nose, though you could tell there was a hint of hopefulness about her as well. “You can do whatever you want with us. It’ll be our pleasure just to be with you–“

You cut her off by saying, “Fine, I’ve come to a decision.” Rose looked ready to cry from joy, but it faltered as you continued. “I’ll accept her,” pointing to Suki, “but you I’m not so sure about.”

Both started sputtering and trying to talk over each other in shock and surprise. You managed to hear Rose say, “But why!?”

You waved your hand, “It’ll be entertaining to break her; she doesn’t look like she’s totally accepting of what will soon to be her place. You on the other hand are almost putty already, and that doesn’t sound fun at all.” Inwardly, you were smiling at this turn of events, sure that having both of them under your thumb was going to be very pleasurable indeed.

Suki was fuming, and snapped out, “No way, we’re a package deal; you have to take both of us or neither of us!” She was acting the part of being a fiery redhead, that was for sure. Rose looked touched that her companion was sticking up for her like that. "And I don't even want this," she muttered, almost as if an afterthought.

You sipped your drink and made it look as if you were deep in thought. In truth, you already knew how you were going to solve this little issue. “Tell you what. I’ll give you a little test, do that and maybe I’ll consider taking you.”

“Oh, of course! I’ll do anything! Like I told you!” she cried out, only stopping when you put a finger to her lips.

“Hmm, let’s see. What would be a good test for you? Oh, I know…” you said with a grin curling your lips.

15431.content:
Lindsay struggled to keep the car under control as it bounced through the rutted snow pack streets. The aging Tesla had come with pre-installed All Weather tires that had been more than adequate to drive it off the lot at Farmer Johne’s New and Used, but were outmatched when pitted against the packed ice ruts the afternoons’ traffic had turned the snow clogged streets into. According to Channel 5 this was ‘A Snow Storm of Epic Proportions’, weather that demanded a good set of snow tires to be even marginally drivable in. That, and a defroster that worked half decent. Seriously, how hard was it to design an electric that could handle a standard Canadian winter?
Not that Lindsay was going to do much driving this week-end. Home was a tantalizing four blocks (but probably still a good 15 minutes) away, and once through the front door the next 72 hours would be spent in VR on a server two continents and five time zones away.

Lindsay had gotten into Flight-Sim games in a big way since his first encounter with them while You Tube surfing 2 years ago. The thought of being able to use virtual reality to soar through the clouds had resonated in the imagination of the young, single, and boringly plain minimum wage drone who had always had a fascination with aircraft. Already having the basic VR node now prevalent in every modern household installed in the common room, Lindsay lost no time acquiring the proper plug ins and harness accessories needed, and then promptly lost every minute of spare time for the next three months.
With the basics of flight mastered, Lindsey moved to testing those skills with other VR pilots, both AI and real. Shuttling freight with the various VR airlines quickly grew boring, so it was only natural Lindsay started looking at combat air war simulators.

Two months more time lost, and then Lindsay had come across that message while viewing a favorite You Tube channel.

‘Calling All Fighter Pilots’ the message had said. ‘Scramble! Scramble! Every available man and machine is urgently needed to defend our lines and attack the enemy convoys and cities. Your job is to destroy enemy supplies, capture airfields, and move our lines forward to victory.’

November 1942. The German 6th army’s advance has the Soviet defenders with their backs against the Volga River. The Soviet counter attack, overrunning the 6th army’s flanks surrounding them and cutting off their supplies. Now both sides fight a desperate struggle for to gain control and survive.
Tactical Air Combat Server 12 (Home of the Fighting 75th) is once again hosting its semi annual ‘Battle for Volgograd’ tournament. Based on the historic Battle of Stalingrad, the tournament is a chance to test your skills both as a pilot and a tactician against other like minded pilots in one of the most realistic air battle simulations to date.
Teams of up to 8 pilots will fly up to 150 missions over a 3 day period. These are not ‘Dog-fight for Points’ battles. Each mission’s success or failure directly affects the mission following. Let a convoy slip through and the enemy is re-equipped. Leave a tank convoy intact and it will capture a city. You must destroy or capture all targets and enemy resistance in an area to capture that map. The game is not won until all maps are captured or time runs out.
As a single player the only option for Lindsay to play in the tournament lay with making an application to the various wing leaders who had posted vacancies. Lindsay had sent an application to quite a lot of them, with no results. Until today, with only eight hours before the tournament began and 2 hours into the work shift, Lindsay’s phone had beeped with a message that an application had been accepted, and a pilots slot was waiting at Jagdgeschwader 127th

Finally, after ages of white knuckle driving and more than one ‘not safe for work’ comment about the actions of the other idiots on the road, Lindsay was finally home. Grabbing a liquid meal replacement out of the fridge took less than a minute. A quick trip to the powder room to ‘freshen up’ and don the VR harness took 5 more. Since the next 60 or so hours would be spent under VR, Lindsay made sure the maintenance program was activated, ensuring the physical body would get a rudimentary exercise and feeding. Lindsay would need a good shower afterwards, but wouldn’t starve or suffer bed sores from chafing. A push of the accept button and 2.7milliseconds of mildly disorienting swirling sensations later Lindsay was standing in the virtual entrance hall of Tactical Air Combat Server 12.
The hall, modeled in the fashion of a large hanger, was set up complete with a desk, flag, and large campaign map pinned to the wall. The hall was also worryingly un-occupied. As Lindsay looked around, trying to figure out how to find the entrance to JG 127, a voice came from directly behind. Lindsay turned, and a short man wearing the uniform of an army corporal saluted, saying simply “If you will follow me.”, before turning and walking out one of the doors set into the big hanger door at the front of the building.
Lindsay followed the corporal outside to the sights and sounds of a busy, and air base. Trucks and jeeps roared past, hurrying men and materials to mysterious destinations. Planes flew past overhead. Marching feet and commands echoed in the distance. All the sounds any skilled Foley artist would keep in a folder marked ‘Air Force Base Noises’ for just such an occasion.
A jeep waited just outside the door, and it was a brief drive across to another hanger where Lindsay was deposited in front of the office bearing the sign ‘Jagdgeschwader 127th (Die Wutenden Kuhe)’
Just below that someone had penciled in ‘Snappy uniforms. Good Beer. Cute Accents.’

Passing through the doorway produced the familiar swirling sensation that indicated Lindsay was being transported to yet another section of the server, this one specific to hosting the parts of the program the 127th would be participating in. This time however, when the swirling ended Lindsay was left feeling more disoriented than usual.

Everything seemed larger, brighter, and the colours seemed more defined than normal. Putting a hand against the wall for balance, Lindsay started to take a deep, steadying breath, which turned into a gasp of surprise at the woman standing directly across the room in front of her. The woman, wearing a blue-grey German duty uniform, seemed startled as well, mirroring Lindsay’s movements and putting a hand to her mouth. In that moment Lindsay memorized this vision of beauty. She was a petite little slip of a girl, maybe 160 to 170 cm tall at the most,. Shapely legs showed below the hem of her calf length skirt. Her long blond hair flowed from under the blue-grey Luftwaffe peak cap in two braids that fell one over each shoulder, reaching half way down the chest. A chest that was putting a severe strain on the buttons of the duty blouse visible under the open jacket.

The sound of a chair being pushed back drew Lindsay’s attention. Behind the desk was another woman also dressed in Luftwaffe uniform, this one with insignia that Lindsey guessed indicated she was the flight commander. When the woman came around the desk Lindsay realized who she looked like. The woman’s avatar bore an uncanny resemblance to Heidi Klum.
“First Lieutenant Lindsay Anderson, I presume” The woman said crisply extending a hand.
Lindsay’s “Yes” came out as an oddly pitched squeak, possibly attributable to the weird affects from the portal. Fortunately the woman continued as if she hadn’t notice.
“Colonel Leslie Von Helgameire, commanding officer. Welcome to the 127th”.

Struck by her looks, and well aware of the status of women in Nazi Germany, Lindsay stumbled over the response, blurting out “I certainly wasn’t expecting…” and trailed off, not sure how to put the statement without sounding sexist. True,woman pilots were rare on the German side, let alone as commanding officers. But this was a virtual reality game, so things like the gender bias of the Third Reich didn’t really apply.
“Yes, I know. I don’t think the guy who programmed these avatars has had a date in his life” Colonel Helgameire smiled, completely misinterpreted the cause of Lindsay’s confusion and taking the conversation in a different direction. “I’m pretty sure his inspiration comes from commercials for German beer and keying ‘Fraulein’ into wikapedia”.

Lindsay turned back towards the other woman and got a shock. Standing across from the door was not another woman but instead was a full length mirror.

As if in a trance, Lindsay realized it was HER reflection that was visible. Open mouthed, Lindsay stared, thinking only that there had to be some mistake. Without any conscious thought her hands crept up and cupped her breasts, bouncing them a couple of times, getting a feel for just how large they were.
“Holy crap”, she said, not meaning to say it out loud.
She looked up and saw the Colonel looking back at her, a bemused expression on her face.
"I take it you’re not used to such, shall we say, ample assets"?
“You got that right” Lindsay replied, unable to take her eyes off her reflection. “For Gods sake, I was a man before this”!

“I know what you mean”, the colonel said with a wry smile, “I’ll admit. I wasn’t much to look at myself. Like I said. The kid’s probably never had a date in his life. Don’t worry too much about it. Once you're in your flight suit the girls will be no problem at all”

That’s not what I’m talking about” Lindsay meant to say, but before she could get a word out the colonel started towards a door at the back of the office.
“Come on” she called back over her shoulder as she left the room, “I’ll introduce you to the rest of the flight”.

154312.content:
The door lead into the hanger attached to the back of the office. Most of the hanger space was taken up by a Heinkel HE-111, the open access panels and scattered tools surrounding the twin engine bomber indicating some sort of maintenance work was in progress. The colonel lead Lindsay passed the aircraft nose to a group of five women lounging in the chairs scattered in front of an operations map. As the colonel approached one of the women noticed them and snapped to attention with a crisp “Herr Colonel” and a salute. The rest of the women copied the actions with varying degrees of enthusiasm, most getting immediately to their feet and giving a somewhat sloppy salute of their own, although one woman declined to get up, electing instead to give a lazy wave from her chair that could maybe pass as a salute if you were feeling generous. The colonel seemingly took no notice of this.

“Ladies, listen up. I’d like to meet our latest recruit. This is First Lieutenant Lindsay Anderson”. The colonel turned to each of the women as she introduced them. “Lindsay, meet Captain Beverly Opperman, Captain Colleen Landsdown, Captain Linda Bray-Lewis, Captain Lorraine Peterson, and lastly the lazy ass over there is Major Lana-Raye Modsley, your squadron leader”.

Each girl in turn acknowledged her introduction with the same varying style salute they had greeted the arrival of the colonel with. As they were introduced Lindsay was struck by how similar in appearance they all were. All were wearing the same duty uniform as Lindsay, although given the game was supposed to replicate the feel of an air force squadron that was to be expected. What wasn’t expected was that all the women had the same slim build Lindsay had just seen in the office mirror. All had their strawberry blond hair done up in pigtails of varying lengths and styles. All had the same pale creamy skin and bright blue eyes. And all had the same need for double re-enforced blouse buttons. There were just enough variations in height and facial features that Lindsay felt that, given time, she might be able to keep track of out just who was who. For now though, the name tag on the uniform jacket was the biggest help.

The whole squad was unmistakably female. Lindsay wondered if this had anything to do with her current situation, and also wondered just how she could broach the subject.
“Colonel, she started slowly, “I, ah, noticed that the squad seems to be, ah, well…” Dam’d. Lindsay had never been good at awkward situations, and was having trouble trying to formulate the question of how she had wound up here in an all female squad. Unfortunately, the colonel suddenly looked at her watch and cut her off in mid sentence.

“Sorry Lindsay, it looks as though our last pilot is on her way here. I’ll let you get to know the others while I go I fetch her”.

The woman wearing the name tag of ‘Opperman’ came over to where Lindsay stood with her mouth still open, the interrupted question on her lips.

“So I bet you were going to say how we all looked the same, right”? Beverley asked. Without waiting for Lindsay to reply she continued “It’s the avatar base models. The127th was only created a couple of weeks back, and the programmer only managed to get two base models in before the application deadline. The Colonel got the Heidi one because she’s in charge. The rest of us, well. As you can see”. She gestured around to the rest of the squad. “Don’t worry. It’s just like twins. They may look the same at first but after a while you can tell them apart”.

“Or Chinese people” the woman with the Tag ‘Landsdown’ added without being asked. “They’re just as hard to tell apart”.

“Thank you Colleen” Beverly said irritably.

“And Japanese. Never can tell one from another.”

Beverly rolled her eyes, seemingly far more irritated that the simple remark warranted. “Yes Colleen”, she sniped “Thank you for also adding that timely and completely non-racist observation to our conversation”.

“You know me”, the woman addressed as Colleen returned as if nothing was amiss “I call it like I see it”.

“Then you should try calling it a little less offensive next time”. Beverly snapped

“Ooohh” Colleen teased ’A little touchy today, aren’t we. This wouldn’t have anything to do with your recent sensitivity training, would it”?

“That has nothing to do with this” Beverly replied, more angrily than Lindsay thought the situation warranted “I’m just asking you to show a little respect”! With this Beverly stalked off and threw herself angrily into one of the folding chairs at the far end of the room. The chair creaked alarmingly but thankfully didn’t collapse

“God”, Colleen snickered, “She is so easy to get a rise out of”.

“You shouldn’t tease her about that” The woman wearing the tag ‘Modsley’ lectured sternly. “You know how upset she is about the whole thing”.

Colleen rolled her eyes. “She needs to grow a thicker skin. I’m just trying to help with that”.

“There’s teasing and then there’s this shit. This event is supposed to be fun and here we are not even half an hour in to it and you’ve already got her bawling her eyes out”.
“She’s not crying” Colleen protested, looking over to where Beverly sat with her face buried in her hands. “Well, not that much” She continued uncertainly, seeing Beverly’s shoulders shaking with sobs. “Oh shit” Colleen was quiet for a couple of moments, then softly spoke “Okay. Maybe you’re right and I crossed a line. Or two. I’ll.. I’ll talk to her”. With that she stood and walked softly over to where Beverly was sitting.

“What was that about”? Lindsay asked as she watched he walk away.

At the far end of the row of chairs Colleen was trying to put a comforting hand on a shoulder whose owner wanted nothing to do with her. Lana-Raye watched the interplay for a couple of moments before explaining.

“In real life Bev works in customer service. Crappy job but it’s all she has for now. And in spite of all the shit she has to deal with she never let it get to her. Until now”

“So what happened”?

At the end of the row of chairs was Colleen was kneeling, finally having got Beverly to stop pushing her hand away every time she put it on Beverly’s shoulder.

“A month ago some customer wanted to do something that wasn’t allowed and when Bev wouldn’t help they played the race card on her. Typical knee jerk management jumped and sent her for a mandatory two weeks of cultural sensitivity training. Since it was the result of a complaint it was deemed an ‘unpaid necessary absence’. They actually threatened to fire her over it if she didn’t go. Never mind that she’s a minority herself and one of the nicest, knowledgeable, and most helpful people you’ll ever meet, and that she was following their own bloody written procedure. As for Colleen, well, she likes to take a tease too far. She’s a nice enough person, but her brain sometimes forgets to pay attention to her mouth.

At the far end of the chairs the two women were hugging at this point, so Lindsay decided it was as good a time as any to try and get answers to her own situation.

“So”, Lindsay began, gesturing to the rest of the women in the room. “I take it this is an all female squadron”.

“Yep” Lana-raye said casually, deciding that the passing crises had been a minor one and flopping back down in her own. “Colonel Helgameire’s idea actually. She had a bad experience with her last group and figured she could do better in a less misogynistic environment”.

Well, if that’s the case I don’t know what I’m doing here. I’m not…

“Herr Colonel”! came a shout from one of the other girls.

The colonel had returned, triggering another round of sloppy salutes. She was followed closely by an unsurprisingly pony tailed woman in a pilot’s uniform.

“Girls. I’d like to introduce to you the last recruit for our squad. This is First lieutenant Addison Garlander. Addison, this is Captain Linda Bray-Lewis, Captain Lorraine Peterson, First lieutenant Lindsay Anderson, The weepy one over there is Captain Beverly Opperman, the damp one with her arm around her is Captain Colleen Landsdown, and that unmovable lump in the chair there is Major Lana-Raye Modsley. She’ll be your squadron leader, if she ever get’s around to moving her butt out of that chair.
Once again each girl gave the new arrival the same salute as earlier; even Beverly managed a weak if somewhat soggy smile and flip of the hand. Lindsay was surprised to see Addison return each salute with a snappy, well executed salute of her own.

The colonel clapped her hands for attention. “Alright people. Lecture time. Game starts in 20 minutes so have a seat and listen up”.
The room filled with rumbles, squeaks, and groans as chairs were rearranged and occupied. After the noise settled the colonel began.

1543121.content:
The colonel stood in front of the operations map where all the chairs could see her.
“As you know” she said in a clear voice that would be at home in a lecture theatre, “This is the sixth tournament that Combat Server 12 has hosted. I’m sure you all read the tournament rules, but I want to go over a few of the major points just to make sure we’re all on the same page. That and there are also a few last minute announcements to pass on”.

“Announcement One: Because of the number of registrants for the tournament, server administration has adjusted some of the settings. Game time to Real time ratio is now set to 24:1. The battle map has been increased to a 50 x 50 grid. A decisive victory is now set at first to reach 97% possession, or 75% plus by tournaments end. Marginal victory is set at 66% plus, and a stalemate is set at 60%. Real time kill notifications and mission results are off but will be updated along with the rest of player stats on the squadron leader board before the start of the next mission”.

“Announcement Two: As a result of a complaints investigation, the 47th Grizzly Rider Squadron has had its permission to participate in tournament play revoked, pending appeal. All squadrons are reminded that artificial targeting systems, navigation aids, and other game modifications not approved by the tournament organizers are not allowed and will be dealt with in a similar fashion”.

“Now. First order of business:. We have a registered strength of eight pilots. That is the bare minimum for an active squadron so we cannot afford to have anybody drop out for any reason. I have a couple of relief pilots in the works but nothing certain, and definitely nothing before tomorrow, real time. That’s about 2 weeks down the road game time. I know this might seem tough, but I am confident we can handle this”.

“Planes are allocated by unit strength. The 127th qualifies for two of the Henklel bombers for being a squadron, plus one plane per registered pilot, plus one back-up plane per pilot. We’ll start off in BF109s, F4 variant, After mission 5 we’ll start seeing the G2’s, if we can afford them. By the end of mission 20 we’ll get the FW190s. If anyone wants to try their hand in a Stuka they’ll be available starting mission 15. Your back-up planes will always be the F4s, no matter what”.

“Second order of Business, and I want you to pay very careful attention to this: Server 12 is not a Dog Fight server. They have tried very hard to make this tournament as close to a realistic air campaign as possible. What this means to you is that your virtual life and your virtual plane are your most precious resource. Yes Lorraine, I’m looking at you. If you die up there you are out for the rest of that mission. If you lose a plane it is gone. If you are one of those who are used to the ‘Engage at will and fight to the deck with the last bullet’ style of combat you will need to adjust to the new reality. Your stats only count if you are not killed or captured. And I’m still looking at you Lorraine”.
“Sometimes this will mean electing not to engage the enemy if the odds are not right, or disengaging when the advantage is no longer on our side. Listen to your leader and if they say disengage, do it”.

“Third order of business: If at all possible try to bring your machine back. As long as you can land at a friendly air base you can get repaired and get back in the mission. This does NOT mean you risk your life in a burning crate. If you have to bail, you bail.

“Now for your flight orders. Our first mission will be to fly top cover for the 83rd, who are bombing a train yard in quadrant 306. This should be fairly easy as we’ll be above the flak for the most part and there are no enemy patrols anticipated in that area. It’s a good mission to start with. That does not mean we can sleep though it. I expect everyone to look sharp. If the 83rd looses a plane I don’t want anyone saying it’s because of lack of effort on our part.

That’s it. If there are no questions I suggest you all head to your quarters and get ready. I want you all on the line at Oh Nine Hundred. That’s fifteen minutes. Dismissed".

Again the hanger filled with noise as the squad got to their feet and gathered up their belongings. As the rest of them wandered out the doors Lindsay held back, still wanting an answer as to how she had ended up in an all female fighter wing as a female pilot.

After the others had left, Lindsay approached the colonel, clearing her throat.

“Yes, Anderson. What is it”?

“Excuse me Colonel, but I’m not really sure why I’m here. I ‘m not…

15431212.content:
“Yes, Colonel, but the truth of it is, I...”

At that moment the air was pierced by the blast of an air raid siren.

“What the Sam Hell”?!? The colonel swore, then moved quickly but with a still dignified pace into her office, leaving Lindsay alone to fend for herself. After a moment of wondering just what was going on, she realized an air raid siren was probably a warning of something dire, and raced out the door the rest of the squad had taken, hoping to catch up with them. Halfway across the field the mysterious siren abruptly shut off, leaving the roar of the airfield seeming quiet in comparison.
By the time she’d located the barracks the rest of the girls were almost fully changed. Locating a locker with her name on it, she quickly pulled off her duty uniform and climbed into the beige coverall flight suit, stuffed her feet into the fur lined boots then grabbed a black leather jacket off the cot next to the locker. Only one helmet was still on the shelf by the door as she passed, so she grabbed it and put it on, stuffing her ponytail up into it as best as she could as she ran to catch up with the rest of the squad.

The ground crew were just pushing the Messerschmitts out of the hangers as the group arrived The sun had been up for almost an hour but had done little to relieve the cold of the mid November morning. Lindsey hadn’t noticed the cold on her way to the barracks earlier, likely because she was distracted by the urgent need to change. Now, standing with the thin Russian wind whistling around her while they waited for the aircraft to be positioned, she was glad of the well padded flight suit she was wearing, both for it’s warmth and it’s bulkiness. With their exaggerated curves wrapped in the beige padding the group lost the blond bombshell appearance and now looked like any typical batch of pilots, waiting for the ground crew to get the aircraft in position.
The Messerschmitts were brand new, judging by the way the paint gleamed in the early morning sun. Climbing into the cockpit confirmed this. The knobs shone bright and colourfully, the polished glass on the gauges glittered, the painted surfaces were smooth and free of the chips and scratches that a working plane developed so quickly. The leather padding of the seats and gunstock were still without cracks or marks. Lindsay felt a shiver of excitement run through her body as she sat in the pilot’s seat and inhaled deeply. Even the smells were new, like climbing into a new car for the first time, but without the cheap cologne smell from the sales guy.
The rapture of the moment was broken by the lead handler signaling for engine start, so Lindsay busied herself with the complex task; Magneto, throttle, prop, fuel. A litany of adjustments that, if she had to list out loud would have taken her forever, all quickly set by muscle memory trained by months of practice. Less than 30 seconds later Lindsay pressed the Ignite switch, and the big V12 coughed and rumbled to life.
While she waited for the engine to warm up she checked the controls, like any pilot would, making sure they were all working. And working they were, fully functional and oh, so smooth. Lindsay again felt that shiver inside her as she played with the rudder and stabilizer controls, feeling how smoothly the cables and levers responded to her touch, the stick between her legs seeming to glide up and back with hardly any effort at all. A glance at the oil temperature gauge brought her back to reality, or at least back to this reality. 40 Degrees C. Time to go. Brakes off, a burst of throttle, and the aircraft began to trundle up the taxiway towards the runway where the flight was forming up. A touch of the toe brakes swung her in position behind and to the right of the forth plane where she stopped, locked the brakes and ran the engine RPMs up and back. Everything was functioning smoothly, so she dropped the engine back to idle and waited for the stragglers to form up behind her, passing the time playing by with the controls and marveling again at how smooth they worked.

As the last aircraft in the group pulled into position the flight leader radioed for take off, and began to move down the runway, slowly picking up speed. As a group the second, third, and forth planes immediately followed. Lindsay hit the throttle to stay in position and suddenly realized that, for all her hours of practice, she’d never taken off in formation. It was a lot more nerve racking than she’d expected. As she picked up speed she had to be careful not to run into the aircraft ahead of her, and also not to change speed so abruptly that the aircraft behind would run into her. It was the most nerve-racking maneuver she’d tried so far; The plane bounced and bucked over the hard pavement, forcing her to make rapid small adjustment to the rudder to keep in line with the plane ahead and away from the plane to here immediate right. Sweat was trickling down the side of her goggles by the time the tail came up level and the plane really started to pick up speed. Someone cursed over the radio, but Lindsay was too busy to spare the time to wonder who. Finally the speed indicator showed 180 and she pulled the stick back. The ride immediately became a lot smoother as the wheels left the pavement and the plane floated upward, into it’s natural environment at last.
15431212.title: If it can go wrong...

choices: Who put these holes in my brand new base?
Where does a girl get a bite to eat around here?
154312122.content:
By the time Lindsay had retracted her landing gear the entire group was chattering over the radio.

“Oh! My. God! That has to be the sloppiest group takeoff I’ve ever seen”.

“Sloppy or not, at least we all made it in the air”.

“Lorrane almost didn’t. My God girl, I came this close to shredding you”.

“So I noticed. What did you think you were you doing”?

“I didn’t see you. Do you know how bloody hard it is to see over the nose of this thing with the tail down”?

“Well, keep your distance next time”.

“I don’t think there should be a next time”.

“I’m with you. Let’s not do this again”.

“Who’s stupid idea was it to take off in formation anyway”.

“That would be the Colonel’s”.

“I beg your pardon”. The colonel’s voice finally broke in on the chatter, indignantly dripping ice from every word. “I said no such thing”.

“Well, you gave the take-off signal, and we thought that’s what you wanted”.

“You thought so, did you”? The cold tone in the colonel’s voice came clearly through the radio. “Well as of this moment there will be no thinking in this unit unless I give the order”.

A voice came back with “You got it, chief”.

‘That’s Colonel to you, Bray-Lewis. Keep it in mind or I’ll put you on KP duty when we get back”.

Lindsay wasn’t sure how the Colonel could tell who was who over the radio, all the voices sounded the same to her.

Someone said “The game has that”?

The Colonel (Okay, Lindsay definitely could tell ONE voice apart from the others) came back hard with a snapped “If it doesn’t I’ll find something equally as unpleasant. Now can the chatter girls and listen up”.

“Modsley, take Landsdown, Peterson, and Anderson. You’re going to be Red Flight today, use the even number call signs. Bray-Lewis, Opperman, Garlander, you’re with me. We’re Blue Flight, and we’ll take the odd number call signs”.

One of the aircraft pulled up and slightly away from the milling group and waggled its wings. “Okay girls. Red leader to Red Flight, fall into position and check in”.

At this two other aircraft pulled into position to each side and slightly behind the lone aircraft.

“Red uhh, what, Red one here?

“Wrong Colleen. You’re Red Two. Even numbers, remember”.
“Okey dokey Red leader”. Colleen’s ever chipper voice came back. “Red Two checking in”.

“Red, mmm, that would be Four, right”?

“Yes Lorrane, you would be Four”.

Lindsay was maneuvering into line behind the left hand plane. Whether it was Red Two or Red Four she wasn’t certain. “Red Six here, she said” as soon as she was in position.

“Red Six”? Lana-Raye asked, obviously not hearing her. “Come in Red Six”.

“Red Six Here” Lindsay said, a louder this time.

“Red Six? Lindsay, you need to press your mike button when you talk if you want us to hear you”.

Lindsay groaned, realizing her rookie mistake. Pressing the button at her throat she tried a third time “Sorry. Six here” hoping that her embarrassment wouldn’t show in her voice.

“That’s Red Six. Don’t forget the colour. Red flight all present and accounted for”.

“Blue leader to Blue Fight. Form up and check in”.

As if to prove their superiority, the blue pilots executed their maneuvers quickly and without hesitation.

“Blue Three, here”.

“Blue Five, present”.

“Blue Seven here”.

“Modsley, your group will be flying escort. Take Red Flight to 7,000 and rendezvoused with the 83rd. Blue Flight will climb to 10,000 and fly top cover from there.

“Roger that, Les”.

“It’s Colonel to you as well, Modsley, unless you want to join Bray-Lewis on KP”.

“Ah, Roger that, Colonel. Red Flight, turn to 130, speed 280. Let’s get out of here before we’re ALL peeling potatoes”.

Lindsay found flying formation a lot harder that she expected. Sure she’d practiced, but the AI flying the wing man position seemed to have no problem keeping up. Lindsay, on the other hand, was out of position almost as soon as the flight started to climb. When she leveled out at 7,000 she found the rest of the flight was nowhere to be seen. She was just starting to feel dread at being lost and alone when the other three planes appeared, pulling up from behind. The relief she felt at seeing them was short lived though, quickly banished by the realization that she hadn’t spotted them until they pulled into position. And these were friendly aircraft.

Either because they had decided to go easy on her, which she doubted, or because they hadn’t noticed her panic, the flight continued towards the rendezvous coordinates without anyone saying anything, for which Lindsay was grateful. It was a little easier to keep formation now that they were in level flight, although more than once Lana-Raye was on the radio telling her to get back into position.

Flying formation with the dozen bombers that made up the 83rd was even easier, although that may have been just because she’d gotten better at it by the time they made the rendezvous. The lumbering Henkel 111’s were slower and easier to keep pace with, and any drifting could be excused as ‘Just maneuvering to get a clearer look around’.

Keeping formation was the most exciting thing that happened during the mission. Only twice did an enemy patrol appear, only to turn tail and run before they could be chased off.
Over the target Red Flight hung back at 4500 while the 83rd went down into the flak to drop their loads, then came back up to regroup remarkably enough completely unscathed. From there it was an even less eventful trip back into friendly territory and then to base for both groups.
154312122.title: That's the 83rd, I presume.
