1543121222.content:
Lindsay was half afraid that, along with everything else she’d done wrong, she’d cap it off with a botched landing, but to everyone’s surprise Lindsay’s touchdown was right out of the textbook, on first approach and not even a single bounce.

Debriefing was in the main hanger, where the Colonel discussed a few of the problems encountered, mainly Lindsay’s inability to maintain formation, and told them how they would be resolved. The major would take Lindsay and Addison up again for a few hours practice, with Colleen filling in as a forth.

There were a few groans, mostly from Colleen, but no serious objection. Actually, Lindsay was looking forward to taking her machine up again; even if it wasn’t purely for fun at least it wasn’t going to be as stressful as a true patrol would have been.

When they headed out after lunch they were surprised to see that this time unit markings had been painted on the fuselage behind the cockpit of each plane, with the pilot’s name and rank painted along the sill of the cockpit side window. Lindsay found she was now permanently assigned as JG-127-06
In addition to the unit markings, a picture of a cartoon biplane being piloted by a cow had been painted onto the engine cowling. Drawn as a caricature, the cow’s big pink nose protruded forward halfway over top the machine gun mounted on the biplanes’ nose, the cow’s mouth was wide open and the tongue was flapping backwards in the wind. The hide was the black and white pattern classic to the Jersey breed, although any horns it may have sported were hidden underneath the leather flying helmet and goggle.
In all, the artist had done a very good job at creating a cartoon image that was unmistakably that of a cow flying a biplane.
The afternoon’s two hour practice went well, and wound up stretching late into the afternoon, ending only when the radio reminded them that the mess hall would only be serving dinner for another hour.

Dinner was served in the traditional mess hall manner, the surly looking cook slopping a variety of questionable looking items into the compartments of an olive drab tin tray.
Traditional military lore claimed that the army had designed the multi-compartment tray system (Winco mess tray, compartmentalized, style B) so that various items would not combine and detonate prematurely. Lore also stated that, while biologically the human body needed 48 hours to turn food into excrement, a trained army chef could do it in 45 minutes. Maybe it was because the mess hall was air force instead of army, but Lindsay found that, while the presentation may have lacked a certain something, the food itself was excellent. She had just polished off the entire tray and was thinking about how she could get away with seconds when Colleen plopped herself down across the table from her.
“Pretty good grub eh”? She asked, seeing Lindsay trying to scrape the last oh so tasty morsels of food out of the edges of the cups.
With a small sigh of regret Lindsay pushed aside her empty tray. “I always thought military food was supposed to be 2 steps below airline quality, but that was amazing”!

“Yeah, it is”. Colleen grinned “The game has us living in war time conditions, but there’s no need to go overboard. We are supposed to be doing this for fun, after all”. She stood up again “Come on” she said “If you’re finished the rest of us are going over to the bar”.
Lindsay put her tray on the dish rack and hurried after Colleen “We have a bar on base”?
“Sure” Colleen called back, “Where else do you think we get drinks”?

Colleen led Lindsay across the compound to another drab tent, one with a wooden sign ‘Die Wutenden Kuhe Gasthaus’ over the door.
The bar tent was smaller than the mess hall, but still big enough for a long table with bench seats down the middle and a couple of smaller round tables with miss matched stools jammed against one wall. Along the opposite wall was a set of cupboards book-ended by a large ice chest on one end and a jukebox, currently playing some 1945 swing blues, on the other. The top of the cupboard was lined with bottles and glasses, and obviously served as the self serve bar. Over the cupboard hung the obligatory 2 blade aircraft propeller standard as decoration in any air force bar, and above that hung a copy of the same cartoon cow that decorated the nose of the squadron aircraft.
1543121222.title: Practice before dinner

choices: Take the easy way out, let them assume you have boys on the brain
15431212222.content:
Colleen tossed a couple of bills into a beat up cigar box and pulled two beers out of the ice chest. Handing one to Lindsay she gestured around the room.
“Velkome to Gasthaus Die Wutenden Kuhe, Offizial home avay from home ov ‘Das Jagdgeschwader 127th ‘ Where ze vomen are real vomen, Ze beer iz ize kold, and ze men are non exzistant.
“No men allowed”? Lindsay questioned, assuming that one of the signs in German posted outside must have said that

“Nein, Ze Colonel vud hav zem shot on zite. Girlz only iz ze bar motto, lok, zee? Iz even posted on door. But don vorry, here you vill vind every zing else ze girl needs to be happy. Alkohol. Beer. More alcohol. Chokolat, zappy muzic, and over zer, ze rest ov your squad matez.
Colleen gestured towards each of the items as she listed them off, but seeing as ‘over there’ was about two feet away, that gesture almost knocked someone’s hat off. Colleen continued as if nothing happened.

“Girlz, look Vo I haft vound”.

She took a seat on one side of the table, gesturing for Lindsay to take another. A couple of the girls were already sitting, beers of their own in front of them.
“Hey Lindsay”, Lorraine greeted them as they sat down “Colleen, what have I said about your Hollywood German”?
“Hollywood German”? Lindsay felt compelled to ask
“In the movies bad guys always spoke English with a bad German accent” Lorraine explained.
“But zeest time ve are ze goot guys, ya”?
“Yeah, Colleen takes that bad accent and mangles it beyond recognition” added Linda, settling down beside Lindsay with a beer of her own.
“Juzt getting into ze karakter”
“Well your character still sounds like some B grade movie director couldn’t decide if their villain was a Nazi or a Vampire” said Lorraine with a roll of her eyes. “Please don’t”.
Colleen’s response was to give a mock stiff armed salute ““Ve fly for Ze Glorious Fatherland, En ze finest of movie traditions, ve should all use ze accent to reflect zat”.
A couple more girls had grabbed beers and joined the table, voicing various, but unanimously negative, opinions on Colleen’s accent
“That’s doesn’t even sound German, it’s more French.”
“Nien” protested Colleen, “Zounds verry German to me. Is goot aksent”.
“Is terrible accent. Now it sounds like you’re trying to be Russian. Stop it”.
“Oh, for pete’s sake”, Lana-Raye scolded, obviously the only one that was on Colleen’s side “let her have her fun”.
“I’d like to point out that, if we were really speaking German we wouldn’t notice the accent”. Addison added, eager to be a part of the conversation”.
“And I’ll point out that Lorraine is being a kill joy” said Lana-Raye, pressing her point.
“Nien, nien,” Colleen said, waving her hands to emphasize her words. “Is merely jellies bekause ov mine mastery of Ze German aksent”.

Lorraine leaned back with an exasperated sigh. “No”, she said “I am just tired of trying to figure out what you are saying. Tell you what, how is this for a fun compromise? If you promise to pretend you are speaking English with a German accent, I promise to pretend to listen in German with an English accent, okay”?
Colleen twisted her mouth sideways and up as she mocked thinking about it, one finger pressed to her pursed lips. She looked so comical Lindsay almost burst out laughing when Colleen grinned and said “Ja, Zat Zounds goot to me”.

Having extracted the promise that there would be no more attempts at speaking with a German accent, at least until someone conveniently forgot, the conversation turned to the hundred other little topics that women discuss while sitting around a table drinking beer. Lindsay half listening to the other women gossip, a little afraid to join in for fear of slipping up and giving herself away. Instead she nursed her beer and let the words wash around her while she studied the cartoon of the squadron’s mascot. There was something, well, off about it. Maybe it was the way the tongue had a little twist at the end. Maybe it was the cartoon eyes pointing in different directions. Or it could have been the drops of spittle trailing down the bi-plane fuselage. These little details added a deeper meaning to the overall picture. A meaning that said ‘Back away slowly and don’t make eye contact’.

“Earth to Lindsay, are you there”?
Lindsay realized that Lorraine had been asking her something “What? Sorry, I wasn’t paying attention”.
“I’ll say. I’ve been talking to you for a couple of minutes. Did you hear anything I said”?
“No”, Lindsay apologized “I’m sorry, I spaced out there for a bit”.

“No kidding”! Lorraine braced her chin on her folded hands and leaned in closer, a impish look of interest on her face. “So just how good looking is he”?
“Who’s good looking”? piped up Colleen, interested enough to turn away from her conversation on prop pitch controls she had been having with Lana-Raye.
“This guy Lindsay’s been thinking about”. Lorraine responded.
“What guy”? Lindsay asked, still clueless as to which direction the conversation had turned.
“The one you’ve been thinking about for the last 5 minutes”.
Lindsay stared at the circle of faces looking at her, confused. A few moments later her brain processed what her ears had heard, flushing them a bright pink.
15431212222.title: Someone else is already there

choices: You don't have to be mad to work here
154312122222.content:
“I wasn’t thinking about a guy”! Lindsay protested.
As if on cue, all the girls let out an exaggerated “Oohed” and all started talking at the same time.
“Something sure had your attention”.
“So it was a girl, then”?
“Or maybe it was several guys”!
“Oh, I want to hear more about that”!
“I’m not surprised YOU would”.
“I’d be more surprised if you didn’t”
“No, no, no, no, no”! Lindsay protested over the teasing babble of girls all talking at her at the same time. “I’m not thinking about men at all” Realizing that statement didn’t exactly get her free of teasing territory, she hastily added “I was thinking about that picture”! And with her free hand she gestured at the caricature on the wall.
“Oh, that”. Lorraine said, obviously disappointed that men, or possibly women, singly and in groups, were not going to be the current topic of conversation. “Lana-Raye here drew it as an art project for school. Leslie saw it, added the slogan, and co-opted it as our squadron mascot. Pretty good huh”?
“I’ve been trying to puzzle out what the slogan means”.
“You haven’t figured it out yet”?
“I don’t know a lot of German, other than what’s on the instrument panel”, Lindsay admitted, “I know that ‘Die’ doesn’t refer to death but instead means ‘The’, but that’s about it”.
“Not even a guess?” Lorraine pressed.
Silence had fallen on the tent and Lindsay was uncomfortably aware that every eye in the place was on her, watching expectantly.
“Well” Lindsay reasoned slowly, out loud, “the word ‘Kuhe’ probably means cow, since it sounds like it, and there is a cow in the picture. Wutenden probably means, what? Wonderful? Or maybe flying? ‘The Wonderful Flying Cow’”?
Lorraine grinned “Not even close. Kuhe is German plural for cow, so that part was close, Wutenden is a phrase that means ‘not quite right in the head’, if you get what I mean”.
Not right in the head? Stupid? Crazy? Insane? Lindsay went through the list of all the synonyms she could think of that fit the definition, stopping suddenly she realized just what word fit perfectly with the cow’s expression.
“Oh my God”, she groaned, as the watching group erupted in laughter at her expression. “I’ve joined ‘The Mad Cows’”
154312122222.title: Deny everything

1543121222221.content:
“Congratulations” Colleen said gleefully, thumping her on the back “you figured it out”.
“Here, drink this” Lorrain said, setting a shot glass filled with a dark brown opaque liquid in front of Lindsay.
“What’s this”?
“Victory shot”. Lorraine said, holding up her own identical glass “its tradition. Cheers”! Lorraine lifted her glass in salute and then effortlessly swallowed the contents.
The other girls lifted glasses of their own, so Lindsay gamely followed suit, only realizing her mistake after the stuff had left a burning trail down her throat.
“What is this stuff”? She gasped when she finally managed to catch her breath through the fumes.
“Jagermeister” Lorraine said, grinning as she watched Lindsay gasping.
“It’s awful”! Lindsay’s body involuntarily shuddered as she spoke “You would think they would have modeled the taste on the real thing”.
Lorraine shrugged “They did”
“You’re joking! The real stuff couldn’t possibly taste that bad”.
“Sadly, it does. I used to drink it in school. And before you ask why, it’s the only thing the boys would bring to parties”.
“Oh yeah”, Colleen added “The official drink of pimply faced little boys trying to prove they’re not little boys anymore”.
“Here, Linda said, sliding her water glass across the table to her, “use this to wash the taste out of your mouth”.
What ever part of Lindsay’s brain that was still taking things at face value got another nasty shock, and once again Lindsay found herself gasping for breath through a cloud of Alcohol fumes.
“Good Russian Vodka” said Linda as Lindsay managed to find her breath. “Probably made not 10 minutes away from here. Let me know if you’re just going to spit it out it next time. Oh, and you owe me 5 bucks”.
“What for”?
“The round of course. New girl buys the first shots. It’s an old squadron tradition”.
Lindsay suddenly thought of something. “Hey, wait a minute, I thought the squadron has only been around a couple of weeks. How can there be old traditions”?
Lorraine jumped in with “What she means is that it’s an old ‘New Squadron’ tradition”.
“Is that five bucks each or five total”? asked Addison, waving a ten spot.
“Two rounds, so five each”, said Linda, helping herself to the offered cash and tossing it into the cigar box. “You’re covering the next round as well”.
“Linda” Lana-Raye scolded, “Stop taking advantage of the newbies”.
“It’s okay”. Addison said eagerly, “I don’t mind. I got money”.
“She’s loaded and willing to buy” laughed Lorraine, sliding herself onto the bench between Linda and Addison, putting her arms around both “That’s what I want in a wing man. Can I have her”?
“I saw her first. Besides, you’ve already got Bev. Don’t break her heart”.
“What ever” Lorraine shrugged her shoulders “Besides, she’ll get over it”.
“Sure”, Linda responded knowingly “probably right after another ‘friendly fire’ incident”.
“Hey” Bev protested “That was proven to be a legitimate accident”.
The three girls started a passionate debate about when you might expect to get away with shooting down a superior officer, with Addison eagerly listening to every word. Lana-Raye took the opportunity to change seats so she was now sitting next to Lindsay. “How was your first day”? She asked.
“Okay I guess” confessed Lindsay. “Not as exiting as I expected. I didn’t even get to shoot anything”.
“First day is usually slow. It’ll start to pick up tomorrow. I take it this is your first TAC tournament”?
“Yeah. I didn’t even know they existed until a couple of months ago. Are they always like this”?
“Pretty much”. Lana-Raye took a pull from her beer “By the end you’ll wonder what the hell you were thinking when you signed up. Then before you know it you’ll be signing up for the next one”.
“I take it you’ve done this before”?
“Uh huh. Five times so far”.
“You guys have been doing this for five years”?
“Not all of us”. Lana-Raye gestured around the room “Some of us have played together on and off with different groups. But never all on the same team until Leslie put together the 127th”.
“Speaking of Leslie”, Lindsay looked around, “I don’t see her. Does she eat at the officer’s club”?
“Officers club? Na! She usually joins us. She’s probably still over at command discussing the game plan for the next few days. Besides, this is the officer’s club”.
“I thought maybe she had her own mess, being the commanding officer”.
“She set up the group, so she gets to be the commander. She pretends to be in charge, and we play along and pretend to follow her orders”.
Lana-Raye took a long swallow before going on “Actually a group acts better as a unit if they all agree who’s in charge and follow along. There are a couple of rules she’s a stickler on, but other than that she’s as much in it for the fun as the rest of us”.

“What rules”? Truth be told, Lindsay had hurried through that part of the information package and had just checked ‘Yes’ without bothering to read it too deeply. She felt a sudden sinking feeling and hoped her lack of diligence wasn’t about to screw her over.

Lana-Raye ticked the rules off on her fingers as she recited them.
“First rule is that you agree to follow the tournament rules”.
That was okay; she planned on following them anyway.
“Second rule is that you follow agree to follow the squadron rules unless they conflict with the first rule”.
“Third rule, don’t lie about something. Or anyone. If you screw up admit it. Don’t try passing the blame off on some-one else”. Lana-Raye leaned forward and stage whispered “I think that’s something from her management back ground”.
Okay, thought Lindsay, she wasn’t habitually a liar, but it was still good to keep in mind.
“And lastly, but most importantly, No males allowed on base”.
“No men”? Lindsay gasped at this.
“Nope”! Lana-Raye shook her head “The 129th is strictly a hen party’. She noted Lindsay reaction at this last bit of information “Don’t worry”, she said soothingly “ If you find you need some action just hang around with Lorraine. She usually manages to find the good party spots by the end of the first week”.
1543121222221.title: We are all mad here

choices: This is why you need a wing man when you go.
Feeling a bit better, what could go wrong?
15431212222212.content:
Lindsay wanted to press for more information on the no men rule, but Lana-Raye had decided to see what music the Jukebox had been loaded with and left her sitting at the table. Left to herself and another opportunity missed, Lindsay grabbed another beer and drank it as she listened to the flood of conversation around her. It was very different than she was used to. With a group of men in a similar situation the talk would be all about sports or women, bragging about accomplishments and conquests in both (whether real and imagined).

She’d never realized before that men viewed tavern talk as a competitive sport, while women treated it as an opportunity to share everything they knew about everyone you might also know, and at a rate that put broadband internet to shame. The girls chattered away about everything and anything, bouncing from one topic to the next like a group of puppies playing.

Sitting there behind her growing pile of empty beer cans it seemed Lindsay learned more in an hour about the women of the 129th than she knew about anyone and everyone else she’d ever known. Bev, shy and sensitive, was working her way through school and training to be a paramedic. Colleen was an irreverent and fanatical practical joker. Lorraine would flirt with anything wearing pants, but was actually very choosy and had high standards. Linda was gay but nobody cared. Leslie had gone through a very messy break up that she hated to talk about.

Lindsay also found out a few things about the base, like that there was a big red button on a pedestal half way between the colonel’s office and the barracks that set off the air raid siren. And that anyone pushing it when there wasn’t a real air raid going on would be forced to jog the perimeter of the base with full combat packs, thanks to Colleen.

However, it wasn’t by listening, but by trying to stand up, that she found out virtual beer was every bit as sneakily intoxicating as real beer. And, just like the real stuff, you never bought it, you just rented it. A growing pressure in her bladder, an organ that she hadn’t noticed before now, was insisting it was time to return the rental, and, judging from the pile of empties in front of her, see if there was a damage deposit involved.

With a quiet ‘excuse me’ that nobody really noticed, she got up and after a couple of miss starts, found the door and headed outside. Usually she would just slip quietly around the corner around to the back of the tent, out of sight, but tonight the cold air sobered her up just enough to realize that, what with the recent rearrangement of her plumbing, the old piss in a dark corner trick was not going to work now. Instead, she put the rarely used plan ‘B’ into action, and set off unsteadily down the row of tents, looking for a bathroom. After a couple of minutes, and purely by accident, she managed to stagger around a parked jeep and blunder into a sign proclaiming the tent behind it to be ‘Die Abzienhende Latrine’. Her addled brain jumped to the obvious conclusion as it focused on the word ‘Latrine’ and she pushed open the door and staggered in, hoping she wasn’t wrong. The pressure in her bladder was getting intense and she wasn’t exactly sure how long she had before she couldn’t hold it in any longer.

Thankfully, her guess was correct and the door opened into a small wood floored tent with a couple of sinks and a row of stalls at the back. Taking the first stall she found she hiked up the skirt, pulled down her underwear and sat. Even though this was her first time alone with her new parts she was too far into the nights drinking to really pay much attention to anything other than trying to figure out what muscles to relax. For a minute she couldn’t get anything going, until she just stopped thinking about it and her body took over from there. Everything just sort of happened at that point so she just closed her eyes and went with the flow, so to speak. The plumbing may have been hooked up different, but the immense feeling of relief was still the same.

As things slowed to a trickle she groggily opened her eyes. The stall was just like any other she’d sat in, only without the crude graffiti marring the paintwork. An odd container mounted on the partition caught Lindsay’s blurred attention. It reminded her of a skinny mailbox, the kind most people had mounted on the front of their house so the post man had a place to put the parcel delivery notices. Fuzzily, her brain wondered about what kind of letter, or parcel notice, someone would get in a toilet stall. She was totally unable to think of an answer but found she didn’t care. She tipped sideways a little and found her own use for the narrow mailbox; the cool metal felt soothing to her forehead as she leaned against it and wished that who ever was spinning the tent around would stop before she was sick.
15431212222212.title: heavy thinking, 'Lite' drinking

choices: Not on my watch you don’t.
154312122222121.content:
Some indeterminate time later, after the tent spinner grew tired of the game and went to bother someone else, Lindsay felt like she could get to her feet again. The attempt was a disaster. For some odd reason she miss judged the point at which she reached vertical and pitched too far forward. Fortunately the door to the cubical was there to catch her and lower her gently to the floor. She lay there and giggled a bit for some reason, then politely thanked the door for its help.

Now you would have thought the door would have responded with an equally polite ‘You’re welcome’, or perhaps ‘No problem at all, happy to be of help’. This door had a hidden sadistic side, and when she tried to use its support to get to her feet again it suddenly swung and threw her bodily to the floor. Then, when she pushed herself up onto her hands and knees, followed that treachery with a vicious blow to the back of her head, and then another into the small of her back as she tried to rise. Pitching forward again onto her stomach, this time she belly crawled her way out of the door’s treacherous reach, regrouping beside the sink while she checked out the damage and weighed her options to counter attack. From her position of cover she could see the stall door watching her smugly, swinging slowly, mockingly, back and forth. Taunting her.
“Come on”, squeaked the hinges. “I’m ready if you want to lose round two,”.

The sink at least, seemed to be on her side, at least for now, helping her get to her feet again, and also trying to talk some sense at her, “It’s not worth it” the sink insisted wetly. Sage advice, even coming as it was from a chipped enamel bowel, so Lindsay reluctantly turned, washed her hands, then lurched towards the exit. Only to have her feet yanked savagely out from underneath her, throwing her once again flat on the floor. Stars exploded in her vision as her head bounced off the smelly pine boards. She rolled to the side, trying to protect herself and wondering which of the treacherous latrine fixtures was after her this time. As she tried to rise into a defensive crouch she discovered that this time the culprit was her own underwear, still wrapped around her ankles from her exertions on the toilet earlier.

Fortunately the sink, still loyally on her side, was there to give her the support she needed as she levered herself back upright. When once again more or less vertical she tried to pull her wayward unmentionables back where they belonged, a task made extremely difficult by the refusal of the local gravity to stop shifting and pulling her in different directions as she tried to bend over. Finally, her stomach decided that it had had enough upping and downing, and projected what still remained of the night’s festivities all over her only loyal supporter in the whole nights affair.

Finding herself on her knees yet again, weakly clutching a now slippery sink, Lindsay came up with an absolutely brilliant alternative solution to her problem. If they won’t go up, maybe they’ll go down. The tangled cloth fought and clutched tight to her ankles and shoes, making it difficult to step out of the tangled fabric, but Lindsay persevered, kicking off her shoes and digging with her toes until at last she staggered barefoot from the battle scene, both shoe and underwear less, but decidedly victorious.

Or so she thought. Anyone who’s survived in battle will tell you constant vigilance should be your watch word. That the time to be wary of an attack is when you least expect it. And that, just as you are sure the enemy is vanquished and the battle won, he will regroup to surprise you with a counter attack. Lindsay opened the latrine door to step back out into the night. The latrine door was just that, a door. It was also the reinforcements Lindsay hadn’t expected. Joining in solidarity with the other doors, it proceeded to pitch Lindsay bodily both out into the night and into the hard right side of that now rather inconveniently parked jeep. As a stunned Lindsay slid down the icy metal and flopped onto her back, the mutinous aperture gleefully slammed shut and delivered one last shot. A coup de grace of sorts, in the form of a large patch of snow that it had been gathering on the roof all evening for just such an occasion. Dislodged by the slamming of the door, the soggy mass slid slowly and wetly down the roof and over the edge to land in Lindsay face just as she was struggling to get up off her back.

Her squad mates found her a few minutes later, shivering and soaking wet. Concerned by her absence they had just started looking for her when they had heard a cry and the sounds of a door slamming. Finding her half buried in the snow and barely conscious, they carried her into the mess tent, and once they saw her in better lighting from there to that remote corner of the same tent that doubled as their emergency medical center.

Of course, as they bandaged her up, they tried to find out what had happened, how she had gotten all those scrapes on her legs, and the bruises on her face. And that bloody lump on the back of her head. Lindsay had a hard time making any sense, what with all that alcohol in her system. Her recollection of the events in the latrine was fuzzy, and her retelling slurred and even fuzzier. Something about a letter and a parcel, and getting into a fight in the toilet. And that she needed to apologize to somebody named ‘Zink’, who had rescued her and whom she’d thrown up on.

The colonel ordered a patrol sweep to make sure who ever had attacked Lindsay was not still in the area. When the sweep turned up empty they set up a watch rotation and agreed to let her sleep it off and find out more in the morning.
154312122222121.title: This is why you need a wing man when you go.

choices: Lie and take the easy way out.
Man up (as it were) and tell the truth.
1543121222221211.content:
Lindsay woke the next morning with someone shaking her shoulder. Her head was pounding and it tasted like someone’s dirty socks had been in her mouth. Her stomach gave little dry heaves when she pushed herself upright, blinking in the intense light shining through the barracks window.
Way too much detail in this game, she thought, not for the last time. Someone had put a cup of coffee and two aspirin on the locker beside her bed. Although her stomach heaved at the thought of putting anything in it, she dutifully swallowed the pills and washed them down. The coffee was black and barely lukewarm. Surprisingly she felt a little better afterwards. Her stomach settled and the light didn’t bother her quite so much.
“About time you woke up”. said Lana-Raye from the foot of her bed. “Colonel wants to see you in her office in 30 minutes. If you hurry you’ll have time for a shower”.
Half an hour seemed like more than enough time for a shower, she was thinking as she dug around her locker for her kit. Until she realized, while it was plenty of time for a man, as a woman she had no idea how long the process took. Quickly she grabbed her kit and ran to the showers.

Lana-Raye had been right. Even though she’d hurried through the shower as quickly as she could, she arrived at the colonel’s office door barely in time, still desperately running a comb through her damp hair. Still, she figured it had been worth it. With the shower added to the aspirin and cup of coffee, she felt almost human again.
Two gentlemen in black leather trench coats were already there, talking to the colonel when she entered. At the sound of her Their shiny boots, peaked military style hats, and red arm bands practically screamed out one word.
“Gestapo!” Lindsay gasped, stopping in her tracks.
“Oh, we’re worse than that.” Chuckled one of the officers dryly, giving Lindsay a slow apprising look. “System Admin.”
Looking closer, Lindsay could see the silver initials on the crisp collar patches indeed read SyS, and not SS as she’d first thought.
“They’re here because of what happened last night.” The colonel said. “They would like to hear about it.”
“According to our report,” said the first Gestapo officer (Lindsay couldn’t help think of them as anything else), looking at the clip board he was carrying, “You were found in a snow bank, badly beaten and semi conscious. Perhaps you would care to tell us how this came to be?”
Lindsay flushed and averted her gaze. The feeling of peace and well being that the combination of pills, coffee, and shower had bestowed upon her was over ridden by a growing feeling of dread that grew in the pit of her stomach. She started to feel sick again.
“I, uh, ran into a door”? She mumbled. As soon as she said it she felt her stomach sink further as she realized with certainty the Gestapo would not accept that as an explanation.
“Highly unusual amount of injuries for running into a single door”, one of them said.
If he meant it sarcastically Lindsay failed to notice. “There were two of them.” she said, then realized that made the explanation even less believable.
The Gestapo officer with the clip board gave her a level look that managed to convey “don’t waste my time, then flipped a page and read “It also says here that you were found naked from the waist down”. He looked up at her with his head tilted and an unreadable expression on his face.

“Lindsay”, the Colonel said softly, “If you’re trying to protect someone”…
1543121222221211.title: In the morning.

choices: Well, that's about it for your career
Through the Flue these Free Fools Flew.
15431212222212112.content:
“Lindsay”, the Colonel said softly, “If you’re trying to protect someone”…

That the Colonel was concerned made Lindsay feel even worse, and she hesitated a long moment before answering, her available options weighing heavily on her. The last thing Lindsay wanted to do was relate her miss-adventures in the toilet. But without lying she couldn’t see any clear way out of the situation that would allow her to save face. Pretending that the Colonel was right, that Lindsay had a lover that she didn’t want to get into trouble might get her to back off, but now the SyS was involved this would more than likely blow up in her face later on. Thinking up a sly lie might be a marginally better bet, but Lindsay was no good at thinking on her feet, and knew any lie she came up with on the spur of the moment would make things even worse than the mystery boyfriend story.
It’s hard to admit to something you did, especially when it makes you look foolish, but in the end that was the course Lindsay chose. She described what had happened as best as she could remember which, now that she was sober, was surprisingly very detailed.
She described how she had gotten very drunk and needed to pee, how she’d lost her balance in the toilet stall and had fallen against the door. How the latch on the door had sprung open when she’d leaned on it and she’d fallen, and how the door had bounced off the wall and swung back just as she had tried to get up. Her face burned a bit as she described how she’d gotten tripped up in her tangled panties, and how taking them off had seemed like such a good idea at the time in her drunken state. After all, she had known (she maybe told a slight little miss-truth here) that there were no men around to worry about. And that she hadn’t known the latrine door swung out as well as in when she’d leaned against it while opening the latch, which is how she’d wound up sitting in the snow.
As she spoke the officer with the clip board jotted notes while the other one stood and stared at her, unnervingly still as he listened to her story. When she’d finished the two looked at her for several uncomfortable moments, then simultaneously shook their heads and started to chuckle.

“Well,” the one with the clip board said, putting his pencil away “Her story pretty much synchronizes with what the video feed shows.”
“You have video feed of this?” the colonel asked. A dark look crossed her face.
Oh yes, the second SyS said. We just needed to verify what it shows against what your pilot says happened.”
“There are videos of me running around with no pants on?” Lindsay was aghast at the thought.
“Oh no! The feed only shows up to the point where you enter the latrine, and then again when you exit it. Nothing from the inside”
“Why do you have cameras on our latrine?” The colonel demanded.
“We don’t.”
The colonel was looking quite angry at this point, and slammed her fist onto her desk.
“First you say you have video feed, now you say you don’t! Which is it? And why are you spying on my girls?”

Officer Clipboard looked shocked, and held up his hands in denial “I didn’t say we have cameras. I said we have video feed.” Seeing that The Colonel didn’t look any happier about this he continued. “Look, this whole world is a digital construct. And the digital imagery generated can be viewed from any local point. That’s how you can record your dog fights from camera angles outside your aircraft. Any local point can also act as a video feed.”
“So,” Leslie leaned across her desk, “everything that happens is recorded and can be played back any time?”
Yes, and no! Because of server limits the data is available only during the game and for a short period after. And nothing is saved unless specifically requested. As much as we’d like to, we can’t save every game indefinitely.”
“Further more, because of various privacy and decency laws, all areas with expectations of privacy, such as the showers and barracks, video feed is available only when specifically requested by all authorized occupants of those rooms at the time involved..
“Which means” the other officer said, turning to Lindsay “only you will be able to request a copy of the video of yourself in a fight with the toilet. And I would suggest you do so within the next couple of hours, before you forget.”
“Why would I want that on video?”
“Are you kidding”? The SyS Officer asked incredulously, “That is the stuff YouTube gold is made of.”
Lindsay wasn’t so sure. “I don’t think anyone would want to watch it.”
“You’d be surprised at what people want videos of, especially in VR”
Lindsay remained unconvinced. “But it’s embarrassing.” A thought suddenly occurred to her. “Hey, if you had video, why did you need me to embarrass myself anyways.”
Officer Clipboard looked up sharply. “The word is ‘Anyway’! There is no ‘s’ on the end of it. And yes, we had video, but only of you entering the latrine, and then falling out the door a few minutes later. Nothing of anyone else entering or leaving
The second SyS officer continued “We wanted to make sure there wasn’t someone else in there, Some one the video feed didn’t detect.”
“You think something is effecting the videos?” Lindsay asked, seeing if she was understanding what the SyS were looking for.
“Affecting!” officer Clipboard said sharply, pointing the eraser end of his pencil at Lindsay .
“What?”
“The word is affecting! Affecting is something that makes something happen. Effect is something that happens”.
“Okay” said Lindsay, taken aback a bit by the sharpness of the reply, but decided to soldier on, “But irregardless of that, why would you think there is someone running around who doesn’t show up on video?” she asked, hoping for clarification.
“Regardless!” The SyS officer actually snapped his pencil in half in irritation. “The word is regardless! There is no such word as irregardless!”
“Hans”, the other SyS officer said warningly, “Don’t”!
The SyS officer identified as Hans held his tongue, but with obvious difficulty.
“But in answer to your question” the other officer broke in, deflecting the conversation back to it’s original course. “There are rumors of a group of hackers trying to develop a way to do this, so any time we get a report where this may have happened, we check them out. All of them have turn out to be false so far, but we have to investigate each one just in case”
“I can understand that.” said Lindsay. “After all, better safe then sorry.”
Hans’ eyes bulged.
“THAN!” Hans shouted “It is better safe THAN sorry!”
“That is enough Hans, let it go.”
“Sorry for that,” the first officer apologized, “Hans can’t help himself and tends to want to correct people over any little improper use of language. But you are correct. So far all reports that could be of cloaked attackers have turned out false, but we do have to check out each one to make sure.”
He picked up his briefcase and motioned Hans to do the same.
“Since it all seems to be okay, we can close the case.
Thank you for being straight up with us. The truth saves us a lot of time.”

At this the SyS officer started to leave. When they reached the door he stopped, turned, and said “I would appreciate it if you don’t talk about the real reason behind our visit. Rumors like this take on a life of their own. Your cooperation is thusly appreciated.
Hans stopped in his tracks and glared at his partner. “Not you, too!”
“What?” The other SyS officer asked, an innocent look on his face.
As the two headed into the hall the girls could hear Hans starting to rant. “Thus is already an adverb! There is absolutely no reason to add –ly to the end of it. It serves no purpose. You are essentially trying to turn an adverb into an adverb!”
The Sys officer paused with his hand on the door knob, then turned and gave them a wink as he closed the door behind him.
15431212222212112.title: The truth will set you up a fool, but a free one.

Get me to church, I'll worship like a dog at the shrine
154312122222121122.content:
You would think that starting your morning with a visit from the Gestapo meant that the rest of the day could only get better, and if you were any one but Lindsay on this fine day, you would be right.
The rest of the flight had already departed on escort duty leaving Lindsay as Leslie’s wing man. Maybe it was nerves, or some residual effect from the hangover she no longer had, but Lindsay couldn’t get the start sequence correct for some reason and twice flooded the engine. As she waited for the excess fuel to clear from the cylinders the Colonel, waiting impatiently at the end of the runway, radioed her that if it didn’t start this time she could push the plane back into the hanger by herself and spend the rest of the day scrubbing pots in the mess tent.
Whether it was Leslie’s tone of voice or the old ‘Third time is the charm’ at work, this time the engine sputtered to life when she flipped the starter switch. Lindsay hurried through the warm up and taxied out to join up with Leslie. As impatient as the Colonel was, she still insisted Lindsay go through the run-up sequence, and then again when she skipped a couple of steps. The last chance to catch any issue that might cause problems during the flight, she said. Lindsay grudgingly ran through the sequence again, thinking all the while that the Colonel was just being a dick about the whole thing. After all, those NPC’s in greasy overalls running around were supposedly there to provide them with an aircraft 100% ready to fly each morning.
Still, following orders to the letter was the price you pay in order to spend some quality time with your CO, even if your CO takes the game way too seriously.

It was another fairly simple mission. Since the rest of the wing was escorting a bombing party that was already half way to its target, Leslie and Lindsay did a hunting patrol, looking for targets of opportunity along the front lines. Lindsay mostly followed the Colonel around watching her back, although she did manage to score a couple of trucks and a tank. She also managed to get a nice line of holes stitched up her right wing, courtesy of an unnoticed machine gun nest protecting a fuel dump they found and strafed.

Lindsay was actually kind of proud of the holes. It showed she’s been in actual combat. Like little badges of honor decorating her until now completely unscathed machine. She kept smiling at the thought of them, right up until the point where she tried to land. That was when she discovered that the right tire, having spent the entire flight tucked up into the wing and not incidentally right in line with three of the holes, collapsed on landing. The 109 pitched forward and almost flipped as it slid and skidded down the runway, finally coming to a stop nose down in a snow bank. Steam rose in a cloud around a twisted propeller that looked more like a pretzel than a piece of airplane. As Lindsay hung from her flight harness and struggled to open the canopy she saw the entire squadron running towards her. Either to help or to laugh, she wasn’t sure which. Everyone, that is, except for the Colonel, who was just standing there beside her own airplane, looking towards Lindsay for several long moments before shaking her head sadly and walking, not towards the gathering crowd, but towards her office. Or perhaps, and more likely, towards the bar tent.

If Leslie had been in the bar, she’d left by the time Lindsay got there. All the other girls seem to be having a good time, but Lindsay was still a bit depressed by how the day had gone. Her truck and tank kills seemed pale in the light of Lorraine’s 2 fighters and Beverly’s bomber. And no one else had crashed their plane on landing. While everyone else drank beer and chattered away Lindsay decided to turn in early.
154312122222121122.title: Looks like we're in Dire Strafes.

choices: So, back to two trucks and a tank.
Maybe a career in interior design?
1543121222221211222.content:
The next day wasn’t much better. It started out great, as any day does that starts out with the Gestapo not waiting for you in the Colonels office when you wake up. That, and her newly repaired plane started on the first try.
Red flight did another hunting patrol, and Lindsay added to her growing list of downed flying machines four more trucks, a train, a tank, a gas station, and some sort of wagon thing. She was just starting to wonder where she might be able to find a couple of balloons and a zeppelin when she heard Lana-Raye’s voice in her headset.
“Red six. Two bandits, 6 o’clock high”. Lindsay looked and sure enough two Russians where angling in on her tail. Too late now to climb away from danger, so she pushed the throttle into the emergency position and began what her Grampa used to call ‘Contour Chasing’. That’s where you fly low and fast, hugging the ground as you sped along. And speed she did, with the bandits giving chase, the first dropping down low behind her in hopes of getting close enough for a shot, the second staying high to catch her if she tried to climb away. Lindsay knew that the Russians had the edge in speed, that if she kept this up of they would eventually catch her, but she wasn’t worried. Well, maybe a little worried, but not too much, having seen the other three of her flight dropping in behind the bandits. Lindsay figured the best thing she could do now was to act as bait and keep the bandits distracted long enough for her team mates to get in behind them and start shooting.
The plan was proceeding perfectly, right up to the point where Lindsay lingered a bit too long looking out her rear window, marveling at how well her team mates were maneuvering into position, only to look forward to find that the quiet tree lined valley she was currently hurtling down came to an abrupt end. A box canyon would be how it was described in the old westerns. Lindsay hauled back on the stick and climbed. In her minds eye she could see the Russian pilots practically salivating as she rose up into their gun sights, and prayed that her teammates were also closing in on the distracted enemy. Who would fire first was anyone’s guess.
Lindsay crested the hill with inches to spare, a little amazed at how free of bullet holes her plane still was. It was as she started down the other side that she saw it. It was the most amazing cathedral she had ever seen. Even bombed out there was still an architectural beauty in the Gothic facade, facing east to catch the rising sun as it came over the hill. Beauty in the spires still rising into the sky. Beauty in the big stained-glass window currently approaching at over 500km per hour. Lindsay barely had time to wonder how the big, beautiful stained glass front had survived the bombing relatively intact when suddenly it wasn’t so intact any longer, having acquired a BF109 shaped hole in the middle of it.
The murals on the back wall became punctuated in the same fashion, although Lindsay didn’t remember hitting them. She only found out about that part the next night when she got back from being dead and discovered the girls had set up what looked like a 16mm film projector pointed at the back wall of the bar tent. Colleen had copied the imagery of the crash from several different angles and had spliced together a ‘Greatest Hit’ reel. Of course the girls could have watched it at any time earlier but had waited for Lindsay to re-spawn so she could join them and they could all watched it together. There was even Popcorn.

Of course Lindsay’s kills didn’t count because she hadn’t survived the mission, but the rest of the girls had rung up an impressive tally, including the two Russians that had been chasing Lindsay, although it had been tough keeping it together after Lindsay’s spectacular distraction. Fortunately, for the German side at least, the Russians seemed to have had an equally tough time and had been easy pickings. At least they had probably died laughing was how Colleen put it.
1543121222221211222.title: Are you into redecorating...

15431212222212112221.content:
After the second time through Colleen pulled the film out of the projector and threaded in the reel she’d compiled from the following day’s missions. Lindsay picked up her beer and moved to the small table against the wall to sit down. After missing the day as a penalty for being killed, she didn’t feel like watching and laughing over what the others had accomplished. She didn’t feel like much like joining in anything. She just felt like being alone for a bit. She sat and nursed her beer morosely.

Bev plunked a bottle and a shot glass down and slid into the only other chair available at the small table.
“Hey.” she said.
Lindsay glanced up, “Hey yourself.” She replied indifferently.
Bev poured a shot out of the bottle and sat back, giving Lindsay an appraising look.
“You look pretty down for someone just back from the dead. You want to talk about it?”
Lindsay shook her head “Not really.”
She meant it, too. All the women seemed to do was talk, and she wasn’t in the mood.
“Okay.” Bev didn’t press her. Instead she slid the shot glass across the small table. “Here, have a shot of this”.
“What’s this.” Lindsay asked, sniffing the vaguely fruity smelling liquid
“Peach Schnapps. Sounds very German”.
“Smells very girly. Like something you’d drink if you can’t shoot whiskey.”
“Don’t drink it then”.
“I didn’t say I wouldn’t drink it” Lindsay said, tipping the glass back and swallowing. “God, that’s sweet. Like peach flavored pancake syrup”.
“Yeah. Hardly any alcohol.” Bev sat for a couple of minutes, then broke the silence “So what’s bothering you.”
Lindsay wasn’t going to say anything, then she sighed. Maybe talking would help.
“I don’t think Leslie likes me”.
“So what”, Bev shrugged. “She doesn’t like a lot of people. It’s not the end”.
“But it’s so unfair’ whined Lindsay, “It’s not like I’ve done anything, not really.”
Bev tossed back another shot, then poured one for Lindsay and slid it across the table.
“Then why do you think she doesn’t like you. Did she say so”?
Lindsay tossed back the shot before answering “No, not as such”.
“So how do you know”?
“Well, she doesn’t seem too happy with me lately”.
“Why, because you crashed a couple of planes”? Bev snorted, then motioned for the shot glass again “She’ll get over it. Crashing is a traditional part of being in the Luftwaffe. It’s inevitable. You know why?”
Without really pausing for an answer she kept going “There are maybe a dozen things you need to do in sequence to get a BF109 airborne, and then you need to undo most of them once you are. And if you forgot something you either have to fix it fast or you crash”.
Lindsay matched Bev’s shot with one of her own. “I don’t think that’s right”.
Bev shrugged “Count them some day” she said “You’ll be surprised. That’s why real life pilots have a checklist they use for everything. Want to guess who invented the check list”?
Lindsay didn’t have a clue. “I don’t know. Some German guy”? she guessed.
“Ah yes, the ultra perfect ever precise master race. Well, you’re wrong. The Germans did everything by memory. That’s why their pilots were so good. The bad ones never graduated. And that mentality of flying appalled the British, who were very much fond of doing things by the book. All about neat little columns of numbers and checkmarks they were, so they came up with the idea of the check list. It didn’t matter how bad a pilot you were, if you followed the check list you could get your machine up in the air. Another checklist and you were back down again. Ultimately, their ability to get more people into the air won them the war”.
Lindsay shook her head “I thought it was the bravery of their pilots”.
“Okay, maybe it was”, Bev conceded “I don’t really know. The point is, every one is going to crash once in a while; don’t let it get to you”.
By this time they had done away with the shot glass and were taking swallows right from the bottle they passed it back and forth as they talked.

Lindsay wasn’t about to quit her self pity party so easily though.
“I feel like I keep letting her down. No matter what I do, I always seem to screw it up”.
“Let me ask you this then. Bev said, pressing her steepled fingers to her lips as she leaned her elbows on the table and looked hard at Lindsay. “Why is it so important to you that Leslie likes you”?
Well I, umm, of course, ahh, it’s, well… I, don’t know, really. It just seems that she should”.
Bev shook her head sadly. “I think that’s about the stupidest thing I’ve heard you say so far. Do you like her”?
“What do you mean by that”?
“I mean, do you like he enough to be her friend”?
“Of course”.
“Really? Tell me why”.
“Sure, it, well. I mean, I think I do. I, I guess I don’t know”.
“Why don’t you know”?
Lindsay was floundering under the questioning “I, well, I guess I don’t know her well enough”.
“Exactly.” Said Bev, pointing a finger at Lindsay “And she doesn’t know you either”. Leslie doesn’t form snap judgments. Once she gets to know you she’ll like you for who you are or she won’t, and there’s nothing you can do about it. You can’t make someone be your friend. And I’ll tell you something else. She doesn’t have to like you. She doesn’t need to be your BFF or even your BF de’jure. As long as she knows she can trust you things will work out”.

With this Bev got up from the table, but she wasn’t quite done dispensing advise. She leaned in towards Lindsay. “So far you’ve spent just about every night moaning about how Leslie doesn’t like you”. She said firmly “There’re six other girls here. If you’re going to spend the entire game moping about someone not liking you, pretty soon nobody’s going to want to hang out with you. And that will really wreck any enjoyment you could have gotten out of the game”.
15431212222212112221.title: Just drink pancake syrup until you feel better.

154312122222121122212.content:
Lindsay remained seated, taking sips from the bottle of tasty syrup Bev had left as she mulled over what had been said.
Bev was right, of course. Righter than she knew. Lindsay was doing the same thing in game that she did in real life. Instead of embracing all the good things about the game she had been focused on one little negative aspect to the point of ruining everything, not only for her but the others as well. And in spite of being handed complete freedom to reinvent herself, to become the new and improved person she’d always wanted to be, she’d practically squandered it by sticking with old habits.

It was time to stop missing the good stuff, she decided. She was literally a new person, so it was time for some new habits. The change starts now, she decided, chugging the rest of the bottle down, then getting up and moving over to the main table where the others were sitting. Before she sat she stopped and gave a small salute to the 127th’s mural on the wall above the bar.

“Well, look what the crash recovery team dragged in”. Lorraine said as she watched her sit down “Decided to join us, have you”?
Lindsay glanced back at the mural before answering.
“Yeah”, she said. “I guess I did”. And she meant it. As of now she was going to give being a part of the ‘Mad Cows’ her best shot.
“Nice salute. We should adopt that as a ritual”.
“Seemed appropriate some how, although now I’m wondering where the name came from, actually”.
“Jagdgeschwader? It’s German for ‘Hunting Wing’. Kind of self explanatory when you see the translation. It usually refers to a fighter squadron”.
“No, I was referring to the ‘Mad Cows’ part. What made you decide to choose that as a name”?
“Oh, that. That was Lana-Raye’s idea. Her and Leslie had a disagreement over a point of order or something with the last gaming group they were with. One of the boys trotted out the old ‘They only call it ‘PMS’ because ‘Mad Cow’ was already taken’ chestnut. Lana-Raye suggested that maybe the ‘Mad Cows’ should start their own group”.
“Where did the picture come from”?
“Lana-Raye has a niece that was studying graphic arts who did up a banner. Looks good up there doesn’t it”.
“I like it. It’s kind of silly yet meaningful. We should put up some of her other pictures. Make it a little more cheery in here”.
“What’ca planning”? piped in Colleen. “Going to pull an ‘Allison Victoria’ on us”?
“Probably not”, replied Lindsay, “as I have no idea who you’re talking about”.
“Seriously? She hosted that reno show ‘Kitchen Crashers’ for years. And the spinoffs, Kitchen Crashers Vegas, Extreme Kitchen Crashers, Remember”?
“Oh. Crashers. hah hah hah! Funny”.
“Well” retorted Colleen, “It was a lot funnier before I had to explain it”.
“Colleen”, Lorraine broke in “Remember what we said about working a joke to death”?
“Are you saying Lindsay crashing into a church wasn’t funny”?
“No. I’m saying to give it a rest”.
“Aww. I was just going so suggest that we get Lindsay her own show. We can call it Cathedral Crashers”.
“Joke is officially on life support now. Don’t make us pull the plug”.
“Fine. But I want to be her wing man so I have a front row seat next time we go strafing trenches”.
“It’s pronounced Strah-fing”. Addison piped up, eagerly wanting to be part of the conversation. “It’s a German word meaning punish. The Germans used to say Gott Strafe Englund”.
“Yeah”, Colleen rejoined “And the British used to say ‘I’ll stay-rafe you bloody Huns back to the bloody stone age”.
“Actually”, Lana-Raye put in “I think either pronunciation is correct. I’ve heard it both ways”.
The conversation bounced off in the direction of pronunciation, and how people kept mixing the soft and hard ‘J’s when sight reading German, then ricocheted into favorite foods, moved on to drinks, then skidded around a corner into fashion. Twenty minutes later they were back at fashion for the third time and discussing having a period authentic bathing suit contest when Lindsay’s head thudding on the table brought the conversation to a stop.
“Hey Lindsay. We’re only joking. Don’t go getting all over-dramatic on us”.
“Wha”? Lindsay barely lifted her hear. “No, ’s okay. Jes a lot drunker than I sh’be on beers”.
“Oh Wonderful”. Lorraine said sarcastically. “The game has you pegged as a light weight. Too bad. You can get up to some serious drinking in these SIMs. Good parties too”.
Colleen grinned and stood up, spreading her arms wide, and with the voice of a Catholic Priest at high mass began to intone ‘And lo, it came to pass, the lord Lorraine spake, and sayeth ‘Begone, for surely thou art a lightweight and unworthy of my sight’ “
Lorraine rolled her eyes and buried her face in her hands, shaking her head. Heedless, Colleen continued.
“And then did she raise on high the Holy Fifth of Glenfidich, saying, ‘Bless this, O Lord, that with it thou mayst become intoxicated, in thy mercy.’ And the people did rejoice and did drinketh the bar dry of the scotches and beers and rums and brandies and whiskeys and lemony fruit coolers”.
Lana-Raye peevishly broke in “You about done, Colleen”?
Colleen continued, ignoring the tone of Lana-Raye’s voice. “And the holy barkeep spake, saying, ‘Thy drink minimum shalt be three, no more, no less. Three shall be the number of the drinks thy shalt order, and the number of thy drinks shalt be three. Four shalt thou order if thy so desireth, but never shalt thou order two, excepting that thou then proceed immediately to ordereth thy a third. Five is right out, umm. I mean five is all right. Shoot. Lost it there”.
“Let me guess”. Said Addison “You’re a Monty Python fan, right”?
“How could you tell”? Was Lorraine’s sarcastic aside.
“You know. I was thinking we could rename the bar” said Colleen, half seriously “After the Rabbit of Caerbannog”.
“No!”
“What do you think Lindsay”? Colleen asked her semi conscious seat mate.
“I think I enjoy dental surgery” was what the mumbled response seemed to sound like. Colleen pulled Lindsay’s head up so she wasn’t talking into the table.
“Didn’t quite catch your transmission there, Crash. Can you repeat”.
Lindsay’s mouth gaped for a moment. Then her eyes focused “What”? she asked.
“Dang girl, how much have you had to drink”?
“Dunno”. Lindsay’s forehead crinkled in concentration. “Three, maybe four”. She gestured weekly at the bottles in front of her.
“Don’t forget the shots of…” Bev started to say, then spotted the empty Schnapps bottle sitting on the small table “Hey, did you drink that entire bottle”?
“Yeah. S’okay though. No alcohol, y’ said”.
“I said there was no alcohol taste. That stuff’s 40 proof”.
“Ohhh”. Colleen grinned “She may be a light weight but she drinks way above her weight class”.
“I think that’s enough for you”. Lana-Raye advised. “Colleen, take her back to the barracks and put her to bed. And stick around to make sure she isn’t attacked by the latrine again”.
“But that would derive the rest of you of my keen wit and hilarious sense of humor” Colleen protested.
“Oh, really”? Lana-Raye said “Gee, I hadn’t thought of that. Still, I think that’s a sacrifice we’re all willing to make if it gets Lindsay safely to bed”.
When the other girls voiced similar sentiments Colleen dramatically rolled her eyes, picked Lindsay up and slid an arm around her shoulder.
“Come on you”. She said, half carrying, half dragging her along. “Let’s get you home”.
On the way they did stop at the latrine, which was blessedly peaceful and well behaved that night.

Two women, and a bed…

1543121222221211222122.content:
The two figures lurched across the compound. One guiding, the other staggering. And singing. Singing in a glorious happy way that certainly wasn’t about to let that only bits and pieces of the song could be remembered get in the way. To make up for the blank parts she merely repeated the bits she thought she remembered over and over in that infuriating tuneless way drunk people have.
“Get me to church, I’ll worship like your dog at the shrine in your light. I’ll tell you of my sins as we pass in the night. Good God, let me give you my knife. Ooh oh oh.
“Here we are kiddo”, Interrupted the other “Home sweet Barracks. In you go”.
“You guys are really great, you know that”.
“I know kid. I know. Here’s your bunk”.
“I mean, even when you’re being mean to me you’re great”.
“Nobody’s being mean to you. Now let’s get you undressed”.
“But I’ve decided I’m not going to let it bother me”
“That’s nice. Can you finish taking off your shirt”?
“And you want to know why I’m not going to let it bother me”?
“I’m sure you’re going to tell me. Think you can you put your pajamas on while you do”?
“It’s not going to bother me cause I’m not going to let it”.
“Good for you. No, leave those on dear. You can change them in the morning. Finish putting your jammies on”.
“Ya got anything to drink? I could use a shot”.
“I think our little light weight has had enough for tonight”.
“Still wanna drink”.
“No, you’re done. We have to go to sleep now. Going to get up early tomorrow. Impress the boss you know”.
“Na, I’m through with trying to impress the Colonel. She don’t like me, and it ain’t no skin off m’nose no more”.
“Best not to let her hear you say that”.
“Why? What she gonna do. Hate me more”?
“I thought you and Bev worked that out. The Colonel doesn’t hate you”. You’d know if she did.
“Thass what Bev says. If she don’ hate me why she alwaysh on my case. An yellin”.
“Yelling’s a lullaby compared to what she’d do if she really didn’t like you”.
In the dark Lindsay couldn’t see the mischievous look that had developed in Colleen’s eyes. Actually, in her currect condition it could be broad daylight with a sign saying look here, and Lindsay would miss it.
“Did anyone tell you about her earrings? The little diamond ones wears that she calls her family jewels”.
“Family jewels”. Lindsay giggled at the phrase. “ ’S funny, cause family jewels is a eupfin... a youphan... a wahatchacall it name for…um… ya know… um…” Lindsay faltered, Even extremely drunk she had a hard time talking about things that had always been a taboo subjects in mixed company.
“A man’s balls”? Colleen said, obviously not as constrained by the same strict upbringing as Lindsay. “Yeah, that’s exactly what we’re talking about here”
“There’s a story behind them, but I probably shouldn’t tell it.
“Aww. Come on, tell me a story.” Lindsay giggled again.
Sure thing sweety. You just curl up and make yourself comfortable, and Auntie Colleen will tell you a nice bed time story”.
Colleen sat against the head of the bed, and Lindsay curled up under her arm as requested. Both of them were giggling at this point, the image of Lindsay being told a bed time story like a little girl seemed particularly funny, if in completely different ways, to each of them.
“It starts with a Danish company. You know, the one that turns cremation ash into diamonds”
“Din’t know ‘bout that”.
“Simple process really, there’s companies been doing it for years. Take carbon, heat, and high pressure. Presto. Tiny industrial diamonds for saw blades and drill bits”.
“Uh huh”. Lindsay said softly, eyes half closed.
“Anyway, this Danish place figured out a way to get the larger jewelry grade ones. ‘Course the diamond lobby freaked out and tried to shut ‘em down. They tried to claim the artificial diamond were worthless so nobody would buy the product. Company was going bust until someone marketed the bright idea to cremate your beloved pet and memorialize them by turning them into a fine jewelry. Demand soared, and once they got the technique down it wasn’t long before people moved from pets to turning the earthly remains of dear aunt Ethel into the center stone of the family heirloom.”
Lindsay’s eyes popped open. “Shesh got a dead people in ‘er earlobes? ‘S creepy.”
“It get’s creepier. And it’s not just people. It’s her fiancé. Bits of him, anyway.
“Eh?”
“Turns out he was a cheating bastard with three other girlfriends.”
“No, really?”
“Yep. They were on holiday when she found out. He denied it at first, then turned it around and tried to make like it was her fault.
Long story short he wound up in hospital with a higher voice and what they called unspecified injuries, and she came home with a brand new pair of earrings”
“Sho th’ diamonds…”
“More like diamond chips, actually”
“Are her ex’s, umm…”
“The word you’re looking for is balls. Testicles. Stones. Reece’s Pieces. Gonads. Whatever you want to call it, any chance for him to pass his DNA on to the next generation is now dangling from her earlobes”.
“Don’t get me wrong. The Colonel is really a wonderful person, with just a few trust issues now”.
Slowly, the implications of what she was hearing soaked into Lindsay’s alcohol fogged mind. “Oh crap”! She thought. “And this is the woman I piss off every day”.
“Would she really do that? Cut off a man’s balls for lying to her”.
Lindsay hadn’t realized she was thinking out loud until Colleen answered.
“Absolutely. And not just the balls. I suspect she’d want the whole package and go for a matching necklace this time”.
“Oh God”! Lindsay groaned
“Don’t worry. We’re fine. Us women she’ll forgive for a lot of things. And we don’t have the bits she’s interested in anyway. But, like I said. You’ll know if she was really mad at you”.
If she expected this last bit to comfort Lindsay, it didn’t.
“Oh! Almost forgot. And all the girls lived happily ever after, the end”
“Wha”?
“Gotta end a story with a ‘Happily Ever After’, even if it doesn’t apply to everyone. Story book rules”.
“But…”
“Story times over, Sweetie. Night night”!
At this Colleen gave her a peck on the forehead, then turned out the light and crawled into her own bunk. Soon the soft sounds of her snores where all Lindsay could hear. That, and the muffled disjointed screams of her own foggy thoughts. Just what had she gotten herself into?
1543121222221211222122.title: Let me tell you a Bed Time story.

15431212222212112221221.content:
Once again Lindsay’s day started with someone shaking her awake and handing her an aspirin and a cup of lukewarm coffee.
The ritual of chasing one down with the other she performed while fumbling through her locker until she found her shower kit. Of course all the stalls would be occupied by the time she got there, so she trotted over to the latrine. By the time she was finished there a stall had opened up and she was able to grab a shower before heading to the mess tent to join up with the rest of the squadron.
Breakfast was soft scrambled eggs with bacon, hash browns, 3 kinds of fruit, and a soft custardy cake like crepe layered with a thick topping of caramelized apples that Allison said was called a German Apple Pancake. Whether it was really German was a good question. Whether it tasted good was beyond doubt. Like all the food, it was absolutely fantastic. It was with no little reluctance some 20 minutes later that Lindsay finally pushed her plate away. If this was real life all the delicious food would have her really packing on weight. Maybe she’d go for a run later and work off all the extra calories, like that girl she knew in high school. That girl could eat anything and yet never put on any excess weight.
Dumping her plate at the wash station, she grabbed a fresh cup of coffee and sat with the others as they sat chit chatting around the stove. She didn’t really paying attention to what was being said, just let the idle chatter wash over her in waves like a soothing bath of noise. Before they knew it, it was time for flight duty.

“If anyone’s interested “Colleen radioed as they escorted the 87th north “The church of Lindsay is directly below us.”
Colleen was Lindsay’s wing man for the flight. Lindsay was grateful, even with the reasons Colleen freely admitted. At least with her watching her back maybe she could score more than the pitiful 2 trucks and a tank that her score card currently boasted, although boasted was probably the wrong word.
“Interesting way point Colleen”. Came the Colonel’s voice “Good code word for a rendezvous point as well. That’s, what, 20 minutes due north”?
“22 minutes, 10 seconds exactly”.
The squadron was escorting the 87th on a mission to take out a munitions factory, with a secondary target of a rail depot. Both targets were hit with the fighters meeting little opposition, so once the big planes were safely home the 127th split up and spent the rest of the day hunting for targets of opportunity. Blue flight got lucky and strayed across a Russian bombing run; the Colonel and Linda each bagged a PE-2 from that, and everybody got a YAK or two from the escort, with Lorraine hogging the lions share with three. Even Addison scored her first dogfight kill, finishing off a YAK that wouldn’t give up, after Lorraine had crippled it. Mistaking Addison for an easier target, the YAK had swung back and tried to get behind her. Addison drew him into a nice simple powered loop and then pounced on him when he stalled out.
Nobody came near Red flight, so Lana-Raye and Lorraine took off to strafe an airfield or two, while Lindsay and Colleen amused themselves by chasing down convoy trucks. They each managed to bag several, including a group just as they were about to head home for the day. A line of five came trundling over a bridge, then obligingly stayed in a straight line as Colleen swooped down on them, so she was able to strafe the line of them, as well as take out the bridge, one pass. Lindsay did a follow up pass when she spotted that one of the damaged trucks was somehow still mobile and limping away from the rest of the burning column. As Lindsay came in low the driver abandoned the truck and ran. Like an idiot, he ran away from the truck straight in line with Lindsay’s strafing. All she needed to do was hold the trigger a second longer and he was a dead man, killed by his own stupidity. At the last second the driver threw himself to the ground and put his arms uselessly up to cover his head. A twitch of the rudder and the deadly line of bullets veered harmlessly to one side of the prone victim. Then she was up and away, not even bothering to look back at the driver, who was very much astonished to find that, against all odds he was still alive. When he looked back at his foot prints, and the machine gun churned path of earth that followed them before veering off at the last second, he knew why. Maybe not why, exactly, but the how.
As for the why, even Lindsay couldn’t really say, so she tried not to think about it as she climbed back up and joined Colleen. “One more truck for the tally”, was Colleen’s only comment as the two headed for home.
15431212222212112221221.title: German Apple Pancakes make everything better.
