It's been a hard day's night.
154312122222121122212211.content:
Over the next two weeks Lindsay got quite good at ground kills, which was probably a blessing as that was all she seemed to get. The colonel, using the excuse of letting the girls get used to each other’s flying styles, mixed up the flights quite regularly using some complicated roster that paired you up with a different wing man every second day. It certainly kept you on your toes, but Lindsay looked at her record and began to suspected a darker reason. It could have just been a statistical anomaly, but it seemed that no matter what flight Lindsay was on, it was the other flight who found and shot down the Russian planes. Almost as if the game was programmed to keep aircraft off her score card.
She continued to add trucks, and jeeps, and tanks, and a couple more of those weird wagon things, and a goat (purely by accident). Never individual soldiers though. A machine gun nest she had no trouble with, they were firing back after all. And buildings with snipers. But to target a single soldier, or two, running or not, she couldn’t bring herself to pull the trigger. But that was okay, there were plenty of other ground based targets, including parked aircraft, for her to blast away at. Not that she spent all her time hugging the ground. She did get into a couple of dog fights that resulted in battle damage on both sides. Yet an actual honest to goodness in-flight aircraft kill remained stubbornly absent from her score card.
On the plus side, she also hadn’t been shot down yet, so at least in that regard she was leading her group. That, and crashing on landing.
It seemed like every second landing she was either ground looping or planting the nose and wrecking her machine. The first couple of times she’d freaked out, until she reminded herself that she had decided she wasn’t going to worry about what the Colonel said, not about the planes. And oddly enough the Colonel herself had also backed off, not freaking out every time Lindsay put her plane out of commission. Of course, when both her main and back-up planes were out she did make her fly the gull winged JU-87 dive bomber. But Lindsay kind of enjoyed that. She was doing nothing but ground kills anyway, so the Stuka just made her all the better at it.
It was Lana-Raye that came up with the idea of what she called ‘Aversion Therapy’ or making the penalty for damaging your plane by screwing up your landing something unpleasant enough that the offender would go out of their way to avoid having to ever do it again. Something slightly demeaning. Something like serving drinks at the Gasthaus while dressed in traditional Oktoberfest garb. And by traditional not the modest Dirndl with it’s full skirt and high neckline, but the more popular (among men at least) Dirnlkjoler that would be worn by the more adventurous party girls and waitresses who’s living depended on the size of tips they got. The blouse still had the puffed sleeves of the traditional costume, but was cut to allow bare shoulders and a deep neckline. Couple that with the laced up bodice and a push up bra, and the girls of the 127th sported cleavage that, if actually worn during the time period the game was set in, would be banned in all but the most progressive of US states. Fortunately they were both not actually in that time period, or the United States. Which was good, because Lorraine added an even racier aspect to the costume by pinning up gussets in the laced edging of the mid thigh length skirt, giving a tantalizing glimpse of the chiffon underskirt, and garter belt holding the white stockings in place. Personally, Lindsay had her doubts about the authenticity claimed, even though Loraine swore up and down that every part of the outfit was authentic, right down to the traditional lace thong.
And all of it was really quite silly, really. Due to the ‘No Men’ policy enforced at ‘Die Wutenden Kuhe Gasthaus’ the only patron who might truly have appreciated the look was Linda, whom Lindsay wondered if wasn’t somehow involved in the outfit selection. What ever the reason, by the third (consecutive) night, the aversion punishment had taken on the feeling of good natured hazing. To Lindsay it became just another outfit, nothing particularly special. Even when Colleen stuffed a couple of wet bills down her blouse as a tip Lindsay just rolled her eyes and took it in stride. And gave them all back (one at a time) the next night when Colleen overshot the runway and tore off a wing on the radio hut. Of course Lana-Raye got it worse when it was her turn. But again, worse was a relative term when nobody really went overboard. Everything that went on happened in the spirit of good fun. Perhaps because of this the punishment was tolerated and actually helped develop a deepening respect for each other amongst the squadron. Because you trusted that the person on the other end could be expected to behave in a reasonable fashion. And in return they trusted you.

Also, it was good to take a night off from drinking every once in a while.
154312122222121122212211.title: Keep on Truckin.

1543121222221211222122111.content:
Lindsay moved as one with her machine, adjusting trim and flaps with precision, her movements on the controls firm and accurate, perfect to move her machine precisely in the direction she wanted it to go as she soared, spun, and twisted through the sky. Her BF109 danced to her slightest whim. And it was barely good enough. No matter what she did, no matter how she dodged, the YAK on her tail grew relentlessly closer. What she really needed was back up, a wing man to jump in and break up the battle and give her a chance, but she hadn’t seen or heard from her wingman, or any of her flight for that matter, since the squadron of YAKs had jumped the bomber wing they had been escorting. The 127th had scattered, chasing and being chased. Fortunately only one of the YAKs seemed interested in Lindsay. Unfortunately, he was very interested. He was also very persistent. Lindsay tried every trick she could think to shake him while he clung to her tail with the tenacity of a bull dog. And, in spite of the desperateness of the situation, Lindsay was enjoying the fight immensely. This was the kind of flying she had envisioned when she first saw the ad copy. Man and machine against man and machine. They were turning and twisting around each other at just over 1,000 meters, with the low altitude superiority of the YAK very much in evidence. In spite of her skills it was all Lindsay could do to keep out of the gun sights the YAK was trying to bring to bear on her. The YAK didn’t carry a lot of ammunition, but it wouldn’t take many hits from the 7.62mm machine guns and that 20mm cannon to turn Lindsay and her plane into shredded tinfoil.
Lindsay flew with all skill and precision she’d possessed, and yet it was all she could do to stay alive. Sooner or later the YAK would be in position, then he’d fire and it would be all over. The YAK’s pilot was better at turning. His plane was better at climbing at this altitude. And faster in a dive. He was just that much more maneuverable than she was. Or was he? Chance time baby, she thought grimly, and she put her plane into a shallow right bank, dropping her flaps a notch to give a touch more lift and slowing herself down slightly. As expected, the YAK turned with her, maneuvering to get her into the center of his sights. When she saw this she tightened the turn and cut her throttle slightly, not enough that he would detect, but still enough to slow down. Then she dropped the nose towards the ground to throw off his aim just as he fired.
The tracers passed harmlessly but still way too close as the YAK overshot her position, Lindsay flipped her plane over and turned hard left, opening the throttle and pushing her machine to its limits as she swung the nose around, trying to center her opponent in her gun sights and squeeze off a few shots of her own. The YAK rolled out of the way, and she rolled right along with it. Now the two planes were doing a simultaneous barrel roll around each other, upside down and directly above relative to the other as they jockeyed for position. Lindsay looked up and with a shock realized she could see the other pilot looking up at her, a wild crazy grin splitting his face. A grin that she realized mirrored the one on her. Unable to resist, she brought up her right hand and saluted her opponent. To her amazement, the salute was returned. Quickly taking advantage of the fact her opponent now only had one hand on the controls she broke out of the barrel roll and went into a shallow dive. Moments later the YAK did the same behind her. Once again, he tried to get into a position where he could fire. Lindsay banked into a tight right turn, watching the YAK carefully. The timing would be tight for what she was going to try, if it was off even by a little she’d likely be ripped to shreds by cannon fire. Wait for it, she thought, focusing all her attention on the Yak, judging its position. Lindsay held the turn for several long nerve wracking seconds, then at the last possible second flipped her plane 180 degrees and banked hard left. For a brief moment, the most dangerous moment, she tracked square across her pursuer’s gun sights and should have been an easy target. But the element of luck was with her, and by the time the YAK reacted and pulled the trigger she was across and away with just a few holes in her tail, the rest of the tracers falling harmlessly below her. Moments later the YAK also flipped and banked to the left, following her. He was still on her tail, but now the two aircraft were following the same path as they inscribed a great circle in the sky, the YAK moving just a little faster and slowly catching up. Lindsay was not about to let the YAK do that though. She pulled a lever and deployed the slats. The BF109 lurched and slowed slightly, but more importantly the tight turn she was making grew even tighter, smaller that the one the YAK was following. Now, although he was slightly faster, he was also traveling a lot further. She was pulling away from the line of his guns. If they kept this up eventually it would be her guns coming to bear on him. It didn’t take long for the YAK pilot to figure this out, and once he did he broke away. When Lindsay broke out of the turn behind him she was slightly too far back for her guns to be truly effective. She let of a burst anyway, just to let him know she was there, and was pleased to see the YAK dive away in response. For her part she was just as quick to begin climbing up to where her good friend altitude was. They were done playing for now.
1543121222221211222122111.title: Dogfight

15431212222212112221221112.content:
From the relative safety of 15,000 she began to look around, trying to locate the rest of her squadron. Where had they gone? Why weren’t they answering the radio? And where had all that broken cloud cover come from? It hadn’t been there when they were escorting the bombers. Surely someone would have mentioned it. Come to think of it, The Colonel had mentioned a possibility of bad weather during the mission briefing. Stubbornly, Lindsay continued to circle, trying the radio at various intervals, hoping for contact with anyone of the 127th.
When nobody answered she tried the frequency for the 104th, and finally the 42nd. The only thing that answered her was just static, so after about half an hour of endless circling and watching the clouds build up, she decided to give up and head for home on her own.

As she flew towards base the clouds grew thicker, the breaks between them growing less and less frequent until you were hard pressed to see any holes at all. Lindsay wasn’t worried. Not too much. She knew where she was, approximately, and although she couldn’t see the ground she figured that if she flew due south for 30 minutes she would be close enough to the airfield that she should be able to spot it even if the clouds was only 1,000 meters above the deck. She figured this was a great plan, until she spotted a group of 30 or so aircraft way ahead in the distance, flying a ragged V formation in a sort of figure 8 pattern hunting pattern. Too far away for Lindsay to positively identify as Russian, but their behavior was odd enough that she decided not to take any chances. She dropped down into the clouds to hide.

Although her 109 was not equipped with the radio directional compass that would have made it a snap to locate her home base, it did have enough other instrumentation that allowed the 109 to operate ‘flying blind’. The artificial horizon to keep her wings level. The gyro compass to keep her heading steady. A magnetic compass to correct the gyro when it wandered. An altimeter so she could tell how high she was. Vertical climb indicator so she could tell if she was climbing or sinking. Instrumentation that was needed, as the swirling cloud outside the window could play tricks on your mind. She knew that from the introduction to instrument flight tutorial she’d taken when she was learning to fly DC-3s. The human mind is wired to seek patterns, and will try to form them even when none exists. There is a reason native folklore is rich with tales of beast and beings that lurk in the clouds. The result of a mind trying to make sense of the swirling mist. It would see patterns where there were none. Patterns that could get you killed in mid air. The way around it was to focus on your instruments. Cloud says you’re falling, but your altimeter and vertical show no change? Trust your instruments. Cloud tells you the plane is turning but the compass and horizon are steady? Trust your instruments. Your instruments will feed you information you can trust. Lindsay focused on her instruments as she descended into the swirling grey mist, using small corrections to bring them back when they strayed too far from where they should be reading.
15431212222212112221221112.title: Where did everybody go?

choices: Not the most intelligent of AIs
154312122222121122212211122.content:
Slowly and carefully she descended, until she reached 7,000 meters and leveled out. She would still be over enemy territory, and having no idea how far down the cloud bank went, she didn’t want to drop out into clear air only to find herself in reach of the anti aircraft fire from the ground. She decided to stay at 7,000 and feel her way home.

Carefully, she added the clock to the multitude of instruments she was watching. Time was another measured quantity that stretched oddly inside the cloud. The minute hand seemingly took an hour to travel a tense 10 minutes. And then not 5 subjective minutes later it was telling her 20 minutes had gone by. The swirling gray played with her mind. screaming that she’d been in there forever, but she trusted her instruments and held steady at 7,000 until the full 30 minutes had passed. By now, as she reckoned, she should be over German occupied territory. It was time to figure out where she was, so she began once again slowly feeling her way down out of the cloud. Although she had become acclimatized to flying through cloud over the last half hour when she finally broke through at 5,000 she let out a small sigh of relief, then glanced downward. What she saw made her pull quickly back up into the cloud again. Right below her, maybe 500 meters or so on the same heading, were three Russian bombers.

Why the Russians hadn’t fired on her as she broke out of the cloud she couldn’t say. They certainly had the opportunity. Unless she was mistaken and they were not Russians. After a full minute (watching the clock again) she slowly descended. Not completely out of the cloud, but low enough that the cloud thinned a little and she could see through gaps in it.
The aircraft were Russians all right. There was no mistaking the red star decorating each wing, even if they hadn’t had the distinctive silhouette of the Peska Pe-2 model 87 twin engine bombers. In addition to the three model 87’s that she had first spotted, there was a model 110 that must have been right underneath her when she’d first broke cover. Thankfully, they hadn’t seen her. That much was obvious by the way the turret guns, the ones that by rights should have been tracking her and preparing to rip her to shreds, were still stowed in travel position. The bombers even had their navigation lights for crying out loud. It was either a trap or a particularly dumb AI flight.
154312122222121122212211122.title: Look who I found.

1543121222221211222122111221.content:
Deciding that either way she didn’t care, Lindsay pushed the nose down, opened the throttle, and came bursting out of the cloud like an avenging angel, firing into the lead bomber as she did. She pulled up in a loop at the last second, almost too late, having tried to maximize the few seconds she’d had to fire on her target. Her 109 staggered and clawed its way back up into the gray mists above, disappearing once more into the cloud. Not having the time to build up enough real airspeed to be gracefully aerobatic, Lindsay staggered over the top of the inverted loop solely on by virtue of the sheer horsepower behind her prop. When she came out of the cloud again she was pointed straight down and, while not exactly where she thought she’d be, close enough that she was able to correct and fire a burst into the trailing Peska, shredding the cockpit just ahead of those bunny ears that were the 110’s most distinguishing characteristic. The 110 lurched and flopped over into a spinning dive as she roared past. The remaining two bombers veered off, banking in opposite directions as Lindsay pulled out of her dive, and since the one on the right was closest she went after it, catching up quickly and firing a long burst that she held until the bomber caught fire and a wing came off.
Then she turned her attention to the forth bomber.

It was dumping its bombs, evidently hoping to lighten the load and gain the speed and maneuverability it need to escape. An escape that an adrenaline hyped Lindsay wasn’t about to let happen easily.
The crew had either been sleeping or had their attention otherwise distracted when she first attacked. Which ever it was, the survivors were giving her their full attention now. As she drew near the defensive guns swiveled in her direction and firing, warning her off. She fired back, a long shot that was more for her moral than inflicting any damage, both aircraft were too far away from each other for either guns to be effective. Following at a safe distance for a few moments, she studied the bomber, getting an idea of its heading and speed. Then, with a wry grin, she climbed back up into the cloud.
1543121222221211222122111221.title: Avengence is mine!

15431212222212112221221112211.content:
Carefully watching the clock and gyro compass, she did the math in her head. The bomber looked to be doing about 300k, she was currently doing 350. If she estimated the position correctly, she would be over top of him in slightly less than 90 seconds.
84 seconds later she dove out of the cloud. Too far off to the left and almost right along side, too badly positioned to get a good shot so she swooped back up and back into the concealing mist as tracer fire from the turret gunner started flicking her way. Tight left turn, hold for 20 seconds until she did a complete 360, then drop down again. This time she was in a much better position. She centered the sights and got of a 3 second burst that might of hit something or not, she didn’t stick around to find out as once more tracer fire started flicking her way and she ducked back up into the cloud. Four more times she did this, managing twice to be in position to squeeze of a quick burst before being chased off by tracers. On the fifth she decided to change it up a little. This time she flew a straight heading that would take her over the bomber, Holding her course for a good 2 minutes before doing split S turn, coming out of the cloud cover head on in front of the bomber.

It shouldn’t have worked. All the pilot had had to do was change his heading by 15 or 20 degrees and she would have come out too far away to get an effective shot. And although he had changed course slightly, it wasn’t enough. Lindsay made him pay for that error with a short burst that left him with a tattered and smoking engine as she roared past. An Immelman turn brought Lindsay back up into the cloud cover again as tracer licked at her tail. If it worked once is should again, right? Wrong. AI or human, the pilot wasn’t stupid enough to fall for the same trick twice. This time when she dropped down she found that he had changed course and she was facing in the wrong direction when she came out. Tracer fire flicked around her once again, so up she went.

Now they were playing a game of cat and mouse, with her trying to guess which way he’d run, and him trying to guess where she’d come out of the clouds at. They kept this up for several minutes, long enough that Lindsay was beginning to hope the defensive gunners would run out of ammunition before she did, until she popped down and discovered a swarm of Russian fighters making a beeline for their position. The Russian cavalry had finally arrived, so she pulled the stick back and climbed back into the swirling gray that was currently her best friend. In the thick mist she altered course, picking an angle that took her not towards the fighter, or directly back into friendly territory, but one that took her at an oblique and hopefully unpredictable angle away from both. Either it worked, or the Russians were not about to climb into the clouds after her, because the next time she dropped out of the cloud again she was alone. Once again she began the task of trying to identify where she was in relation to home.

There’s nothing like looking for your base as the clouds grow darker and lower, and the ground gets more and more monochrome. You thought you knew where you were, but the landmarks aren’t there, and you are rapidly running out of time.
Lindsay felt the desperation threatening to crush her spirit. It couldn’t end like this, could it? It was so unfair. Then she spotted a familiar object. It was a cathedral. The big one that was special to her. The one with the airplane silhouetted in the big stained glass. The battle with the bomber had dragged her a lot further north that she expected, but at least she knew where she was now. With a feeling of relief she turned nose south and headed home as the darkening clouds slowly pushed lower. By the time she cleared the outer marker on final approach there was only about 500 meters of ceiling left, but by then it didn’t matter. She was home.
15431212222212112221221112211.title: I knew we'd meet again.

154312122222121122212211122112.content:
Lindsay didn’t park her plane in front of the maintenance hanger so much as abandoned it, un-buckling and climbing out almost as it stopped rolling, so eager was she to share her news. Her first aerial kill, and she couldn’t wait to tell everyone.
Too early for dinner, she figured everyone would be hanging out at the Gasthaus. Walking at a quick pace, almost running, she hurried over. She’d play it cool, she decided, sort of casually bring it up in conversation. Something along the lines of ‘So how was your day? Mine, oh, nothing special. Dog fight with a yak, shot down a bomber or two. How was yours’?
Sure enough, Linda and Colleen were at the bar when she entered, Addison, Beverly, and Lorraine were seated around the small table, bottles already in front of them stating how they had planned to spend the rest of the afternoon. All conversation stopped as she walked in, then broke into excited babbling.
“Where you been girl"? Colleen said, rushing over and hugging her. “Last we saw of you was when the Russians hit us. We thought maybe you’d been shot down”.
“Almost”, Lindsay replied, thoughts of playing it casual evaporating as soon as she walked through the door. She began to eagerly relate the events of the day.
“I got tangled up with a YAK that wouldn’t quit. We must have fought for an hour. When I finally got rid of him nobody would answer the radio. You guys aren’t going to believe what happened on the way home.”
“Let me guess”, Lorraine broke in with a voice like a wet blanket. “You ran into a squadron of fighters? Yeah, we saw them. Too many of them so we left them alone. And we wanted to get home before the clouds closed the airport down. Speaking of which, you should let the colonel know your back”.
“Hey, You didn’t try to tangle with them did you”? Bev asked, looking worried.
“Do I look stupid”? Lindsay replied, “No, I went down into the clouds to sneak passed them. But this is the really wild part. You’ll never guess what I found hiding under the clouds”.
“A wardrobe”? Asked Lorraine lazily, “With a secret passage to a magical land of rainbows and unicorns”?
“Well, I can see you’re not really interested”.
“If it’s another truck story you’re probably right”.
“Well”, A voice came from behind her, “I, for one, would love to hear what you’ve been up to, Ms Anderson”.
154312122222121122212211122112.title: About time you got here

choices: Guess who is our newest Ace?
1543121222221211222122111221122.content:
Lindsay turned, and saw both Lana-Raye and the Colonel standing behind her. She gulped. No doubt Leslie was going to take her to task for failing to come straight home.
“Uh, Colonel, uh, sir”.
“Care to relate why you didn’t come home with the rest of the flight”?
“I got separated from the flight. Couldn’t find them so I came home”.
“That much I figured”.
“I tried to radio. Really, I did. Nobody answered”.
“Not surprising, seeing as the radio has a hole in it”.
“It does”? Lindsay asked, shocked, trying to remember when she’d actually been hit.
“We were just over at the hanger. From the condition of your plane it looks like you saw a bit of action today”.
“Yes sir”.
“At least you didn’t crash on landing for a change. I believe for that at least you are owed some congratulations”.
“Um, thank you, sir”? Lindsay said, not sure if that was a compliment or not”.
“Now I believe you were about to tell us all what you found so interesting under the clouds that made you late to return”.
“Um, sure”.
Lindsay had always had a problem speaking in front of any one she considered an authority figure, and the Colonel certainly qualified as authority at the moment.
Gone was the giddy excitement she first felt when walking into the place.
“Well”, she said nervously, “When I came out of the clouds there were four Peshkas right below me”.
“What”, Exclaimed Colleen “You’re kidding”!
“No, really”.
Now all the girls started chattering excitedly for details talking over each other and asking questions, mainly along the lines of “What did you do” and “Did you get any of them”?
“I got shots on all four”. Lindsay exclaimed, the giddy excitement start to return now that she started to relate the tale of the encounter. “Not sure what happened to the first one but the third one exploded, so I know I killed him for sure. Fairly sure I got the second. Tried to get the forth, but couldn’t get enough good shots to knock him down.”
“No way”. Said Lorraine, still being the buzz kill she started the evening as, “You finally got a kill? I find that hard to believe”.
“Don’t mind her”. Bev put in “She’s just pissed off because some hot shot from the 104th stole two of her kills today”.
“It shouldn’t count. I damage them, and while I maneuver into position to finish them along comes bone head and steals the kill”.
“Be that as it may” Bev continued airily, “I for one am glad Lindsay finally got her first.
“Maybe even two”. Lindsay grinned.
“Actually”, the Colonel broke in, shaking her head, “I’m afraid Lindsay is slightly mistaken about her kills today”. A slight smile playing at the corner of her lips.
“Not two”? Lindsay was dismayed. “I thought for sure I might have got a second”.
The colonel still shook her head.
“Well, at least I got one”. Lindsay said, then felt her heart sinking as the Colonel just shook her head again. “I know I got one. They’re not taking that away are they? They can’t. I saw it explode”!
“They can’t take any of them away”. The colonel said, breaking into a wide grin. “You officially got all four”!
1543121222221211222122111221122.title: It's the Colonel, along with the Major

choices: Does anyone have a dart board?
15431212222212112221221112211222.content:
“What? Four? No way”! The girls babbled incredulously. Someone said “I gotta see this for myself”, and the squad rushed to the hanger attached to Leslies office where the leader board was mounted.
“Sure”, they heard Leslie shout after them, “Don’t listen to what your CO says”.
The leader board in the main hanger confirmed what the Colonel had said. After weeks of logging nothing but ground kills Lindsay was finally on the board with four bomber aircraft. For a few minutes they compared their scores against each other, and while Lindsay hadn’t yet caught up with the rest of the group, she wasn’t that far back. Colleen excused herself, then she and Lana-Raye took off to the radio hut.
As the rest of the group walked back to the Gasthaus to celebrate, there was much laughing and ribbing, which Lindsay both took and gave, once again feeling the giddiness that she had felt after landing return..
When they got back to the Gasthaus they were startled to find Leslie behind the bar wearing her own version of the Dirnlkjole.
“Well”, she said by way of explanation “Seeing as none of you crashed today, I figured it was my turn”.
An hour and a half later Colleen and Lana-Raye came in, ready to thread the fruits of their labor into the projector. Whatever Colleen did on real life must have given her a cinematographic back ground, her spliced together ‘Best Of’ reels were always really good, and she out did herself that night, splicing together a reel showing the unsuspecting bombers and Lindsay’s attack, set to the JAWS sound track.

Leslie in particular was impressed by Lindsay’s use of the cloud as cover, saying most people would just use it to duck and hide, and that her ability to judge where she was and launch an attack was quite impressive.

The Colonel was confusing. Lindsay had thought that she would be all stand offish and authoritarian, but watching her taking part in the drinking party that had become the official nightly ritual of the 127th you would think she was just another one of the girls.
And tonight she’d willingly put on her own Dirnlkjoler, one that was tailored specifically to emphasize her size and shape, so different from the rest of the squad. Lead by example, she’d said.

And she’d exhibited a playful side that Lindsay didn’t recall ever seeing before, the way she’d teased her, leading her on about the number of kills she’d made today.
Tonight, she watched Leslie, really noticing her for the first time as a person instead of a commanding officer. She’d never noticed before the butterfly barrettes that Leslie used to hold her braids together. Of course the butterflies had little iron crosses in the middle of each wing. But that’s what you’d expect of a German officer, right?
Now, watching her tend the bar and wisecrack with the rest of the group, she was seeing a human side of Leslie she’d never noticed before, and that was confusing her. And then, as the truth hit her, it wasn’t so confusing anymore. All this time she’d been seeing Leslie was a superior officer, and her mind had automatically lumped Leslie in with all the other people in that category. The boss in charge of the outfit, The person of authority whose mission in life was to make sure you didn’t have any fun. Now she realized, this wasn’t her boss. Leslie was just another player. Someone who was in the game specifically to have fun. She was having fun playing the officer, and the rest were having fun letting her be in charge. Lindsay should have realized this weeks ago.

Except the diamond chips glinting in Leslie’s ear lobes reminded Lindsay of a darker side of the Colonel. One she didn’t want to see.
15431212222212112221221112211222.title: We're off to see the Leaderboard.

choices: You follow Colleen to see what she's up to.
154312122222121122212211122112222.content:
Eventually, Lindsay got up and made her way to the bar for another beer.
“So”, Leslie said, gesturing to a stool and indicating Lindsay should sit. “Have a seat.
Lindsay plopped herself down, not sure of what was coming but with enough alcohol in her system that she didn’t really care. It was one of those rare times when she was feeling like she could do no wrong.
“I missed how you got separated from the flight earlier today” Leslie said conversationally.
Lindsay smart mouthed her reply. “That, I’m afraid, is a tale long in the telling. And the kind that makes a person rather thirsty while telling, if you get where I’m coming from”.
Leslie gave her the kind of look librarians studied years to master. “And I’m sure you could consider it a debriefing for your commanding officer, if you get where I’m coming from”. She replied in a dangerously level tone.
Lindsay’s confidence took a nose dive, she gulped and started to stammer an apology, but before she could get two words out Leslie smiled and put a beer on the bar in front of her.
“So, what happened”?
“It was when the YAKs first jumped us”, Lindsay said “Colleen went after one, and his wingman went after Colleen, so I went after the wing man. I was just getting a bead on him when suddenly I was getting fire from someone on my 6, so I broke off and tried to lose him. Unfortunately he was very persistent. I don’t think he got a good hit on me, but it was darned close a couple of times”.
The rest of the room drifted closer, listening as Lindsay described the various techniques she’d tried to break away, until they were all standing in rapt attention as she reached the part of how the two had wound up staring at each other during the barrel roll, then broke into laughter when she told them how she’d used the salute as a distraction to try and gain position.
“And then, it happened”! she said, taking a large drink of her beer for dramatic effect.
“What happened”? ask Addison, elbows on the table as she listened enraptured, “Finish the story. What happened”?
“Then I tricked him into overshooting my position, turned the advantage, and chased him away”.
“You didn’t shoot him down”?
“Not today”, Lindsay said”, lowering her voice, then turning and looking off into the distance, “But you’re still out there somewhere, my friend. And someday, somewhere, we will meet again”.
“And in the category of best melodramatic performance in an insignificant supporting role, if I may have the envelope please”! Said Lorraine, somewhat sarcastically.
“Now that’s not a bad idea”, Colleen added. “I kind of wish you’d spoken up earlier, I could have added it to your best of reel. Still can, come to think of it”. And with that she lurched to her feet and staggered gamely for the door.
154312122222121122212211122112222.title: Drink beer and chat.

choices: The VIP is a no show.
1543121222221211222122111221122222.content:
Lindsay watched her go. She had no doubt that Colleen, drunk as she was, would be back in a couple of hours with a new reel that included the added dog fight footage.
She didn’t return that night. When an artist gets inspired they lose themselves in their work, and it was over a year before Lindsay saw the result posted on Colleen’s YouTubeToo channel. A short, sappy, and slightly humorous video revolving around a young pilot torn between tracking down the enemy ace responsible for the death of her husband, and finding a hair style that worked for her. The dog fight and subsequent bar soliloquy scene was cut and mixed with dialog lifted from several drinking sessions, all stitched together to form a fairly cohesive tale of obsession, respect, admiration, and changing hairstyles that sounded as if it was scripted by a romance novelist. It actually won some prestigious award in a category of art form that she’d never heard of. Not for the acting, however.

But that was in the future. Currently most of the squad was still drinking the evening away. Lindsay shifted her stool a little closer to the bar so she could rest her elbows on the bar top more comfortably.
“Hey Colonel”, she said, suddenly feeling apologetic. “I’m sorry. About earlier today, I mean. I didn’t want to worry you”.
“That’s okay”, Leslie replied. “Not your fault really. Nothing to worry about. I was a little shocked when your leader board status started totaling up points like crazy though”.
“Yeah. I guess after not seeing any movement to see it jump like that was a bit of a shock”.
There was a minute’s pause while Lindsay cast about, trying to think of something else to talk about. The leader board and the way it calculated points was a topic that had been talked about practically every night over the course of the game, and most of the girls, including Lindsay, where heartily sick of it. Even with her new points Lindsay was reluctant to continue using it as the topic of conversation, so she changed it to one that was standing right in front of her.
“Hey”, she said suddenly “I like what you’ve done with your dress. It’s a little different from ours”.
“Thanks”. Leslie smiled “I had the supply guys tailor one to fit me. And I had it styled to be more befitting of an officer. Of course the shoes don’t really go with it, but they’re all I have for now. Maybe I’ll see if I can pick some up in Voroshilovgrad”.
The Russian city was a three hour flight away. Lindsay thought that was a long way to go just to shop for shoes and said so.
“Sounds like a long way to go for a pair of shoes. Why don’t you just have the quartermaster issue a pair”?
“Seriously? And miss the opportunity to go shoe shopping? What woman does that”?
“One that thinks it’s too long trip for shoes? It just doesn’t sound like fun”.
“For real”? the Leslie asked.
Lorraine had come up to the bar for a refill in time to hear the Colonel’s question. “What’s for real?
“Turns out Lindsay here doesn’t like shopping”.
It was one of those quiet moments that happen every so often in busy places. The juke box was changing songs, so the room was quiet enough that everyone heard the Colonel’s comment. Uh oh, Lindsay thought, seeing every head in the place looking her direction. Women were supposed to love shopping, so not liking it was suspicious.
“No, I didn’t say that”. Lindsay protested, trying to think of a plausible explanation that wouldn’t give her away. What the heck, she decided. She was who she was, at least for the time being.
“Well, maybe I did say that”. She admitted “What I meant is I, well, I like to look and all that, but I also like to know what I’m looking at. I’m not all that crazy about shopping for shoes, and Voroshilovgrad is in occupied Russia so everything will be in a language I don’t understand, so even more difficult, and it just doesn’t sound like a fun time to me”.
“I know the feeling.” Lana-Raye said. “I feel the same why when I’m looking at Vitamins”.
“Oh come on Lindsay” Lorraine said, taking the Colonels side, “Where’s your sense of adventure”.
“Shot down over St Petersburg? No, seriously. I like to shop, but I also like to know what I’m looking at. How am I supposed to know if a 15 ruble shoe is a good sale if I don’t know what the real price is? We’re the occupying force. They could be charging us triple just to get back at us.”
“That’s Voroshilovgrad all right”. The Colonel admitted. “But I checked. They’re only charging us double”.
“See. I knew it.”
“So” the Colonel said, handing Lorraine her drink and putting another beer in front of Lindsay, “I take it you’re not interested in the escort job tomorrow”.
Lorraine had been about to return to the table, but stopped and turned back. “The escort what now”?
The Colonel grinned. “Surprise advance notice of tomorrow’s job. The 127th gets the VIP Escort scenario”.
Now the whole bar was listening. Most of the veteran players knew the VIP scenario was a chance to get away from the fighting and do some R & R.
The Colonel saw the blank look on Lindsay’s face and explained.
Some big wig VIP has been touring the front lines, and our job is to make sure he gets back to Voroshilovgrad safely. If we do we get to stay over two days before heading back”.
What’s so great about that”? Lindsay asked, still not seeing what the excitement was.
“It’s like a Holiday”. Lorraine explained. “We fly in. Head into town. And party”.
Maybe Lindsay was just dense, but she wasn’t getting it. “How’s that different from what we do now”.
“It’s a city”! Lorraine said excitedly.
“Road Trip”! shouted Addison, somewhat inaccurately
“Shopping”. Added Leslie “New shoes”.
“Men” added Lorraine.
“Bars” added Lana-Raye.
“More men” added Lorraine with growing enthusiasm.
“Clothes” added Beverly.
“And men” re-iterated Lorraine.
“You’ve already mentioned men” Lana-Raye pointed out.
“Gotta focus on what’s important” Lorraine said, grinning.
Linda shook her head and rolled her eyes. “What did you expect”? she said “It’s Lorraine”.
1543121222221211222122111221122222.title: Bar Talk.

15431212222212112221221112211222221.content:
The next morning the squad enjoyed yet another sumptuous breakfast, loaded with virtual waist threatening calories, then headed to the hanger for the mission briefing. As they passed the hanger apron they saw that their eight duty aircraft were joined by two JU-52 Tri-Motor transports as well as a couple of the newly released FW190 fighters, so new that the morning sun gleamed off the factory fresh paint, and the normal unit markings and insignias had yet to be painted on. The Focke-Wolfs were faster and deadlier than the BF109s the 128th was currently flying, and Lindsay was quite looking forward to next week when their eight allotted fighters were scheduled to be delivered, provided the 127th could score the points required, of course.

“Alright”, Colonel Helgameire said, unrolling a map on the wall once the creaking of the wooden chairs died down as the group settled into place. “Today’s job is to see that the visiting VIP’s make the trip back to Voroshilovgrad safely. Voroshilovgrad is just over 700 kilometers to the west of us. The trip will take us a little over 4 and a half hours given the cruising speed of those two ‘Iron Annie’s’ you saw on the way over here. And those two Fockers belong to the pilots joining us as the VIP’s personal escort fighters. I want to work them into the rotation and have you each fly wing with them, just to see what the new machines are capable of. Since none of the VIP pilots felt the need to join us for briefing I guess I’ll just issue the positions now and inform them of their assignments once we get into the air. Colleen, you will fly wing man for who ever is in the left hand fighter. Lindsay, you take the right. Lana-Ray and Lorraine fly escort for the left Annie, Linda and I will take the right Annie. Bev, you and Addison will be flying bird dog. We’ll rotate partners every hour so you’ll each get a chance to buddy with a 190. Most of the flight will be over occupied territory, so we shouldn’t run into too much trouble once we’re away from the front, but keep a sharp eye out. The Russians seem to be getting bolder and putting a lot more planes in the air lately so don’t let your guard down. Once we reach Voroshilovgrad we lay over for 36 hours then return. The time between when we touch down and the return flight is your own, so pack an overnight kit with shopping in mind. Any questions? No? Right, grab your gear. I want wheels up in 20 minutes. Let’s get this mission started.
Lindsay followed the rest of the girls out of the hanger in a slight state of panic as they headed to the barracks to pack. What did you take on an overnight shopping trip? All she could think to grab was a change of underwear, blouse, and jacket. That didn’t seem like enough, so after a little hurried deliberation she grabbed a pair of comfortable shoes. Tossing them into her carry all she hesitated. 36 hours was two days worth of clothes, right? She added another pair of underwear, blouse, and a pair of slacks, then tossed in a sweater and a scarf she’d seen in her locker but hadn’t worn before. Hoping that would be enough, she buckled the canvas carry-all closed and headed to the latrine for the ‘Safety Pee’ that had become the pre-flight ritual for most of the squadron.
Afterwards, carefully wiping herself dry of the inevitable spray residue, she found herself again marveling at the detail and complexity of the SIM programming. Who really needed to feel a droplet of urine trickling down their leg, she wondered.
She was slightly startled at the size of the bags the other girls were carrying when she rejoined them on the runway, wondering briefly if she had miss-heard and the colonel had actually said they were lying over for a week. seeing the expressions on a few of their faces when they’d caught sight of the size of the bag Lindsay was carrying, she hastily stuffed it into the cargo pod and climbed into the cockpit. Thankfully, nobody pressed any awkward questions, and soon the entire squad was coaxing their machines into position for take-off.
Once in the air they took up their assigned positions. The FW190 pilots grumbled a bit, but for the most part accepted the Colonel’s group assignment. Not so with one of the transport pilots. He’d had a bad breakup with a former girlfriend and absolutely refused to have any one named Linda anywhere near him, and raised such a fuss that the Colonel finally rotated her with Addison, which seemed to settle him down. With everybody happy, or at least not bitterly complaining, the flight turned westward.

It was almost half an hour before the Russians found them.
15431212222212112221221112211222221.title: On the way to Voroshilovgrad.

154312122222121122212211122112222212.content:
“Red 6! Red 6!” the radio squawked. “This is bird dog. Three bandits, four o’clock low”.
Lindsay craned her neck and searched the target area, spotting the three aircraft headed in their direction.
“I see them”. She radioed back. “Too far away to make a positive ID, but definitely headed our way”. She kept an eye on the three aircraft as they steadily drew closer.
“They’re Russian” Linda’s voice announced through the radio speaker. “Looks like three LaGGs from here. Should be no trouble.”

It is a fundamental and universally accepted law of the cosmos that any form of conflict, be it combat, sporting event, public debate, or even crossword puzzle, that is entered into directly following the speaking of those words, is almost certainly guaranteed to not be ‘No trouble’. A cosmos that was decidedly not going to make an exception for Lindsay and her new wingman
Needless to say the melee did not go well. The FW150’s may have been technically advanced, but their pilots flew them like it was their first time in combat. The ‘four on three cakewalk’ turned into a ‘three on one drubbing’, with Lindsay in trouble from the moment they engaged the enemy. For some reason all three of the enemy decided that Lindsay was the prime target, and with her hopeless wingman unable to provide any assistance, took it in turns to get of several bursts on her. By the time the rest of the squad arrived to drive the Russians off she’d been shot up by each of the enemy fighters at least once, and it was only through shear luck she hadn’t been killed multiple times.
Of course her wingman fared much better, emerging from the fray without so much as a scratch on his shiny paint job. Lindsay, on the other hand, was leaking fluid from every system the plane had.
154312122222121122212211122112222212.title: They're trouble all right.

That's a long way to go with a dud engine.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121.content:
“What the hell Franz” The Colonel radioed as the squad slowly regained formation, all except Lindsay who’s plane was obviously struggling just to keep up.
“You were supposed to be helping her”.
“My name is not Franz” the FW190 pilot radioed back. “And how was I supposed to help her. She flew off in the wrong direction”.
“She flew precisely where she was supposed to. You on the other hand…”
“I would have gotten there” Not-Franz replied defensively “And besides, the other pilots helped her out. I wasn’t needed”.
“The other pilots shouldn’t have had to jump in” the Colonel shot back “You were her wing man, it was your responsibility to help”.
“I didn’t ask for her. You assigned her to me as MY wingman. Her job is to help me”.
“And your job was to help her”.
“I was on my way”.
“And by the time you would have gotten there it would have been too late”.
“So? No big deal. You lose planes all the time”.
“It’s a big deal when your goal is to not lose any at all.
“Sometimes you lose a pawn. They come back”.
“My girls are not pawns. You know what Franz? Screw this. Since you made sure you don’t have a wing man any more, for the rest of this mission you’re going to park yourself in front of the lead transport and give the flak something to shoot at”.
“My name is not Franz, and YOU cannot tell me what to do”.
“As long as you are part of my flight I can. If you don’t like taking orders feel free to head home by yourself”.

Not Franz’s response was to open his throttle full. Pushing his plane’s engine to full power and accelerating away.

After watching him for a couple of moments to see if he was actually going to do it, the Colonel turned her attention back to Lindsay and her smoking aircraft.
“Lindsay? Are you okay”?
“Personally, I’m fine”. Lindsay radioed back “But my plane’s shot. Oil, Coolent, Fuel, Hydraulic fluid. You name it and I’m probably leaking it. Forget the mission. I may not make it back to base”.
“Anyone else take damage”? The Colonel asked.
Linda spoke up. “A few holes here and there. A possible coolant leak. Nothing serious”.
Nobody else seemed to have been, at least noticeably, damaged, in the fight.
“Okay, listen up” The Colonel said “Linda, you escort Lindsay back to base. You two are officially scrubbed on this mission”.
“Colonel, I protest”. One of the transport pilots broke in. “The mission is to escort these transports and the visiting VIPs. Every plane is vital to see we get back to base safely”.

“Shut up Fritz” was the Colonels sharp reply. “Thanks to one of YOUR so called pilots, one of my planes is out of commission with a second one damaged. I’m sending them both home so as to not compromise the fighting ability of my remaining aircraft”.

“But if you do that you won’t have enough planes to provide adequate coverage”.
“The six of us are more than enough coverage for two transports. What I don’t have is enough planes to baby sit a crippled machine on top of two transports and an idiot.

The squad heard the transport pilot key the mike as if to reply, but what ever he was going to say he must have had second thoughts about it, because the radio clicked off a second later. After a couple of last minute instructions, Lindsay turned away from the flight, Linda following and taking up position on her left wing.
Together, the two headed west towards base.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121.title: Turn back to base

15431212222212112221221112211222221212.content:
Lindsay heard the change in engine’s sound and let out a soft “oh, poop!” The big Daimer-Benz V12 had been running, while not exactly smoothly, at least steadily along as Lindsay nursed her crippled ship back home. Now a minor rattle that had started a few minutes ago grew alarmingly louder. A rattle that, in spite of Lindsay’s determined interest in peering at the few still functioning engine gauges, refused to identify its source.
She keyed her mike. “How far away do you think we are”? she asked, trying to keep her voice calm, lest it betray how worried she was. She was having to rely on Linda for course information. Normally the information would be almost second nature to her, but that was when she’d known things like how fast she’d been going and what time it was. Unfortunately, among other things both her clock and speed indicator were gone, casualties of a 23mm calling card from one of the LaGGs. The brass shell had punched a hole just below the throttle lever, leaving a crease of torn metal and smashed glass diagonally across her instrument panel. How it had missed the throttle cable and her left knee she had no idea, but she was thankful it had, needing both of those to help maneuver with what little control surfaces she still had functioning.
Unusual movement caught her attention. The oil pressure gauge was twitching oddly, so she picked a scrap of white cloth that was stuck in the broken glass face out of the way so she could see it better. Then she paused, staring at the cloth held in her fingers intently. It looked like silk, but why would there be scraps of silk blowing around her plane, swirling in the draught from the multitude of shell holes surrounding her. And so many of them. She was staring at a not so small pile caught in the eddy below her left foot, thinking there must be something important she was missing, when Linda radioed “Looks like about fifteen minutes yet. Everything okay over there”?
“I’m not sure” Lindsay replied, worry creeping into her voice. “I may not be able to hold together that long. What do we have for alternates”?
“ ’Fraid the only field closer is the 104th, they’re about 2 minutes South by south east of us. But I haven’t heard good things about their commander. From what I’ve heard he’s a bit of a dick. Probably better to give it up and hit the silk if it comes to that”.

And there it was. An reasonable explination of all the scraps of cloth being whipped around the cockpit. “Sorry Linda”, she radioed back “but I don’t think bailing out is going to be an option for me”. Before she could elaborate there was a crunching bang from the engine, which began to stutter and lope alarmingly as the manifold pressure plummeted. “Looks like I’m out of the other options as well” she yelled over the engine’s death rattle. Out of options she turned towards the 104th and its faint offer of safe landing.
As if Lindsay didn’t already have her hands full, the stuttering engine was belching black smoke and oil, partially obscuring all vision forward. Thankfully Linda didn’t ask questions or try to argue. Instead she took up position behind the crippled plane and began to call out the information she knew Lindsay wasn’t able to get from her ruined instruments.
“Swing just a couple of degrees to your left now. That’s it. We should be on track now. A little high for the glide slope but that might be a good thing. Stand by while I radio in a distress call”.
The tortured engine decided it had put up with enough already, gave one last airframe shaking crunch, and quit. The resulting silence was almost deafening in itself, even though it wasn’t really that quiet, being filled with the whistle of wind passing bullet holes and shattered glass.
Lindsay struggled not only with the plane now, but also to fight down the rising panic she felt. With oil smeared across the windshield and no instruments she was almost flying blind. “Level out Lindsay”, Leslie was saying. “You’re starting to turn again. Get your wings level”!
“I can’t. I need to see! I can’t see a dam’d thing!”
She needed to see. Fumbling at the cockpit cover release she tried to wrench the cover open, intending to jettison it and lean out, only to discover it wouldn’t open. The frame was twisted and jammed. In desperation she punched and pounded at the cracked side glass. Thankfully the 23mm shell hole had weakened the glass enough that it shattered and fell away, allowing her to at least see the horizon out over her left wing. Encouraged, she did the same to the glass to her right with the same result.
“I can see the sides, but I can’t see shit in front of me” she said into her mike. You’ll have to watch and call out the numbers for me. I’m dead stick, so we only get one chance at this”.
The last bit was completely unnecessary. Both of them knew that coming in ‘Dead Stick’ left no option to abort the landing and go around again.
Linda kept her voice calm and dry as she counted off the numbers, guiding Lindsay down.
“Okay Lindsay, we’re on course at about 500 meters and 350kph. Knew that extra altitude would be handy. Deploy landing gear.”
“Gear down and locked.”
“That’s good. Speed 270. Still a little fast. Bring your nose up a touch. Speed 250.”
“Okay, speed 250, 10 degree flap.”
“Speed 220. Nose down Lindsay, your rising. That’s good. Decent rate 20. Speed 200”
“Roger 200. Going full flap.”
"Looking good. We’re crossing the threshold. Decent 15, 50 meters.”
"Dam’d. I can see both sides of the runway. Nice navigating”
“Bring the nose up a touch Lindsay. Good. Flare out. Flare out!”
The wheels touched earlier than she expected, and the plane bounced up into the air again. Pushing the stick forward to bring it back down and she bounced again, hard. The tail came up. Way, way up. Far enough up that the nose skimmed the runway and the propeller would have struck had it been turning. Then the tail came down and slammed onto the runway and she was rolling down the runway, slowing, until eventually she stopped.
A crash truck came roaring up behind her, slewing to a stop. The men piling out were dragging fire extinguishers and aiming hoses all around, ready for the usual fiery crash landing result, but it seemed they were late to the party and all the excitement was over. Unless you count the cursing and prying as they tried to get the lid open and get Lindsay out.
Although the way the men acted when they finally pried the cover off and got a look at who they were rescuing you’d have though the excitement was just starting.
15431212222212112221221112211222221212.title: That's a long way to go with a dud engine.

choices: My, that's certainly a big hanger.
154312122222121122212211122112222212122.content:
All the men enthusiastically pitched in to help pull Lindsay from the wreckage. In fact, there were so many hands helping that some of the men were having trouble finding parts of her to hold on to. More than one, purely by accident she was sure, grabbed her in places she really wished they hadn’t. The men also seemed quite worried that the wrecked plane might spontaneously explode with hither to unknown great force, so they made sure they had carried her an extra safe distance away, then picking her up again and carrying her even further before setting her down again. They also seemed quite concerned she may have been hurt in the crash and they all wanted to make sure she was okay after enduring such a traumatic event. A couple of the men, fresh from basic first aid training, even insisted on checking her for broken bones, in spite of her protesting that she was fine. Fortunately, the base medic arrived and chased them off before they could start the full body search they were so enthusiastically insisting she needed.

“So” said the Medic, holding her face and temporarily blinding her with a flash light, no doubt to check if she was mentally alert enough to realize she couldn’t see. “Have a little bit of a crash?”
“No” She replied, blinking rapidly “I just had a nice big one, thanks anyway. Probably more than I need at the moment.”
Now it was his turn to blink as he turned her reply over in his mind.
“Well,” he said shortly, suppressing a smile. “We certainly wouldn’t want to over indulge in such things. It’s not healthy and we can’t have that now, can we.”
Fortunately he proceeded to dig a pair of rubber gloves out of his kit without waiting for her answer, for which Lindsay was grateful, having borrowed heavily against all her witty post-crash repartee and having nothing good to come back with.
Of course the medic himself did the same basic evaluation the crash truck boys wanted to do, but in a decidedly more sedate and professional manner, gently squeezing parts of her limbs slowly while asking her if anything hurt. Not finding any injuries more serious then that long bruise across her back, likely from whatever had turned her parachute into silk confetti, he was helping her to her feet when another jeep pulled up, this one containing Linda along with another officer.
“Lindsay!” squealed Linda, running up and giving her a hug that blatantly disregarded any potential injury she may have suffered. “You’re okay!”

“That’s what the doctor here says,” Lindsay replied, gently disentangling herself “Right doc?”
“Judging from the number of holes in that crate she was flying,” the medic said, gesturing towards Lindsay’s distant plane as he packed up his med kit. “She’s in a whole lot better shape than she has the right to be. Just a couple of minor cuts and scratches.”
“Glad to hear that!” said a voice behind them. Lindsay suddenly remembered the officer that had arrived with Linda. She turned and saw that the man standing there was an officer, and a major at that. “Oops, sorry sir,” Lindsay said, snapping off a salute, “Didn’t see you there.”
“Not a problem” The major said, returning her salute. “Obviously you had other things on your mind. Major Eric Kinsman, second in command of the 104th”
“First Lieutenant Lindsay Anderson, Jagdgeschwader 127th”
“Ah yes. Colonel Helgameire’s outfit. How is that old Battle Axe these days?”
Lindsay faltered at this, not knowing how to respond. She looked at Linda, hoping for guidance, but Linda looked as bemused as she was. The Major laughed when he saw the look on the two women’s faces.
“Leslie and I go way back” he said with a grin “Before her ‘I hate all men’ phase we were actually good friends. So is she still making life miserable for all the men in her unit?”
“Actually” Linda said “The Colonel set it up so it’s a women only squadron. There are no men in the 127th.
Now it was the Major’s turn to look nonplussed. “Well do tell. All women eh? Sounds like something she’d do. I'd love to hear all about it. Tell you what. From the looks of your plane you’re going to be a while. Let’s get you over to the hanger and introduce you to the Commander."
The Major climbed into the drivers seat, starting the engine as Lindsay and Linda clambered in after him. “We’ll see what he says about your plane” he shouted over the rattle of exhaust from the rotted out muffler of the little 4 cylinder’s engine. “If he gives the okay you can tell the boys in maintenance to get started on repairs, and then join me in the mess hall for dinner.”
And with a grind of gears they sped off towards the hanger the 104th was using as it’s headquarters.
154312122222121122212211122112222212122.title: You can't be too careful around crashed aircraft!

choices: You were not supposed to see that.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
The hanger itself was identical to the one Colonel Helgameire was using as her office, except that the big HE 111 that was always parked in the 127th hanger was missing, likely so during briefing the men could see the all of the big bulletin board that made up one wall.

“Whoa!” Lindsay gasped when she saw the size of it. She always thought the bulletin board they used at the 104th was excessively large, but the sheer massiveness of this one looked like someone had been given the budget of James Cameron and told to buy office supplies. The sheer amount of notices and charts pinned to it would have caused a severe pushpin shortage in any country smaller than Liechtenstein.

“Impressive, isn’t it?” The major said when he saw Lindsay’s reaction. “From that board the Colonel and I can get just about any statistic you want on the 104th. How we’re doing, where we stand in the game. Individual player’s stats.”

“Our board just tracks kills and points.” Lindsay said, “Oh, and flight hours. I didn’t know there was anything else.”

The major grinned. “The Colonels adjutant does data analysis in real life, so he’s used to digging up data on anything. The Colonel’s got him graphing pretty much every aspect of the game for us. You’d probably be running a default version of the basic leader board set-up, so most of this stuff isn’t available to you. Check this chart here” The Major pointed to a sheet of foolscap pinned pretty much in the middle of the board, “This one shows the standings and points of all 36 members of the 104th”.

One entry at the bottom of the list caught Linda’s eye. “How come the one on the bottom is written in red?” she asked.

The Major turned and called over to a group of airmen seated scribbling away at some reports at a bunch of desks in one corner.
“Hey Eugene.”

One of the men looked up from the report he was scribbling on. “What?”
“The lady wants to know why your score is in red.”

A look of annoyance crossed the man’s face.
“Fuck off Eric.”

“Watch the language Captain! Remember we have company.”

The man’s expression didn’t change much. “Sorry. I meant fuck off Major Kinsman, Sir!” Then he made an obvious show of returning to his paperwork.

“That’s better!” The major looked unfazed by the captain’s insolence and filled in a little background on the story. “Eugene there has a tendency to shoot at the wrong targets. So far he’s shot down two of our own transports and strafed a couple of machine gun positions of ours.” Then he sighed dramatically “And there was that supply convoy.”

“Hey. I made a couple of mistakes, okay?” The captain was obviously still listening. “Way back at the beginning. And it takes a lot of enemy kills to offset the penalty points.”

“Yeah, he’s still working on it. Although the Colonel doesn’t let him go up alone anymore. Always makes him take someone along with better eyesight.”

Over his paperwork Eugene gave the Major a dirty look, so more to change the subject than because she was interested Lindsay turned back to the board. “There sure are a lot of charts up there.” She said.

“Oh yeah,” the Major replied, leaving the Captain alone for now. “Fuel usage, Ammo usage, types of aircraft encountered, Types shot down. You name it. Pretty sure there’s a chart up there showing how much urine every member of the squad has passed and when.” He finished with a laugh.

Linda let out an expression of disgust. “Eeww. Why would you want to know that for?”

“Well,” the Major said as if stating a matter of fact, “Great way to call out someone for bragging they weren’t scared. You could look at the sheet and prove otherwise.” Then he saw the look on Lindsay’s face, belatedly realizing he had just picked her up from a crash landing. “Just kidding.” He back pedaled, just in case he might have said something to offend her. “But I’m sure if I wanted that information, it’s there somewhere,” the major finished.

Lindsay hadn’t really had time to be scared during the landing, of course. Everything had happened so quickly. But even if she had, of all the times she’d brought in an aircraft leaking fluids, urine had not been one of them.

The Major lowered his voice and confided “Frankly, I really only ever look at the points and accrued flight hours myself.”

“What’s that chart?” Lindsay asked, changing the subject again by pointing to a large four column chart off to one side. “The one with all the funny letter codes.”
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: My, that's certainly a big hanger.

choices: Oh look, something shiny to distract us.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“Oh, that?” The major read the chart header and smiled “That’s the deployment chart.”
A deployment chart was something neither of the girls had heard of, and the Major was only too happy to show them what it was.
“These four columns” he said, pointing to the larger section of the graph. “Are the most important ones, show the status of every member of the 104th. Name. Rank. Position in group. And a code for current status.”
“As an example here” the Major ran his finger down the coded letters in the last column.
CTS. That stands for currently on station, like Cal and Eugene there. A fancy term for hanging around the base and goofing off.
I’m CTS as well, see. With a small ‘m’ showing that I’m liaisoning at the moment, so I’m not goofing off. I’m being important and giving a tour of the base. Let’s see what else we have COP is currently on patrol, and, oh. The Colonel is COP, guess there’s no point knocking on his door.

Linda pointed to another set of code letters. “What’s MIA?”

“That means missing in action. It usually means we’ve been shot down and survived, and are sneaking around trying to make it back to base without being captured or killed. You get more points that way.”

“How do you know they haven’t been captured?”

“Easy.” The Major said confidently. “Captured prisoners are flagged as CAP the moment they arrive at a POW camp.”

“POW camp?”

“Prisoner Of War. Special camps where the prisoners are kept so they don’t get mistaken for enemy troops and accidentally targeted.” The major laughed and glanced in Eugene’s direction. “Now that would add some serious negative number to your score”.

Lindsay ran her finger down the list, mentally adding up the figures. “You seem to have a lot of MIA’s!” she said finally.

“Really?” The Major seemed genuinely puzzled. I didn’t noticed.” He looked over the columns of numbers himself, “Probably because our men are skillful at avoiding capture.” He declared.

“Not so good at finding their way home again, so it appears.” Linda observed. “That doesn’t help when they can’t get back to fly missions against the enemy.”

“Pilots get shot down all the time.” The Major waved off “Most of them show up again in a day or two. Likely we’ll see some of them tonight in the officers club lying about their exploits behind enemy lines.”
“Speaking of the officers club reminds me.” The Major said, changing topics smoothly, “It’s almost 13 hundred. Since the Colonel is out, it’s up to me to authorize your repairs.”

“You think they can repair my plane?” Lindsay asked. “It was pretty shot up.”

“That it was,” The Major agreed “But the airframe was still intact, and it doesn’t look like you bent anything too badly when you landed. Probably take overnight but the maintenance guys are good, so you should be able to fly out of here in the morning. Talk to the corporal in charge of the maintenance hanger. Tell him I’ve authorized any repairs necessary, then you two can join me for lunch in the mess. My treat, okay?”

“Sounds good.” Linda replied, and the girls left to find the maintenance hanger.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: No Uncharted Territory

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“Hey pretty lady!” The short corporal said as soon as they walked in. “What brings a couple of babes like you to my airbase today?” He leaned on the counter and gave them what he probably thought was an invitingly suave smile that in reality made him look more creepy than friendly as his eyes roving up and down Lindsay’s figure. Yeah, a lot more creepy.

“The lieutenant” Linda said, stressing Lindsay’s rank “made an emergency landing and needs to have some repairs done to her aircraft.”

“Not a problem babe.” he said, fumbling under the counter for a clip board while managing not to take his eyes off them “What’s the matter? Oil pressure not reading right?” He slid the clip board across the counter with a leer that made Lindsay want to surreptitiously check to make sure her flight suit was zipped all the way up. “Or did you just forget to fill up on gas?”

“She had lots of fuel when we left.” Lina said flatly, “but I think most of it leaked out from all those bullet holes.”

“Ooh, Got yourself a couple of bullet holes. I can see where that might cause you girls problems. We’ll see about getting that fixed.”

“You’ll need to replace the engine as well,” Lindsay started to say “I’m afraid it was…”

“Making a funny noise?” the Corporal broke in. “I’m sure it’s nothing major. Don’t you worry your pretty little head over it. I’ll get the men to check for any funny little noises that might bother you girls.”
“Umm, that’s not exactly the problem” Lindsay tried again “I don’t think you understand…”
“Sweetheart,” he said, cutting her off again, “We’re the experts here. Just let us do the job that we’re qualified for.”
Lindsay turned to Linda and shrugged. Linda returned it with a look that said ‘Let him find out for himself’. She had tried.
“Now” said the corporal with another less than subtle leer that found Lindsay not so surreptitiously tugging the zipper higher on her already fully zipped jacket. “I need get the paperwork started, so if you’ll just fill in your vitals.”

“Vitals?”

“The basics, you know. Name, Squadron, Ident Numbers, Body Measurements.”

“Measurements?” Lindsay asked, blinking confusedly.

“Standard procedure.” The corporal continued oily, “For a change of uniform. In case you need to stay overnight. Also are you good on the bottom or do you like to be on top?”

“What?!?”

“I’m talking bunk beds, babe. Do you prefer top or bottom bunk? Of course, we could make other sleeping arrangements, if you know what I’m saying.” He waggled his eyebrows suggestively.

“Don’t you need to know who authorized the repairs?” Linda cut in.

“Not at all babe, those bazookas you’re carrying are all the authorization I need.”

“I don’t think so.” Linda said, having just about had enough of Corporal sleezy. Finished with filling in only the officially required information, she slapping the pencil on top of the form and pushing the clip board back across the counter at him. “How long are the repairs going to take?”

“Hard to say,” the corporal said, still obliviously smiling oily, “The boys will need to look your plane over very carefully. Make sure there is no hidden damage, you know? Some stuff is not obvious to the untrained eye. That could take some time.”

“Oh?” Said Linda, having a very good idea where the corporal was headed. “How much time, do you think?”

The Corporal didn’t disappoint. “That checking for hidden damage could take some time, several hours at least. Most likely overnight.”

“And so we’ll likely need food and lodging, then?”

“That’s why I asked the questions Babe. Just in case, of course. There’s a spare tent I can put you up in, over near my place. As for food fortunately for you I know this great little place just off the base. The chef there is a personal friend.”

“And I’ll bet he does Italian” she said sarcastically

“But of course. Brushetta and Crostini. Pesto, Antipasto, Minestrone, and Pizza, and a Crème Brulee so good his own mother weeps.”

“Crème Brulee?” Linda looked at the Corporal levelly, “Isn’t that more French than Italian?”

“Of course it is,” the Corporal recovered quickly, “He trained in Paris for 3 years. And he buys all of his food daily at the town market so it’s fresh.”

Linda gave Lindsay with a ‘Can you believe this?’ look, then summarized what she’d been hearing “So you know a Parisian trained chef making Italian food with local ingredients sourced in German occupied Russia. Sounds wonderful.” Then she gave a heavy theatrical sigh “It really is a shame that we have already promised the Major we’d join him and the other officers for supper, isn’t it lieutenant?” She said to Lindsay, stressing the word officers.

Lindsay picked up on the offered escape immediately “Yes, Captain. It sure is. They’re probably already waiting for us, given how long we’ve been talking to the Corporal here.”

Linda pushed the clipboard all the way across the counter to rest against the Corporal’s elbow. “We’ll be in the mess tent.” She said with a small grin. ”Do be a good little soldier and let us know when we can expect the Lieutenant’s plane to be ready, will you?”

Outside the two women looked at each other and rolled their eyes, then turned and walked quickly towards the mess tent. They almost made it half way before they couldn’t take it any more and burst out laughing.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: The Hanger of Maintenance

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
If they had looked back they would have seen that the Corporal standing just outside the maintenance hanger with an ugly look on his face as he watched the two women laughing.

“You know” Lindsay felt compelled to say when they saw the amount of people headed to the same direction., “The food at that other place would probably be just as good as the mess hall.”
“Oh, probably” Linda replied, taking the time to smile at the soldier that politely held the door open for them. “But packed as this place looks, I’ll take a crowd over spending another minute in the company of Corporal Lascivious back there.” Scanning the crowd, she spotted the Major seated at a table along the back wall, waving to them. “Besides” she said as she waved back and started towards his table, “We are expected, remember?”
The Major smiled and stood up when he saw them approaching. “Ladies, welcome. Have a seat. Glad you decided to join us.”
“Us?” Linda asked. The bench table the Major was sitting at could comfortably seat 20, although at the moment only four of the seats further down were taken. “How many more are coming?”
“One more.” The major replied. “Talk about timing, here he is.”
To the girls surprise the forth member of the group turned out to be none other than the luckless Captain Eugene, taking his lunch break.
“I don’t believe we’ve been formally introduced,” Linda said, holding out her hand, nudging Lindsay with her other elbow. “Captain Linda Bray-Lewis, 127th”
“I’m Captain Conner, 104th , as you undoubtedly guessed.” Replied the Captain, removing his cap and giving the offered hand a quick shake.
“First Lieutenant Lindsay Anderson. Also with the 127th” said Lindsay, also holding her hand out for the Captain to shake.
“Delighted,” he said “What brings you ladies to our humble airstrip?”
“I’d hardly call it humble” replied Linda, gesturing at the milling crowd with a smile. “Judging from the amount of people eating lunch right now.”
“Speaking of which” The Major broke in “We should grab some food and eat so others can use the table.”
“One of us should probably stay and save our spots,” Lindsay suggested, eyeing the crowd still trickling in.
At this the Major had just laughed and tossed his hat on the table. “These four” he said to the men sitting at the end of the table. The men nodded. “Perks of being a Major” he grinned, leading them to the line queuing up at the counter.
“Mmmm” Linda said inhaling the delicious fragrances wafting from the steam tables. “Smells wonderful.”
The day’s lunch menu was surprising heavily slanted towards Italian dishes.
“Oh yes” the Major said when this was pointed out. “There’s a local guy who comes in twice a week to give a bit of variety. Mondays he does Italian, Fridays he does a more French Cuisine lineup. He’s really quite good.”
Lindsay looked at Linda, briefly wondering if she should feel guilty for some reason. But to her surprise Linda just shrugged and suggested they line up.
Lindsay had a hard time deciding which of the myriad of dishes she wanted. Even after the five minutes they stood in line she’d only narrowed it down to a choice of either a Linguini or a Fettuccine, but she was still faced with a dozen variety’s to choose from when it came their turn. Grabbing almost at random, she wound up putting a bit from five different dishes onto her tray, with a small bowl of Minestrone and a spinach salad, plus a couple of Gnocchi Della Nonna’s because she liked the way they looked.
Once they sat down and started eating the conversation dwindled off, consisting mainly of comments about how good the food was. It was a while before anyone spoke.

“So,” Eugine said, about halfway done his Cannelloni, “Back to my original question. What brings you two to the 104th?”
