"Lindsay had to make an emergency landing.” Linda said, answering for Lindsay when she saw she had her mouth full of Linguini Kitsilano. “And you need to take smaller bites, dear.”
“Sorry” Lindsay said “It’s just so good.”
“Of course it is” laughed Eugene. “That’s why Italians are usually so fat.”
“They’re not all fat.” Protested Linda.
“Look at any depiction of popular culture. If there’s an old Italian in it, chances are he’s fat. And if it’s a woman it’s practically a guarantee.”
“I’m pretty sure that’s just stereotyping” replied Lindsay after swallowing.
“Or typecasting” said Linda. “Colleen’s studied that, so she’d be the one to know. At least I think she’s studied it.”
“And Colleen is?” asked the Major
“She’s the unofficial videographer of our squadron.” Linda explained “She takes the recordings of our fights and turns them into movies. She’s quite good at it too. I think that’s because she works in the industry in real life. Her best one so far is Lindsay here taking out a four ship Russian bomber squad while acting like a great white shark.”
“Really?” said the Major as both men turned to look at Lindsay who was hunched down over her plate, embarrassed at the sudden attention. “That I’d like to see.”
“Oh yeah, she’s good.” Linda continued with a wicked grin. “There’s another where Lindsay and this top Russian ace spend almost 10 minutes dog fighting, trying to get a bead on each other.”
Both the men looked suitably impressed.
“Of course,” Linda continued “we’ve also got film of her losing a fight with a toilet.”
“Linda!” Lindsay shrieked, going bright red. “Nobody needs to know about that.”
“Oopsies. I guess I shouldn’t have said anything. Too late now.”

The two men were obviously trying their best not to laugh at the poor girl, and just as obviously losing. “We should do the same.” Eugene said. “Take the recordings and make them into a movie. Greatest Moments of the 104th. I’m surprised no one thought of it.”
“Speak for yourself” the Major said. “Remind me to screen ‘Captain Conner Verses the Supply Column’ for you some day.”
“Only if it’s a double bill with ‘Major Kinsman and the Foggy Landing Strip’.” The Captain shot back.
“Maybe a triple feature. I can dust off that copy of ‘Eugene’s greatest hits’”. was the Major’s reply.
“Do we have a copy of ‘The Major’s Mis-wired Throttle Cable of Mayhem’?”
“Yep. Right beside ‘Who’s Chute is That, Anyway’.”

Watching the two men trade barbs Lindsay was struck by two realizations, the first being that the Major and the Captain were actually good friends, and the previous needling about Eugene’s negative score was an extension of the good nature hazing all men engage in with their buddies. The type where neither makes too much of it, but it sounds far more serious to an outsider than it really is.

The second realization was that, as embarrassing as the toilet incident was, in hindsight it actually wasn’t that bad. And did make for a hilarious story.

“So anyway” the Captain said, breaking Lindsay’s mental musings by bringing the topic of conversation back around to its initial heading “The major tells me you Dead Sticked a block of Swiss Cheese in earlier. So how does a pilot of your skill wind up with a ship having that many holes in it?”
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: The Corporal follows them to the door

choices: The Captain also has to leave
The Captain can stick around for a bit.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“I drew an incompetent idiot for a wingman” Lindsay said, then hastened to add “No, not Linda.” seeing the men glance in her direction. “She’s the one who pulled my bacon out of the fire. The Colonel had us rotate wing duty with a couple Bomber Wing officers to see how the new Folker Wolfe FW190s performed. Three Russians jumped me, and the Kampfgeschwader pilot was a total Noob.
“Ah, the VIP escort scenario,” Captain Eugene said knowingly “You know who was flying those 190’s, don’t you?”
“Not a clue” was Lindsay’s reply.
“The pilots were the actual VIP’s you were escorting.”
“Really? How do you figure that?”
“A clever bit of classic miss-direction.” The Captain ticked off the points on his fingers as he made them “You have a couple of visiting VIP’s touring the front, gathering information or what ever. The enemy gets wind of it, and sends a squad out with orders to get the transports carrying the VIPs at all costs. Since their orders are to take out the transports they are going to ignore the escorts unless forced to fight them. Only what they don’t know is the transports are just decoys. The real VIPs are in two of the escort planes which they automatically try to avoid”
“So you’re saying the idiot I had as a wingman..?”
“Was some high up muckity muck from Kampfgeschwader high command. A qualified pilot but with no fighter combat experience.”
“That’s quite a stretch” Lindsay said. “Admittedly, it kind of makes sense, but how would you prove it?”
The Captain grinned. “No proof needed. We flew the escort mission last week. Only our group ran into a squad of 20 Russians. We lost 4 machines and both transports.”
“Ouch”
“Yeah, but since we got the VIP’s in their fancy fighters safely home, so technically we won the scenario. Say, are you going to eat that?”
Lindsay had pushed the last Gnocchi to the side of her plate. “I don’t think so.” She said.
Not that it wasn’t delicious. Just something about the Captain’s comment about getting fat and suddenly it didn’t seem so appetizing. “You can have it if you want.”
Maybe, she told herself, she’d go for a run in the morning.
“Thanks.” Eugene speared it with his knife, transferring it to his almost empty plate and cutting it into large pieces while continuing. Since we were successful we had two days liberty in the city of Taganrog.”
“Ours was supposed to be in Voroshilovgrad, not that I know anything about it. Other than it’s a seven hour flight to get there.”
“Taganrog’s about the same distance. I believe it is a little further south. It’s a port on the Sea of Azov.”
“A seaport? Sounds wonderfully romantic” Lindsay said without thinking. Now where had that come from?
“If you say so.” Eugene said, “I spent most of my liberty seeing how many bars I could hit.”
“No shopping?” asked Linda.
“Women and their shopping.” The major exclaimed “Give them a few days off and I swear all they’d do is look at shoes.”
“That’s not true!” Lindsay
“Oh really? And what were you planning on doing in Voroshilovgrad?” Eugene asked.
“Look at shoes,” Lindsay blurted before she could stop herself.
“The Major’s point, exactly.” Eugene said, stuffing the last half of the Gnocchi into his mouth as a single bite.
“Well, I mean, sure. But that’s not the only thing.”
“Mmm?” Eugene raised one eyebrow questioningly, his mouth still full of Gnocchi.
“Well, umm…” Lindsay said, floundering “We were also, umm, going to do some, I don’t know. Other stuff?” she looked pleadingly at Linda.
“I have no idea what Voroshilovgrad is like." Linda said "I’m sure there are museums and theaters and night clubs and stuff, but neither Lindsay or I have been there, so we were just going to follow the rest of the girls around. .”
“Frankly” said Eugene, swallowing, “If it’s anything like Taganrog it’s just another war ravaged Russian city without much to look at. The bars are probably your best shot.”
“That’s all rather academic now,” Linda pointed out. “I’m sure the rest of the squad will tell us what it was like when they get back to the base.”

“Speaking of bases,” The Major said, getting to his feet, “I’m due over at the 77th for a strategy meeting so I need to head out.” He gave each of the woman a small handshake “Thank you for your company ladies. Any time you’re in the area please feel free to drop in.”
“Thank you for your hospitality Major.” Linda replied as she returned the handshake. “And for lunch.”
“Anytime.” He replied in turn, then made his way through the thinning crowd towards the door.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Blame it of the wingman

choices: The repairs are not going as well as they thought
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Eugene looked at his watch, noticing the time. “I should be getting back to work as well.” He said. “As much as I’d love to sit and chat I need to get ready for our next patrol. Maybe I’ll get lucky and get enough points to be back in the black again.”
“You don’t seem to be bothered as much by your score as you seemed earlier.” Linda observed.
Eugene shrugged, wearing a good natured smile “That was when Eric and I are ribbing each other. Doesn’t bother me that much, really. And I’m getting better at telling Friend from Foe.”
He stood up and liked around the mess tent, frowning slightly. “That’s odd.” He said.
“What’s odd?” asked Lindsay.
“Well, usually this place is so crowded at lunch time it’s hard to find a seat. Not today though.” Then he shrugged “Probably just the game adjusting the crowd so we can talk easier.” He concluded. “I’d say about ninety 90 percent of the crowd still here are NPC’s.”
“Really?” Lindsay asked “How can you tell?”
“It’s in the way they move. NPC’s tend to repeat the same gestures. Also their eyes don’t follow you as closely as a player’s do.”
“Really? I hadn’t noticed. Of course, I never looked that closely. I’ve never needed to. There’s only the eight of us at the 127th, so I just automatically assume anyone else I see on base is an NPC.”
“There’s over a hundred of us at the 104th. I don’t know everyone by sight, so I’ve gotten pretty good at picking out players among the crowd. There’s only 4 other real players here eating lunch today. If you watch carefully you can pick them out. Anyway. I really should get going. The flight hates it when someone’s late.”
“Well good luck, and thanks again for lunch.” Said Lindsay, shaking the offered hand.
“Thank the major for that. But if you’re still around this evening look me up and I can buy you dinner.”
“Sure,” Lindsay said with a smile “I’d like that.”
Lindsay watched Eugene thread his way through the computer generated throng. As soon as he was out of earshot Linda cocked her head. “Oohh. Looks like someone has a date tonight.” She teased.
“What are you talking about.” Lindsay asked, slightly flustered at being caught staring.
“The handsome Captain Eugene.”
“What?”
“He did say he would buy you dinner.”
“Us. He said he would buy us dinner.”
“He was looking at you when he said it.”
“But he was talking to both of us.”
“What do you want to bet he brings the Major along as his wingman.”
“Why would he need a wingman?”
“So he doesn’t get shot down.”
“It’s not a patrol.”
“No, it’s not” Linda said, grinning “It’s a date.”
“It’s not a date!”
“If you want to tell yourself that, go right ahead.” Linda stood up. “You want more coffee?”
“Might as well.” Lindsay said, sliding her empty cup across the table.
When Linda returned with fresh cups she sat beside her at the table. To her relief Linda didn’t bring up the date thing again, but instead joined her in watching the crowd. Sipping their coffee and comparing notes they quickly realized spotting NPCs wasn’t as easy as the Captain said. Still, it was a way to pass the time.
The sounds of aircraft warming up and taxiing had been a part of the back ground noise to their conversation, largely unnoticed. Until one engine caught their attention. It was louder and closer than the others, coming from the maintenance hanger. With nothing better to do the two girls put their coffee mugs on the dish rack and headed over to investigate.

As they walked towards the maintenance hanger they saw one of the maintenance crew climbing down out of Linda’s plane, leaving it sitting outside the hanger with its engine running.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: The Captain also has to leave

choices: Walk a mile (or twenty) in her shoes.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
The Corporal had seen them coming and met them at the door carrying his clip board.
The look on his face was one of smug satisfaction. “Good timing” he said, “Saves me having to hunt you down. Which one of you broads is signing for number three?”
Linda spoke up, “That would be me”.
“Thought so, Captain.” he said with a thin smile and that odd emphasis on her title. “Here you are.”
“What’s this?” Linda asked, looking at the sheet of paper the Corporal handed her.
“Your invoice. The Major authorized repairs, that don’t mean the 104th is paying for them. One replaced the radiator hose and your plane’s warmed up and ready to go. Have your commanding officer authorize payment on this as soon as you get back to base.”
“And Lieutenant,” the Corporals thin smile turned up a little more in the corner of his mouth “Here is your invoice.”
“You’ve done the repairs all ready?” Lindsay asked, amazed and delighted that the work would had been completed so soon.
“Repairs? Who said anything about repairs?” The smile on the Corporal’s face was that of someone who loved the taste of crushed dreams, and has been eagerly anticipating his next sampling. “This is rental on the bulldozer we used to push your wreck off the runway.”
Lindsay blinked, not quite following what he was saying. “The what to do what now?”
“It ain’t a parking lot, doll. That runway is to be kept clear at all times. Since it weren’t safe to roll your wreck out of the way we had ta’ push it.”
With a sinking feeling Lindsay walked numbly over to the edge of the runway to where she could see the spot where she left her plane, stopping in shock as soon as she saw the sight that greeted her. Off to one side sat what had been a badly damaged, yet still salvageable aircraft; turned into a twisted pile of scrap metal that looked as if it had been run over by a tank.
“Oh yeah”, the Corporal continued at the look on her face. “We may have run over it once or twice. Sorry about that”. He somehow managed to sound convincingly not sorry at all.
“You… you crushed it”? Lindsay managed to squeak out, still trying to come to terms with what she was seeing.
“Can’t have bits sticking up where they could hook a wing, so yeah.”
“You wrecked my plane?”
“Nope. You wrecked it when you crashed it.”
“But the Major said it was still fixable.” She protested.
“Underlying structural damage!” the Corporal said, stressing each syllable as if talking to a small child, “Not repairable in my opinion, and I’m the expert here so that’s the only one that counts.”
“But that was my plane!” She cried.
“No. That was a heap of junk you piled up on my runway and left me to deal with. So I dealt with it. You want to make an issue of it, have your CO call my CO. Meanwhile, you have 5 minutes to get the hell off this base.”
“Say what?”
“You got a base pass?” The Corporal asked, knowing full well what the answer would be.
“A base pass. Well, no. But…”
“You two ain’t part of this squadron, toots,” the Corporal interrupted “So ya got no business being on this base. Maybe you can wave those Bazonga’s at the Major and get a free dinner, but that don’t mean a hill-o-beans to me, and unless you’ve got a base pass you’re trespassing.” As he spoke a jeep with two MPs pulled up to a stop along side of them.
“You need to show some respect here, mister.” Linda said “You know we’re here because of an emergency landing…”
“Which has been handled with repairs.” The Corporal came back “Completed and invoiced for. Also a crash team response and rescue for Lieutenant Hooters over there, along with disposal of her wrecked plane. Which are also complete and invoiced for. End of emergency, doll face.”
“You can’t expect us to just leave.”
“I don’t expect anything, other than maybe enjoying the sight of you two being frog marched off the base by those MPs there in five minutes.”
“You can’t.” Linda said hotly.
“We’ll see in four minutes and forty seconds, toots.” The Corporal said, smugly setting the timer on a very large and elaborate wrist watch.
“You don’t seem to realize we both out rank you.”
“And you don’t seem to realize that only works when you have authorization to be here.”
“And just how do you expect us to leave?” Linda asked, possibly in a last ditch effort to appeal to the Corporals good side.
“You” The corporal sneered, indifferent, and apparently not having a good side. “Can fly. If Lieutenant Udders there can squeeze into the cockpit with you, all the better. Otherwise it looks like she’s walking. Unless she can sweet talk the Major into authorizing someone to give her a ride.” Then he smiled smugly again “But since I saw the Major’s crate take off earlier I guess that ain’t an option.” His smile managed to grow even more smug. “Come to think of it, it looks like anybody else who can authorize a ride seems to have left on patrol.”
“You insolent little piece of shit.” Linda spat “You know two people can’t fit in a 109.”
“And I don’t care,” he sneered, “As long as what ever you do about it is done in the next four and a half minutes. After that you can deal with the MPs here.”
From the way the burly MPs had just sat there during the exchange it was obvious the two were NPCs, and Linda had no doubt they would do exactly whatever Corporal Sleezebag told them.
“You little shit.” Linda snarled at the smug little Corporals face. “Your commander will definitely hear about this!”
“Yeah, yeah, yeah,” The Corporal said “Like I care. Four minutes!”
Linda glared at the Corporal, who matched the glare with a self satisfied smug grin. At this point the presence of the two MPs the corporal was the only reason the corporal was not playing craps using his own teeth. As it was all Linda could do was glare at him, before turning and storming towards her idling aircraft, Lindsay in tow.
“You haven’t heard the last of this, she yelled over her shoulder.”
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: The repairs are not going as well as they thought

choices: And now for the walking part.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“Linda!” Lindsay protested as she was dragged along. “There’s no way we’ll both fit, you know that!”
“I know.” Linda replied through gritted teeth “I just wanted to get out of there before I do something I wouldn’t regret.”
“But what are we going to do?” Lindsay asked desperately.
“I don’t know.” Linda was thinking as she pulled her along. “Wait. I know. We’ll borrow a Stuka. That seats two.”
“From who? Corporal Dickhead?”
“Oh God no, are you kidding? If I thought that was possible I’d just borrow you another aircraft. No, I was going to grab one of ours and fly back.”
“And then what?”
“Your right. Dickhead will probably deny me landing privileges. I wouldn’t put it past him. Tell you what. You start walking.”
“But that’ll take me hours” Lindsay cried
“No it won’t. As soon as I get back to the 127th I’ll grab a jeep from the motor pool. If you stick to the main road I’ll be back to pick you up in about an hour.”
“I don’t want to walk.”
“I don’t want you walking, but I don’t see an alternative. Have you got your gun?”
Lindsay nodded. “Good. Be careful.” With that Linda climbed the ladder into the cockpit of her fighter and settled herself in.
“Remember,” she shouted as she reached up and grabbed the hatch handle “Stick to the main road so I can find you.”
Then she gunned the engine and began to pull away.
Lindsay stood in the propwash until it died away, Clutching her coat around her, feeling very much alone and abandoned.
But not for long. The little Corporal’s eyes were no doubt glued to his watch, marking the minutes were rapidly ticking away, so she couldn’t afford herself the luxury dwelling in depression. There would be plenty of time for self pity when she was off the base and on the road.
She was only about half way to the guard house when a jeep pulled up on her left, brakes screeching in that way brakes do when they’ve reached the end of their service life. The lone MP behind the wheel leaned across the seat to her “Get in, he said.”
“Oh, come on,” she said bitterly. “I’m like, a minute away from the entrance.”
“Yeah,” the MP replied “And your about one minute and six hours away from home. So unless you’re really looking forward to walking the whole way I suggest you get in and let me give you a lift.”
Lindsay looked at the MP, torn between puzzlement and suspicion. This must have shown on her face, because the MP grinned. “Oh, right” he said. “Daddy probably told you to never take rides from strangers.” He removed his helmet and held out his hand. “I’m First Lieutenant Darryl Mackentyre, communications specialist, mediocre pilot, and part time policeman.”
Lindsay hesitated for a moment before deciding the guy was legit. Nobody else would describe them selves as mediocre, would they? “First Lieutenant Lindsay Anderson.” She said, accepting the handshake. “Uhh, I fly fighters for the 127th.”
The MP held onto her hand and helped her into the Jeep. “I know. I was in the com tent when you were doing the tour. I heard you needed a lift and came to offer you one.”
Lindsay froze half seated “Corporal Dickhead sent you?”
“Dickhead?” The lieutenant threw back his head and laughed “Yeah, that pretty much describes Gary alright. And no, I’m the last person he’d send. I overheard him talking about ordering you off base and decided I’d throw a wrench into his plan.”
“Well, I must say that’s mighty nice of you.”
“What can I say, I’m a nice guy.” Darryl put the Jeep in gear and headed towards the guardhouse down the road. “Besides,” he said as they waved to the MP at the gate, “As a police man finding an un-escorted soldier wandering the base it’s my duty to confront, apprehended and / or safely remove said soldier from the premises.” He looked at the gate house receding rapidly in the rear view mirror. “I think we can say that part of the job is done.” He looked at Lindsay, so she nodded in agreement.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Alternate Transportation becomes available.

choices: One week later, the 10th is returning from patrol.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
After a couple of kilometers had passed she asked “You’re not going to get in trouble for this, are you?” She had to raise her voice to be heard over the noise of the tires on the gravel road.
“Nope.” Darryl replied “Part of the policeman thing. It’s not safe for anyone, especially a woman, to walk these roads alone. So it’s sort of my job to see you safely home. As long as I’m back by 19 hundred I’ll be fine.”
Linda’s 109 roared past overhead, then swung up and around as Lindsay waved.
“Your friend up there seems concerned” Darryl said, watching the fighter circle around for another pass.
“Probably just making sure I’m okay.”
This time as Linda came up on them Lindsay stood up, gripping the windshield to steady herself as she turned to face the fighter, and gave her a ‘thumbs up’. It was kind of hard to tell, as the 109 roared past at better than 200kph, but Lindsay could have sworn Linda was grinning widely, returning her thumb gesture with a wink and the okay sign. What the hell was that all about?
“Good to have a friend up there looking out for you.” Darryl said as the noise of the fighter faded into the distance.
“Yeah,” Lindsay replied “I guess it is.”
“Well I do appreciate the ride.”
“As I said, not a problem. Sorry the corporal went full out dickhead on you back there.”
“What’s his problem anyway?”
“Gary? He suffers from Little Man’s Syndrome in a big way. Nobody likes him and everyone out ranks him, so he tends to abuse any little bit of authority he gets.”
Darryl maneuvered the jeep smoothly around a shell hole in the roadway, continuing to talk over the noise of the engine and gravel “He’ll probably be pissed when he finds out I offered you a ride. But I don’t care, and even a first lieutenant out ranks him, so he can’t do anything official about it.”
“He’s not a very likable person, is he? I think if he was in my squad I would probably shoot him down myself.”
Darryl was grinning like a small boy with a secret. “I probably shouldn’t tell you this, and you have to promise not to tell the Major.”
“Not to tell the Major what?” asked Lindsay.
“Most of the guys have been doing that.”
“Doing what?”
“Shooting him down.” Darryl confessed “Accidentally, of course, or so we make it look. We’ve turned it into sort of a game.”
Lindsay looked at him in shock “You shoot him down as part of a game?”
“Oh yeah. Carl started it all.” Darryl furrowed his brow in thought. “We were returning from probably our second or third mission, and Gary was being particularly obnoxious. Kept saying inappropriate things about Carl’s girl, and this after Carl had repeatedly told him to shut up. Finally Carl had enough and let him have it with every shell left from his mission allotment. Last we saw of Gary that day was him spiraling into the Volga River. Then the Major gave a little speech about cooperation and appropriate behavior, which didn’t stop Gary from talking, he just made sure he didn’t say anything in front of the Major. Three days later he did the same thing to Trevor, with the same results. That time the Colonel gave the same speech, busted Gary a rank to Corporal, and threatened to ground him if he caught him talking crap again. He also said he’d do the same to anyone caught shooting Gary down.
Of course, that didn’t stop Gary. He acts like a little suck up whenever the Colonel or Major are around, then crap talks behind their backs. Everyone else knows this, but he never does it where the Colonel or the Major see him, and always denies it if someone complains. So he gets shot down occasionally as a moral booster.”
Lindsay was incredulous. “Surely they know something is up?”
“Maybe.” Darryl admitted “One of the rules we have is that it can’t look deliberate, since nobody wants to be grounded. Since you can’t just outright shoot him you have to arrange it so he happens to be in the line of fire. It’s tricky, but someone still manages it about once a week.”
“Is that why Eugene’s score is so low?”
“Eugene?” Darryl shook his head. “Na, his numbers are in the negative because he shot down two of our troop transports. That and a couple of other things the Major won’t let him forget. No, Eugene and the Colonel are about the only ones in the squad who haven’t had a shot.”
Lindsay thought about this, frowning. “Are you saying even the Major took a turn?”
“Well, I can’t say for sure. It was either a legitimate accident or very well played by the Major. He even hauled Gary’s ass to the office and gave him a severe dressing down for getting in the way. Highlight event of the week, and put the Major on the board with a full 10 points. Two points ahead of me.”
“Points?”
“Of course we assign points. How else do you keep score?”
“And they say women make things complicated. I’d just shoot him and be done with it.”
“Suit yourself. But, hey, could you do me a favor?”
Lindsay looked warily at Darryl. “Depends on what you need.”
“Well, Gary usually flies a plane with unit marking JG104-52.”
“So?”
“Well, if a returning patrol happens to buzz your compound, it would be perfectly understandable if you panicked and mistook a friendly fly by for an attack. And somebody might get shot down in the confusion.”
“Somebody who happens to be flying with JG104-52 on their aircraft?” Lindsay said with a conspiratorial grin.
“Why should we have all the fun? Plus that would get me an easy 4 bonus points.”
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Continue with the ride.

choices: The Lieutenant sticks around for a bit.
The Lieutenant has to get going.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Lindsay mulled the thought over. Watching the antagonistic little Corporal go down in flames had a certain appeal to it.
“I suppose it would serve him right.” She said eventually, as the jeep turned up the drive towards the 127th’s guardhouse. “With any luck he’d end up becoming one of your MIAs. That would keep him off your backs for what, a week?” She looked over at Darryl questioningly “How long is your average MIA gone for?”
The Lieutenant looked surprised at the question. After a moments thought, he said “You know, I don’t know.”
“What? With all those charts and reports you guys print and you don’t read them?”
“Well,” he said “Colonel Seiler has never asked for that particular bit of information.” The Lieutenant shrugged offhandedly. “If he had then I’d have set up a data mining routine to dig it up for him. It’s just never come up.”
“Set up data mining? You mean you’re the guy behind the wall of reports?”
“You could say that. Communications specialist, remember? I do data mining for a living, so creating the Colonel’s reports comes naturally to me. He does go a bit overboard, I’ll admit.”
“Overboard isn’t the word for it.” Lindsay said as they pulled up to the guardhouse and presented their papers “I don’t think the people running the game look at that much data.”
“Oh, I think you’d be surprised at the amount ‘they’ look at.” Darryl said, continuing the conversation while they waited for the guard to do his thing. “They have a team of data miners and report writers. I actually applied for a job there once. Didn’t get hired, but I did get to tour their control room. It’s like something you’d expect to see at NASA or the Pentagon But then again,” he shrugged “They’re looking at keeping the whole game running, not just one squadron.”
The guard finished his cursory check of their papers and waved them through.
“What does the Colonel do with all that data?” Lindsay asked.
“He says it’s to keep tabs on what is happening. Personally, I think he just likes to kill trees and watch numbers dance. Anyway,” He said as he brought the Jeep to a stop in front of the hanger office of the 127th, “Here we are.”

“I can’t thank you enough for the lift, Lieutenant.” Lindsay said as, like a true gentleman, he hurried around to her side and helped her climb out of the jeep. “Would you care for a cup of coffee or something to eat before you head back?”
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Let me sleep on it.

choices: They had to turn back and should be landing shortly.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“No thanks,” Darryl said. “I need to start heading back. I’ll call you the next time we have a patrol in this direction, and we can set up that little surprise for Gary.”

He spun the wheel and took off in a spray of gravel. Lindsay watched him head back down the road. The Lieutenant seemed all eager to incorporate the 127th in their vendetta against the unpopular little corporal, but as she watched the taillights of the jeep disappear around the bend of the guardhouse road she was having serious second thoughts about the whole thing. Although she had sort of agreed to the plan during the drive, the more she thought about it the less inclined she was to go through with it. Shooting the man down in the heat of an argument would maybe make her feel better, at least for a little while. But this, plotting to shoot him down in cold blood, had too much of a cold, calculating feel to it that she didn’t like. No, she decided as she walked to the barrack room she shared with Addison and Beverly, it just felt wrong.
She changed out of her flight suit and went looking for Linda, not sure if she should share the Lieutenant’s plan or not. For some reason it still bothered her, maybe talking to someone would help.
Surprisingly, Linda was in the mess tent when she finally tracked her down, drinking coffee and reading what looked to be some trashy romance novel.
“Oh, hey,” She said, looking up in surprise “That was fast. I didn’t expect to see you for another hour or so.”
“We made good time” Lindsay said, stirring her coffee. “I’ve been back for almost 15 minutes.”
“I know, I heard the jeep. I just thought maybe you’d be a little longer. You know,” She arched one eyebrow, “Thanking him for the lift.”
“Well of course I said thank you, what do you think I would say. wait” she said,catching the look in Linda’s eyes “what are you referring to?”
“The two of you. Alone on the open road. A good looking man. A woman wanting to show her gratitude. You know?”
“Linda!” Lindsay gasped, colouring as she caught on to what Linda was alluding to.
“Relax.” Linda burst out laughing “I’m only teasing. Although I wouldn’t blame you if you did. That man is sure easy on the eyes.”
“That he is.” Lindsay joined in with her own laugh. “Guess I missed an opportunity there.”
“I wouldn’t worry about it.” Linda reassured her “There will be others. At least until Lorraine gets back. But tell me you at least got his number”
“No.” Lindsay admitted. “But he is going to call me.” Her face betrayed that she wasn’t all that happy with the prospect.
Linda shook her head mockingly “That’s what men always say.” Then she caught the look on Lindsay’s face. “Although you don’t seem as happy about that as you should be. What’s the matter?”
“It’s… Well…” Lindsay stumbled over the words, not so sure of how to begin. She knew she was desperate to talk about it, and Linda had given her the perfect opening, but evidentially the subject she was about to bring up bothered her a lot more than she cared to admit. She took a deep breath, and then rushed headlong into the explanation, counting on sheer momentum to get the words out before she could choke up.
“It turns out the 104 is taking turns shooting that creepy little Corporal and now Darryl thinks I should take a turn and at first I was thinking it sounded like a good idea but now I don’t know ‘cause it doesn’t feel right only I’m pretty sure he thinks I’m onboard with the whole idea and I’m not sure how to tell him I’ve changed my mind and don’t want to do it.” The words came rushing out.
“Whoa, there girl” Linda said, when Lindsay took a breath. She held up her hands like she was trying to stop a runaway truck “Slow down. If you don’t want to do it just tell him that.”
“But do you think Darryl will be okay with that?”
“Doesn’t matter. If you don’t want to do something you don’t. The opinion of some guy you just met an hour ago doesn’t matter, no matter how good looking he is.” Linda looked at Lindsay speculatively “That’s the same talk I have to keep giving my kids. How old are you, anyway?”
“Twenty six.” Lindsay said meekly.
‘Humph” Linda snorted. “Your old enough to know you don’t need some stranger’s approval not to do something. You haven’t had much experience with men, have you?”
“No,” Lindsay admitted. “Not really.”
“Figures.” Linda rolled her eyes. “Just remember. Nobody should talk you into doing anything you don’t want to do. Speaking of which, what do you plan to do this afternoon?”
“I don’t really know. I kind of wanted to hang around until we heard from the squad to make sure they made it to Voroshilovgrad okay. But after that I have no idea.”
“Actually,” Linda grinned, “I got a message from the Colonel a few minutes before you got here.”
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Things to do and places to be.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“She says the squad made it to Voloshilovgrad without incident, and wants to know if you prefer heels or pumps?”
“Heels or pumps?” It took Lindsay a second to catch on. “Oh, right. Shoe shopping. Umm, heels I guess. I hope they know my size.”
Linda gave her a level look. When Lindsay didn’t catch on she pointed out “You bunk with 5 women who are the same size and shape. I’m sure they’ll figure it out.”
“Oh, right.” Lindsay’s ears turned slightly pink “I keep forgetting. Guess that’s one advantage of being a clone.”
“Yeah,” agreed Linda “That and you can see what styles don’t work on you. You know,” she mused, tapping her finger on the table thoughtfully “it’s too bad all the clothes we have are Luftwaffe issue. The six of us could have the ultimate mix and match wardrobe. Maybe I’ll get them to see about picking up a few cute skirts as well.”
“And when are we going to wear them?”
“Who cares? That’s the real reason you buy clothes anyway, so that you have them just in case you suddenly have some place to wear them. And so the others can borrow them. Then you get to fight over your favorites.”
“Who would fight over clothes?”
“You would, of course. Didn’t your sister ever steal your favorite skirt?”
“No. I only had brothers, and they wouldn’t be caught dead in a skirt.” That much was true. “Although” Lindsay said, suddenly remembering a fight between two of them “my brother did lose a tooth over an Eminem hoodie.”
“See. My sisters swapped outfits so often they’d sew their names in their favorite’s so there was a chance they’d get them back. It’s too bad we’re stuck here. I would totally blow my pay packet on skirts and blouses. Maybe a nice purse to go with the shoes I’m borrowing.”
“Yeah.” Lindsay said, as the conversation tapered off and the two women fell silent, thinking about the missed opportunity. As much as she hated shopping, Linda’s enthusiasm had actually made Lindsay regret she wasn’t in the city with the rest of the squad.
After a few minutes of silent coffee drinking, Lindsay asked the question that lingered in her mind.

“So what do we do now?”
“I don’t know about you,” Linda answered lazily “But I’m just going to relax and read for a bit. How about you?”
“I don’t know. I’m not a big reader. Maybe I’ll wander over to the hanger and see what’s up.”

There was nothing happening at the hanger. Literally. The only planes there were the two rarely used HE-111 bombers the squad had been issued at the beginning, and Linda’s 109. The two Stukas were undergoing maintenance, so their engines were mostly in bits around the maintenance hanger. Of the maintenance staff there was no sign, probably taking the day off, as supposedly there was no officers around.
Without a plane the chances of flying were off the table, so Lindsay wandered over to the Gasthaus and sat at the bar, helping herself to a beer. After a while the silence of the empty room became annoying, so she plugged a handful of change into the juke box and punched a bunch of buttons at random.
4 hours later Lindsay was staring blurrily at the drawing of the 127th mascot hanging over the bar, slowly coming to the realization that, as a recreational activity, drinking alone sucked. She really missed the company of others. It was not the same without all the rest of them around. Tipping her head back, she drained the last of her latest beer, getting a goodly portion of it in her mouth, and staggered back to the barracks to crawl into bed.

Morning came, and with it the all too familiar pounding head from too much to drink the night before. Staring at the raw pine rafters of the barrack roof Lindsay decided that, while there was probably some obscure definition of enjoyment that could be used to describe how her day off was starting, she’d be better served with the aspirin, shower, and coffee that formed the miraculous instant cure she’d adopted as her normal routine.
It was later, as she was drying her hair, that she remembered the idle promise of taking a run that she’d made herself over lunch the day before. Before her brain could talk her out of it she dug through her locker until she found a pair of pants and a warm looking shirt that were soft and loose enough to suffice as workout gear. Since all she could find for running shoes were a pair of combat boots she laced them up and headed for the maintenance track that circled the base.
45 minutes later she found herself slumped against the generator shed, sweating and gasping for breath. After a few minutes her breath started to sound more like someone just breathing hard and less like someone drowning in mid air.
Still, she felt good about the exercise, and had discovered several undeniable truths about jogging at the 127th. The first was that the pothole filled dirt track around the perimeter of the base may be great for vehicles with four wheel drive, and not so great for navigating on foot.
The taxiways along the runway however, were beautifully smooth and straight. Another important truth was that, even as a digitally simulated person, she was a little out of shape.
The crunch of gravel under boots made her look up.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: They've just landed in Voloshilovgrad.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
The man approaching was also dressed for running; loose fitting slacks and a grey t-shirt. However, he had managed to get his hands on a pair of running shoes instead of being forced to wear boots. “You okay?” he asked, jogging to a stop alongside her.
“Yeah,” she gasped “I’m okay. Just catching my breath.” She became conscious of just how much her chest was still heaving as she gulped air into her lungs, and this was after her breathing had calmed down. Good thing he wasn’t here earlier, she thought. It must have been quite the show.
The new arrival unclipped a canteen from his belt and drank thirstily before offering it to Lindsay. Gratefully, she accepted, passing it back after a few swallows. She hadn’t thought to bring her own, and it really seemed to help.
He poured a bit of water into his hand and splashed his face before screwing the cap back on and fixing the canteen back to his belt.
“I haven’t seen you out here before,” he said.
“Yeah, I sort of just started.”
“Well good for you. I find it’s a great way to get rid of stress and focus. I’ve been doing it for weeks now.”
“It’s not stress I’m worried about,” She replied “I just thought I’d try and get back into shape.”
As soon as she said this the guy cocked his head and quite obviously looked her over. She could almost hear the unspoken ‘If that’s what you look like when you’re not in shape…’ but instead he asked “Do you mind a piece of advise?”
When Lindsay didn’t say no he continued “Boots are all right for everyday combat, but for running you’ll want to get a proper pair of shoes. The Quartermaster might be able to get you a pair, but they don’t keep them as stock and you’ll have to hound him to do it. I finally had to get a friend pick a pair up for me last time he was on liberty.”
Lindsay nodded. “That’s a good idea. I’ll get the Colonel to pick a pair up for me.”
“Oh,” he said, and looked at her oddly. Lindsay wondered why, then realized she wasn’t wearing any rank insignias on her outfit. The poor guy was probably wondering who he was talking to, who had a Colonel to run errands for her.
“Um, yeah,” he stammered “And stay away from the perimeter road, unless you like having a twisted ankle. It’s pretty bad.”
“I’ll keep that in mind.” She said, having already come to that conclusion herself.
She stood up and arched her back, stretching. She could feel his eyes following her every move, so she added a couple of gratuitous twists and side stretches, just to see his reaction.
“What would you recommend as a good route?” she asked.
With some effort he tore his eyes off her and looked her in the face. “Me? I usually just follow the edge of the taxiway. Twice around is about 5k. That’s my usual distance.”
“Sounds too much for me.” She said “Maybe I’ll just do once around. Are you out tomorrow?”
“Oh Yeah.” He said eagerly “Every morning at oh eight hundred, usually. I’m late today.” He added.
“I’m kind of glad for that.” She said with a smile. “Gave us a chance to meet. Maybe if I have someone to jog with I’ll actually stick to it.”
“Oh yeah.” He agreed. “All exercise regimes recommend you have a partner or group to encourage you.”
“I can understand that. What say I meet you here at oh eight hundred tomorrow?”
“Make it quarter after. I usually start my run at the far end. Lieutenant Frank Maddigan, 83rd Kampfgeschwader, by the way.”
“First Lieutenant Lindsay Anderson, 127 Jagdgeschwader. You’re part of the ground pounders that take up all the south part of the compound.”
“That’s us.” Frank said with a grin “And you’re one of the mad cows that fly out of the hangers by runway 10.”
“At your service,” Lindsay said, returning his grin with one of her own. “So, oh eight fifteen it is. See you tomorrow?”
With a little wave of her fingers, Lindsay turned then started an easy jog north towards the barracks of the 127th.
A few meters later she looked back and saw Frank still standing where she’d left him, watching her. As soon as he saw her looking he turned and started jogging the other way. Lindsay grinned. Maybe she was getting more comfortable with her body. She was certainly having fun seeing the various reactions she could get out of men.

Now for Breakfast

Later, in the Shower.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: It's someone from the 83rd

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
After a second shower, she was in the mess with Linda, enjoying another scrumptious German breakfast.
“I noticed you were gone fairly early this morning.” Linda said, taking a bite of the massive strudel that dominated her plate.
“Yeah, I woke up early so I went for a run.”
“You should have said something. I might have joined you.”
“It was an impulse thing. I’m going out again tomorrow if you want to come along.”
“Twice in a row. Should I be impressed?”
“Actually, I’m meeting up with a guy from the 83rd at Oh eight hundred.”
“Oh, another date. I hope this one turns out better than your last.”
Lindsay paused, fork half way to her mouth “Last what?” she asked.
“Your date with Eugene yesterday.”
Was it just yesterday? So much had happened. But what had happened, or didn’t happen as it turned out, wasn’t what she considered to be a date, and she said so.
“That wasn’t a date.”
“Just because you didn’t go doesn’t make it not count.”
“For the last time that wasn’t a date, and this isn’t either.”
“Girl, you’re meeting a man at a specific time to do something. That’s pretty much the definition of a date to me.”
“We’re going jogging. It’s not a date.”
“You know,” Linda continued “Lorraine has only been gone a day and you’re already turning into the camp party girl.”
“What,” Lindsay protested “Because I met someone while jogging?”
“It’s like I can’t turn my back and you’re meeting men everywhere you turn.
So far there’s been a Major and a Captain and a couple of lieutenants. Heck, there’s even that dick of a Corporal. I mean, and who have I met?”
Lindsay suddenly noticed the undertone to Linda’s words that she hadn’t been aware of until now. Beneath the teasing was more than a slight touch of jealousy.
“Linda?” she asked carefully “You’re not jealous, are you?”
“What? No. Why would you think I was jealous?”
“It’s just that you sound jealous.”
“Well I’m not.” Linda said defensively, savagely spearing a sausage.
“I think you are.” Lindsay said, thoughtfully. After a couple of silent moments she added. “Tell you what. I’ll skip tomorrow.”
“What?” Linda said, looking up from her plate. “No, that’s not right.” She put her fork down and sat back, sighing. “Listen, I’m only teasing about the date thing. Don’t skip it because of me.”
Lindsay looked at her, watching her reaction “But you’re obviously upset about it.”
“I’m not.” Linda said, an obvious lie. After a moment she seemed to realize this. “Well, okay. Maybe I am, just a bit. You’re right and I am a little jealous.” She grudgingly admitted.
“Why?” Lindsay wanted to know “Believe me, I never asked for any of this.”
“And that makes it worse.” Linda said with a grimace
“Worse? How could that be worse?
“Look,” Linda said thoughtfully. “I think what bothers me about it is just, well, we’re identical. Like twins. Yet the men are drooling all over you and ignoring me. And that, well, that bothers me because it brings up all sorts of issues.”
Lindsay wasn’t sure what to say, so she just waited.
Sure enough, after a moment Linda continued. “Look, growing up I was never that popular. As a result I’ve always been a jealous of people who make friends easily. Like the other girls I grew up with. For the longest time I told myself it was because they were prettier than I was. Or funnier. When I got married all of a sudden I didn’t have to worry about it so much. Then the divorce happened and suddenly I was alone and struggling to meet people all over again. And here you are meeting people and not even trying.”
“Linda,” Lindsay protested, “Eugene and Eric were talking to you just as much as they talked to me. As for that little Corporal you should be glad he ignored you. And you can’t count Lieutenant Mackentyre. That was a direct result of the little sleezeball’s actions.”
“But you still met him, which is the point.”
“Well, if you want to look at points, you’ve met Eugene and Eric, which gives you two points.” Lindsay said, holding up her hand and ticking the points off on her fingers. “I’ve also met them, plus Darryl and Frank, which gives me four points, and that Corporal, which probably counts as a negative five, which puts you way ahead of me.”
“That’s ridiculous. It’s not like it’s a contest.”
“And that is my point.” Lindsay said, pointing the finger she was using to tick the points off at Linda to emphasize what she was saying. “You’re looking at a sample of five people over two days and deciding I’m more popular than you, which is utter nonsense.”
Linda looked like she was considering what Lindsay was saying for the first time, which she probably was.
“I am being silly about it, aren’t I.” she concluded at last “I suppose you can go jogging any time you want.”
“Gee, thanks mom” Lindsay said, slightly sarcastically.
“It such a silly thing, really.”
“Personal issues are never silly. Just remember I’m here if you need to talk.”
“Thanks,” Linda said with a small smile “I appreciate that.”
“And you should come jogging too.” Lindsay said, pressing her advantage “I’ll introduce you to Frank.”
“Won’t that put me even further ahead of you on points?”
“Like you said, it’s not a contest. And he probably has all sorts of buddies at the 83rd he can introduce us to.”
Linda gave her that level stare that really needed a pair of librarian glasses to pull off correctly. Eventually, Lindsay said “What?”
Linda made a wry face “For a moment I thought Lorraine was back.”
“Seriously?”
“Yeah, then I remembered she probably already knows all the guys over there. You want more coffee?”
“Sure”
“Oh Good” Linda said, as she started gathering up the dirty dishes on the table. “While you’re up would you mind filling mine as well? Two cream one sugar.”
Lindsay got up to get herself more coffee. As she walked up to the massive silver urns at the front of the mess tent she spotted the book Linda had been reading still on the table they’d sat at the day before. She picked it up on the way back to the table and idly glanced over the cover while she waited for Linda to get back from clearing the dishes.
‘Belinda Blinked, by Rocky Flintstone.’
Thinking it was some trashy romance novel, and with nothing better to do, she nonchalantly flipped it open, stopping as her eye caught a descriptive sentence.
‘The Duchess stood up and stretched her cramped body.’ The sentence read. ‘Her nipples hardened with her feeling and they were now as large as the three-inch rivets which held the hull of the fateful Titanic together’.
“Da-Fug did I just read?” Lindsay said, not realizing she’d spoke out loud.
“That was my reaction too.” Linda said from behind her.
Lindsay dropped the book like a hot potato and spun around.
“You can read it if you want,” Linda continued as she collected her coffee cup and sat down, seemingly not the least bit perturbed that Lindsay had been reading her book. “But I wouldn’t bother. It is a truly awful piece of tripe that barely deserves the generous one star rating the reviews have given it. I honestly only picked it up because of the podcast.”
“Umm, no thanks” Lindsay decided. “I think I’ll pass.”
“Smart girl. My estimation of your intelligence just keeps going up and up.”
“Speaking of smart, I should get the Colonel to pick up us some running shoes.”
“It would be better if I ask Lana-Raye to do it. Leslie might be offended if a mere First Lieutenant started asking her to run errands.”
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: And now, Breakfast!

choices: Back to the barracks to change.
What the heck, go with it.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Oh eight fifteen found Lindsay and Linda warming up on the taxiway beside the generator shed. Once again the sound of gravel caught Lindsay’s attention. This time however, it was the sound of many pairs of feet crunching their way up the gravel taxiway. Seven pairs, in fact. She looked up to see that Frank was accompanied by six other men, all dressed for jogging.
“Well,” Linda said as she watched them approach. “When you said you were meeting someone you never mentioned it was the whole squad!”
“I didn’t know!” Lindsay said honestly. Frank hadn’t mentioned that he was bringing company, let alone what looked to be half a side for football.
“I think someone has finally one-upped Lorraine.”
“No, really!” Lindsay protested. “I thought it would just be Frank.”
“Good thing I came out today or you’d be way ahead of me on points.” Linda said with a grin.
“Hey there!” Frank greeted them as the group came up. “I hope you don’t mind.” He said addressing Linda with an apologetic tone. “I sort of mentioned that you were joining me today and suddenly everyone wanted to come.”
“Oh, I don’t mind.” Linda said with a mischievous grin and deliberately not correcting him. “The more the merrier.” She looked over the group “Do all you guys fly with the 83rd?” she asked, in spite of the obvious.
“Sure do ma’am”, said one barrel chested man with a handlebar moustache. “Captain Rhett Jackson, at your service.”
“Captain Robert Stone.” said the man next to him. Of the group it was clear he would be most to benefit from regular exercise, given his shorter and more portly frame.
“Captain Andrew Kelly” was next, followed by an unremarkable Lieutenant Fred Murphy and a very Brazilian looking Captain Anthony Jervis.
Last to introduce himself was the big black guy who was hanging around the back of the group. “First Lieutenant Arichikuruku Yakamura” he said, bowing slightly as he did.
Linda couldn’t help but raise her eyebrows at this. The group burst into snickers, and the big guy grinned. ‘I lost a bet.” He said. “Everyone calls me Archie.”
“Pleased to meet you Archie. I’m Captain Linda Bray-Lewis, and my running partner and the one who talked me into doing this over there is First Lieutenant Lindsay Anderson” Linda said, waving her hand in Lindsay’s direction.
“Oh” Frank said, noticing for the first time the rank insignia on the girls shirt sleeves and realizing his mistake.
He started to apologize, but Lindsay waved him off, enjoying Linda’s little joke. The look on his face just now had been worth it.
“Lindsay and Linda?” asked a slightly confused looking Anthony. “I thought one of you was named Lorraine”
Linda laughed “She’d be our evil twin.” She said, “except there’s more than two of us. And it’s Lindsay’s turn to be the evil one.”
Anthony didn’t look a whole lot less confused by Linda’s explanation, so she elaborated.
“Look, there wasn’t a whole lot of choices for avatars when we joined up. If it helps, think of us as Sextuplets.”
“Doesn’t sextuplets mean six” Lindsay asked “There’s seven of us.”
“Oh God,” groaned Frank. “I hope you at least wear nametags.”
“Nope!” grinned Linda. “We like to keep people guessing. Shall we go?”
With that the group set off at an easy pace, Frank in the lead. After about a kilometer Lindsay noticed something peculiar. The group stayed together, letting the girls set the pace. Two men would always be in the lead, with Lindsay and Linda following, the rest close behind. Occasionally one of the men would drop back and another would move forward to take his place. They were halfway around the taxiway when Lindsay developed a sneaking suspicion they were doing it on purpose. Frank leading and the rest taking turns dropping behind, probably staring at their butts. Try as she might though, she couldn’t catch anyone being obvious about it, although she did catch a few guilty looking grins when she glanced back. After a while, she decided it didn’t really bother her that much anyway. There was that growing part of her that found the attention flattering, and she decided to let them have their fun. At least they were being discrete about it.
The group continued in this fashion until they had made a full circuit. Stopping when they returned to the generator shed a water break and brief rest. They were all gasping for breath at this point, all except for Frank, who was just breathing slightly hard.
All was good until Lindsay tried to pour a small amount of water on her forehead to cool off and misjudged how quickly water would gush out of the canteen.
The result was a disaster. Or not, depending on your point of view. Her shirt was immediately soaked, and the chill mid morning air, which was fine when they were running, immediately played havoc with her nipples. Brief thoughts about the hull of the Titanic flashed though her mind for some reason as she stood there gasping.
There was nothing discreet about the attention she was suddenly getting. The air was filled with wolf whistles and appreciative comments.
Frank and Rhett, quick on the uptake and obviously both raised as gentlemen, stepped forward and offered their shirts when they saw the problem. As Lindsay quickly covered herself she glared around the group, now seeing eyes pointedly look in directions other than hers, for which she was grateful, although she was sure she saw several of them sneak a few lingering glances when they thought she wasn’t looking.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: The next morning

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Frank’s shirt was quite a bit larger that the one she had been wearing, and a bit more smelly. It wasn’t a bad smell, just honest sweat with a touch of shaving crème. And maybe a hint of musk. Since they were done the run anyhow, or at least the portion the girls were up for, Lindsay headed to the barracks to change, promising to return the shirt that afternoon in spite of Franks protests that he had several and she could keep it if she wanted.

“Well, that was clever” Linda said as they headed back to the barracks
“What was?” Lindsay asked, practically swimming inside her borrowed shirt. It was not a whole lot warmer.
“Drenching your shirt like that. Talk about attention getting.”
“It was an accident.”
“Sure it was. I think Lorraine has finally got some competition.”
“Oh please.” Lindsay rolled her eyes.
“Nice move on Frank’s part, though.” Linda continued, declining to notice Lindsay’s expression.
“Yeah, it was nice of him to lend me his shirt.”
“I think it was more of ‘You showed me yours, so I’ll show you mine.”
“Now who’s trying to one up Lorraine?”
That got a laugh and another eye roll, because they both knew they were just kidding around. Innuendo seemed to be an occupational hazard of rooming with Colleen.
“Seriously though,” Lindsay said “Did you notice the boys were watching us the whole time?”
“I noticed they were watching you. Especially towards the end there.”
“The shirt thing really was an accident.”
“I mean before, while you were running. That extra little wiggle you put into your step.”
“I did no such thing.”
“Girl, I was watching you. Trust me, you did.”
Lindsay was silent for a moment “Did I really?”
“Uh huh! If I didn’t know better I’d say you were enjoying the attention.”
“Well, maybe a little.” Lindsay admitted. Knowing the boys were watching had made her feel special.
“Nothing wrong with that. People like others to pay attention to them. Just try not to go overboard.”
“Overboard?”
“Like the shirt.”
“But that was an accident.”
“Of course it was.”
“But it was!”

A couple of hours later Lindsay pulled the jeep to a stop in front of the 83rd mess hall, figuring that there should be someone there who could let her know where Frank was. To their surprise, the mess tent was being used as a mission briefing room by the base commander, who looked a little less than pleased at the interruption when they walked in.
“Umm, Hi.” was all Lindsay could think to say as the Colonel’s glare turned to the two intruders standing in the doorway. Anything else she could have said would have been drowned out by the sudden burst of whistles and cat calls as the crowd of airmen noticed who was in the doorway.
The Colonel cleared his throat and the room fell silent again.
“Sorry.” Lindsay stammered and the catcalls died down. “I was, ummm, just wanting to return Frank’s shirt. I didn’t mean to interrupt”
This got a synchronized ‘Oooh’ from the assembled crowd. The Colonel himself didn’t say anything, although his arched eyebrows indicated what he was thinking as he swiveled his glare towards Frank, seated the middle of the group of airmen.
Surprisingly, Frank seemed indifferent to the Colonels look, waving nonchalantly in their direction.
“Sorry Colonel,” Frank said. “Linda there is with the 127th. The Lieutenant had a wardrobe malfunction earlier today during morning exercises so I loaned her a shirt. I told her not to bother, but it looks like she insists on returning it”
The Colonel looked back at Lindsay. “I thought her name was Lorraine?”
“Lorraine’s the girl that comes over to play pool. Linda there joined us for the morning jog.”
“Actually, I’m Lindsay. That’s Linda.”
“Well” the Colonel harrumphed “Returning borrowed property is all well and good, and I’m glad you managed to convince these slug-abouts to get out of bed early for a change, but we’re smack daub in the middle of a strategy meeting right now, and that doesn’t involve input from the fighter escort of the 127th, so unless you’ve had experience as a bombardier I’m afraid we’re kind of busy at the moment.”
The comment was an obvious dismissal as the Colonel turned back to his flip chart.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Back to the barracks to change.

The pilots talk about their next poker game.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“Oh, Lindsay has experience” Linda volunteered before Lindsay had a chance to say anything. “She’s actually pretty good.”
That was true. During that first week of combat the Colonel had insisted that they try crewing the HE-111’s the squadron had been assigned, on the premise that they had two of them so they might as well see what they were like. Although no one had crashed, none of them had showed any proficiency behind the controls, and they had overwhelmingly decided that, given a choice, they would prefer a machine where you were the pilot, gunner, and bomber (when equipped) combined, instead of being assigned one position through the entire mission.
Although she didn’t like to brag about it, Lindsay seemed to have a gift for thinking in three dimensions, and this innate ability had carried over when she was operating the bombsight, allowing her to score more targets than all the rest combined. Trust Linda to bring it up.
“Is that true?” The Colonel asked.
“I don’t know about the pretty good part,” Lindsay stammered “I mean, I only hit five out of six targets.”
“Five out of six you say?” The Colonel thought about that for a moment.”And what about your partner there?”
“Oh” Linda said “I’m nowhere near as good. I only hit two, although I almost got a third.”
“So two out of six?”
The Colonel looked speculatively at the two women standing in the doorway.
His face a little less sour all of a sudden. More speculative.
“That’s as good as our boys here are doing. What would your commander say if I was to borrow you for a couple of missions?”
“I don’t know” Linda admitted “She’s in Voroshilovgrad at the moment.”
“Too bad.” The Colonel said, his face turning sour again. “Our problem is I have too many targets and not enough that can hit them. I could have really used a couple more Bombardiers on this mission, but with Colonel Helgamiere in Voroshilovgrad by the time I she gives me permission to requisition you it will be too late.”
“What if we volunteer?” Linda asked
“What?” Lindsay said
“Look, we’re both bored out of our skulls. It’s either this or we go back to playing poker and I’m frankly getting sick of cards.”
“What are you talking about? We don’t play poker!”
“Volunteer?” The Colonel asked, focusing on what, to him, was important. “Yes, I suppose I could make that would work.” He fussed his way though the implications. “You’d need your CO’s permission for that, but I could assume you have that already. Of course, you’d be listed on the flight manifest as an observer, since you’re not officially part of the squadron.” His face broke out into, what for him, passed as a grin. “Yes, we could make that work. If you’d be willing to go.”
“Sure” said Linda. “We’re officially on leave anyway, even though we’re stuck on base. Might as well be doing something for fun.”
“Right then” said the Colonel, rubbing his hands. “Jervis, you’re back at the helm of your bomber, that young lady there just volunteered to be your bombardier. Jackson, the other young lady there is yours. That puts us back up to 12 aircraft for this raid. Pilots, fill your bombardiers in on the targets and get ready for takeoff at thirteen hundred.”

And that is how the two pilots from the 127th wound up flying as crew on a bombing raid with the 83rd.
The Colonel in charge of the 83rd was happy enough, it gave him two more bomber crews.
Rhett and Tony were also happy, they were flying instead of targeting, something none of the pilots really liked, but tolerated because the alternative was to use an AI, and with only a 12 percent success rate that alternative sucked. With the girls manning the sights this time they had a much better chance at success. Of course, it didn’t hurt matters that, under all that bulky flight gear, the two were gorgeous.
The bombardier in a Henkle 111 didn’t have a seat so much as a bench that he could kneel on as gunner, or lay flat on as bombardier. Lindsay settled in as gunner as the flight bounced it’s way across the runway and up into the sky. Once airborne she re-checked the 20mm MG that would serve as her weapon. Normally it would protrude through an opening in the bubble nose of the craft, although in a pinch it could be picked up and pointed through any available opening, something she had seen done in training films. Satisfied that it was fully operational she settled in and watched the scenery scroll past underneath them. The glass nose of the Henkle was often described as ‘like flying a green house, offering an unobstructed view in all directions forward for both the pilot and nose gunner, something Lindsay rarely got to experience flying her 109, what with the big engine in front of her. Plus today she had the rare luxury of being a passenger while someone else was doing all the dirty work of flying. For several minutes she just luxuriated in the passing scenery until radio traffic broke through on the headphones.
“Keep an eye out” the voice of the lead pilot crackled “We should be seeing our escort out there pretty quick.”
Lindsay turned her attention to the sky around them, forgoing the beauty of the scenery below to search the delightfully clear blue skies around her. Soon enough, a flight of BF109s merged with their group.
With a mild shock, Lindsay saw the markings of their escort. It was the 104th
For the most part, the greeting between the two squads was routine. Identification, confirmation of target and flight orders, etc. Then the conversation got more casual. And a little more personal.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Actually, we can help.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
It started with one of the pilots saying “Hey, you guys fly out of the same field the 127th does, right?”
“Yeah, that’s correct.” replied the flight leader. “They’ve got the north end of the compound. Why do you ask?”
“We had a couple of their pilots at the base yesterday. A couple of real good lookers.”
“Sounds like the 127th alright.”
“Thought maybe you’d know them.”
“Couple of women doesn’t narrow it down too much. The 127th is all women, didn’t you know? ”
“You’d know these two if you saw them. Twins, about five foot six, blue eyes, long blond hair, Built like Victoria Secret models. Sound familiar?”
“You’ll need to get more specific. That describes about 90 percent of the 127th.”
“Seriously? A squadron of twin lingerie models?”
Several other voices broke into the conversation “Man you guys got it lucky.”
“How do I get transferred to your squadron?”
“Do they really all look like that?”
“I have it on good authority they do. I’ve only met a couple of them personally.”
Lindsay looked back at Rhett. He had his goggles pushed up onto his helmet and she could see he was grinning, hugely amused by the conversation. Probably getting a kick knowing that one of the topic of conversation was kneeling on the gunners bench in front of him being described as a Victoria secret model. With her flight suit on that comparison required a highly imaginative imagination.
“Seriously?” the pilot from the 104th was saying. “I’d have thought you guys would be all over them.”
“Their CO has banned us from their part of the base.” Was the matter of fact reply.
“Banned?” That voice sounded astonished. “What did you guys do?”
“Nothing. She just likes their privacy.”
All true, when you thought about it. Although it was also partly the attitude the flyboys were demonstrating.
“There’s one that visits us fairly regular, but other than that I’ve only met a couple others.” Lindsay thought maybe this was Frank that was talking, although she couldn’t say for sure. The distortion of the radio made identification of the voices difficult.
“Too bad. If the rest look anything like the two that visited us, Friday night parties would be something else.”
“Man, you got that right,” a voice that no amount of static distortion could disguise said. A voice Lindsay had hoped to never hear again. “Those two were some delicious looking pieces of ass.”
“Thank you for sharing that observation Gary.” This voice too was familiar, although Lindsay currently wasn’t in the right frame of mind to identify it. “There’s more to a woman than what their ass looks like, you know.”
“You got that right,” the voice of Gary continued “Those tits of theirs were something else, too. Mighty firm and fine. Sure felt nice in my hands. Did I tell you I got to hold them?”
Lindsay’s eyes got hard as she glared out the bubble in the front of the plane. In spite of what she had told Linda yesterday, about not forgiving and just forgetting, she found her finger poised over the trigger. If she could only pick out the little runt’s plane.
“Get real! You never touched them” someone else was saying.
“Sure I did” bragged Gary “The little one was all upset over her plane being wrecked, so being the soul of understanding that I am, I had to comfort her. One thing leads to another, if you know what I mean. You’d be amazed what they feel like pressed against you. Mighty fine, indeed.”
“Give it up” someone else radioed “It never happened.”
But Gary must have felt he was on a roll, because he kept going “I tell you, she was the nicest piece I’ve had in a long time. Natural blond too. I tell you, that chick was a wild one too, once she got her freak on. The things she did with her mouth. Man, if I’d known being upset turned her crank like that I’d have wrecked her plane myself.”

That did it. Lindsay flipped the safety off the 20mm and began looking over their escort, searching for a plane with JG104-52 on it.

Before she even started looking there was a sudden yelling over the radio.
“Hey” Gary was shouting “Watch what you’re doing. You almost hit me.”
“Ooops, sorry about that”
“What the hell happened there Mackentyre” came a new voice, one Lindsay hadn’t heard yet.
“Sorry Colonel,” Darryl radioed back “He got me distracted while I was checking my guns. I accidentally hit the trigger with the safety off.”
“Colonel!” The little Corporal protested “He tried to shoot me!”
“Did you try to shoot him, Mackentyre?”
“With all respect, sir, if I really tried to shoot him do you think he’d still be here.”
“Good point. Be more careful how you check your guns next time Mackentyre.”
“But Colonel,” the corporal whined “You’re not going to let him get away with that, are you?”
“O’Brian, shut up. If he says it was an accident, it was an accident.”
“But Sir. That’s the second time he’s had an accident and almost hit me!”
“Save it O’Brian. I don’t want to hear another word. But I’ll tell you one last thing. I know the CO of the 127th. If you touched one of her pilots in way she would consider inappropriate, she’ll make you think getting shot down was the best thing to happen to you.”
“As for the rest of you, talk about women all you want when we’re back on the ground, for now shut up and concentrate on doing your job.”
With these words the two groups settled down to business, the only radio chatter being status and position updates.

Until the flak started, and the Russians came up to play.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: The pilots talk about the 127th.
