I think the Russians are mad about this.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“5 Minutes to target” Came the flight leader’s voice over the radio. “All bombardiers to your stations.”
Lindsay had already been hunched over her station for several minutes, checking and rechecking the settings. Current altitude. Heading. Wind direction both aloft and on the ground. Making small adjustments as she noted discrepancies between the posted reports she was reading and what she could see through the bombsite.
When the call to man stations came in she glanced back at Rhett, who nodded. The work of controlling the bomber was now divided between them. For the next five minutes Rhett’s job was to keep the bomber as straight and level as possible. Lindsay would make the small corrections to their heading that would put them over target. Once the target had been reached and the bombs released Rhett would then once again be in charge of the whole aircraft.
A successful bombing run, when you thought about it, it was simply a matter of mathematics. A bomber moved forward at a velocity of X, along an altitude of Y. Bombs fell at a constantly accelerating rate until they hit maximum speed, or terminal velocity. Therefore, if you knew how high you were, you could figure out Z, how long it took for a bomb to reach the ground when you dropped it. Factor in your speed and you knew how far back you had to be when you dropped it so it reached the ground when you wanted it to. It was all very simple and straight forward, and in no way involved quadratic equations.
The Russians, of course, had their own math to work out as well. They had a target moving at a velocity of X, along an altitude of Y. Flak guns shot shells with timed fuses with a delay of Z and were station along the path of X. Factor in the enemy’s speed, position, and heading, and you knew where to point your gun and when to fire. It was all very simple and straight forward, and suddenly math became far more exciting and deadlier than the man with the tweed jacket standing in front of your middle school chalkboard had ever made it out to be.
Currently both sides were doing their best to make sure the other couldn’t solve for X.

Lindsay watched the ground waiting, for the target to swim into the eyepiece through the sudden clouds of smoke that kept appearing. Anti Aircraft fire from the guns protecting the factories below. A swarm of YAKs and IL2s boiled up from airstrips dotted here and there, driving upward to break though the fighter escort that was protecting the bombers. The fighters diving down to meet them midway, doing their best to keep them there. And through it all, the Bomber droned on. Straight and level. Lindsay making small corrections as the cross hairs inched slowly toward their destination. Lindsay was zoned. She had no control over what the enemy fighters were doing, so she trusted the escort to do their job. She had no control over the Flak, so she trusted that to chance. She had no real control over what the bomber was doing, so she trusted in Rhett and his skill. Around her she could hear the sounds of combat. The radio squawking with status updates. Reports of being hit, requests for help, expletives of pilots desperate for help, or now beyond help. And occasional cheers of victory. Defensive machine gun fire rattled the floor, and occasionally the airframe around her shuddered. All of this she felt as mere background noise. Her world was the sighting scope. That she could control. And when at last the target was firmly centered in the cross hairs and she pushed the button, the airframe bucked and shuddered as the load released, completing that part of the job they trusted her to do.
Widening the field of view, she racked the scope back, keeping it centered on the target, waiting the long seconds until grey plumes of bombs detonating precisely where she had aimed them appeared. Grey plumes that hung briefly in the warm afternoon air, to be quickly obscured by smoke and flames and further explosions as the target munitions factory obliterated itself. Only then did she give the pilot a ‘thumbs up’, before leaning back and allowing herself to feel a sense of satisfaction.
A sense of satisfaction and well being lasted for almost 5 minutes. Long enough for the flight to form up for the trip home.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Over the Target.

choices: Skip forward to where they're all getting drunk after the mission.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
She was leaning back, stretching her cramped muscles as the flight reformed around them. Rhett was grinning like a little boy at Christmas. She went to look out the window and was shocked to discover several panes in the glass nose were missing. When had that happened?

The radio chatter was mostly group updates. They hadn’t come out of the raid unscathed. Two bombers were missing and five fighters were unaccounted for, but on the whole the raid was a success.
“Echo Two,” came the voice Lindsay thought likely belonged to Colonel Seiler, commander of the 104th “This is Eagle Leader. That was one nice pattern you laid there.”
Rhett pushed the button on his throat mic. “Well, I didn’t feel like making another run through that mess, so I thought I’d make the first one count.”

“Well, I think that one counted for sure, Echo Two. Might as well pack up and go home boys, I don’t think there’s two bricks left stuck together down there. Good job Echo Two.”
Rhett keyed the mic again. “Thanks Eagle One. But I’m just flying this thing. All the credit goes to my bombardier.”
“That it does Echo Two. Tell Yancy it’s good to see him back on his game.”
“I would if he was here, Eagle Leader. He’s still MIA. We picked up a couple of subs for today. From the 127th.”
“127th? You mean the Mad Cows? Helgamiere’s squad? The fighter pilots?”
“Yes Sir. We had First Lieutenant Anderson on lead dropping the eggs today.”
“Anderson you say? There was a Lieutenant Anderson who dead sticked a plane into my runway yesterday. Same one?”
“I wouldn’t know about that. Tell you what, why don’t you ask her yourself.”
Motioning Lindsay closer, Rhett pulled his headset cord out of the radio and replaced it with hers.
“Umm. Hiya Colonel, Sir” Lindsay said. “Yeah, that was my plane.”
“You left a hell of a mess by my runway, kid.”
“Sorry sir. I didn’t mean to. I was kind of shot up and didn’t have much choice.”
“I could see that. I’m still thinking of sending you a bill for the clean up.”
“But, I already got one from the Corporal.” Lindsay protested.
“What? Oh hell, I was just kidding about that. O’Brian, did you give the young lady a bill?”
There was no answer.
“O’Brian?”
“I don’t think he’s here sir.” Some one responded.
“Yeah, he got himself shot down again.” Someone else added.
“Let me guess. Another Accident?”
“No Sir”
“It was Flak sir,” Someone else chimed in. “I can testify to that. Happened right in front of me. A direct hit. Completely obliterated him. Nothing left but a couple of wing tips fluttering to the ground.”
“So Flak got O’Brian today then. Well then, I guess that means no points to any of you.”
There was a pregnant pause before someone answered.
“Uh, points, sir?”
You know what I’m talking about. Negative points for accidentally shooting down a friendly.
“Oh. Ah, right. Yeah, no points against any of us.”
“After all,” the Colonel continued. “It’s not like someone was keeping a spread sheet of how many times O’Brian kept getting in the way of the guns from his own unit.”
“Uh, right sir. No spread sheet.”
“And of course they’re also not posting it on the bulletin board, and maybe assigning point values, just so you could see who’s got the worst luck with him getting in the way and all.”
“Of course not, sir.”
“Too bad. I’m thinking that would be a good idea. Mackentyre, make it happen.”
“Sure thing Sir. Sounds like a good idea.”
“Of course it is Mackentyre. It’s mine. See to it as soon as we get back to base. I want a report within an hour of touchdown.”
“Yes sir.”
“And just so we all understand each other. What I said still holds. If I catch any of you intentionally shooting that man down, I’ll bust a rank and ground you for a week.
And I look very much forward to reading the latest version of that spread sheet you haven’t been making when you post it.”
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Nothing to see here, time to head home.

I think that's enough for now.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“So,” Lindsay was saying to the crowd of men around the table she was at. They were buying and she was telling the crash landing story for about the fifth time. “Here I am with a plane all shot to shit.” Normally she wouldn’t talk like that, but she had about 5 beer in her and it wasn’t even suppertime yet. “There was no way I’d make it back to the 127th, I needed to put down not now but right now. Closest field was the 104th, so I headed there. And wouldn’t you know it, as I lined up the approach the engine quit. But I managed to stretch the glide to hit the runway. It wasn’t a crash, it was a landing. Scraped the prop, sure, but I stopped sitting on the gear.”
“Oh Yeah,” said Linda, currently the only other female in the room. “Don’t forget the oil on the window. She left out her windscreen was blacked out with oil, so she was doing this all blind.”
“I’ve landed on instruments” one of the pilots in the group said. “It’s tricky, but not big deal”
Lindsay leaned forward, beer can in hand as she pointed her finger at the pilot. “No instruments. Half the bloody panel was blown to shit. Anything that was working was giving me shit for information. The only thing I could rely on was the compass. Punched the side windows out so I could see my wingtips and keep level.”
“Right.” Mr. Instrument Pilot said. “So you expect us to believe you lined up and landed on a runway you couldn’t see.”
“Mike,” said one of the other men, “Just shut up and let the pretty lady finish her story.”
“Thank the other pretty lady for that” Lindsay waved to Linda “She got me lined up and talked me down. Couldn't have done it without her. Any way, all that work to get my plane down in one piece, and then that little shit of a corporal drives over it with a tractor! I tell you, I was so mad. I wanted to kill the little shit.”
“That’s not the way he was telling it during mission earlier.” Someone unwisely said.
“Everything that man said was an outright lie!” Lindsay said hotly, getting unsteadily to her feet. “First he trashed my plane, then kicked me off base and tried to make me to walk home.” She slapped her hand on the table, tears forming in the corner of her eyes. “All just because I wouldn’t have dinner with him.”
“Oh yeah,” someone said “That sounds like O’Brian over at the 104th.”
“You should have shot him down during the mission today.” another voice said.
“Yeah" someone else said. “Make it look like an accident.”
“Accidents happen in the heat of battle,” someone else added “I hear he’s exceptionally accident prone.”
“Oh, I was thinking about it” Lindsay admitted, Blinking away the tears. She swayed and flopped back down in her chair “He’s just lucky I couldn’t pick him out in the crowd.”
She tipped her beer back only to discover it was empty. When had that happened? She waved the empty can over her head “Another beer here?”

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“I don’t think so, “Linda said, even as several men started to get up. “I think you’ve had enough for now.”
“Nonsense!” Lindsay slurred “I’m just starting to have fun.”
“It’s four in the afternoon and you’re half smashed. I think we should take a break.”
“But I’m still conscious. And I haven’t told them about the Church of Lindsay yet.”
“I think that’s best left for another day. Come on you. Time to get home. You can come back for more fun tomorrow.”
“But I’m having fun now!” Lindsay whined, yet still allowing Linda to lead her out to their jeep. There was a general muttering and a few complaints from the crowd. It was obvious the men didn’t want them to leave, but nobody stopped them.
On the way back Lindsay kept complaining about having to leave. Finally, Linda pulled the jeep up in front of the barracks and shut the motor off. Instead of getting out, though, she turned and asked “Lindsay, how many men were in that room?”
“I don’t know” Lindsay said thinking fuzzily “I’d say, twenty, maybe twenty five?”
“There were twenty two. And just the two of us women.”
“So,” Lindsay said, “We were just drinking and telling stories. Nothing else.”
Linda reached over and took a hold of her chin, pulling her face around until Lindsay was looking directly at her. “Just drinking and telling stories now. What about in a couple of hours when you’re really smashed? What if they decide they want a little different type of entertainment? Then what?”
Lindsay stared at Linda trying to figure out what she was talking about. Slowly the thought of what could happen penetrated the fuzzy wool around her brain. “They wouldn’t.” she said, aghast.
“You think not?” Linda said, releasing her hold on Lindsay’s chin. “Maybe not all of them, but enough of them would.” She held Lindsay in place with the shear force of her gaze “And if they decided they would, what then? What kind of chance do you think you’d stand?”
“But. But.” Lindsay stuttered in protest “Lorraine does this all the time.”
“Lorraine knows what she’s doing.” Linda said with a hard edge in her voice “She’s been doing it for years. And she doesn’t start off by getting half wasted. You, on the other hand, haven’t a clue what you’re getting into.”
“I can take care of myself.” Lindsay said, belligerently refusing to admit the obvious.
“Right. Girls who say that usually wind up as mothers. Or worse.”
“No way. That wouldn’t happen to me.”
“You just keep telling yourself that. Let me know how it works out for you.” Linda was quiet for a moment. Then she said “I’m going inside and read a bit before dinner. You decide what you want to do.”
With that she got out of the jeep, leaving Lindsay to sit there alone, thinking. Linda was probably right. But part of her really wanted to head back and continue the party. Surely there was a way to pull it off so that she wouldn’t have to worry about things getting ugly.
How would Lorraine pull it off?
Be Sensible about it

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Sighing, Lindsay got unsteadily out of the Jeep and went inside to change. The flight suit she was wearing smelled of sweat and grease with a touch of bar smoke, and was a bit sticky in spots. Holding onto her locker for support she eventually stripped the suit off and tossed it into the corner. Maybe a shower too, she thought. Get cleaned up a bit before she went back. She had just intended to sit on the edge of her cot for a minute while she decided what to wear, but it felt so comfortable she lay back. Just rest for a minute, she thought, while part of her brain tried to figure out a way she could get back to the party.
Another part of her brain, thinking surprisingly sober thoughts given her current condition, realized the truth of what Linda was saying. Being a woman and getting drunk with a crowd of strange men was just asking for trouble.
Moments later it seemed, the barracks door opened and Linda poked her head in.
“Mess hall is closing in an hour.” She said “Better get over there now if you want something to eat.”
Lindsay looked at her watch, wondering what happened to the last four hours. She must have dozed off for a bit. Grabbing her duty uniform she quickly dressed and headed over to the mess hall.
“Decided to join me, did you?” Linda asked, not even looking up.
“Yeah,” Lindsay replied. “Guess I was sort of hungry.”
Linda had obviously finished eating not too long before, judging by the dirty tray and utensils on the table. Now, she was sitting at the table reading what appeared to be, at least from the cover design, yet another Romance Novel, something called ‘My Immortal’. Whatever it was about had Linda’s complete attention, for which Lindsay was grateful. She didn’t really feel like talking just yet. As Linda sat reading Lindsay set to devouring the evening meal, Jaeger Schnitzel and Szegediner Gulasch. The breaded veal and mashed potatoes were done to the perfection she’d come to expect from the unit’s kitchen. As was the stew.
She was just about done when Linda suddenly looked up and asked “Planning on heading back to the 83rd tonight?”
“I was thinking about it earlier,” Lindsay admitted, tearing a chunk of bread off a loaf and dipping it into the spicy stew that had accompanied the veal. “Now I’m not so sure. You’re probably right about being drunk with a crowd of drunken flyboys.”
“Probably right?” Linda managed the trick of raising one eyebrow as she looked across the table.
“Okay,” Lindsay admitted “Definitely right.” She sighed, knowing that Linda was due an apology, but not relishing it. Still, it was better said than not.
“I’m sorry.” She said, “I was stupid, and you likely saved my ass by pulling me out of there. Thanks for that.”
“I would say naive more than stupid. And it’s okay. That’s what a wingman is for. Bailing you out of trouble.”
“Even so, thanks for getting me out of there when you did. I owe you.”
“Anytime. Want to go back tomorrow?” Linda asked.
Lindsay looked at her. “Do you really thing that is a good idea.”
“Sure. You need to learn how to handle the boys if you’re going to keep this up. This will be good practice. Just keep the drinking under control and we’ll both be fine.”
“I don’t know. The rest of the squad’s due back tomorrow. What would they say?”
“Actually,” said Linda, pulling a folded sheet of paper she’d been using as a bookmark out of the novel and sliding it across the table to her. “It doesn’t look like they’ll be back for another day or two.”
Lindsay looked at the paper. It was a telegram.

From Col. Helgamier Stop.
Voroshilovgrad Stop.
To 127th Jaggswinder Stop.
All flights grounded Voloshilovgad due to storm stop.
Expected to last two days stop.
Two man or less missions expressly forbidden stop.
Amuse yourselves otherwise stop.

“Looks like they ran into a storm front and are stuck for another day or two.”
“So what does she expect us to do?”
“Relax and take it easy I guess.” Linda shrugged “Colonel doesn’t want us running two man patrols for some reason. She specifically said that. Not that there is much available for two man missions, anyway. And you don’t have a plane, unless you want to take the Stuka up, and that would be an even worse idea. We might as well lend the 83rd a hand, unless you can think of something else you’d rather be doing.”

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Lindsay couldn’t think of anything else to do, so it was decided they would head over to the 83rd again in the morning. With that decided, both girls fell quiet. Neither of them were much for conversationalists. Lindsay was very much in the habit of letting others start the conversation, and just adding to it when she could. Linda was very much the same, although she preferred to pick up a book and read when not talking. This made for what Lindsay felt were awkward silences between them, which sort of blended together into another relatively quiet and relaxing night for both. As Lindsay would say later, they just kicked back and relaxed, played a bit of cribbage, tossed a few darts, randomized the jukebox, and the odd snippets of awkward conversation while drinking beer. Eventually it was late enough that they could justify heading to bed.
Early morning was joining the 83rd for another jog around the base, much like the previous day. Only without Lindsay soaking her shirt this time around, much to the disappointment of guys.

Of course the guys were still happy enough to have them join the 83rd for another mission. This time take off took them straight north, so Lindsay spent the first 25 minutes of the flight sneaking peeks through the bombing scope at the land below them.
“What are you looking for?” Rhett finally asked her curiously.
“Nothing, really.” Lindsay replied. “Just seeing if I could spot an old church.”
“Shouldn’t be hard.” Rhett said. “The place is lousy with them. Seems like every fifth building has a spire on it.”
“Now that’s an exaggeration!” Lindsay said “Besides, this church is kind of special to me.”
“Planning on getting married in it are you?”
“Oh, heaven forbid that should happen. No, when I said special I meant that it brings back memories. I crashed into it.”
“Oh. I see.” Rhett grinned as he started inventing an imaginative back story to her statement. “I’ll bet you were badly injured in that crash, weren’t you? Pulled from the mangled wreckage and nursed back to health by the priest in charge of the church, who turned out to be a handsome young man who had just taken his vows of celibacy. Forbidden by faith, you both knew you could never be together, so you had no choice but to fall deeply and madly in love with each other. You knew it was wrong, but daily your feelings grew until one night the young priest had no choice but to sent you away for your own protection. Now you spend your days heart broken, living only for the moments when chance brings your course near his church, and you can only hope for a glimpse of your loves face as you speed past.”
Lindsay stared open mouthed at Rhett’s grinning face. “You’re weird, you know that?” she said finally, shaking her head in disbelief. .”
“So you weren’t nursed back to health by a kindly handsome priest?”
“Of course not. I was killed on impact. I just like to check up on the place every now and then.”
“You are looking for the place you died in?”
“Hey, it’s the one grave I have that I know precisely where it is.”
“And I’m the weird one?”
“You fly bombers for fun. I think that kind of answers the question.”
“Don’t knock it if you’ve never flown one.”
“Oh, I have, didn’t you know? First week we were here, there was an HE-111 parked in our hanger so the Colonel said we might as well take it out for a spin.”
“So what don’t you like about it? Too many controls for you?”
“No, that wasn’t it. I flew cargo planes before joining up. Some of them were way more complicated. The Heinkle is a piece of cake compared to a 707. I just could never get the hang of keeping the machine flying straight.”
“Ah, I see.” Rhett gestured with a free hand “Come up here for a minute.”
Lindsay moved as close to Rhett as the cockpit allowed. “No,” he said, gesturing over his shoulder towards the sliding door that separated the cockpit from the main body of the bomber, where the gunners and radio operator would be stationed. “Stand behind me.” Lindsay stood behind Rhett, pressed against the cabin door. From here she could see over his shoulder towards the front of the bomber. A thought suddenly occurred to her; If the radio operator was to come forward without warning, when the door was slid open she’d fall back into the center compartment. And if that happened she’d likely cripple the belly gunner when she landed on him. To prevent that she wrapped her hand around a support strut as she leaned over Rhett.
“I’ll bet you point the nose of the plane exactly where you want it to go.” He was saying.
“Yeah,” she replied. “But that never works. The plane tends to crab to port.”
“Typical of fighter pilots.” Rhett said “You’re used to using the point of the nose as your focus, and with all that glass up here, the only thing you can focus on is the gun port. That port is in the point of the nose, sure, but it’s offset from the center line, see?” Now that it was pointed out, Lindsay could see how the bubble nose was shifted slightly to the right, putting the gun port directly in front of the gunner. “That’s so the gunner can work and not block the pilot’s line of sight. I’ll show you a little secret.” He reached forward and twanged a support cable that ran down from the cockpit roof into the floor in front of him. “This,” he said “Is your center line.”
“You’re kidding,” Lindsay said. “The roof support cable?”
“It’s not a support cable” Rhett said. “In fact, this cable has no real purpose at all except to give the pilot something to focus on as a center line.”
“That wasn’t in the manual.” Lindsay said, slightly miffed that the answer to something she had so much difficulty with was something so simple

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“So who learns to fly from a manual?” Rhett laughed. “You need someone who’s wise to the little tricks this beast has. Tell you what. On the way back maybe I’ll let you take the controls for a while.”
“No thanks,” Lindsay answered. “I’m good. Besides, there’s only one set of controls, so wouldn’t that mean I have to sit in your lap for that?”
“Only if you want to.” Rhett grinned “Otherwise we’ll just switch places. Bomber pilots do it all the time if they needed a break. Or are too wounded to fly, which happens more often that you’d expect.”

Over the target was much the same as the previous day. There wasn’t as much enemy aircraft, but the flak was far heavier. This time they lost only one Bomber on the raid. The token fighter patrol defending the target was no match for the German side. It might have been different if the enemy had managed to put more fighters in the air, but this time the escort had no trouble keeping them at bay.
They were about 15 minutes from base when Rhett’s voice came over the aircraft intercom into her headset.
“So what do you say” He asked “Want to try your hand at landing this thing?”
“No thanks” Lindsay said “I’m more of a fighter pilot. I’ll leave the big toys to you big boys”
“Suits me,” Rhett said “The view is much better from here anyway.”
“Same thing you fly over every day.”
“Today it has your butt in front of it.”
“What?” Lindsay shrieked as she spun around to look at him. “Don’t you dare!”
“I’m just teasing.” Rhett said with a grin “Can’t see much through those bulky overalls anyway.”
Lindsay sat up and glared at him “Is that what you’ve been doing? Spending most of the mission staring at my butt.”
Rhett realized his attempt at humor had backfired, and hastily backtracked.
“I promise I wasn’t staring. I don’t have time anyway, I’m too busy flying the plane.” Lindsay kept up the glare, which prompted Rhett to keep going with his attempt at an apology.
“Keeping this thing flying straight and level doesn’t give me time to do much more that a passing glance every now and then. Besides, with the flight suit on your butt looks pretty much like anyone else’s.”
“So you look at the guy’s butts too?”
“That’s not what I said.”
“You just said that in a flight suit my butt looks like everyone else’s, so you practically admitted you’ve been checking out guys as well?”
“Oh hell no.” Rhett said, a little too defensively “That’s not what I meant at all. Stop putting words in my mouth.”
“Well maybe you should tell me what you did mean, then.” Lindsay said, arms folded across her chest as she glared back at the pilot.
“How can I tell you what I mean when you just twist the words around?”
Lindsay kept up with the glare, even though she was beginning to realize she had possibly over reacted. Still, a part of her stubbornly refused to back down now.
Back at the controls Rhett chose his next words with care. This was a classic ‘no win scenario’ but maybe if he played it straight he just might survive until touchdown. “All right.” He admitted “I won’t lie and say I didn’t look, it was right there after all. But I don’t stare. I meant what I said about how I was too busy keeping the plane straight and level to do more than a passing glance every now and then. And the remark about the flight suit just means that there’s not much to see anyway. With it on your butt looks pretty much like anyone else’s would.”
Rhett stopped for a moment, watching her for a reaction.
“Is that you’re way of apologizing?” she finally asked.
“No.” Rhett let out a deep sigh “This is. I’m sorry. I was trying to make a joke and it didn’t work.”
When Lindsay didn’t say anything he continued. “Look, It’s really nice to finally get a bombardier on my plane that knows how to do the job. That she also happens to be drop dead gorgeous is great, but I’m more impressed by the way that twice now you’ve dropped the entire payload on target with pinpoint accuracy. Most of the crews who will take on the bombardier position are either pilots who are too pig headed about someone else flying the plane, or gunners who are used to just spraying the target and hoping something hits. So far not one of them has managed to hit a target twice in a row except for Yancy, and we haven’t seen him since he went MIA 2 weeks ago.”
Rhett paused again to see how Lindsay reacted, then continued. “I’m sorry if my saying I was staring at your butt made you uncomfortable and upset you. I didn’t mean anything by it.”
Lindsay didn’t say anything, just turned back towards the nose, watching the ground moving beneath the window. Behind her she heard Rhett mutter, quite clearly because he had forgotten his hand was still on the mike switch, “Who’d have thought flying through Flak would be the easiest part of this mission?”
Staring through the bubble Lindsay was trying to get her thoughts to settle down. She wasn’t sure why she’d made such a big deal out of the comment. Sure, maybe Rhett been a little out of line. But she could completely understand where he was coming from. Hell, if she was in his shoes she’d probably be doing the same thing. Still, she was both flattered and offended at the same time, and didn’t know what to make of it. It wasn’t something she’d ever envisioned needing to know how to handle. She really needed to talk to someone about this, but who?
She sat there trying to sort her thoughts out until the wheels touched and the big bomber taxied to a stop with the rest of the group in front of the hangers.
She still hadn’t come to terms with her swirling thoughts, but decided the big guy had suffered enough, so when they had climbed out of the plane she went over to him. “Buy me a beer and I’ll consider it apology accepted.” she said as she gave him a light punch on the shoulder.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Of course they wound up at the 83rd officers club after the mission.
Taking Linda’s words to heart, Lindsay did her best to limit the amount she drank when the 83rd dragged her into the officers club that evening, sticking to the one beer that Rhett ad bought her at the start. One thing she had not anticipated though, was just how hard it was to get the men to not buy her drinks. It seemed that none of the boys really knew of any other way to get a girls attention. Lindsay felt a little sad every time she had to say no. At first it sort of felt like she was personally insulting them each time she turned one down. Then it just got annoying.
Fortunately she was not alone, Linda was getting the same treatment. It was Linda who finally snapped at the group after the 7th offer in as many minutes. She’d stood up on her chair and shouted to the crowd to stop it, they had all they wanted for now, and if she wanted another drink, which it didn’t look very likely at this point, she would dammed well buy it herself. The crowd seemed to back off a little after that.
Of course, there are always those that don’t discourage easily, and figure ‘No’ means 'Try a slightly different tactic'. One of the men, a man she hadn’t met before, had sidled up and insisted on telling the girls ‘The Worlds Funniest Joke’.
“So this English Colonel is asked if one of their well renown pilots would be willing to speak at a fancy dinner,” he was saying “And the Colonel, having no choice, of course said yes. Now knowing that the pilot had a rather colorful way of speaking, he gave this famous pilot a very stern warning to be on his best behavior and also sent along his adjutant to keep an eye on things and hopefully smooth over any miss-understandings.”
“Of course,” the man said, lowering his voice “half way through dinner the daughter of the host asks the pilot how he got his purple heart, and the pilot, being just a little drunk, starts telling the harrowing story of an epic air battle.” At this point the man’s attempt to speak in an English accent was horrific and only succeeded in making him sound drunker than he likely was “ ‘E says, reaching the end of ‘is ‘arrowing tale, roight when we thought we was done with ‘em, these five Folkers came screaming down on us, straight down out of the sun. At this point the adjutant, realizing the possibility of the audiences misunderstanding the pilot, spoke up and explained that Folker was the name of a German manufacture who made fighter planes, like the BF109.”
“Aye, the pilot said, the BF109 is a very fine machine and no mistake about that, but these Folkers were flying Messerschmitts!”
There was a silent pause for a few seconds, then Linda spoke up. “Actually, I prefer the Messerschmitt myself. Better power to weight.”
“Oh, I don’t know.” Lindsay added, quickly catching onto what Linda was doing. “I haven’t had a chance to fly one myself, so I don’t know if it’s any better than the Focke Wulf I’m flying now.”
“Oh, didn’t you hear?” Linda asked “We’re getting the 190’s next week.”
“Really?” Lindsay asked. “It’s about time. I really need a new plane.”
“And these are like, totally new, you know?”
“The joke is the word Folker.” Was the exasperated reply from the man who had been chatting them up.
Linda just looked at him blankly, then frowned. “It’s pronounced Focke.”
“It's his accent. That’s what the adjutant thought he was trying to say.That's the joke.”
“Wait, are you saying the Focke Wulfs we fly are a joke, then?”
Giving up in disgust, the guy made his way back to where his buddies were standing, undoubtedly laughing at him, on the other side of the room.
As soon as he was out of earshot the girls started giggling.
“Like, Totally New? Seriously?” Lindsay criticized.
“Sorry,” Linda grinned “Got a bit carried away with the airhead act.”
“That wasn’t very nice.” Archie scolded.
“Oh come on,” Linda said when she got a hold of herself. “It was hilarious. Besides, I could tell that joke far better than he was.”
“And really,” Lindsay said “We’re Germans, right? If he’s going to tell jokes, they should be good German jokes.”
“German jokes?” Rhett shook his head disbelievingly. “Germans don’t have a sense of humor.”
“Sure they do”
“Yeah” put in Linda “Like, Knock, Knock.”
“Who’s there?” Lindsay said, grinning.
“Guest Tapo.”
“Guest Tapo who?”
“Open zee door now!” Linda said, her voice flat and humorless “Und I’m afraid ve vill need to zee your papers.”
Archie snorted, not quite a laugh, but close.
“Or how about this one?” Lindsay said,” My Vife iz zo fat.”
“How fat is she?” Linda responded, classically.
“I’m azking zee questions here.”
This got another snort and a head shake from Archie, and a face palm from Rhett.
“Oy, Mien Gott!” He declared, getting to his feet. “What say we play some pool.”

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Linda pulled up in front of the Gasthaus and shut down the motor. “I suppose” She said conversationally, as she set the parking break “That could have gone better.”
“I’m sorry” Lindsay said. “It wasn’t intentional, honest.”
Anything else Linda might have said on the matter was cut short by the bang of the Gasthaus door.
“I thought it would be you. “A silhouetted shape called, standing in the light spilling out of the doorway. “About time you two showed up.”
“Colleen!” Linda hopped out of the jeep and made her way to the door. You’re back!”
“We’ve been back for hours.” Colleen declared. “Get yourself in here. I can’t wait to get caught up. And the Major says it’s your turn to buy.”
The rest of the squad already had a pretty good party going. There was a large amount of noise as everyone tried to talk over the jukebox. The squad wanted to tell them all about the trip, and also wanted to know where the two of them had been all day.
“We’ve been spending time over at the 83rd,” Linda said, “trying to fill in some of the holes in Lindsay’s education.” A couple of the girls exchanged a quick glance. “What holes would those be?” Bev asked.
“How to behave like a real woman.” Linda said. “You’d swear the kid was raised by Nuns or something.”
Bev exchanged an odd, guarded look with Lana Raye. “What types of behavior.” She pressed.
“You know, interacting with boys. The finer aspects of how to string them along and get them to do stuff for you, like buying drinks. Basic feminine fundamentals. I had her practicing on the 83rd.”
“Guy’s,” Lindsay protested “Do we have to talk about this now?”
“Something wrong Lindsay?” Colleen asked.
“Nothings wrong, I just don’t want to get into this right now.”
What Lindsay wanted, however was not what she got.
“So how did she do?” Bev wanted to know.
“Meh, only so so. She’s getting better, but there’s still a lot of work to be done. The first night was a disaster and we had to abort early in. Tonight was a bit better. She practically had Rhett eating out of the palm of her hand.”
“Rhett?" Lorraine asked. "The big Texan with the mustache?
“That’s the one.”
“Good choice, he’s a big sweetheart.”
“It was going great until she screwed up on his Let me show you how to shoot a combo ploy.
“No!” Lorraine gasped, “She didn’t.”
“I don’t see what the deal is.” Lindsay said, grumpily “He offered help I didn’t need, so I said no thanks. I was doing just fine on my own.”
“Oh God, she did.” Lorraine covered her eyes in mock horror at the thought. Another voice added “Looks like Linda really has her work cut out for her.”
“Yeah, a lot of work.” Commented a third
“What? Lindsay defended “I play a pretty good game of pool.”
“Oh Lindsay, honey,” Lorraine said, shaking her head sadly “A woman doesn’t play a game of pool to play a game of pool.”
“That makes no sense.” Lindsay said, “Why else would you play pool?”
“A woman plays pool so the man can show her how.”
“But I know how.” Stated Lindsay, still not seeing where the girls were going with this.
“Oh my God, is she for real?”
“So far to go, our young apprentice.”
“What?” Lindsay demanded, getting confused and irritated at the circle the girl’s were talking in.
“Lindsay,” Lorraine explained sadly “The whole point of the pool game is the woman plays hopelessly, and the man gallantly shows her how to improve. It’s not about playing pool, it’s about playing the man until he gets you right where you want him to be.”
“Oh?” Lindsay thought about this, her ears turning pink as she realized the implications.
“You want to know the worst part of what my clueless little Padawan did?” Linda added bluntly.
“Linda, NO! Don’t!” cried Lindsay desperately, but it was too late.
“She nutted Rhett with her cue.” Linda said firmly, in spite of Lindsay’s plea. “Quite hard, too.”
“What? The group broke into babbles of disbelief.
“It was an accident.” Lindsay cried “I didn’t know he would be standing right behind me. I was just trying to put a little English on the ball.”
“Yeah, you might say she put a lot of ‘English’ on a couple of them.”
“I’ll bet he wasn’t speaking English.”
“It was hard to make out what he was saying, what with the moaning.”
“I said I was sorry!” Lindsay said dejectedly, obviously feeling bad about the whole incident.
“I’m sure he knows that.” Linda said. “After all, you only apologized about 6 times.”
“Well I am”
“So.” Linda said, wrapping up the story. “Since all that ice kind of put a damper on the rest of the evening, we left early. What have you guys been up to?”

“What do you think?” Colleen said enthusiastically “Shopping! Too bad you missed it, you wouldn’t believe the shoe shop Bev found.”
And just like that, Lindsay found the whole embarrassing incident swept away and forgotten, or at least tucked away for discussion a later date, if ever, as the girls chattered excitedly about the trip.
“Most of the stores where pretty low on stock, being in the middle of a war. Most of the time the choice was take it or leave it. But this girl” Colleen said, thumping Bev on the back “is amazing. In the middle of occupied Russia she finds a freaking warehouse full of shoes.”

“Oh yeah!” Allison added with youthful enthusiasm. “Bev locates, and Colleen negotiates.”
“And we appreciates!” tossed in Lorraine. “We’re a lean mean shopping team.”

“See, no problem”
“Hey Lindsay, I got you a couple of tops as well.” This was Beverly

“Hey Lindsay,” Leslie suddenly asked “Where’s your plane? I didn’t see it down by the hangers.
“Yeah, last we saw of you, it was smoking pretty bad. What happened?”
For Lindsay the question sucked all the fun out of the conversation.”

Lindsay took a deep breath and exhaled slowly, unclenching her fist as she did so. Before she could say anything, Linda piped up “What’s left of Lindsay’s machine is over at the 104th.
“She crashed?” Asked Allison from behind the bar.
“I Did Not!” Lindsay said forcefully. The crowd of girls fell silent she continued. “I landed it.” She said, quietly at first, but with increasing venom in her voice as she continued. “It was a good landing. I took a shot to shit, badly damaged machine and brought it down in one piece. It was full of holes and the motor was wrecked and I had no instruments I could trust, but in the end I had it sitting nicely in one piece on all three wheels in the middle of the runway.” Her words started to come out with more force as she continued. “The only reason it’s sitting on a trash heap at the 104th right now is because some little dick corporal who can’t handle rejection decided the best way to pay me back was by driving over it with a bulldozer.” These last two words were practically spat out.
“Yeah,” Linda added. "Then he tried to make her walk home afterwards.”
“From the 104th? But that’s what, 30 km?”
“Probably,” Linda said “But it doesn’t matter. She got a lift. And,” Linda leaned forward with a wink “You should have seen the hunk that was driving.”
“Ooh” was the collective response. Not quite the sympathetic reaction Lindsay was hoping for. The whole dynamic was different. Sure, the girls listened politely as she when she retold the harrowing tale of the forced landing, of how she had punched out the windows so she could keep the wings level while landing blind, but it was not with the grudging admiration she’d received while telling the story at the 83rd. The girls were less interested in the technical stuff and more interested in the people she’d met afterwards. More focused on the feelings than on the action. For her part Lindsay was surprised by how easily she could answer the questions the girls asked. Apparently she’d picked up on a whole lot of details without consciously noticing, all she needed was something to frame the information around so she could share it.
Once she had finished telling the story everyone chipped in. It seemed everyone had met someone like the little sleezeball of a Corporal, so they all had their own horror story and / or advice to share on that topic.
And so the rest of the night passed, gossip, fashion tips, advice, and beer flowed freely until the hour grew late and the members of the group dragged themselves to their respective bunks.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
At some point during the evening Linda had brought up that she and Lindsay were trying to get into the routine of going for a run in the morning, and managed to talk Bev into joining them. Addison, once she’d heard about the plans, of course joined in with all the naïve eagerness of someone who likes the sound of an activity but has no idea of what’s really involved. Lana-Raye had let them know, in no uncertain terms, about what she thought of the idiots who got up that early to make themselves sweat. Lorraine wasn’t thrilled about the sweating part but hey, the boys from the 83rd would be involved, so she was in.
Oh Eight Fifteen the next morning found Lindsay leading the girls through their warm ups beside the generator shed that had become their default meet up place for the ad hoc jogging group.
“Morning ladies.” Called Frank as the group from the 83rd up the taxiway.
Unlike the group from the 127th, who’s ranks had swelled considerably, the 83rd has down a couple of members. Rhett was there, which for some reason made Lindsay both happy and anxious. She was hoping he bore no hard feelings about the incident from last night.
“Well, looks like we have a couple of new faces today.” Frank said as he looked over the increased ranks of the 127th, the irony of his statement completely escaping him.
After a moment he hesitantly turned to Lorraine and said “Captain Linda Bray-Lewis, Right? This is…”
“Captain Samuel Weinstein,” interrupted Lorraine. “We’ve met. Actually, I’m Captain Lorraine Peterson.”
“Also,” she continued, turning to each of the group in turn, “You’re Lieutenant Frank Maddigan, that’s Lieutenant Fredrick Murphy, the big guy there is First Lieutenant Archie Yakamura, and the beefcake that Lindsay is mooning over is Captain Rhett Jackson.”
“Hey!” Lindsay protested. Before she could say anything else Lorraine continued.
“If you haven’t guessed, that’s Lindsay.” She waved a hand in the general direction of the others. “That’s Beverly, Addison, and Linda over there.”
Lorraine seemed to think this was adequate for introductions. Completely ignoring Frank and the sheepish look on his face she turned her attention to the big First Lieutenant. “So,” she said, “How have you been, Archie?” The two of them fell into conversation and ignored the rest of the group.
Frank shook his head and turned towards Lindsay. “I really wish you’d wear name tags.” He said.
“And miss out on all this fun?” Lindsay said with a laugh. “Besides, you figured out who I was quick enough.”
Oh, that was simple enough.” Frank said with a shrug. “There are only two lieutenants, and I don’t remember you bouncing around like a puppy.”
“She’s not bouncing.” Lindsay said, looking over at where Linda and Addison stood talking to Sam. At least Linda stood there. Addison was sort of hopping on one foot as she stretched her calf muscles. “Okay,” Lindsay grudgingly admitted. “She does bounce just a little.”
“I don’t think it’s possible for any of you to bounce just a little.” Said Fred with a grin as he wandered passed, tucking his shirt into is waist band.
“Just for that remark you’re on point.” Said Frank.
“Fine with me.” Said Fred, seemingly unperturbed by being put in the lead position.
“Alright ladies” he said, deliberately nodding to the rest of the 83rd as he did so “If you and the girls are finished warming up, lets get this show on the road.”
With this the group set off down the gravel taxiway into the pre-dawn morning.
This morning there was no set pattern to the jog, people moved in and out of position at random. At one point, maybe by accident, Lindsay found herself running in step beside Rhett. “Hey,” she said. Not the wittiest thing to say, she would admit, but she couldn’t really think of anything better. “Hey yourself” was Rhett’s reply, obviously having just as much difficulty coming up with topics for small talk. Or more likely, Lindsay thought, he’s still holding a grudge. If he was, she wanted desperately to clear the air.
“About last night,” she said, “I can’t tell you how sorry I am for what happened.”
“Don’t worry about it,” Rhett reassured her, “It wasn’t your fault. If anything it was mine.”
How do you figure that?
“I work with horses. I know better than to come up behind one and startle it. A pool cue’s nothing compared to what a hoof feels like.”
Lindsay visibly winced at the thought.
“Anyway, no lasting damage.” Rhett continued. “One of the emergency med kit bandages and a bit of salve, everything’s right as rain.”
“So you’re not mad at me?” Lindsay said, relived to hear him say it
“Mad at you? Why would you think that.” Rhett managed to sound offended that she would even think that way. “I’m only sorry we didn’t get a chance to finish the game. What’s the chance we can have a rematch?”
“Oh, I don’t know,” Lindsay said, deciding to toy with him a little, payback for the anguish he had put her through. Well, that she’d put herself though, but it was still the same thing, right?
“Why not?” Rhett asked, “I’ll try not to startle you this time.”
“Well,” Lindsay said coyly “Seeing as how it sounds like you just compared me to a horse…”
“No, I was saying I should know better than to startle one.”
“So you do think I’m a horse.”
“No, that’s not what I said. Well, maybe it sounded that way, but that’s not what I meant. I’m sorry.”
“Now I suppose you’ll buy me a beer as an apology.”
“If that will work, sure.”
“So now you’re planning on getting me drunk?”
“What?” Rhett sounded confused “No. That’s not what I’m doing at all.”
“Isn’t it?” Lindsay continued matter of factually “Sounds like a workable strategy. Accidentally insult a girl then buy her a beer as an apology sounds like a move in a game of getting her drunk and taking advantage.”
“Now just a minute here.” Rhett protested hotly “You’re the one who suggested the beer.”
Lindsay realized maybe she’d gone too far. “Hey, relax, I’m teasing you.”
“Well, you could have fooled me.” Rhett said, an angry tone to his voice “It sounded like you were serious accusing me of planning to take advantage of you.”
“Honest, I was just joking around.” Lindsay back tracked “I wasn’t seriously thinking that was your plan.”
Just great, she thought. She’d just been trying to be silly because men like that sort of thing, and wound up screwing up everything.
“I see.” Rhett was silent for a moment before asking “Was all this just you taking your turn as the evil twin?”
“The evil what?” Now it was Lindsay’s turn to be confused.
“You know? When we first met you said one of you was the evil twin, and you took turns to keep people from figuring out which one it was.”
“I did?” Lindsay tried to remember if that’s what she had actually said.
“Yep. Then you referred to all seven of you as sextuplets.”
“I’m pretty sure that would have been Linda.” Lindsay said firmly “Sextuplets means six, and there are seven of us. That’s not the kind of mistake I would make.”
Rhett started to opened his mouth as if to comment, but then closed it, letting whatever remark he might have been about to make go unspoken. Instead he returned to the original topic of conversation.
“So how about that game of pool we never got to finish? When do you want to play the rematch?”
Not if, Lindsay noticed, but when. A subtle but important change. Maybe she hadn’t screwed this up after all.
“Well,” she said, pretending to think about it. “I’d kind of like to play a game. And I do sort of owe you one. How about tomorrow night? I should be free, unless something comes up.”
“Sure! That sounds great.”
“And I promise this time I’ll treat it as a non contact sport.”
“Even better. It’s a date then.”
These words brought the realization home. There was no getting around it, she admitted to herself. She’ had just agreed to go on an actual date. When Linda had teased her in the past about dating she’d gotten defensive about it, yet strangely today it didn’t bother her at all. It was just a date. With a boy.
Oh no! She suddenly thought, What was she going to wear?

Lindsay did a quick scan of her airspace, checking for hostile aircraft, then turned her attention back to the column of smoke that marked where the YAK that had been giving her so much trouble was spiraling earthward. No chute, she noted, putting her plane into a shallow dive and following it down. That meant her opponent was likely dead at the controls. Or maybe wounded and unconscious. Or, she thought with an involuntary shudder, trapped with a canopy that wouldn’t open. She watched the YAK spiral downward until the reason why didn’t matter anymore. This last guy had the skills, and it was only a bit of luck that kept her airborne while her opponent became a part of the landscape.
Now that he was out of the picture, she turned her attention to finding out where the heck the rest of her squadron was. It was a few minutes before anyone responded to her transmitting, the answering call was weak and full of static.
“Red 6,” Came Leslies’ voice, while understandable, crackled heavily. “This is Red leader. Where are you?”
“Red Leader, this is Red 6. I’m just south of the river. Right over where that bomber went down, I think.” The whole mess had started when the bomber flight they’d been escorting had run into a Russian patrol. Fortunately for the 83rd the 127th had managed to drive most of them off, loosing only one bomber this time. In the category of making the best of a bad situation, the burning wreck made for a heck of a navigational beacon.
“Okay Red 6, That puts you, what, holy crap. You’re a good 40 kilometers north of us. How the hell did you get that far away?”
“That stupid Yak I drew wouldn’t give up. I kept trying to disengage but he kept coming after me. I guess I got lost while I was trying to get away.”
“Where is he now?”
“I managed to drag him up to 4500. He ran out of bullets and died.”
“Nice one Red 6. Let’s bring our stray bird back to the flock. Red flight, turn 360, speed 200, Red 6 Turn to heading umm, 220. Follow the river and you should see us in a few minutes.”
Lindsay dutifully acknowledged and turned to the requested heading. The river was clear and free of traffic as she flew over it, although she noted several barges tied up along the south bank that may make viable targets. She made a note to mention them to the Colonel once she was joined back up with the rest of the 123rd. 10 minutes later, just as she was beginning to worry that she’d somehow missed the group, the radio crackled to life again, this time with the signal much stronger.
“Red 6, this is Blue 5, I’m bird dogging and I can see you from up here. Change to 240 for intercept. You should be home in about five minutes.”
“Roger that Blue Five, changing to intercept” Lindsay transmitted as she banked the aircraft to the right, settling in on the new course. She wasn’t out of the woods yet, but she was getting there.
“Red six, this is bird dog. Bandits! 6 o’clock high.
“Again?” Lindsay pushed the stick forward and opened the throttle, pushing the engine passed maximum into emergency power, trying to get as much speed into her plane as she could. Peering hastily back over her shoulder she couldn’t see the enemy, but if Bev said they were there she wasn’t going to waste time looking for them. They would make them selves known soon enough.
And sure enough, then she could see them. Three small dots behind and above her that sprouted wings even as she watched. ‘Crap, they’re moving fast’ she thought. The dive they were in must be pushing their planes right to the limit of their airframes. Unfortunately, it also meant that they were moving much faster than Lindsay, even with her engine wide open. If she’d been smart earlier she would have climbed back up to 3500 where her aircraft performed better, instead of sticking to 1500 and sight seeing. It was a mistake she hoped she would live to regret.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Lindsay pulled the throttle back, out of the emergency setting, allowing her airspeed to fall. Not that she wanted to, just the opposite in fact, but any longer and the engine would be badly damaged, maybe destroyed. Now all she could do was watch her pursuers as they fanned out behind her, closing in. She counted 5 winged dots now. One either side, one directly behind, one above him. The fifth following behind as back up in case one of the others overshot her position. “What did I do to become so popular” she said to herself, squinting into the low sun as she raced towards the remote safety of the rest of the flight. Logic told her she wasn’t going to make it. Only a minute had passed, there were still four more to go and the enemy was almost on her. Still, last minute rescues were a common theme of cheesy movies and video games.

“Any time you’re ready guys. I could use the help!” she radioed. Witty battle banter was also a must have.
“Hang in there Lindsay, the cavalry is coming.”
“Don’t be too long.” She replied. “I wouldn’t want you to be late to the party.”
“Stall them if you have to, but don’t start the party without us.”
Okay, She thought, we now have the witty cliché movie banter.
Lindsay looked back at the rapidly closing enemy almost upon her, weighing her options. Dive and she could gain a bit of distance, but then they would catch her at a low altitude. Climb and she’d loose speed and they would catch her all that much sooner. Stay as she was and they would catch her anyway. For long moments she agonized over the choices, unable to make a decision, until the options were no longer available to her. The enemy had closed the gap and were almost in range.
“Oh well,” she sighed. “If you’re going to die, you might as well take a bastard with you.”

With that she rolled her aircraft over and dove, pulling out in a split S turn that had her pointing right back the way she came, heading straight into the sights of the lead attacker. As soon as her nose came up she triggered her guns. No sense carrying unspent ammo into the great beyond.
It was obvious the lead pilot wasn’t expecting her to come up guns blazing, because instead of keeping his head and firing back he panicked, banking and turned away. Briefly Lindsay hoped to rake his belly with cannon fire, but before she could he was suddenly spinning away out of control, a victim of that nasty accelerated stall the La-5 was infamous for. At low altitudes that was deadlier than enemy fire, but Lindsay didn’t watch to see if he’d recover in time. Her attention was on the other, more level headed pilots who smoothly maneuvered out of her way and swung around in behind her, boxing her in. The fight was joined, and it was clearly one sided, that side being behind her and shooting.
Now she no longer had the initiative. In spite of twisting and turning, she no sooner got herself out of one set of gun sights when another opened up on her. Within minutes both her wings were in tatters, her maneuverability, at this altitude not as good as the La-5’s she was fighting, dropped wildly until she was just barely able to keep control as she fought to evade her attackers.
And yet, in spite of the numbers of shells fired in her direction, not one of them scored a killing shot. They were toying with her, she realized. Like a group of cats with a mouse. Each taking a turn, seeing how badly they could hurt her without actually killing her. They don’t know help is on the way, she thought. If she could keep this up, stalling for time until the 123rd showed up, she might just last long enough to get one of those overly cliché last minute rescues.
Just as that glimmer of hope kindled within her, the port wing broke off and her plane began to cork screw down.

With a strong enough engine and the correct control moves you can land a one wing plane. There was a YouTube video from several years back where Lindsay had seen it done. A couple of times she’d even wondered if she was capable of landing like that herself. This time however, she wasn’t about to even try. Grabbing the canopy eject handle, she pulled upward, flinging the canopy into the air stream and away. A slap at the seat belt release and she didn’t even have to climb out; the centrifugal force of the spinning plane ejecting her before she had time to change her mind about it. Something hit her leg a painful blow as the remaining wing spun past, then she was out was away from her doomed machine and hurtling earthward. Below her aircraft. For a moment it struck her as funny that she was actually falling faster that her out of control wreck of an aircraft. then she pulled the rip cord and the sky disappeared in a cloud of silk. The jolt when she hit the end of the chute cords shot a bolt of pain from her leg, no doubt courtesy of that long thin chunk of aluminum she found speared through her thigh when the blackness cleared from her vision enough that she could look around. Things weren’t so funny anymore. There was a nasty gash in the leg of her flight suit as well, the fabric below soaked with bright red blood. Must be from when the wing slapped me. She thought. That’s going to really start to hurt in a minute. Something about the colour bothered her, but she couldn’t put her finger on it.
The ground that was rushing towards her looked all wrong as well. The snow was a greenish grey, covered with a glittery pattern that moved as she looked, making it hard to focus on exactly where the ground was.

And then she hit, plunging below the surface of the river she’d bailed out over, the icy water momentarily paralyzing her in shock until her survival instincts kicked in and she fought her way to the surface, gasping as her head broke the water and she gulped in a lungfull of clean cold air. She floundered on the surface for a moment before the shroud lines coiled around her boots pulled her back under the water. Frantically she reached down and tried to free her legs, but her numb fingers couldn’t get the knotted lines off. She slipped the knife clipped to her belt free, using the sharp blade to hack and saw the rubbery ropes, trying to cut her legs free. The blade caught on something and slipped from her numb fingers, but by that time she’d cut deep enough that when she yanked the last few strands parted and she kick desperately towards the surface. Just as she reached the surface something grabbed her, wrapping itself around her face. She tried to use her hands to pull it free, but her arms were also being tightly held by whatever was holding her underwater. In a last moment of clarity she realized she’d come up under her own parachute; the strong silk that had been her salvation was now her doom. Trapped, her lungs burning for air that wasn’t coming, she sank helpless into the gloomy depths. There was only one thing she could do.

She screamed.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
She was still screaming and thrashing about as the rough cloth gave way, pitching her head first onto a cold hard wooden surface. Fighting for breath, she scrabbled away on her hands and knees. Her feet tangled in something and she fell heavily forward, knocking what little breath she managed to grab out of her. Flailing about, trying to get her legs under her and right herself, she felt hands on her shoulders, grabbing at her. She twisted and slapped the grappling hands away, managing another weak scream as she did so, blocking out the sound of the distant river calling her name. Freeing herself from the clutching hands she lunged away, half falling forward, only to smash head first into the edge of something. Something very hard and unforgiving. Stars exploded behind her eyes, knocking her sprawling backwards, dazed. Before she could recover a heavy weight fell on her, pinning her backwards to the cold wood she was laying on. Too weak and dazed to struggle anymore she could only lay on her back, trapped under whatever it was that was holding her down while the watery world swam in circles around her, calling to her. “Lindsay” It was saying frantically. “Lindsay, wake up!”
The voice sounded almost desperate. And familiar. Recognition chased the fog of panic away, and as it receded and she stopped struggling. Suddenly she knew where she was. Where she must be. No longer was the clutching silk of the treacherous parachute holding her trapped in the icy depths. What she thought was the cold waters of the river were now cold hard wood against her back. She took a deep, shaky breath. And then another. She could breath. Oh God, she could BREATH! She opened her eyes and saw the heavy weight holding her down had a very worried looking face.
“Linda?” she asked, hardly believing it was true.
“Are you okay” Linda asked, sitting up and peering into Lindsay’s face with an expression of deep concern.
Instead of answering, Lindsay lunged upwards and wrapped her arms around her, hugging her fiercely. “Oh God” she sobbed, clutching her roommate as hard as she could. “Oh God oh God oh God...”
“There, there.” Linda said softly, hugging her in return “Hush now. Everything’s going to be alright. You’re safe. Everything’s going to be okay now.” Softly, Linda stroked Lindsay’s back, shushing and soothing and rocking the sobbing girl as she slowly calmed down.
Suddenly the overhead light came on. “Seriously, you two?” Came Colleen’s voice from the door. “I know it’s your room and all, but are you trying to wake up the entire base?”
Without stopping to look up Linda said calmly “Do us a favor Colleen and put a sock in it. And while your at it fetch us a cup of tea from the mess. Something herbal if you can find it.”

A remarkably short time later Colleen was back with a steaming pot and a handful of mugs. By this time quite a crowd had worked their way into the girls room.
“So,” Colleen said, passing out mugs, giving an extra to Lorraine to hold while she poured, “What’s going on?”
“Lindsay had a nightmare, what does it look like?”
“Well,” Colleen said with a shrug, pouring tea. “You hear screaming and walk in on the camp lesbian and her naked room mate hugging the crap out of each other…” Colleen caught the look the others were giving her and realized that tonight no one was in the mood for her attempt at humor. “So yeah,” she trailed off “Nightmare was my first guess...”
By this time Lindsay had calmed down enough that Linda felt it was safe to move her back to her bed and cover her up.
At first Lindsay refused the blanket, fearing its touch would trigger a return of the nightmare she’d woken from, but once it was loosely draped over her shoulders she found the warmth and slightly scratchy roughness to be actually quite soothing. The mug of tea Colleen handed her with helped, and after a bit she had calmed down enough that Bev could convince her to talk about what happened. She didn’t want to, but Bev had insisted it would help. Lindsay had been skeptical at first, but now, after pouring her heart out to the sympathetic group of women while wrapped in blankets with a mug of tea, she had to admit she did feel much better.
And after assurances that she was going to be all right, the girls started to trickle away, heading back to bed to try and catch what was left of the sleep period. After they left Lindsay sat, huddled under her blanket in the middle of the bed. It felt warm and safe there. She was in the middle of her bed in the middle of the room in the middle of her friends. The illusion of safety was comforting.

Even so, she was pretty sure she was done sleeping for the night.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Lindsay was still a bit shaken as she headed out for breakfast the next morning. She had to force herself to step under the shower head, even though the water was warm. Instead of relaxing her she found herself tense and nervous. Then, she tried to wet her face by cupping her hands and splashing the water into her face like she usual did, water went up her nose and that was it. Shower was over. She barely took the time to towel off before she was out of the showers, still half dressed with her wet hair still wrapped in a towel. She didn’t care. She would finish with the buttons and clips on her way to the mess tent, away from the running water.

She was staring at her coffee cup when Colleen and Bev slid onto the bench across the table from her.
“Morning Lindsay,” Bev said. “How are you feeling today?”
“I’m okay.” Lindsay said non committal. “As well as can be expected, I guess.”
“Really?” Colleen piped in. “ ‘Cause you don’t look it. Did you get any sleep after we left?”
“No.” Lindsay admitted.
“Didn’t think so.” Colleen said in a matter of fact voice. “You look like death warmed over.”
Lindsay shuddered at the word death. Bev noticed and put a hand over hers, patting it comfortingly.
“I know it seems bad now, but it’ll get better.”
“Does it?” Lindsay sighed, closing her eyes. Then she shook her head and looked up, straight into Bev’s eyes. “It doesn’t seem so. Each time it just gets worse.”
Bev looked back, trying to smile reassuringly.

Lindsay did not have a great day. Lack of sleep, coupled with being nervous and on edge, really threw off her game. She kept making stupid mistakes and missing easy targets. On the plus side, she wasn’t shot down, so the day evened out at the end.

After supper she hemmed and hawed, putting off going to the Gasthus as long as possible. She wasn’t sure what to expect, and that made her even more nervous. She seriously contemplated just blowing the session off, getting drunk, and going to bed. Then she realized all the beer for the 123rd was in the Gasthus with the rest of the group, so she couldn’t even do that. Unless, she suddenly thought, she could head over to the 83rd. But then she realized that if she did that then she’d likely run into Rhett, and since she’d stood him up for their date the other night that was something she wasn’t really looking forward to. Although technically being dead was probably one of the better excuses, she’d still felt guilty about it. Because she dreaded what his reaction would be, she decided to phone him instead of going over there in person, and when she’d finally screwed up her courage to call he was unavailable. After three calls and left messages and he still hadn’t returned her call, she figured that meant that he was probably mad about the whole thing. To actually confront him was something she didn’t have to courage for at the time, and she worried that another call would make her seem desperate, and the more she thought about it the harder it was to actually do anything about it, so she retreated into her old habit of doing nothing and hoping the problem would resolved itself, preferably somehow where she wouldn’t have to get involved.

Which was the same sort of thing she was doing now, standing and staring at the Gasthus door, shuffling indecisively from foot to foot, putting off making an uncomfortable decision in hopes she wouldn’t have to.
And, as if to affirm the justification of her actions, the immediate problem did in fact resolve itself without her help, in the form of Bev coming up behind her to drop a reassuring arm around her shoulder and pull her inside, saying “Come on, it won’t be that bad. It might even be fun.”

Inside Bev steered her to the larger table away from the door, where Colleen and Linda were already seated. Colleen, with a couple of beers on the go already, looked up expectantly when Lindsay sat down. “Just in time to pay for the next round.” She said, tipping her glass up and polishing off the last of the pre-drinking drink she’d obviously ordered earlier. “And you’ll be a bit more talkative than Linda there.”

Linda, in contrast to Colleen’s booze fest, had a china cup and saucer of tea in front of her. And a new book she was reading. When the girls sat down she carefully folded over the corner of the page and set the book to one side. Lindsay could just make out what seemed to be a giant robotic ant carrying off a screaming buxom blonde woman while a smaller figure with a black vest and a pony tail was running up the road behind them, waving something that looked like an old remote control. The woman was obviously a scientist of some sort, judging from the safety glasses and lab coat she was wearing over the OHAS challenged (but visually obligatory) string bikini. When Lindsay looked closer she could read the title.

“Nukees, The Movie’
Below that, the sub text proclaimed
From the stage play by Steve Spoon with characters copyright Darren Bleuel

Lindsay, more from the dread of starting the group session than any real interest, asked “Good book?”
Linda fluttered her eyes and blew across the surface of her tea before answering. “Compared to the others I’ve managed to find here, yes.”
“What’s it about?” Lindsay asked, seizing the chance to delay a bit longer.
Linda took a small sip from her cup. Deciding it was still too hot, she set the tea to one side and settled back against the tent support behind her. “It’s about the adventures of a group of nuclear science grad students at the University of Berkeley.”
“Do they have a crazy teacher who wears dark glasses?” Colleen asked.
“What?” Linda asked, completely missing the musical reference. “No. At least I don’t think so. He does have a giant nuclear powered robot ant though. And a calculator that houses a Gigapet eating monster called Teri.”
“Was it really a movie?” Lindsay asked. “I don’t ever remember hearing about it.”
Colleen piped up “It was actually a stage play first, written as a fan-fic of a web comic from the late 90’s. It got optioned to be a direct to video release. The guy I was dating was part of the test audience and I got to sit in on a couple of the daily screenings. Not exactly an Oscar worthy effort, but still a fairly good showing for a budding director. Actually a bit better than a lot of the other movies at the time.”
“So how come I’ve never heard of it?”
“It was never released. Turns out the executive producer had a history of stiffing authors on their royalties. Rather than fight with the exec when the advance cheques bounced the copyright holder went straight to the producer. He stopped production and threatened to can the project unless the EP cleared the funds. Of course the Executive Producer threatened to sue back if they didn’t go ahead, but that was just a smoke screen to keep everyone off balance until he could drain the accounts and fold the production company. By the time the dust settled and the rights were returned the copyright holder was heartily sick of the whole game. And since the EP held onto the option nobody could touch the project anyway so the whole movie was shelved. The novelization you’re holding is all that remains of that Spoon guy’s dream.”

Lindsay thought about it for several seconds “So, if I’ve got this right, basically she’s reading the novelization of a script for a movie that never happened, based on a stage play that was a fan-fic of a web comic?”
“Yeah, that’s pretty much it.”
“I can’t decide if that is the coolest or the geekiest thing I’ve ever heard.” Bev said, coming back with a rather large tray of drinks. “I don’t know if I’ve ever said this Colleen, but you know a lot of really weird shit, you know?”
“What can I say?” Colleen replied, helping her self to a fresh beer off the tray “I spent a semester at Berkeley in my second year. Weird shit was a required course.”
“So was Carl Jung,” said Bev, setting the rest of the untouched tray in the middle of the table. “Which is why we’re here tonight.”
“Right,” Lindsay said in a resigned tone. The moment was upon them. “And I’m getting stuck with the bar tab. Hope my pay will cover it”
“Think of it as bargain rates.” Colleen said. “If this was a real session the bill would be a hell of a lot higher.”
“Yeah,” Lindsay replied “But at least I’d walk away with my brain all fixed up.”
“Sorry Lindsay.” Bev said, shaking her head “Therapy doesn’t work that way. There’s no magic patch they put on your brain that instantly heals the hurt.”
“So, what’s the point then?”
“To let you know people care, and give you tools to help you cope.”
“That’s all?”
“No,” Bev admitted “There’s tons more stuff. But that is the realm of your practicing professionals. I’m more of your down and dirty hobbyist type.”
“Great.” Lindsay groaned “DIY psychotherapy. Can’t possibly go wrong with that.”

“DYI Medical is all the rage in Paris.” Commented Colleen, chugging back her beer with the abandon of someone who knows she doesn’t have to worry about the tab. “Like those places that allow you to do your own stitches in return for a discount on your surgery.”
“There’s no such place” Lindsay said, watching as yet another fifty cents of hers vanished down Colleen’s throat.
“Sure there is.” Colleen insisted. “It’s called ‘Suture Self’ and caters to the most interesting people in the world.”

“If you’re done with the wisecracks,” Bev admonished “I’d like to get started. Colleen, perhaps you’d like to go first.”
“Why me?” Colleen asked, reaching for another beer. “I thought I was just here to drink beer and offer moral support.”
“And just think of how supportive it will be when Lindsay knows she’s not the only one subject to bizarre nightmares.”
“I don’t have nightmares!” Colleen insisted, drinking half of the next glass down. “At least, not major ones like Lindsay’s.”
“We all do,” Bev said. “But if you’re not comfortable sharing them then you don’t have to.”

“Na, I’ll share.” Colleen said, dismissively waving the hand not wrapped around her glass “There’s one I used to have all the time. Not really very interesting, but it’s one I remember. I’m always trying to give some kind of presentation only when I get up on stage I realize I forgot to put clothes on.”
Bev nodded. “That one’s actually quite common. Naked in public. Social anxiety, the fear of people seeing who you really are. People use clothing to construct an image of what they want people to think. You want people to think you’re smart and successful, wear a suit. You want people to think you’re a fun person, you dress in party clothes. Clothing is one of the biggest identifiers of social rank and status we have.”
“You’re right about that.” Colleen said. “I hadn’t thought of it that way, but I do know you need a good wardrobe tech to give your film the right look. I hadn’t thought it would be like that in my dreams though.”

“Oh it does.” Bev continued “People are basically insecure about how they look to other people. Everyone has something about their body they don’t like so they use clothes to change and enhance the way they look. Stripes for slimming. Girdles and tummy shapers to control stomach bulge, the list goes on. Imagining yourself naked in public is to strip all that concealment and coverings away and let people see the real you, without the facade you’ve built up around you. It brings all your insecurities home.”
“Lindsay was naked this morning.”
“I was?” Lindsay asked. She hadn’t noticed. Of course, she’d had other things on her mind at the time.
“Lindsay was naked because she had just re-spawned, and that’s the way you come back into this world. She didn’t realize she was naked.” Bev confirmed what Lindsay had been thinking.

“So you’re saying Strippers wouldn’t have these kinds of dreams then?” Colleen said, straying even further off topic.
“Yes, they do. There’s a big difference between finding yourself unexpectedly naked in public, and being there intentionally.”
“And so nudists would have the same dreams too, then?”
“I think you’re focusing entirely on the wrong part of this conversation, Colleen. It’s not about who’s naked. It’s about why people have nightmares about it.”
“But there’s streakers…”

“My nightmare is also a manifestation of insecurity,” Bev said, interrupting before Colleen derailed the conversation any further. “Only in it I’m sitting down to a test I have no idea what the answers are. Sometimes it’s the questions don’t match the answers available. Other times the writing is blurry and unreadable. Again, those are my old insecurities manifesting themselves. Writing tests in school were the one way you could prove to the world that yes, you do know what you’re talking about. Not being able to write the test is your fears and insecurities manifesting themselves to say you’re not really as smart as you think you are. I can accept that, because some days I know I’m not. That’s my most common nightmare and how I deal with it.”

Both the girls turned to Lindsay who’d been quietly sipping her beer while the others had been talking.
“Okay Lindsay,” Bev said. “It’s your turn.”
