Lindsay chugged the rest of her beer. She’d known this was coming. Oddly enough, the fact that the other two were willing to share gave her courage. Even if Colleen seemed to be more joking around than anything, at least Bev was sympathetic,
She paused and took a deep breath before continuing. “After Pitomnik. It was, well… That night I dreamt I was in a kitchen, cooking for Thanksgiving. Or Christmas. Or something. I had on this plain cotton dress and a frilly apron.
“Oh yeah,” Colleen just had to say “I could see why that would be just awful.”
Bev shushed her, but Lindsay continued as if she hadn’t heard.
“The table was perfectly set; Fine white china, crisp white table cloth, a covered white trivet of turnips or something. A dish of cranberries to add a dash of colour. Like the whole thing was being painted by Norman Rockwell, you know?”
“Then I opened the oven. Everything was beautiful and perfect and then I opened the oven and suddenly it wasn’t a turkey in the roasting pan any more.”

She regretted her question the moment she saw the look in Lindsay’s eyes as she answered.
“Me. I was in the roasting pan. Trussed up and garnished and surrounded by potatoes and probably stuffed with bread crumbs and onions.” Lindsay closed her eyes and shuddered. “And all I could keep thinking was I’m not ready yet. People will be here soon and the skin isn’t even starting to brown.”
After a moment she said, quietly “I think that’s the part that bothers me the most.”

“Lindsay,” Bev said softly. “It was just a dream.”
“Was it?”
“Of course it was. Let me tell you a little about dreams. Dreams are your subconscious trying to make sense of the world. It takes the information received during the day and tries to match it with what it already knows. And sometimes it doesn’t quite work right.”
“You think so?”
“Sure. The subconscious doesn’t think in words, it uses symbols. Also, it doesn’t have any imagination, so it relies on information already stored. It drags memories out to see if there’s a match. When it finds one it thinks is close, it throws the whole mix into a pot to see what comes out.”
“Sometimes when you look at the different aspects of the dream you can see where they come from. For instance, you said it looked like a Norman Rockwell painting. I’m going to guess you’re referring to his 1942 ‘Freedom From Want’?”
“No,” Lindsay said, shaking her head, thinking about what she’d seen in the dream. Normally she‘d avoided that, but right now was actually quite easy and surprisingly non stressful. “It was more like the one about Thanksgiving Dinner. Now that I think about it, there was the same dumpy looking housewife and her family in the dream. And the good clean china. I never thought about it before, but the plates were all clean, not like any thanksgiving meal I’ve been involved in.”
“It’s the same picture, you’re just thinking of the more colloquial name for it.” Bev said “And yes, the clean plates are intentionally painted that way, part of the symbolism Rockwell worked into the painting. It’s one of his most iconic works, and has been parodied so often the chances are you’ve seen one almost exactly like what your subconscious brought into the dream, even if you don’t remember. So your subconscious is trying to put being trapped in a burning aircraft into perspective, rummages around and comes up with a roasted turkey analogy, which is linked to the parody of Rockwell’s painting. This dream is just the combination of a couple of things you’ve already experienced, and isn’t even all that creative.”
“I don’t know about that. It sure freaked me out at the time.”
“And how do you feel about it now?”
Lindsay thought about it. By approaching the dream from an abstract, more clinical point of view instead of dealing with it surprising her in her sleep, she was able to recall the dream without it bothering her that much.
. “Okay, I guess. Better than I thought I would. I don’t see how it results from any insecurities I have though.”
“It doesn’t.” Bev said. “Insecurities are only one thing that can trigger a nightmare. Sometimes, like in yours, it’s your subconscious not being able to understand what’s going on. Talking about them helps. Dreams and nightmares can be pretty devastating, and it’s tempting to stuff them into a dark closet and hope you never see them again. Much better to drag them out in the light, shake the dust and wrapping paper off, and see what they’re made of..
“You know” said Colleen, exhibiting that sudden leap of logic that the inebriated are blessed with, “We’re probably piling up a shitload of subconscious symbolism with this game.”
“You’re probably right. And your point is?”
Lindsay’s going to have to let me know what her subconscious comes up with when her and that boyfriend of hers have their first fight.”
“He’s not my boyfriend.”
“It will probably something with machine guns, probably. Or getting bombed. Hey, maybe like something from a Quentin Tarantino movie.”
“Colleen!” Said Bev sternly
“He’s not my boyfriend.” Insisted Lindsay.
“Not even after your date to shoot pool the other night?”
“We didn’t go.”
“Oh, why not.
“Because I was dead, remember.” Lindsay said. It came out harsher than she meant it to, but she didn’t want to admit that it bothered her. “And now he won’t return my calls.” She said angrily.
“Lindsay,” Bev said slowly “He was shot down the day before you were. And he hasn’t re-spawned yet. Didn’t anyone tell you? He’s MIA.”

It had been a lousy day for hunting. All those Russian planes that had been travelling in swarms lately seemed to have been grounded. The one patrol they had made contact with consisted of only six planes. To their surprise the Russians ignored the obvious bad odds, engaging recklessly but fighting so poorly that they had all six been shot down in a space of three minutes.

To fill in the time they had attacked a train depot that the bombers hadn’t yet taken out. Probably not the best idea, Lindsay had come away from that with major control damage, which was why she was dressed and serving tonight. She’d barely made it back to the airbase as it was, so the crash landing hadn’t really been her fault. Still, as Lana-Raye said, any crash landing you can walk away from still puts you behind the bar.
Grumbling, but mildly since they’d all agreed to the rule and had stuck to it, Lindsay had donned the Dirndl Kjole and took her place behind the bar for the night. The new bar had been Bev’s contribution. She’d argued that if they were going to have a bartender they needed an actual bar to tend. So the big trestle table had been tossed and the counter pulled away from the wall and turned around. A snazzy front had been fashioned from the cowl of a LaGG that Addison had shot down nearby. Someone had dug up a few stools from some where to put in front, and the cozy self serve bar had turned into a cozy bar with service.

Tonight, it was almost closing time, and Lana-Raye had just ordered the last round when the air raid siren started its mournful howl.

Someone playing a joke was Lindsay’s first thought, looking around. Of the group, only Lorraine and Linda were absent, having left to go to the washroom earlier. Neither of them were the type to pull this kind of prank though. Addison, quicker on the uptake, went tearing out of the tent towards the airfield as the rest of them exchanged baffled looks. Then they heard the cough of engines starting up by the hangers. “Oh shit” the Colonel said, putting a voice to what they were all coming to realize, “We’re under attack”!

Now they could hear the engines of approaching aircraft.
An explosion rocked the camp as they ran out the door. As they all dived for cover as rocks and dirt rained down on them. Several more explosions quickly followed the first, further away towards the airfield. When they picked themselves up they could see several fires burning by the hangers. Two aircraft were rolling down the runway, attempting to take off even as they came under enemy fire. A third, less luckier plane lay crumpled in the middle of the runway, broken and on fire. Even as they watched it exploded, sending a ball of flame skyward. Then three Russians swooped over the compound, strafing the tents and barracks and causing the group to dive for cover again.

“Listen up”! The Colonel yelled. “Everybody grab a buddy and head for the motor pool. Take a jeep and head for the 104th”.
“What about our planes”? Yelled Colleen.
“Forget them”! They all ducked as another group of planes roared overhead.
“Even if they were still in one piece you’d never get a chance to take off. We’re sitting ducks”. Running in low crouches, the girls started towards the motor pool, diving for cover each time the Russians swooped over the compound.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Another day, another mission gone wrong.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
There was another explosion, huge this time. One of the bombs must have hit the fuel depot. Lindsay watched the huge fireball, so bright she could see two of the attacking aircraft illuminated by the flare of light. As she watched the flames roll upward, she started to get mad. Her long promised Folker 190 had just been delivered yesterday, and now the place her shiny new plane was parked was an inferno of burning fuel and wreckage. And it was still being bombed.

Changing course she sprinted over to an AA gun emplacement, vaulting over the sand bags and onto the gun platform in one smooth movement.
“What are you doing”, screamed Bev.
“If those bastards want to blow up my plane, they’re gonna pay the price”! Lindsay shouted back. “I’ll be dammed if I’m going to let those bastards have a free run”.
“But the Colonel said…”
“Go”, Lindsay shouted back, “You can pick me up on the way past”.
“She’s gonna kill you, you know that”! Bev yelled as she ran.

“Well, maybe I’ll get lucky and she won’t have to” muttered Lindsay as she pulled the camo netting off and fed an ammo belt into the machine gun. Cocked and ready, she waited for the next group of planes to make a pass. The wait seemed both longer than it should have, and at the same took no time at all before two Russians came in low, strafing down the line of damaged but not yet burning planes. Lindsay centered the sight ahead of the lead plane and pulled the trigger, holding the gun steady. Not chasing the target, instead letting the planes fly themselves through the stream of tracer and lead. Both planes went down, one crashing into the parked planes and setting them on fire, the other cart wheeling across what was left of the runway.

Lindsay hunkered down, scanning the dark sky for the planes she could hear over the roar and crackle of the flames. Something came roaring past overhead, something she couldn’t see in the smoke and darkness. She could hear the scream of engines and cannon fire overhead. Moments later she saw red tracer and knew at least one of their BF109’s had made it off the ground. Whoever it was faced some steep odds that were definitely not in their favor; she saw at least three groups of white tracer crisscross that same part of the sky. She swung the gun around, sighting on that patch of sky. Just as she’d suspected, three dark objects came screaming out of it towards her. She let the first two roar past unmolested, not sure who was who, targeting instead the third trailing behind which was firing the white tracer the Russians were so fond of, turning and firing upwards into the belly as it roared overhead. She was rewarded by a dark plume of smoke, almost impossible to see against the night air, and flames that burst to life along the fuselage. As the burning plane soared up and away one of the other two planes slam into the ground and exploded; the other vanished into the darkness above.

Whatever side controlled the plane that had gone down she didn’t know. She could only hope it was an enemy. Then another aircraft came roaring in, strafing Lindsay’s position and blowing up a fuel truck behind her. This one she barely had time to swing the gun around for, and most of the shells went wild of her target. Behind her the burning truck bathed her area with light from the flames. Still, the tracer had its effect and the plane veered off. Lindsay targeted the tail of the escaping fighter and held the trigger until the last of the belt fed through and the gun jammed. She was out of ammo.

There was another belt, down in the pit. Normally a second gunner would have passed the belt up to her so she could feed it into the gun and keep going. Without a second gunner she’d have to climb down and fetch the belt it herself, a move that would eat up precious time. Time she didn’t have. With the glare of light of the burning truck turning her position into a brightly lit defenseless target, Lindsay decided it was time for a strategic withdrawal.

Shoving the gun aside she ducked under the spinning muzzle and jumped from the gun platform, running for the cover of the darkness between the rows of tents. In the distance she could hear a jeep approaching, the driver honking the horn wildly, so she ran towards it. Another aircraft came roaring overhead just she reached the edges of the tents, and she barely had time to throw herself flat on the ground when the world exploded around her.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Now you've made me angry!

choices: No! She can't be dead. She just can't be!
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Bev was right about the Colonel being mad when she hadn’t shown up with Lindsay as was expected, but there was nothing she could do, really. Lorraine and Linda were also missing. Then Addison showed up, saying at least one of those two had gotten their plane off the ground during the attack. Maybe even both. She tried to take off herself but had been caught in the strafing and had barely escaped before her plane blew up.

Addison, Colleen, and Lana-Raye piled into one of the jeeps and took off, headed for the dark road away from the airfield, while Leslie and Bev took a second jeep and headed back to pick up Lindsay. They were just in time to see a Russian IL-2 race overhead being chased by one of their 109s, that was in turn being fired on by a second Russian IL-2. As the three planes passed over the line of tents red tracer rose from the ground and set the trailing Russian on fire, just as cannon fire from the 109 tore the wings of the lead aircraft. “That’s Lindsay, on the ground” Bev yelled and pointed, as the jeep tore across the open field back towards the compound.

The stream of tracer had caught the attention of other attacking aircraft, and they could only watch helplessly as another fighter came roaring out of the night sky, strafing the gun position. A ball of fire rose into the air, but the red tracer rising from behind the tents after the plane told them that Lindsay was still alive and still shooting.
“Shit” the Colonel swore as she floored the jeep and hammered on the horn. Couldn’t that girl see the tracer is making her a target? They were still about 100 meters away, and could now clearly see to see the machine gun silhouetted in the light of the burning truck behind it; the long barrel slowly rotating as it searched for it’s next target. The colonel hit the horn again, letting Lindsay know her ride was coming.

Then the Russian bomb hit, blowing the position to smithereens.

The Colonel hit the brakes, skidding the jeep to a stop while Bev grabbed a hold of the windshield and stood up. They stared at the smoking crater for a long moment in shock and disbelief. Then another fighter roared by overhead, and the Colonel let forth a long string of very passionate curses as she jammed the jeep into gear and spun the wheel, fish tailing the jeep around and speeding them to safety away from the attack. Away from the smoking crater that was all that remained of the machine gun Lindsay had occupied moments before.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: And she's dead?

choices: Things always look better the next day.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
It was a wild ride as Bev and the Colonel fled across the dark open fields, away from the fighting to safety.
Open fields that looked as smooth as silk from 100 meters, in reality contained hidden potholes and ruts that jarred and bounced the little jeep, and more than once they were tossed into the air and almost up ended on landing. The Colonel couldn’t risk using the lights, and fought a constant battle with her foot on the accelerator, balancing the need to move as fast as possible with the need to not wreck their only means of escape. At last they made it to the road, and the ride became a lot smoother. The Colonel still refused to turn on the headlights, fearing that even with the glare shrouds covering them the light created would stand out against the pitch black night and make them an easy target for the hunting aircraft.

Eventually they made it to the 104th . The other refugees from the 83rd and 123rd had arrived earlier, judging by the state of high alert they found the base in.
Eventually, they found the rest of their squad, grouped around a table in the mess. Drinking coffee and staring into space, talking in low tones. The news about Lindsay wasn’t a real surprise. The group had figured it out when they saw Leslie and Bev come in without her. Someone wondered when Lorraine and Linda would be joining them, but for the most part the talked about inconsequential things. Avoiding talking about anything that reminded them of just how badly the Russians had hurt them.

After a long while Linda and Lorraine turned up, having managed to bring in their aircraft relatively unscathed. They had also managed to take out some of the enemy aircraft. Lorraine had scored two, Linda with three. Balanced against the loss of their planes on the ground, well,. Nobody felt much like talking. After a while the Colonel arranged for some temporary billets, and they went to bed.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: Oh yeah, she's dead.

choices: The 123rd is done, the survivors join the 104th
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Leslie sat grimly on the hood of her jeep, parked in the middle of what had been the 123rd’s parade ground. The others were poking around in the smoldering wreckage, looking for anything that hadn’t been wrecked or burned. Lindsay didn’t bother. Everything she would have wanted had been in her office at the hanger. An office that currently consisted of two charred upright timbers and a heap of twisted smoldering metal. While the rest of them dug around to see if there was anything to salvaged, she sat and stared at the rising smoke.

Eventually the others gave up and headed back to where the two jeeps, the sum total of the 123rd's surviving equipment, were parked.

“I can’t believe nothing survived” Leslie said. “I mean, it was quite the fight, and we were taken by surprise, sure. But there weren’t that many enemy aircraft. And usually there’s something that doesn’t get shot up.”

“That’s because it wasn’t just aircraft.” Lana-Raye said “The place is covered in tire tracks and boot prints. Someone was here before we were. Several trucks worth of someones, judging from the number of prints.”

“What, you’re saying ground troops came in and finished the job.”

“More than likely looted the place first. Stuff isn’t just burnt and wrecked. A lot of it is missing. See the Gasthus?”
Where the Gasthus had stood was now only a flat burnt space, with bits of canvas and wood embers smoldered in the ashes.

“The Jukebox” Exclaimed Colleen, realizing what Lana-Raye was telling them.
“What about the Jukebox?” Addison asked.

“The jukebox had this large metal frame inside, and a bunch of gears and such. It wouldn’t have burnt up. It’s gone. And the ice box, and the bar. Whoever was driving the trucks must have taken it”

“Exactly.” Lana-Raye said, pleased at Colleen’s quick uptake “Looters. They swept into camp, probably moments after the bombing stopped, took everything of value, then burned what was left.”

“Anything of Value?” Addison asked “Like our jukebox?”

“Sure!” Colleen threw in “Why not? Russians like to get down too. I’ll bet they’re plugging nickels into it even as we sit here talking about it.”

“Can’t say as I blame them.” Lorraine added “Nothing like boogieing down to help you relax.”

“I’m afraid the Jukebox is the least of our worries.” Lana-Raye said flatly.

“Yeah, they got the Bar and the icebox too.”

“No," Lana-Raye said "I’m talking about the aircraft. We had 10 brand new 190’s sitting in the hanger. How much you want to bet that they’re now sitting in a Russian hanger having red stars added to the wings.”

“Well, this just gets better and better!” Lorraine sighed. “We got bombed, beaten, and looted.” Lorraine said with a sigh. “Then they burned what’s left to the ground. And to top it off you're saying we're going up against our own fighters. So what do we do now?”

“We start again.” Said Leslie firmly, falling back into her commanding officer role. “Lets move out!” With that she climbed into the jeep and started it up. The others followed suit.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: It just gets worse.

choices: They discover that re-spawning isn't the only thing gone wrong.
But what is the real reason Lindsay hasn't re-spawned?
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“Can I ask you a question.” Leslie said suddenly, breaking the sullen silence hanging over the temporary office she’d set up in the corner of a tool shed. What was left of the 123rd had set themselves up on a small airfield they had commandeered. More of a training field that an operational airbase, but it would do until they were able to set up operations on a proper airfield, if they ever did.

Bev looked up from the cup of whisky she’d been nursing. “I assume that’s why you asked me to come over.” She said. “It seems to me that when you invite several people over it’s a party, but when it’s just me and Lana it’s because you have something on your mind.”

“Am I that obvious?” Leslie looked up, sloppily setting her own glass aside for the moment.

Bev shook her head. “Only on occasion. This time I know something’s bothering you. If you need to talk, I’m here. So spill it already.”

Leslie smiled grimly. “It’s this thing about Lindsay." she said, words slurring slightly as she spoke "Her dying on us the other day. It was pretty traumatic.”

I know” Bev said. “I was there, remember.”

“Only too well.” Leslie said, picking up her glass and downing it in one gulp. “And that’s the thing. The three of us have been playing these games for what, two years?”

“Closer to three. Ever since we all got together and bought those surplus VR helmets from the D.O.D contractor that boyfriend of yours worked for.”

“Thanks for bringing him up.” Leslie said as she poured herself another two fingers of whiskey “Now I have two reasons to get drunk.”

“Hey, if you need a reason to get drunk I can come up with a lot more. Anyway, I’m sure there was a point to that question.”

“Yeah, there was a point. And it had to do with Lindsay, and this SIM. Have you noticed just how real this SIM is?”

“Sure. I mean, we all have. The game is modeled to give us as realistic an experience as possible, right. What about it?”

Leslie took a sip from her glass as she spoke “I’ve been thinking about something Lindsay said to me a couple of days after she joined us. She said, who really needs to feel a drop of pee run down their leg? At the time I thought it was an odd thing for her to say, don’t you think?”

“Maybe.” Bev said “She may have still been trying to get a handle on all the little hygiene things a woman needs to know.”

“She was. And she was referring to the incredible detail in which everything around us is modeled. Tiny details that you wouldn’t think are necessary, yet are there, just in case you notice them. Tiny inconsequential things. A bead of sweat on the end of your nose. The way your bra strap gets sweat built up under it, or a hang nail catches on your glove. "

“So they’ve put a lot of effort into making the SIM as real as possible.” Bev shrugged “Do you think there’s a problem with that?”

“The problem” Leslie said, “Is maybe it has become too real. It’s so real it’s starting to mess with my mind. I mean, I know it’s just a game, yet Lindsay was blown to smithereens in front of me, and I can’t get past it.” She took another drink, finishing her glass again. “Why am I thinking that way? It’s just a game, isn’t it? I shouldn’t feel this sense of loss. I should be all ‘Dude, you really got yourself pwned that time’, not staring at a whisky bottle wondering why it’s not helping me feel better.”
She picked up the bottle to pour herself another drink, then thought better of it.
“Bev, you’re the psychologist here. What’s happening?”

“You know as well as I do I’m no psychologist. That’s just our inside joke because of the semester I spent at Berkley. Linda or Allison are just as qualified.”

“Yea, but unlike those two, you listen.”

“Linda listens too.”

“Linda makes me uncomfortable for some reason. Besides, you’re my friend.”

“We’re all your friends. Someday you’ll understand that.”

“So you say. And I lost one of those friends today.”

“She’ll be back.”

“Will she?” Leslie closed her eyes and sighed. “It’s been two days now. If she was coming back she should have re-spawned by now.”

“Sometimes MIA’s take a bit longer.”

“She’s not MIA. She’s dead. She was blown to pieces right in front of me. If she was going to re-spawn she would have by now. I’m just afraid that, well…”

“Afraid of what?” Lana-Raye asked.

“You’ve heard what they say about SIMS? About what happens if a SIM gets too real?”

Lana-Raye and Bev just looked at each other, neither of them had a clue what Leslie was talking about.

“Someone once said that, If you die in the game you die in real life.”

“Pretty sure that’s a meme from some cheesy horror flick.” Lana-Raye said “Colleen would know which one if you ask.”

“Those are just rumors.” Bev said “Urban legends. Things people make up to tell each other. Nobody believes them.”

“Maybe. But what if they’re not? What if all those MIAs aren’t showing up because they’re not MIA, they’re really dead?”

“That’s nonsense. We’ve all died and come back.”

“But what if it takes a really brutal death to trigger it. Something horrible like been blown to bits?”

“More horrible than drowning?” Bev asked bluntly “Or being trapped and burnt to death? Or being sliced to ribbons by a plate glass window? Because that’s just a few ways Lindsay has died, and she always came back. If you really think about it, being blown to bits would be rather painless. At least it’s instantaneous.”

“Well, maybe it’s something else that triggers it.” Leslie said taking a pull straight from the bottle she’d been holding on to during the entire conversation.

“You’re really determined to believe the game is out to get us, aren’t you.” Bev said softly.

“I’m just trying to make sense of this. Of Lindsay’s death. Of this war that never seems to go anywhere. And why is the game re-equip mechanism so screwed up. Did you know that as of this morning the 83rd now has one and a half bombers for every pilot? And we have two fighters each in the new hangers?”
Hangers was a generous term to apply to the Camouflage netting and low mounds of dirt that served as a poor windbreak around three sides of each parked aircraft. Still, the news caught both the women by surprise.

“Wasn’t that something to do with having them all destroyed in the raid?” Lana-Ray asked.

“You think? By rights we should have gotten one plane each. That was in the rules.” Leslie said, waving her bottle in the direction of the hangers “I’m telling you someone’s messing with the game mechanics.”

“Have you told the System admins?” Bev asked.

“I’ve tried.” Leslie said “You can’t get a hold of them. You can’t get a hold of anybody.” She took another pull from the bottle, then sat in the battered chair behind her desk. Well not so much sat as fell back into the chair so suddenly it was like she collapsed. She rested her head on one hand, still holding the bottle. “I… Well.. Bev, Lana… I think we’re screwed.” She looked up at them, her face almost white. “I think we’re really and truly trapped here.”

Lana-Ray and Bev looked at each other, then Bev reached over and pried the bottle out of Leslies’ hand. It didn’t take that much effort “I think maybe you’re just a little too deep into that bottle to talk about this right now.” She said “Why don’t we all go to bed and see how things look in the morning. Maybe Lindsay will be back by then.”

The two friends exchanged a worried look. Leslie was far drunker than either of them had seen her in a long time. Whatever background information she had, and they were sure there was a lot more to it than what she had let slip, that information was worrying the usually unflappable Colonel. That in turn worried her friends. By mutual agreement they decided not to say anything to the others until they were able to talk more when Leslie was sober. Having decided that, they helped her into the communal barrack room they all shared now and put her to bed.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: We will rebuild again.

choices: Dive behind the bar for the cache of weapons kept there
Don't move, he's got the drop on you.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Lindsay wasn’t sure how long she was out. Just that the attack seemed to be over when she groggily picked herself up. That, and her head hurt like hell. And there was a ringing in one ear, the sound kind of fuzzy on that side. With the other ear she could clearly hear the crackle of flames from the burning hangers and an occasional small pop as something burst.

As she dusted off the dirt and small rocks that covered her she looked around, trying to assess the damage. The hangers were gone, along with her new Folker. And anyone else’s aircraft too, she supposed. The light of the burning wreckage, where the fires hadn’t burned themselves out yet, showed that quite clearly.

There were a lot of fires still burning over at the section of the airfield the 83th called home up until now. Most of their part of the compound was flattened.

Her group had been spared the worst of the damage. Other than the hangers, most of the compound of the 127th was still standing, including their generator shed. She could tell because of the light leaking out from under the black-out curtains on the windows the Gasthaus, telling her that the lights were still on. Nothing else stirred. As far as she could tell, she was alone.

Figuring the Colonel and the girls would be back any time, and that the Gasthaus was as good a place to wait as any, she headed over there.
Inside there was no real damage to be seen. One of the tables had been knocked over, and the round Lana-Raye had ordered was spilled all over the bar, a coating of dust covering the sticky liquid. Other than that, and the acrid smell of burning that permeated the air, from inside it was as if the attack had never happened.

Lindsay stood the table up, wiped it, then sat herself on the stool behind the bar as she cleaned that up too. She was still pretty dazed from the explosion, functioning mostly on autopilot. Mostly cleaning to keep herself occupied while wincing and wondering where the bruises on her back had come from, and why her head hurt so much. She was just finished cleaning the sticky goo off the bar and wiping it dry, and thinking that maybe she should have another drink herself, strictly for medicinal reasons, when she heard the sounds of truck brakes and shouting outside. Half expecting it to be the Colonel or one of the other girls she turned towards the door, trying and failing to think of something witty or sarcastic to say when the door slammed open and the first soldier burst in.

The witty retort she’d been failing to think of vanishing in the shock of his entrance. A man in the Gasthaus? Could he not see the sign? The soldier shouted something unintelligible, pointing a rifle directly at her. Too late, Lindsay realized the soldier was wearing a Russian uniform.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: You Re-spawn 24 hours after you die.

choices: Is that a Machine Pistol in your pocket, or are you just happy to see me?
Now Serving in The mad Cow Bar and Grill...
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Two more soldiers appeared in the doorway, guns leveled. Lindsay froze, not sure what to say. Once again the soldier shouted something, probably in Russian would be her guess, then gestured with the rifle.

Later on, Lindsay would swear that something, perhaps the true spirit of the Dirndl Kjole, took over and guided her actions. That was the only reasonable explanation she could think of. She certainly wasn’t mentally capable of coming up with the plan, not still concussed as she was from the explosion. Whatever the reason, Lindsay waved the rag she was holding towards a table, then picked up a serving tray. Putting on her cheesiest false smile she said “Welcome to the Mad Cow Bar gentlemen. What can I get you”?

Whatever the soldiers had been expecting, it obviously wasn’t being invited to sit down at the bar. The three soldiers looked at each other uncertainly, lowering their rifles and looking around. Two of them warily stood guard the door while the first one carefully poked around, making sure there were no enemy soldiers hiding under the tables or behind the bar. Or in the icebox.

“Hey! Get out of there!” Lindsay said loudly. Not that she was going to try and stop him if he insisted, but it was something a barmaid would say, right? It felt right so she went with it. She bustled over and shooed him away from the icebox, and to her surprise he complied meekly. The three soldiers gathered in a huddle by the door and stood there, talking. Lindsay didn’t speak Russian, so she had no idea what they were saying, but they weren’t pointing the guns at her any more so she figured it was good.

One of the soldiers left, leaving the two standing at the door awkwardly watching her and talking between them selves. She asked them again if they’d like something to drink, not really expecting an answer, and getting none. Never the less, more to keep busy than anything else, she loaded a tray with beer mugs, just in case.

The soldier reappeared, this time with an officer in tow. Lindsay could tell he was an officer because he had a huge bushy beard, a much warmer looking heavy coat with a fancy hat, and grumpier attitude than the soldiers meekly standing in the doorway. This time when she offered the drink tray he slapped it aside, spilling the mugs to the floor. Lindsay let out an indignant “Hey” which he ignored, turning instead and questioning the three men at the door.

There was a lengthy exchange in Russian, during which the officer never took his eyes off her. For her part she stood there, trying her best to think of what an NPC barmaid would do, and deciding it would be something like putting clasping her hands together and swaying slightly as she stood.

The officer, obviously tired of asking his men questions they didn’t know the answers to, decided that a better use of his time would be to ask a barmaid questions she couldn’t understand. He stalked up to her, so close she could almost feel the whiskers of the massive bushy beard brush against her. Not using his inside voice he said something straight into her face.

Obviously the perks of being an officer stopped at including a tooth brush in the basic hygiene kit. Gagging at his breath and unable to stop herself, she turned her head and tried to push him away. Before she realized what happened he cuffed the side of her head, not too hard, but still hard enough she lost her balance and stumbled back a step and had to grab the edge of a table to stop from falling. Moving forward, the officer leaned forward and yelled something, as if he was going to break the language barrier with shear volume of voice. With as much dignity as she could muster, Lindsay picked herself up an then, hoping she wasn’t making a big mistake but not really caring, haughtily turned her back to the glowering man, deliberately walking the short distance to the bar until a rattle of guns being cocked came from behind her. She stood stock still for a moment, and when the half expected being shot from behind didn’t happen, she glared over her shoulder at the three men, standing watching her over their aimed rifles, then back at the officer who was glowering at her over his bushy beard. Then, slowly and as deliberately as she could, knowing it was probably a mistake, she reached up.

And turned off the open sign. Then she sat down on a bar stool with her arms folded, watching to see what they’d do.

For a moment nobody moved, then the officer turned and spoke, practically spitting in disdain. The soldiers sheepishly looked at each other and shrugged. The officer cuffed one of the men on the ear and stalked out, obviously on his way to take care of more officery things, leaving the problem of the uncooperative bar maid in the hands of his minions.

The three of them spoke for a couple of minutes, one looking out the door as if expecting the officer back at any time, while the other talked rapidly to the third, obviously trying the talk him into something he wasn’t too keen on. Lindsay watched them for a couple of minutes, then picked up her rag and cleaned up the spilled beer mugs. As she was mopping the last of it up she heard a rattle from the counter, so turned and found the more talkative one leaning over the bar, trying to help himself to the contents of the icebox.

“No Touchy” she said, running over and slapping his hand away. The soldier glared at her and picked up the rifle he’d leaned against a table. Before he did anything else though his buddy said something to him and he paused, then looked at her questioningly. For her part she folded her arms and glared at him from in front of the bar. Looking back at his buddy he engaged in another exchange of undecipherable Russian, then looked back at where Lindsay stood, blocking access to the bar and icebox. Shrugging, he laid the rifle on the table, then dug into his pocket and offered up a crumpled bill of some sort.
Okay, Lindsay thought, wheels turning in her head. Maybe there was a way out of this mess after all.
She looked at the bill as if studying it, then shook her head, holding up two fingers.
After a moment, the soldier digs another bill out of his pocket.

Lindsay held the two bills up to the light, studying them. The bills looked like money. She had no idea if they were or not, or even how much was there. But that’s something a bar maid would do, right? And she was going for effect at this point anyway, wondering how far she should go. Before she could say anything the second soldier pressed another four bills into her hand, gesturing at the spilled beer mugs.

Okay, she thought. There’s still a good chance I’ll get shot, OR this just might keep me alive long enough to escape.
Deliberately, she folded those bills and tucked them into her cleavage. As the man at the door hooted with laughter she turned the bar light back on, then reached into the ice box and pulled him out a beer.

It seemed they had reached a basic trade agreement.

The soldier grinned, and chugged down the beer in one go, then belched and held up another two bills. After swapping them for another beer Lindsay tucked these bills into the shoe box under the bar that served the 127rd as their cash register. There was a brief discussion from the two soldiers at the door. One of them kept a nervous look out while the other, the one that had laughed out loud at Lindsay stashing her ‘tip’, leaned his rifle against a table and pulled out a couple of bills of his own.
Finishing his second beer at a more sedate pace, soldier #1 picked up his rifle and after a brief word with the one nervously keeping watch, headed out the door.

A few minutes later a couple more soldiers trickled in, looked around, and took over a table. At first they seemed to expect her to know what they wanted, and were quite irritated that she couldn’t understand them. Finally, by pointing and holding up fingers, she finally got them to understand the very simple ordering process. If they wanted a beer. They held up two bills. If they wanted a shot of something harder, it was three bills. Except for the good stuff in the center cabinet. Those were 4 bills a shot. Once that was established things ran fairly smooth after that.

More soldiers trickled in and the place got a little rowdier. Not being able to speak the language she relied a lot on gestures and pantomime. What some of the soldiers pantomimed back sometimes was pretty crude, but thankfully no one took it any further. A couple tried, at first, sneaking a quick grab of her butt as she took their order, but she slapped the hands away and that was as far as it went. At least at first. Later on a couple of the drunker men would try to take it a bit further, but surprisingly were shut down by their comrades, who obviously become quite fond of the novelty of having a captured German server girl waiting on them. Lindsay did make up one more rule, after she caught one of them intentionally distracting her while his partner tried to help himself to the icebox. Anyone touches the ice box but her, and she would shut the bar down. This made Mister Clever and his partner a little less than popular, but the crowd of soldiers seemed for the most part to side with her.

Actually, she was quite surprised that she was getting away with as much as she was. In a room packed with enemy soldiers she was feeling no more threatened than she did that summer when she’d done a stint working as a restaurant server. Maybe this is what being a waitress at Hooters feels like, she thought. The men staring and drooling over her, and tipping poorly. Part of that she was sure, was that Russian soldiers didn’t get paid a lot. And a big part of it was also Lindsay’s fault. There was no ‘keep the change’, seeing as the established price was two bills, any kind (because she had no idea what Russian currency looked like) and Lindsay wasn’t giving any back. But often when she delivered the drinks one of the men would slide an extra bill across the table. Then she realized she kept forgetting and putting those tips in with the general cash, so she started tucking the tips into her bra, much to the delight of the soldiers, who immediately started tipping more often.

Then the officer came back in and started shouting.

The officer glared at Lindsay, then stalked over the bar sign, reached up, and turned it off, much like Lindsay had at their first meeting.
Some of the men scrambled immediately to their feet and grabbed their weapons. Others, more nonchalantly took the time to toss back the remainder of their drinks.

In less that five minutes all the men had left. Lindsay followed the last of them to the door., peaking out to see what they were up to.

All the Russian trucks were lined up outside, being loaded with crates and barrels looted from various tents. Briefly Lindsay wondered if now was the time to sneak away, while they were distracted. Unfortunately, that same officer and the three guards were standing at the back of a truck, right in front of her, discussing something. Then they turned and came back towards the Gasthus. Lindsay ducked back inside when she saw them heading her way.

When they reached the door she was back behind the bar, trying to look like she was not one of the enemy looking for a chance to escape, but instead a mere bar maid cleaning up. The guise was still working apparently, as the men paid her no notice. Instead, two of them walked over to the jukebox and started pulling it away from the wall.

“Hey” Lindsay shouted, bustling over to stop them. She stopped though, when the officer pulled out his pistol and aimed it at her head. One of the soldiers shouted something, then grabbed the officers arm. There was a brief discussion between the two, then the officer stalked over to the beer cooler and opened it. Lindsay started to protest, then stopped when he pointed the gun at her.

The officer rummaged around in the ice for a bit, then came back, empty handed. The soldier who had stopped him from shooting Lindsay (there was no doubt in her mind that’s what would have happened had he not intervened) gave him an I told you so look, then pulled two bills out of his pocket and laid them on the table.

Lindsay couldn’t figure out what was happening, and only looked at the bills confused. The officer pointed to the bills with the muzzle of his pistol, then at the ice box. Slowly, not sure of what was going on, Lindsay pulled a beer out of the icebox and gave it to him, automatically scooping up the bills for payment. At this, the officer only grunted, and instead of drinking put the un-opened beer into his pocket. Then he spoke to the soldier.

More soldiers appeared and started stripping the Gasthaus of its furnishings, heedless of Lindsay’s protests. The bar, icebox, jukebox, tables, chairs, and almost anything else that wasn’t nailed down too solidly was loaded into the back of the waiting truck, herself included.

She wasn’t asked nicely either. Instead two of the soldiers loading proceeded to roughly tie her hands behind her back, then forcing a gag in her mouth to silence her when she protested at being so rudely handled. Of course one of them took a few additional liberties as well, putting his hands in places they needn’t be in order to lift her into the truck with the rest of the looted furnishings.

Minutes later the convoy headed off into the night, destined for the Russian lines.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Larry stood on the truck’s running board, waiting for the convoy to move out of the compound. As soon as the last of them had passed his position he aimed his flare gun at the row of tents and fired. Of course, the tent to the left of the one he had been aiming at burst into flames, but that didn’t matter. They had emptied several fuel cans earlier, and the fire spread rapidly along the lines of spilled gasoline until the whole camp was ablaze, flames shooting high into the night. With a grunt of satisfaction Larry swung himself up into the cab and settled into the passenger seat.

“Now that’s a beautiful sight!” laughed the driver as he jammed the truck into gear and started after the rest of the convoy. They could just make out the taillights of the rest of the trucks in the distance, but the driver was in no hurry, casting lingering glances into the mirror until the blaze disappeared behind a hill. Only then did he speed up enough to eventually catch up with the rest of the convoy.
It was just the way his luck was running that the driver was that one weird guy every outfit has. Far too fond of fire and explosions, and far short of conversation about anything that didn’t include them. To him the night’s raid had been a success, in spite of Larry’s complaining. As soon as he realized that he and Larry had completely different views of how the raid went he shut up and just drove.

That was okay with Larry. He wasn’t much in the mood for talking right now. In his opinion the raid was a complete FUBAR, and he was planning what he was going to say to the commander about just how badly the whole mess had been organized. Sometimes the incompetence of the people in charge was irritation. At other times, like tonight, it was so outstanding as to be award winning, if there was such a category, with it’s little trophies and ribbons and better luck next time certificates. Larry wondered who’s name would be engraved on the trophy for tonight’s fiasco.
.
The Commander would have his vote, he decided, his thought going back to the day when he’d gone into Commanders office to give him a piece of his mind and instead had been talked into going along with a raiding plan.

The commander looked up when Larry knocked.
“Come in, Comrade Ivontabitch,” the commander said, deliberately mocking the phrasing Larry was fond of using. “What seems to be on your mind?” Obviously the tone of the meeting was already set. Still, Larry forged ahead, wanting to get the grievances he and his friends had out in the open.

“This game sucks!” he said, coming right to the point. “Me and my friends are all pilots. We didn’t sign up to be infantry and prison guards. We signed up on ‘Battle for Volgograd’ because it was air combat. Only for the last two weeks we’ve done nothing sit around and guard prisoners. If we wanted that we would have joined the ‘Called to Battle Duty’ server.

The commander just shook his head with a sad smile. “You must realize that at this point in the war our side faced severe equipment shortages. And since you lost your entire flight when you messed up your last bombing mission, we don’t have the planes for you to fly right now. That’s just the realism built into the game.”

Larry wasn’t buying it “I don’t care shit about realism.” He said “We signed up on an air combat game server, expecting to fly air combat. Instead of flying we’re guarding prisoners and slogging through mud to loot bombed out trucks and supply trains. The closest thing we’ve been to a fucking airplane in the last week is watching the Germans fly patrol overhead.”

The commander’s smile changed. “You know I can’t issue equipment I don’t have. But, if you and your friends are interested, I just may have the solution to this.”

The commander’s solution was simple. Since currently the Russian supply of equipment was so limited as to be almost non existent, they would re-equip by raiding the enemy. Which was how Larry and the rest of Bulldog Squadron ended up bouncing around their way across the frozen countryside in the back of a transport truck. The Bulldogs, as well as about 20 other pilots turned grunts in four additional trucks, had gone through their meager equipment and kitted themselves out as best as they could for the mission. Larry hated the cold, so he wore his warmest coat and hat. Others went for mobility and dressed accordingly.

Their target, a previously unmolested German airfield, was fairly small; Only about two dozen bombers and half as many fighters, relatively unprotected. It was also close enough to their base to make it easy to reach by ground.

The plan was to attack just after the Germans were snuggled into their beds. After the ground force was in position Grizzly Squadron would fly over and drop about half dozen bombs on the maintenance hangers to wake them up and draw them out. Then Bulldog squad, Team Mongoose, The Loosey Goosey’s, and whatever the other two squads were calling themselves would lay down sniper and machine gun on the confused Germans as they came running out to man their planes. Once those were dealt with, they’d mop up, load up all the wounded and captured prisoners into the trucks, then take the German’s fancy planes and fly them back to the Pitomnik airfield to be painted and added to the glorious people’s air force.

It was a good plan, Larry had decided, hiding a happy grin. It promised everything he wanted in a war. Or at least one where he was stuck on the ground. The ambushing of a confused enemy, Wholesale mayhem and slaughter, and a chance to capture and fly the high performance German BF109 that he’d always wound up on the wrong side of. Larry liked the plan so much, he was still grinning when the truck screeched to a stop and they unloaded, not in the dark forest clearing as the briefing had lead him to expect, but in the middle of a tented compound.

His face fell as he and his friends looked around. There was a lot of smoke, and a few fires smoldering in the distance. “What the hell’s going on? He shouted.”

The rest of the men that had been on the truck with him also stood around equally confused. Then someone from the front truck started shouting “Search the tents! Take prisoners!”

Okay, the Germans hadn’t been lured out yet, he decided. That was bad. That meant they were still inside where they had been sleeping. And there was no way in hell they were still asleep after all the noise being made out here. Shit, any moment the shooting would start.

“Don’t just stand there!” Whoever was up in front was screaming. “Search those damned tents already! Capture the survivors”

Larry started directing the men from his truck down the row of tents. Bulldog Squadron cooperated without question, heading towards the tents he indicated. But when he tried to do the same with the others he ran into trouble. Goose Company flatly refused to follow his directions and took off towards the big tent at the far end of the compound. The others, seeing this to mean there was no real command structure, decided it was every man for himself and took of in other directions. Swearing after them had no effect, so Larry turned and headed towards the row of tents that his friends were methodically searching, as the rest of the raid collapsed into a disorganized mêlée of random shouting and door kicking, with the occasional shot ringing out.

The first couple of tents he broke into were empty. Completely. No tables or furniture or anything. Just tent shells along the pathway. The third had a bunch of tables stacked in it, but was otherwise also empty. Before he could break down the door of the forth George came running up.
“We got one Larry” he said excitedly “A prisoner. We got one. Oh Larry, you gotta see the one we got.”

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
George lead Larry to one of the tents they’d been searching. This one was obviously the officers club, judging from the way the tables had been set up. There was a bar made out of an engine cowling, one of theirs by the look of it. Also an icebox, a juke box, lamps, comfortable looking chairs, and a bar maid with big bosoms dressed in the traditional German waitress outfit. Over the bar was a glowing OFFNEN sign. Something about the cheery redness of the lettering lead him to believe it said the bar was open. As he stood there, looking around, the barmaid came up and smiled, asking him something. In German, naturally. Having no idea what she said, he angrily brushed her away and turned back to the rest of Bulldog squad. “Where is the prisoner?” he demanded.

“That’s her”

“What?” Larry looked back in disbelief. “A bar maid?” That’s your prisoner?”

“Yeah!” said George, a stupid grin on his face “Captured at great risk.”

“Great risk?” Larry shook his head “The only great risk here is presenting her to the commander as a prisoner. Where are the others?”

“Still searching, I guess.” George shrugged.”

“I meant the other prisoners!” Larry shouted in annoyance.

George shrugged again, his hands open in an empty gesture. “There are no others.”

“What do you mean there are no others? We’re on an enemy base! How can there not be any others?”

“There’s nobody here!” Greg said as he and Fred came into the tent. “These tents are all empty. Nothing but empty storage shelves.”

“If the tent’s have storage shelves, they’re not empty” Fred put in.

The others looked at him. “Just saying you can’t call something empty if there’s something in it.” He continued. “And not all the storage shelves are empty. Every fifth shelf has a box on it.”

“Yeah,” said Greg. “I looked in a few. They’re full of car parts.”

“We’re on an airbase, so I suspect those would be aircraft parts.” Fred said. “And scattered among them will be the occasional box of universal ammo and maybe a first aid kit. Or a ration pack. That’s how things work in these games.”

“File that under good to know, Fred.” Larry said, not quite sarcastically “If we were in the middle of a pitched tent to tent fire fight. Which we are not.”

“But we could be!” Fred shot back.

“Have any of you heard any gunfire since we got here?”

They all looked at each other. “Now that you mention it…” Greg said.

“The answer is no. The only ones shooting are those boneheads breaking into tents out there. That’s because this whole camp is empty” Larry said, leaping to the most obvious answer. “There’s nothing here but empty tents and this NPC!”

“How do you know she’s an NPC?” George said. “Maybe she’s a player. Wouldn’t that make her a valid prisoner?” At that they all turned to look at the bar maid, still standing where they’d left her in the middle of the room. She was swaying slightly, a vapid look on her face.”

“Sure. Larry spat, his voice a mixture of contempt and sarcasm. “She’s one of their pilots. Probably the squadrons ace player.” His voice rose half an octave in anger “You can tell because that’s the way the Germans always dress when they’re off duty!”

“Larry stalked over to the bar maid. “Hey!” he shouted. “Where’s all the fucking pilots? Huh? Where’s all the fucking planes?”

Not that he expected to get an answer. He was just mad and had to take it out on someone. Mad at the camp for being empty. Mad at the commander who’d sold him on this mission. Mad at himself for being mad.
.
Of course she cringed back, frightened. What did he expect? Still angry, he turned and threw up on hand. He had meant it merely as a dismissive gesture, and was just as surprised as everyone else when he felt it connect.

The bar maid gave a startled cry and fell back, stumbling into the table, grabbing it to stop herself from falling to the floor. Larry stood there, half in shock at what had happened. He had never struck a woman before, no matter how mad he had been. It was just something you didn’t do. Defensively the irrational anger he had at himself for doing this turned towards her. “Your own fault,” he screamed “That’s what you get for standing too close!” Even as he yelled this, Larry knew the words to be false. But they came out, none the less. And like bullets, words fired in anger cannot be recalled.

The anger washed out of Larry at the realization of what he’d done. He’d broken the pact he’d made when he was 10, watching his father and mother fight. Numbly, he watched as the bar maid rose haughtily to her feet, then deliberately turned her back to him and walked over to the bar. Was she going for a weapon? Some instinct for self preservation kicked in and his head cleared. Larry un-holstered his pistol and cocked it, just in case. Behind him he could hear his friends ready their own weapons. Perhaps, there would be a fire fight after all.

Then, she turned and gave him a look that spoke volumes about the stupidity of the situation, of what they were all ready to do. Slowly, deliberately she reached up.

And shut off the ‘OFFNEN’ sign.

Of course, Larry thought, letting out the breath he hadn’t realized he was holding. That’s what she’d do. Probably programmed for that action the instant there was a problem. Turning the light off meant the bar was closed. Then the good little Germans would scurry off to their little beds.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Larry heard his friends at the door laughing. Turning, he yelled at George. “This? This is your prisoner? An NPC barmaid? Better watch she doesn’t do something stupid, like getting you drunk and stealing all your hard earned pay.”

“No problem there, boss.” George said between fits of laughter “I don’t work all that hard for that pay anyway.”

Larry angrily headed for the door. “I want a couple of you to keep an eye on the place.” He said, pausing just inside the door. “From what I’ve seen so far this is the only tent worth looting, and I don’t want the others to lay claim to it. And one of you search the other tents. Maybe there’s something else worth taking back. I’m going to see what’s going on with all those planes we were supposed to be collecting.” With that he pushed open the door and stalked out.

After Larry left, the other three looked at each other for a moment. Then George grinned and said “Now that he brought it up, I could use a drink.”

“I don’t know if we should.” Greg said “Technically we’re still in the middle of an attack.”

“Nonsense.” George replied, looking around “Larry said we’re looting now, and sampling the spoils is a big part of your basic looting process.” He made his way over to the bar. The bar maid was too busy cleaning up the glass from the spilled drink tray to notice him until he started digging through the ice, looking for what was buried inside.

As soon as she noticed him she ran back to the bar, jabbering away, and slapped away the hand he’d dared touch her ice with.

George was shocked, and began to bluster. Before he got started though, Frank let out a laugh. “Threatening her isn’t going to work, you know.” He said.

“What are you talking about? We’re the conquering army. Doesn’t she realize we have the right to do anything we want?”

“I’ve played enough of these games to know that threats only work against Civilians and Criminals. With shop keepers you need to negotiate and barter. Otherwise nothing happens.”

“I don’t know about her being a shop keeper,” George said thoughtfully. “She’s in the middle of a German base here. That says soldier to me.”

This got another chuckle out of Frank. “Sure,” he said, “If you overlook a few minor details, like the short skirt and a corset. And serving beer in what’s obviously some German pub. I’d say there’s a pretty good chance her NPC class is either shop keeper or camp follower.”

“Your reasoning is sound,” George said, rubbing his chin. “But how can you prove it?”

“Offer her money” Frank said “See what happens.”

George pulled a bill out of his pocket, one of the single chervonet ruple bills the men passed around. Not worth a whole lot, it generally took 2 of them to buy you a decent cup of coffee at the company mess. As expected, the woman just frowned at it when he handed it to her, so he handed her another. She stood there, holding them up to the light suspiciously. He sighed and dug out a half dozen more. To his surprise, the woman took the bills, separated out two of them, then tucked the rest into her blouse.

“No way!” He heard Frank laugh from the door as the woman pulled a beer out of the ice box and handed it to him. George just grinned and took a sip of the beer. It was cold, and bitter, and the best thing he’d drank in weeks.

Frank leaned his gun against a table, pulling out a couple of bills of his own.

“Guy’s,” Greg said nervously, looking out the door. “Do you really think we should be doing this?”

“Sure!” George said, belching and holding up another two bills. “Not only do I think it’s a good idea, I think it’s a good idea for all of us.”

“I don’t think the three of us should be getting drunk on duty” Greg stammered nervously.”

“What duty?” George said as he downed the second, taking only slightly longer this time. “We’re looting. And besides, I wasn’t talking about just the three of us.”

“What do you mean by that?” asked Greg

“Watch as I make the Bulldogs the most popular squad on base. I’m going to let the other’s know what a sweet deal we’ve pulled off here.”

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Larry was stalking angrily across the compound, muttering about the unbelievable stupidity of the whole thing. The timing had been screwed up royally. Grizzly squadron had taken off at the same time the trucks left. Of course they were faster and had arrived early, way before the ground troops were in position. And then, instead of blowing up a couple of non essential work sheds like they were supposed to, they had proceeded to bomb the hell out of the base, destroying anything that moved. Planes, trucks, jeeps. If it moved they had hit it. Then they had gone home to bed, leaving only a twisted smoldering scrap yard to greet the loot hungry ground troops who arrived 3 hours later.

The precious planes were twisted junk. All the fuel and ammunition was burnt. Any surviving Germans were long gone, probably loaded up any guns they could carry and moved in with Aunt Gertrude up the road. It looked like the only thing they would be getting out of the raid was whatever they found in that small collection of empty untouched tents they’d started at.

The trucks were sitting there half loaded when he got back from his survey, with only a few men attended them, wandering back and forth and occasionally loading a box into a truck. “Where the hell is everyone?” he shouted.

One of the men pointed. The answer was obvious. Sputtering angrily, he stormed towards the laughter he could hear coming from the tent where the Bulldogs had found the bar.

Larry stormed through the door. “What the fuck are you guys doing?” he shouted.

“We’re looting” someone yelled, to much laughter from the rest of the crowd. After the laughing died down a bit Larry stalked over to the bar, turning the OFFNEN sign off.

“Hey, what gives?” someone asked.”

“Don’t you guys remember the plan”? Larry yelled back. We need to load the trucks and get out of here. They’re going to bomb this place again in 30 minutes.

Some of the men got up immediately and rushed out, others were more casual, figuring there was still lots of time. Still, before 5 minutes had passed the men were all back out in the cold, loading whatever they could into the backs of the trucks. Most of it was from the big mess tent.

As George was leaving he pulled Larry aside. “What’s this about a bombing? I don’t remember that being part of the plan.”

“Well it got that bunch of louts moving again, didn’t it.” Larry said.

Since the Bulldogs had laid claim to the bar, Larry had their truck back up to the door so they could load the furnishings. He still wasn’t sure how much, if any, of this he was going to get this passed the commander, but there was no harm in trying. The first thing to load up was the big juke box, and he got a couple of men on that task at once.

Of course that bar maid started giving them grief the moment they touched it. Annoyed, he pulled out his pistol, more to scare her off than shoot her. Shooting a woman was a line he had yet to cross.

Yet George must have thought he was really going to shoot her as he flung himself between them and grabbed is arm, yelling at him not to shoot.

“What the hell’s gotten into you!” Larry demanded, shaking him off.

“You can’t shoot her.” George said, putting himself between Larry and the girl.

“The hell I can’t” Larry stated. He wasn’t about to admit that he wouldn’t. But can’t and wouldn’t were two very different words, and he wasn’t about to admit that weakness in front of his friend.

“You can’t kill her. She’s valuable.”

“She’s not a player, she’s a useless NPC.”

“She’s the only one who can pull beer out of the ice box.”

That gave Larry a pause. “What?”

“Try it.” George insisted “Grab a beer for yourself.”

Larry did so, opening the ice box and rummaging around. Other than ice, there was nothing there.

“So, you guys drank all the beer on me. Thanks a bunch.” He said bitterly.

“No, we didn’t.” It’s a bar tending thing. Here, watch this.” He pulled out a couple of bills and handed them to Larry.” Larry looked at them, puzzled.

“Give them to her.” George said. Larry put the bills on the table, pushing them towards the bar maid with the barrel of the pistol he’d forgotten he still had in his right hand. She looked at him for a moment, puzzled. Then took the money and went over to the empty icebox and pulled out a cold beer he would swear wasn’t there a moment ago, handing it to him. For a couple of moments he just stood there, gun in one hand, beer in the other.

“See.” George said, “She’s part of the system. As long as you give her money she gives you beer. Without her the ice box is just a box of ice. Less than worthless in the middle of Siberia here. She has to come along with it.

Larry shook his head. “We can’t take an NPC as a prisoner. The Commander will kill us.”

“She’s not a prisoner.” George pointed out “She’s captured equipment. A part of the beer serving machine, don’t you see”

Larry thought for a second, then came to a decision. “You have a point. Okay, load everything up. Take her, but keep her quiet. If the commander finds out he won’t see it the same way I do, and we’ll all be shot at dawn.”

Apparently, asking politely if Lindsay would care to join them wasn’t part of the Russian’s plan. Instead two of the soldiers bound her hands behind her back. When she started yelling at them in protest one of them grabbed a table cloth and tore a couple of strips out of it, wadding one between her teeth, tying the other over it and behind her head. Bound and gagged, she was loaded into the truck like a side of beef. One of the soldiers took the opportunity to cop a feel in a most inappropriate place, laughing when she tried to kick him. In short order she found herself stacked in with the rest of the looted furnishings. A few minutes later five soldiers climbed into the back with her as the engine rumbled to life.

The truck lurched forward several meters, only to come to a stop just as they exited the 123rd's compound. With her back against the cab she watched the rest of the line of trucks snake their way passed her until the compound was empty. Her last look showed her a forlorn and miserable looking huddle of tents and sheds, their doors broken and leaning, contents scattered. Then a flare screamed past them, and all the tents and sheds she had called home exploded into flames.

At that, the truck she was in started moving again, carrying her away into captivity as her burning home receded into the night.

With all the bar equipment the Russians had looted there was barely room for Lindsay and the 5 soldiers she had to share the ride with. They were all jammed up against the cab trying to shelter from the icy air that blew in around the canvas tarp that covered the back. A couple of them, part of the group that had first burst in on her, saw her shivering so one of the wrapped a blanket around her, then wrapped another blanket around them both. The others joined suit, and soon all of them huddled under a mountain of blankets, no doubt swiped earlier from the 127th, as the truck ground its way through the freezing night.
It was almost three and a half hour when the truck finally came to a stop and everybody jumped out. Everybody but Lindsay, that is. When she started to struggle to get up one soldier pushed her back down where she was sitting, pointing a finger at her in an unmistakable gesture to stay. Lindsay settled back down, trying to capture the last remaining warmth in the blankets, joints aching in protest over the broken promise of some exercise. Fortunately she didn’t have to wait too long, the truck started moving again almost immediately, turning and backing up. When the canvas was thrown back and Lindsay stopped blinking in the harsh glare of the single flood lamp shining onto the load she could see the truck had backed up to an improvised loading ramp. Some of the barrels looted from the 127th were stacked along the back wall, while boxes and crates were being hand carried through wide timber doors into the dark cavern beyond. Several soldiers Lindsay recognized from the group that had been drinking in the Gasthaus earlier started unloading; dragging all the bar furnishings, including her, through the door and inside.

Lindsay didn’t get much of a chance to look around the cavern. By the time her eyes had adjusted from the sodium lamp glare to the lack of light the soldier leading her shoved her into a store room and closed the heavy wooden door, plunging her into even deeper darkness. As she stood there in the dark she heard the sound of a heavy key in the lock behind her.

The room was warmer than she would have expected, but still too cool to be standing around dressed as she was. Moving around wasn’t really an option, the room was crowded and she kept bumping into things, and with her hands tied as they were it was hard to keep her balance. There didn’t seem to be anywhere she could find to sit.

By the time the door opened again she was shivering once more in the cooling air. The soldier looking in didn’t look too pleased to see this. She could hear him yelling through the door as he moved away. Then he was back, carrying a blanket that he draped over her. Then he pulled out a knife and cut the ropes holding her hands and arms before leaving and locking the door again.

Once she had rubbed some feeling back into her numb fingers she started to feel around her prison. In the dark she wasn’t able to locate anything she could use as a weapon, at least not one that would help her escape from a dark locked store room in the middle of what she assumed was Russian held territory. At least with her hands free she was able to create a place to sit while she waited for what ever happened next. And clutch the blanket around her for warmth.

Some time later the door opened again. This time the soldier had an electric lamp on a cord that he hung up, illuminating the room. As soon as he did this more soldiers, the same ones that had unloaded the truck it looked to Lindsay, swarmed in and began hauling away the looted furniture. Handing a box to Lindsay, the guy that had hung up the light and given her a blanket gestured for her to follow the other men.

The line of men snaked their way across the crate strewn cavern to a set of stairs that lead upwards into a massive network of carved stone tunnels and corridors. If she hadn’t been following someone else she would have been uncharacteristically lost in the dizzying maze, which she wouldn’t have minded, and which the soldiers were obviously there to prevent. At last, they entered a largish stone room lined with shelves.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Earlier that night, after the raiding party returned to base, the commander had called for Larry to update him on the raid. He had asked Larry to meet him in the planning room instead of his office, which surprised Larry a little. Normally debriefing reports occurred in the commanders office. Still, the commander wanted the report soon as they’d returned, so Larry headed off to the planning room.

The commander was bent over a topographical map of the local area when Larry came in, studying reports and moving small models into new positions. He looked up when Larry knocked

“Ah, Comrade Ivantobitch. Welcome home. I trust the raid was successful?”

“Successful? Hardly” Larry said “Try Disaster.”

“How many planes did you capture?”

“Zero.” The commander looked puzzled, so Larry continued “Zilch. Nada. Not a one.”

The commander looked disappointed. “You didn’t capture any?”

“There were no planes on that airfield.”

“Did you look?” the commander asked. “Intelligence reports say that airfield had a strength of 16 BF109G fighters, as well as 24 Henkle 111 bombers. In addition at least eight FW190s were delivered yesterday. Surely you would have managed to capture something.”

Larry rolled his eyes “Let me rephrase my answer. There were no planes on that airfield that had not been turned into scrap metal by the air strike three hours before we got there.”

“That’s too bad. Prisoners? How many Germans players did we capture?”

“One for each plane we brought back.”

“But I thought you said…? Ah! Your famed sarcasm. I should have known.”

The commanders calm attitude was beginning to irritate Larry, and his demeanor slipped a little. “Damn right you should have known. The whole fucking raid was FUBAR from the moment Grizzly squad screwed up the timing and took off at the same time we did. They got there way before we did and blew the shit out of everything.”

“So, I give you a mission to raid an undefended German airfield and capture as many planes and prisoners as possible. You come back and tell me you managed to capture exactly zero planes and zero prisoners. Not a very impressive looking report to send to command.”

“We captured all we could. From my perspective I would have to report that our secondary ground attack captured 100% of the men and equipment still available. And we destroyed all parts of the German airbase that the air attack missed.”

The commander looked at Larry, questioningly “So that’s your report?”

“With all due respect, we were still three hours away when Grizzly squadron started bombing. By the time we got there any players still alive had bugged out and most of the airfield was a smoldering garbage dump. Anything we got was from an isolated collection of tents the bombs missed. My report is the only way I can think of to put a positive angle on the fiasco.”

“Yes, that was unfortunate. The intent was that you would be able to capture the planes and fly again. Unfortunately, it looks like some of the attacking squadron was a little too enthusiastic, and, as you said blew the shit out of everything. Still, accidents happen. I’m sure that the next raid will go much better.”

Larry shook his head. “You can count Bulldog squad out. The only reason most of them agreed to take part in this raid was because we were promised captured planes and equipment in return for being the ground troops. Then we get there and discovered the place was destroyed. No planes, no guns, no ammo, no fuel. We did our part, and we got nothing.”

“Actually, you were promised a share of the loot for bringing back prisoners, which you didn’t do. But you did get, what, three truck loads of loot?”

“Sure, if you want to call it that. Turns out most of it was food from the German mess hall. A lot of it the men won’t touch, so we’ll either toss it out or give it to the cooks to feed to the prisoners. The rest of it was tin trays, pots, pans. cutlery, that sort of stuff. Cooking and serving equipment mainly. And some pub furniture.

“Anything of use to the war effort?”

“Possibly. The men won’t like the food but it’s a change. Some furniture we could use to set up a place for them to relax. There’s also something that looks like it could be a still.”

The commander shook his head. “And do we really need another one of those?”

“I don’t think there’s on in the officer’s latrine yet.”

“So a whole lot of garbage then?” the commander said, going back to his models.

This was the point in the conversation Larry had been waiting for. “I was thinking we could clean out one of the crypts and set up the pub furniture.”

The commander looked up “Whatever for?”

“Then the boys will have their own bar to drink at. Sort of a place to go to relax when they are off duty.”

“I’m not sure having a company pub is such a good idea.”

“The men are Russian, so they’re going to drink anyway. Right now they’re hanging around the town or building bonfires in the woods. This gives them a place to go that’s underground and out of sight. If we give them that as a reward, they will see it as a positive outcome of the raid and moral would improve. And they will be more willing to participate in the next raid.”

“All excellent points.” The commander said, somewhat distractedly “Very well, if you think it will help then by all means do it. Clean out whatever crypt you think best suits your needs, then take what you need from the captured supplies and build your little pub. You will have to stock it yourself I’m afraid, but that is another incentive for the men to go raiding the Germans.”

Larry grinned as he left the debriefing. It had actually worked out better than he had thought. Now all he needed to do was decide which crypt to commandeer. And detail a work party to clean it. He was thinking the currently well rested Grizzly Squadron would be an ideal choice.
