Outside the planning room Larry stifled a yawn. It had been a long day and he’d been running adrenaline for most of it. Now that everything was neat and tidy the lack of sleep was catching up on him, and would hit him hard in a few minutes.
With this in mind he headed for the barracks level, intending to grab a few hours sleep. But first, there was no reason he couldn’t get things put in motion.

Almost as if by providence, when he entered the small mess hall adjacent to where the Bulldogs had their bunks, he saw someone he knew could be trusted to carry out orders with a relatively competent level of success. Sammy the Squirrel they called him. Samuel had the ability to grasp what you wanted to accomplish and figure ways to get it done with only limited supervision, right up until he got distracted by one of the innumerable side quests the game kept throwing at him. Nobody was as good at stumbling across the little optional missions hidden in a game as Sam was, and as a result his locker was loaded with enough optional gear to outfit a platoon. Oddly enough, Sam rarely got distracted on a side quest, finishing each one completely before returning to his original job. If you were lucky he would finish that before another challenge rolled his way.

When Larry laid out the plans, Sam listened with growing enthusiasm, and was more than happy to take on the task of starting the project while Larry got some shut eye. Larry watched Sam tear off to wake up the Grizzly Squad. Even if Sam got distracted, he figured, the chances are he’d get enough of the work started that Larry could pick up where he left off with no problems. And with any luck, building the bar would turn out to be a side quest in itself for Sam.

With this arranged Larry made his way to his billet and dropped heavily into his cot, falling asleep the minute his shoes were off.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
The room they had lead Lindsay into was very large, with shelves lining every square inch of wall space, and seemed to be carved from stone. Arches of stone swooped up and across the low, dome shaped rough stone roof. Standing in the middle of the room was a soldier she’d never seen before, obviously the officer in charge judging by his cap, and the way the other soldiers sneered at him behind his back as he imperiously shouted directions to the soldiers who were doing the actual work.

In one corner was a grey pile of rocks and sticks one of the soldiers was scooping up into a wheelbarrow. Against the other wall the line of soldiers were dropping the crates and furniture they’d looted from the 127th. Someone had already set up the LaGG cowl against the wall. Lindsay had a sinking feeling when she realized the Russians were setting up their own pub using the looted furnishings. And she was pretty sure who they had in mind to tend the bar.

The room was quite a bit larger than the Gasthaus tent, and the Russians filled the extra room by adding several solidly built trestle tables and a few heavy, comfortable looking arm chairs that looked solid enough to serve as cover if anyone started shooting. Luckily, Lindsay wasn’t asked to help arrange any of it. Judging from the straining expressions the soldiers were exhibiting it took a lot of effort to move one of those tables.

The soldier who had handed Lindsay the box to carry now took it back from her as she stood there, then handed her a broom. At first she just looked at it, not really believing what was happening. A sharp barked order from the officer spurred her to action and she started sweeping the middle of the room. After a few moments the watching officer slapped her roughly on the shoulder and pointed to the far corner, indicating she should start there. There was no mistaking the disdain on his face as he looked at her, a bar maid too stupid to sweep a room properly.

With a sigh, Lindsay started sweeping the accumulated dust and debris, pushing it into a pile. Every once in a while, when the pile was big enough, the soldier with the shovel would come by and scoop it into his wheelbarrow.

The second time he did this one of the rocks fell out of the soldier’s wheelbarrow as he was pushing it towards her, landing with a hollow Thock to bounce and roll across the floor, stopping at Lindsay’s feet. Lindsay was just thinking how the hollow pits in the rock made it look like a skull when, with a small shock, she realized that was exactly what she was looking at. What she thought were rocks and sticks were human bones.

For the first time, she took actual note of the items she was sweeping up. In addition to the dirt and twigs, there were scraps of rotted cloth and small bits of yellowy white gravel, or what she thought was gravel until she realized that they were actually teeth. Here and there was also the occasional bit of corroded metal. When she bent over to pick one up and try to identify it a sharp blow to her butt and an evil glare from the soldier in charge reminded her that she wasn’t there on her own time. After that she ignored anything glittery and just swept. When she finished, as a reward for doing a good job sweeping, they graciously allowed her to mop.

Eventually the floor and shelves were clean, and the soldiers got the furniture arranged the way they wanted. As the rest of the soldiers settled into the chairs, the one in charge indicated Lindsay should start serving.

Obviously he was wanting to buy the first round, handing Lindsay a bank note of a type she’d never seen before. Not knowing what the note was worth, Lindsay shook her head, pushed the bill back at him, and held up 2 fingers, falling back on the exchange system established, oh so many hours ago.

The officer wasn’t happy about this, and said something angrily. Back and forth they went until Lindsay turned away. Tired, with her back and shoulders already aching from hours of pushing the broom mop around, Lindsay retreated towards the bar and sat down. The officer followed her, slapping the bill on the bar and talking angrily a mile a minute. Lindsay wasn’t in the mood, and just shook her head, holding up two fingers. Let someone else serve for a change, she thought, as she leaned back and closed her eyes. She didn’t care.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
One of the other soldiers came up and started talking to the officer. Another discussion that she couldn’t understand. After a minutes discussion, it got quiet, then she heard someone calling as they rapped on the bar. Stifling a yawn, she opened her eyes. The officer was no where to be seen. Instead, standing at the bar with a pile of bank notes spread in front of him stood Blanket Guy (That’s what she’d decided to call the soldier who had cut her free and given her a blanket it the store room earlier.) With an ear to ear grin he started counting the notes out in twos. If it had been the officer she might have decided not to bother, or that the price was now three bills, just for the hassle. But something about blanket guy’s earnestly goofy expression changed her mind and she started pulling beers out of the ice box. These were quickly snapped up and passed around the tables by the soldiers, who began to laugh and talk among themselves.

It turned out the officer hadn’t left as she first thought. Instead he had seated himself at a table along the far wall. She didn’t realize he was there until she heard him growled out something that brought all noise in the room to a stop and turned the good nature conversation into grumbles of discontent. Sullenly, the soldiers finished their drinks and filed out of the room. As the last of the men left the officer got up, and without even bothering a glance in her direction, followed through the door after them, pulling it closed behind him. As Lindsay started towards the door she heard the rattle of a key in the lock.

Crossing to the door, she confirmed that she was once again locked in. At least this time there were lights on. She turned to explore the room, looking for another way out, but finding none. Just as she’d given up she heard the door being unlocked. Once again Blanket Guy was there, holding a couple of blankets which he handed over with an apologetic look, before turning and closing the door behind himself as he left. And again she heard the sound of a key in the lock.

Oh well, she thought later, curling up on the hearth of the gigantic Russian stove the soldiers had somehow contrived to fit into one corner of the room. At least she wouldn’t freeze to death. The bricks and stone of the stove, heated by the roaring fire the soldiers had built earlier, radiated a comfortable warmth through the blanket she’d laid down as a sleeping pad. A warmth that almost made the top blanket unnecessary.
Tired out from the events of the day, she was sound asleep before she’d finished the beer she’d pulled for herself.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Lindsay woke up groggy, her thoughts fuzzy. That dream was definitely too real, she was thinking, dropping her head back onto her pillow, only to find her pillow wasn’t there to catch her head, And her cot seemed as hard as rock.

With a start Lindsay opened her eyes. The dimly lit rock cavern she was in brought her home to the reality of the present. It hadn’t been a dream. She really had been captured, driven to God knows where and press ganged into a group of enemy infantry as a mere waitress. At least she hoped that was all she was supposed to be. A shudder ran through her as she realized just how dire her predicament was. There were a lot more things female prisoner could be used for, and most of them were far less pleasant than being a waitress.

Lindsay pushed back the thin blanket that covered her, knocking over the stein she’d been drinking from the night before. It fell of the hearth to shatter on the cold stone floor, flooding the immediate area with a large puddle of ceramic shards and stale beer.

Lindsay ignored the puddle for now, concentrating on finding her clothes instead. Fortunately she didn’t have to look far. During her sleep the game had removed all the stains and dirt her Dirndl Kjole had collected from yesterday’s activities, and the small rips and tears patched and sewn. Now, cleaned and mended; the dress hung over the back of a nearby chair. The rest of her clothing was folded on the seat, all neatly pressed. Her shoes, one of the pairs the Colonel had brought back for her from Voroshilovgrad, sat polished on the floor in front.

At least it wasn’t her duty uniform, she thought with some relief. That would have made it very awkward to try and maintain her cover while she worked out a way to escape from this place. Then she realized something. This WAS her duty uniform, now. That thought threatened to depress her even further, so she firmly pushed it aside and quickly dressed.

Decently attired, her hair once again pleated into two ponytails, she began to explore the room, giving it an even more thorough investigation that she had last night.

Finished the tea, but still has no real plan of escape.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
The morning’s investigation revealed little more than it had the night before. None of the low wide shelves had the decency to conceal a hidden switch that caused a secret panel to swing open when she pressed it. The wall mounted candle holders proved equally disappointing, steadfastly refusing to open any hidden corridors no matter how she twisted or turned them.

It looked like the only exits from the room were the three iron banded oak doors she could see. The largest one at the front of the room, where the men had exited the night before, she knew from last night would be locked from the out side. Testing proved this to be the case, so she explored the other two. One of the smaller ones at the back of the room lead to a small chamber, lined with more of those large wide stone shelves that who ever built the place was so fond of Lindsay wondered if these were bunks. They were certainly the right size and shape for someone to lay on. Although there would need to be a good mattress, she decided after seeing the roughness of the carved surface, a thick soft one.

The room was currently being used for storage. Crates and boxes bearing identification of the 127rd mess hall lined the long wide shelves, piled in that haphazard fashion that tells you the person doing the job wasn’t really that interested in doing a good job, just in doing what they were told so they can be finished. Moving these boxes and tapping on the walls revealed there were no hollow spaces hiding behind them, and served to only knock down more of the dust that soon coated her in a thin film. Other than that dust the only thing she came out of the room with was a box of tea, which she had swiped for her breakfast.
Dipping into the water barrel, she filled the kettle and put it onto the stove. While she waited for it to heat she explored the other room.

The last room turned out to be what books about old castles called a garderobe; A tiny, not much more than a closet size room with a simple hole in the floor and a bench over it for relieving oneself. The hole was old and, judging from the lack of smell, hadn’t been used in some time. That would change, she realized, as soon as the soldiers started to make use of the Pub. It was also only about 6 inches in diameter. Lots of room if you were a snake or a rat, but totally useless to someone of her size. That is, unless you wanted to use it for its intended purpose, to which Lindsay put it to now. She was gratefully to have discovered it was there.

There was also a tiny stand below the cracked mirror in the corner behind the door, barely big enough for the stone basin and jug, obviously placed there so a person could, if they felt so inclined, wash their hands after using the facilities. As it had been a crew of men how were setting the place up, of course there was no water in the jug. Not a problem, Lindsay thought, there was plenty of water heating on the stove.
Dipping hot water into the basin she grabbed a rag from the bar and carried it back into the small room. After freshening up everything that needed to be, she emptied the soiled water down the waste hole and set about tidying up.

Her blankets she folded and tucked on a shelf in the store room. Her spilled beer she moped up, dumping the shards of mug into a bucket under the bar. By this time the kettle was boiling, so she made herself a cup of tea and sat down to think about how she was going to get out of this.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.title: There is only one way out, and it is locked.

choices: Beer on an empty stomach for supper.
1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
A rattle of the key in the lock brought her out of a light doze. The officer from the night before came in, looking around. Obviously not happy he slapped Lindsay and gestured around the room. Confused, Lindsay gathered up the few empty bottles from the tables and tidied up, hoping that was what the officer was after. Although not particularly happy, the officer seemed mollified with her efforts. He obviously thought he was in charge, judging from the way he turned the bar light on and theatrically opened the door. What ever he was calling this little impromptu pub, it was now open for business.

The evening passed quickly. Thirsty soldiers filtered in, eager for the drinking and entertainment they’d been promised. As the night wore on and the men became rowdier she was hard pressed to keep up serving drinks. Not to mention that, as the men got drunker, more and more of them felt entitled to put their hands were they weren’t invited, or appreciated. And through it all, the officer who seemed to have made himself in charge sat at the bar and drank. At first, he seemed to think he was entitled to free drinks for some reason, but when Lindsay refused to serve him unless he paid he just shrugged and opened a jar on the bar closer to him. He’d been selling some sort of raffle tickets, putting the money into the jar. Now he dipped into that jar, carefully selecting bills to pay for his drinks.

Finally, just when Lindsay didn’t think it could get any rowdier without a fight breaking out, a fight did break out. Five or six men were arguing at a table, and while she was trying to serve a group nearby one of the men started throwing punches. Several others joined in, including some from the group she was serving. Before long a group of military police came in and arrested everyone involved and clearing out the rest of the bar, shutting is down. The overly entitled officer yelled and swore at them, but did not get them to change their mind. In frustration, after everyone left, he slapped her face, hard, and then locked her in again.
'Seriously?' Lindsay thought, dabbing her split lip with her apron, 'what is with Russian Officers and their habit of slapping women?'

The place was a disaster, and she was aching from the scrapes and bruises picked up during her escape from the brawl. Not to mention the painful cuts on her face from the rings that pig of an officer was wearing. She thought about cleaning up, but decided she was too tired and hungry. Instead, she dug out one of the captured med kits that she’d seen in the storage area, and applied a thin film of the healing ointment to her injuries. Then she drew herself a beer and curled up in her blankets on the hearth again, wistfully dreaming of escape and revenge.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
When she woke up, she had no idea what time it was. Her internal clock was totally messed up by everything she’d suffered through, and it could have been mid- morning, or after noon, or early evening for all she knew. She did know she was staving, almost shaking from hunger. She needed food.

She had just finished searching all the cupboards of the bar, finding nothing that resembled food, when she heard the lock rattle and the door to the pub slash her cell opened.

The officer was back.

He strolled in casually, like he was entering his own living room, completely at home. His jacket was open and she could see that his shirt as well was undone and disheveled. Like he had just gotten out of bed and hadn’t taken the time to dress properly.

There was an apple in his hand. Briefly she wondered where he had gotten an apple in the middle of winter, but didn’t dwell on the question much. Something about the way he looked around the room when he got far enough in to get a clear view of the place terrified her into motionlessness. His eyes narrowed, but he didn’t say anything.

She unconsciously took a step back as he started across the room to where she was standing, but to her relief he didn’t come all the way, stopping at one of the heavy tables close by and seating himself where he could watch her. From his belt he pulled that very large and wicked looking knife, using it to peel the apple in a slow and deliberately manner. Not in one long coil, like you would expect a normal person to. He pealed it as if it was a potato, slicing off small discs of skin that he let fall onto the table as he methodically worked his way around the fruit until it was completely denuded of any trace of the red peel.

Only after carefully inspecting the naked fruit to make sure there was no skin left did he start to cut slices out of it, using the sharp blade to transfer the slice to his mouth, watching her as he chewed slowly and methodically. Swallowing before cutting the next piece.

Lindsay felt like a mouse feels when being watched by a snake. She couldn’t help but watch. The sight of the apple made her mouth water, and she realized just how hungry she was, how little she’d eaten since being captured. When she swallowed she saw him grin, and realized that he knew how hungry she was. That he was deliberately doing this in front of her to torment her. She pushed herself away from the wall she’d unconsciously backed herself against and walked away.

Behind her she heard him laugh.

She stood by the bar and squeezed her eyes closed, breathing deeply and trying to compose herself. That was a mistake, she soon realized. As she drew in her second breath she felt his presence behind her. He must have stood up the moment she turned her back. There was an unpleasant look in his eyes and the wicked knife was still in his hand. She cringed back, but she was trapped against the bar and had no where to go.

With his free hand he grabbed her arm, dragging her roughly out into the middle of the room and tossing her to the floor. She scrabbled to her hands and knees, as he glared at her, but he didn’t move towards her like she expected. Instead he started speaking, loudly and deliberately, like he was issuing orders. Abruptly she realized he was. Each time he issued a command he pointed the knife towards one of the tables, still littered with the remains of last nights drinking. Clearly he was annoyed because she hadn’t cleaned up.

Then he did move towards her. Before she could scrabble away he was in front of her, reaching down and grabbing her face by the jaw in one massing paw, holding it steady while the knife he held was brought up until it just touched her cheek under her eye. Trembling she tried not to move, staring at the wicked tip that threatened her eye as the officer spoke a few more harsh guttural words. Then he pushed her way, hard enough that she hit the floor with a thump, and stalked away from her, back to the bar.

Perching himself on one of the stools he leaned against the bar, watching as she slowly got her feet under her. Too slow for his taste, it seemed. He shouted a word at her and slammed the knife into the bar, hard enough to half bury the blade in the wood top. At this she scrambled to her feet and began to gather up empty bottles and cups. Hauling them behind the bar to the little washing station there.

Another barked command made her turn, and she saw him pointing towards the ice box. No doubting what he wanted. She held up two fingers. Payment first was the rule. He just snarled and shook his head, and pointed again. No doubt about what he was saying, he didn’t think he needed to pay.

Her first reaction was to refuse. That firm resolve lasted until the second time he slapped her for shaking her head. After that she chose the path of least painfulness and brought him the beer he wanted, not surprised that he made no offer to pay when he got what he wanted. Obviously he was used to using intimidation and force to get what he wanted. She was justifiably afraid she would set a precedent of free beer. Maybe she could get him drunk enough to pass out.

As she set about cleaning the tables he sat at the bar, watching her work and drinking beer. The stool he occupied was positioned so that she had to pass right by him each time to get to the sink, and after his second beer he started playfully swatting her rump each time she went passed. The first time he did so she protested. He merely grinned and patted the knife still firmly embedded in the bar. After that she tried to make as few trips passed him as possible.

She must have over built the fire when she was trying to boil the water to wash dishes with, and the big stove had made the room quite warm by the time she was done cleaning. The officer had removed his jacket and shirt, and was leaning back against the bar, bottle of beer propped on his paunch, looking for all the world like white trailer trash watching his favorite game show on television. Lindsay could easily picture him with a remote in his other hand, watching some game show in a run down double wide while eating cheese doodles and complaining about how noisy the trailer park has gotten lately.

The heat and the work and the lack of eating was getting to her. When she stood up her head started swimming and she abruptly sat down. This brought a growl from the officer.

“Stuff it.” She said. “I can’t work any more. I’m tired and I’m starving. You understand?”

The officer growled again, threateningly.

Lindsay just shook her head. “I need something to eat.” She pleaded “Food. Can you understand food?” She opened her mouth and pointed, hoping the gesture might help get her point across.

The officer grinned and said something, getting to his feet. Then he started to unbuckle his belt.

This brought Lindsay to her feet, tired as she was. She started to move away but wasn't fast enough. The officer moved faster, grabbing her before she had moved a step. Drunk as he was he stilled proved to be much stronger than her. Still, she struggled, which annoyed him, and with his free hand he swung a back handed blow across her face that knocked her back against the table and to the floor, dazed.

Tangling one massive, greasy paw in her hair he dragged her up onto her knees; the other paw grabbed a hold of her blouse and tore it open. His mouth split in a predatory grin as he gazed hungrily at her exposed breasts. With an ugly laugh at her cringing whimpers he finished unbuckling his belt and dropped his pants.

Behind them, the door swung open.

Greg pushed the rubber tire buggy, nicknamed the slop truck, down the sloping tunnel towards the dungeons below. The Gruel in the pots was actually quite tasty, just not as pleasing to the eye as the proper food served up in the mess hall was. That was one nice thing about the game. It made good food. Greg couldn’t imagine that there was a professional chef in the mess hall that was making the gruel they served the prisoners, but it sure tasted that way.

The task of delivering the gruel to the guards responsible for feeding the prisoners was supposed to rotate equally among the other guards. Greg was of a rank above the regulars, and normally wouldn’t be doing this duty, but said duty was also used as currency in their nightly game of cards. Greg had lost last night, and was making good his debt.

The long sloping tunnel would take him from the camp kitchen down to the catacombs where the prisoners were being held. It also brought him past Burial Chamber Number One that he had decided was going to be his first stop. His squad leader had convinced the brass to set the chamber up as a squadron run pub, on the argument that it would keep the men happy. Since they were being Russians, the men were going to drink anyway and it made sense to try and keep it located in one area. Plus they had all that pub equipment they had looted from that disaster of a raid on that German airbase the other night. The only decent loot in the lot really, and that was more than just Greg’s opinion.

Amazingly enough, the brass had agreed, and a surprisingly short time later they had evicted the former residents and set up a bar. Pivnaya Catacombs was what they’d renamed the burial chamber they’d cleaned out. Furnished with all the amenities of a beer house the squad could find, beg, borrow, steal, or otherwise scrounge together. And since almost all of it was looted from the Germans, the results were heavily on the 'Steal' side of the ledger.

From what the men were saying about last night, it was apparently quite a lively place. Greg had been on duty, so he hadn’t had a chance to visit the pub yet, and was looking forward to seeing if it lived up to the hype.

The door was slightly ajar when he stopped and ladled out the first bowl of gruel for the day. Technically the bar maid was more in the category of furnishings and equipment, and not categorized as a prisoner. As equipment she didn’t warrant feeding from the prison gruel truck, but the game was funny sometimes about making you take care of your stuff. The NPCs acted as realistic as hell these days, so equipment or not, she was probably starving, or at least programmed to feel like she was. If anybody asked, he would justify his actions with saying that, by feeding her, he was ensuring she would feel gratitude towards him, and he would get better service for all of Bulldog Squad because she thought they were being nice to her. Plus Greg felt that it was the decent thing to do. The thought that she was also nice to look at, and this was the perfect way to spend a little time alone with her, was a thought he refused to think. After all, she was an NPC and he told himself he didn’t need that excuse.

Just as he pushed open the door he was startled to hear slapping noise and a woman cry out in pain.

Two people were in the room when he pushed the door open. One was the bar maid they had so carefully smuggled in the night of the raid. She was kneeling on the floor crying, while in front of her stood Dmitri.

Dmitri wasn’t his real name. If you had the resources and dug deep enough, like maybe just asked one of his online player friends, you would have found his given name to be Phineas. Phineas Delousa Funk. In spite of this, or maybe because of it, he had insisted his in-game name was Dmitri.

Dmitri the Dog the others called him behind his back. Usually with his unspoken approval. That was the way he played the game.

Currently Dmitri’s uniform jacket and shirt were draped over a chair, and he was standing with his pants around his knees while the half naked bar maid huddled before him, trying to hold the ruins of her dress closed. That her dress being ruined was not of her choice or doing was made obvious by the tears streaming down her face. A face that sported a purpleing hand shaped bruise on the left side. That, and the half of her blouse that was clutched in the hands of the Dmitri. You didn’t need to be a dime store detective to put together what was happening.

“What the fuck are you doing!” Greg yelled after a moment of stunned incredulity.

“Showing the little bitch her place.” Snarled Dmitri “Nothing that concerns a little man like you.”

“The hell it doesn’t!” Greg shouted, moving into the room. “Get away from her.”

“Go back to your papers and pathetic little orders from upstairs, little boy. Leave the sluts to those that know how to handle them.”

“You keep your hands off her.” Greg yelled, dropping the bowl and grabbing one of the gothic candleholders off a table as he started across the room towards Dmitri.
The Bulldog squad did not capture this NPC to turn her into a sex toy for anyone, especially Dmitri.

Dmitri’s hand went for the pistol at his belt, fumbling at the flap of the holster. Had it been around his waist he undoubtedly would have quickly drawn it, no doubt shooting Greg before the incident went any further. Instead, with the belt hanging loosely around his knees instead, Dmitri had to bend over, wasting precious time fumbling with the tie holding the flap closed before he could get the gun clear of the holster. Time that allowed Greg to get close enough to plant a kick to the wrist that sent the gun flying.

“You interfering tiny son of a bitch” Dmitri roared, bringing a savage elbow up into Greg’s stomach that sent him flying across the room. With another roar, Dmitri charged.

Greg may have gotten the first blow, but Dmitri was a street fighter. That was another reason they called him the dog. He fought hard and dirty. Greg had been in one fight in his life, at age 12, and had lost that one so badly even the guy who had beaten him up felt sorry for him.

Now Greg, armed with a heavy candle holder, righteous wrath, and good intentions, faced down an unarmed and naked overweight man with his feet trapped in his trousers. Greg didn’t stand a chance. One elbow, three kicks, and a punch to the kidney later he was groggily trying to get to his feet. Or failing that, at least get up onto his elbows and knees. None of his limbs would cooperate and he fell heavily back to the floor. A foot flipped him onto his back, and blearily, his head swimming with double vision, he looked up and tried to focus on Dmitri, standing there grinning down at him. It was an ugly grin, made worse by the angle of view. And the sight of a heavy fireplace poker in Dmitri’s right hand. “I’m going to teach you what happens when you meddle where you’re not wanted” he said, coldly raising the heavy cast iron bar over his head.

Then dropped it as a deafening explosion spun him around, knocking him to the ground. Greg squinted, his double vision coming to focus on the far side of the room where the bar maid was. She was aiming Dmitri’s pistol at them from an almost textbook example of a defensive crouch. Holding the pistol in both hands she kept her aim steady as she rose and slowly walked across the room towards them.

She’d given up on trying to use what was left of her shirt to cover herself. Her magnificent breasts now bobbed and swung free, or as free as they could, given that her two handed grip on the gun had them squeezed between the arms being held straight in front of her. She advanced, gun pointed steadily at where Dmitri lay writhing in pain and clutching at his shattered knee. Greg would remember the sight for a long time, sometimes regretting that he’d paid more attention to the pistol in her hands rather than the twins behind it. Or not, he’d finally decide years later, when he’d matured enough to appreciate what had really mattered at the time.

With a cold look of fury the bar maid advanced on Dmitri, the gun never wavering. It was pointed straight at his heart as she came, until she was close enough that Dmitri, even writhing in pain as he was, couldn’t help but catch sight of her looking down at him. His lip curled back in a snarl as he looked up at her. Greg thought it odd that at this she seemed to waver, the muzzle of the gun, so steady during her advance, dropped slightly. The look on Dmitri’s face slowly became a feral grin. “I’m going to make you pay for this, you stupid bitch!” He snarled. The gun in the bar maid’s hands sank even lower as Dmitri’s hands reached up. Then the gun when off, and Dmitri’s face went white.

His scream galvanized Greg to pull himself into a sitting position, shaking his head to try and clear it. Dmitri was rolling on the floor, crying in pain as blood streamed out from under the hands he now held clutched between his legs.

Putting the pistol down on a nearby table, the woman ignored the bubbling cries of the screaming Dmitri. While Greg fumbled and tried to get unsteadily to his feet, she calmly began pulling on Dmitri’s discarded shirt.

After a few moments, Greg’s head had stopped swimming enough that he was able to fully appreciate what he could see. Which was too bad, in a way. What he now saw was the barmaid, now fully dressed. She’d tied the tail of Dmitri’s shirt together with what was left of her blouse in a knot to one side, leaving her belly exposed and the top half of the shirt buttons undone. Although from the way the buttons strained, that was probably because that was as far up as she could button it. Other than that, or maybe because of that, the shirt actually complemented the Dirndl’s skirt quite well, looking very much like a revamped servers outfit. The only thing that looked out of place was Dmitri's pistol, now tucked into the waistband of the skirt.

Seeing the pistol reminded Greg of his own, still in its holster on his belt. Slowly he reached towards it.

“Nein. Nicht einmal daran zu denken”

The pistol that had been tucked in her waistband moments before was now pointing straight between his eyes. Greg froze. He had no doubt that if he tried anything he would have a third eye before he so much as blinked.

Without breaking eye contact, she nodded towards his holster.

“Gib es mir!” She said, beckoning with her free hand.

Greg didn’t understand the words, but the meaning was clear. Slowly, so there was no mistaking his intentions, he undid the flap of the holster and pulled his pistol out, grasping it between his thumb and finger the way they did it in cop shows. She took it from him and put it on the table beside her.

“Guter Junge.” She said, “Ich könnte dich leben lassen.” She pointed her finger down and spun it in a circle, then pressed a palm forward. “Bis gegen die wand und verteilen, Sonnenschein.”

Greg wasn’t sure what the words meant, but this was usually the point where the prisoner was searched for concealed weapons, so maybe that was what she was saying.

“You want me to put my hands on the wall? He said, half turning and holding his empty hands in the air. He glanced towards where he’d last seen Dmitri and was startled to see only a trail of smeared blood. His expression must have warned the girl, who whirled and snapped off two quick shots, causing Dmitri to tumble from out from behind the chair he had been crawling onto. Now Dmitri was bleeding from both knees as well as the groin.

Without another word Greg placed his hands against the wall and didn’t move as she quickly and efficiently relieved him of his belt knife, the only other weapon he had. Then, after binding his hands behind him with strips cut from a nearby tablecloth, she quickly did the same with Dmitri. Although how much of a threat he was with two shattered knees and a groin injury Greg couldn’t guess. Still, she did a quick and very thorough search, then with a nod of satisfaction, dumped all of Dmitri’s knives in a heap in the middle of a table. Then she picked up Dmitri’s jacket and headed for the door.

Only to stop short beside the bowl of gruel on the floor.

The bowl had landed right side up when he had dropped it, and while some of the Gruel had spilled, a lot of it still clung to the bottom. The girl dropped to her knees and picked up the bowl, sniffed it, then began using her fingers to shovel the thick fluid into her mouth, moaning as if it was the most delicious thing she’d ever.

Greg could hardly believe his eyes. The girl ate like she was starving, rapidly shoveling the food into her mouth and licking her fingers. When the bowl was clean she stared longingly at the food spilled on the floor, as if she was weighing whether or not to eat that too.

“There’s more on the cart, if you want.” He said.

She jumped up, startled, and he realized she’d forgotten he was there. Silently he cursed. If he’d realized she was so distracted he could have captured her. Now, staring once more down the barrel of her confiscated pistol, he was again her prisoner. Sighing he raised his hands back in the air.

“I’m just saying you don’t have to eat that off the floor. There’s more on the cart.

She just looked at him quizzically. Of course she wouldn’t understand. He thought to himself. It’s not that she’s stupid. It’s the language barrier.
He pointed at the bowl, then at the door. Slowly, he moved towards the door, keeping his hands up and in her sight the whole time. When he reached the door he was startled when she pushed her hand against it, stopping him from opening it. Gesturing him back, she eased the door open and checked the hall. Satisfied it was clear she motioned him through.

The cart was where he’d left it, which wasn’t surprising. Nobody would be in these halls to bother with it until the pub was supposed to open, and that wouldn’t be for hours yet. “See, he said, lifting the cover off the huge vat and ladling out another bowl that he held out to her. “Lots of food to eat.” Ordinarily he would have shuddered at calling the gruel ‘food’, but he was coming to the realization that this was probably the first thing she’d eaten in days. Still, she looked at the bowl suspiciously.

“It’s the same thing you ate in there, Greg said. “Maybe a little warmer.” He pulled out a second bowl and ladled a bit for himself. “See?” he said taking a spoonful and smacking his lips. “Food!”

Taking a spoon, she carefully tasted it, then began to quickly spoon it into her mouth. Gone was the ravenous hunger with which she’d downed the previous batch, and she ate a little slower. Still, her bowl was clean by the time Greg had finished the small amount he’d portioned for himself.

“Fude” She said. Setting the bowl down on the cart, patting her stomach and favoring him with a smile.

Yeah” he laughed and smiled back. “Food!”

“Danke für, Decke Kerl.”

Greg wasn’t quite sure what she’d said. He was sure Danke meant thank you, and she was looking at him with a warm smile. The warmest smile he’d seen in a long time, so it was probably a good thing.

Chapter 103

Then her smile vanished as she looked up and down the corridor.
“Was ist die Richtung, die ich, um hier raus nehmen sollte um zu bekommen?”

Greg just looked at her, uncomprehendingly.

“Aus! Aus! Heraus. Ich möchte zu verlassen?” She asked again, gesturing about with the muzzle of the pistol she was once again holding.

Greg couldn’t figure out what she was saying. Die itch hair grouse? Something about Ass? Why was she asking him questions when she was supposed to be escaping? Then he realized why. She didn’t know which way to go. Of course she wouldn’t. There were only two ways out of the catacombs but she would have no way of knowing that. If she went up she would reach the kitchen, in the middle of a town swarming with bored soldiers. If she went down she would reach the loading docks and dungeons.

“The docks are probably your best bet.” He said, not sure why he was being honest with her. By rights he should send her upwards to certain capture.

She didn’t understand, of course, so he repeated himself, gesturing towards the tunnels that sloped downwards.

That time she seemed to get it. Then gestured with the pistol for him to walk ahead.

Of course she would, he thought with a sigh. “Wait.” He said, moving back and grabbing the handles of the cart. “I’m supposed to be delivering the food. If I show up without it they will know something’s not right.”
Her look said she didn’t understand, but she didn’t stop him, just waiting until he’d pushed the cart passed so she could walk behind him.

A few minutes later she spoke again, almost casually. “Das ist eine Menge Lebensmittel, die Sie dort haben.”

Greg again tried to puzzle out what she said. Probably telling him to go slow and not to try anything funny, he figured. She was letting him go ahead because he would be expected, and therefore wouldn’t immediately raise the alarm. Also, she could use him as a meat shield if needed, he thought, being a realist.

As soon as he thought of that he regretted it. Things had a way of becoming real when thought of, and this was no exception. They were half way down a long smooth stretch of corridor when they heard the voices. At least three soldiers, coming towards them. This wasn’t a good place to be trapped, Greg thought. If the soldiers challenged them there would be gunfire. He had no doubt they wouldn’t be too choosy who their target was, and the only thing he currently had to hide behind was roughly 264 litres of soup. Thick, but not likely to stop a lot of bullets. Ahead of them, the soldiers had several alcoves and a corner from which to choose from as cover. In panic he looked back at the girl, wondering what she would do.

To his surprise she had a plan. The first step involved grabbing him by the collar and yanking his face down until it was level to hers. Putting a finger to his lips, she whispered harshly “Ein Wort, und ich verwenden diese Pistole, um sowohl Ihre Bälle abschießen sowie” Without breaking eye contact she tapped the barrel of her pistol against his crotch.

Greg swallowed nervously. He wasn’t any better now at understanding German than when they started, but he was getting her meaning perfectly. Behind them in the locked pub Dmitri was slowly and painfully bleeding to death for what he'd tried to do. Although Greg had helped her escape that, there was very little doubt in his mind that this girl was threatening to inflict the same injury on him if he gave her away. If his own side didn’t kill him, she’d make him wish they had.

Seeing that the message was received she jammed a pistol into his belt, positioning it so it was very obviously there, then pushed him back and took his place pushing the cart, draping the confiscated jacket loosely over one of the handles.

The three soldiers came around the corner moments later. Shoulder patches identified them as being part of the Loosie Goosies, the squad the Bulldogs had been drinking with the night they had captured the girl. Greg even recognized one of them.

“Hey Leon!” he called nervously.

“Greg, my old drinking buddy. What’s up? Got some help with feeding the prisoners I see.”

“Might as well make her useful.” Greg said with a nervous laugh.

“Fote!” The girl exclaimed with that bright smile of hers. “Ich Diene Fote!

“Yeah, Greg said, joining in. She has the food.”

“If you want to call it that.” laughed one of the men. The second, one Greg didn’t know, just looked at her, an odd expression on his face. It was almost pity. Or guilt.

The soldiers moved aside and let them pass as they continued down the hall.

“Hey Greg.” One of the men called from behind them moments later. The girl stiffened and stopped, the hand under the jacket tensing.

“Yes?” Greg said, as they both slowly turned to look at the group now behind them. He wondered if he should dive to the side and hope the bullets would miss.

The man was just standing there, looking like someone who needed to say something but wasn’t sure where to begin. His buddies stood a little bit behind him, looking similar, and a bit shamefaced.

“Something ugly is going down, Greg. Stay away from the Pivnaya Catacombs tonight.”

“Why should I?” Greg asked suspiciously. “What’s happening?”

The man glanced at the other two, as if seeking permission to continue. Neither of them gave any indication one way or the other, so the man continued. “You didn’t hear it from us, okay? But you should know about the situation.”

“What situation?”

“That lottery Dmitri is running.”

“Lottery? What lottery?” Greg was truly confused now. Out of the corner of his eye he could see that the girl still had her hand all the way under the jacket, undoubtedly clutching the hidden gun. .

“Those tickets He’s been selling.” Now that it was out in the open the man started to speak more freely. “10 bucks a shot. First prize being your little lady friend there.”

Greg tried to wrap his head around what the man was saying. “First prize?”

The man’s buddy spoke up. “And second. And third prize as well. All the way down the line to number six. When your ticket is drawn is when you get your turn at her.”

“Your turn?” Greg was lost for a moment, then his eyes narrowed as an ugly suspicion took a hold of him. He looked back at the first man, who made a hand gesture that confirmed his suspicions. “You’re talking a lottery to take turns raping her?”

“Yeah, pretty much.” The first man said, shuffling his feet nervously.” And everyone with a ticket gets to watch.”

Greg put his hand on the butt of the pistol in his belt. Probably exactly the wrong thing to do given the dynamics of the situation, but he wasn’t thinking of about that now. Subconsciously he took a protective half step sideways, closer to the girl. “The hell they are!” He declared. When none of the men denied what he was saying he got madder. “Who the hell would buy tickets for that? And why the hell isn’t somebody doing something about it?”

“We are.” The second guy said “We’re not going.”

“What?” Greg yelled. “Dmitri is selling tickets to a gang rape and your idea of helping the victim is to not participate?”

Beside him the girl was looking back and forth between the two groups, warily watching. Her hand was likely still clutching the gun hidden there, but not drawing it just yet.

“No!” Leon said, coming back to stand beside his squad mates. “He means that we’re not going because we’ve already informed the commander about it.” Both men nodded in confirmation “That’s what’s going down. He’s planning to raid the place tonight and arrest anyone participating. He’ll probably have them shot.”

“I’m sure that will be a small comfort for her.”

“Hey, we don’t like it any more than you. But what can we do? He maybe part of Grizzly squad but he also manages the production line at the plant. And after this all done we have to work with that little dick-wad come Monday. If he finds out we had a hand in busting up his little perverted game he’ll make the job a living hell.” Leon stopped and took a breath. “I’m sorry, but it’s as much as we dare do. Hell, she's only a Sim. We’re only telling you ‘cause you seem like a decent enough chap and shouldn’t get caught up in the crossfire when this goes down.” He clapped Greg on the shoulder apologetically.

“I truly hope the commander doesn’t shut the place down. I kind of like the idea of it. It’s the nicest thing to come out of these stupid raiding parties, and one jackass shouldn’t ruin it for every one.”

He turned to leave, “Oh, and Greg,” he said, turning back “if you’re going to carry your gun like a cheap gangster, you might want to load a clip in it first.” Then the three of them walked away.

Greg looked down at the gun, noticing for the first time the clip was missing. When he looked at the girl she just gave a rueful shrug. He sighed and closed his eyes. The commander was going to be in for a disappointment when he raided the pub tonight, he thought. Dmitri had already been shot, and the girl would be long gone.

A squeaking of tires pulled him back to the present. The girl was headed down the corridor with the food cart.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
It had been a tense few minutes in the tunnel there, and it was all Lindsay could do to keep calm and not start blasting away. The thought that she’d not likely come away unscathed had helped calm the itch in her trigger finger. And then her boy had come through for her. She wasn’t sure what the men had been discussing; Some of the words sounded angry, but at least it wasn’t along the lines of ‘Help! I’m a hostage’. Two of the men kept glancing her way, but they had looked more guilty than suspicious. She realized they were more focused on her cleavage than on what her hands were up to. The tall one actually blushed a bit when he realized she’d seen him looking. Men, she sighed. So predictable. With that in mind she leaned a little further forward. Never underestimate the power of a distraction.

After a pat on the shoulder the group of guards left, but not before saying something that made Blanket Guy check the pistol she’d given him. The look on his face when he saw it was missing the magazine was priceless. Well, what did you expect? She thought. That I’d give my ticket out of here a loaded gun? I may be a blonde but I’m not stupid. Then she started pushing the cart down the tunnel again, anxious to get to the end before they had to bluff their way past any more guards.

Luck was with her, as they didn’t see anyone else until the corridor they were in bottomed out and they came to a large antechamber. In addition to the opening for the corridor they were exiting, there were three other doors around the chamber. Like all the doors in this place they were made of heavy oak and clad with rusting iron straps and hinges. Someone had a thing for heavy oak and iron. At a table in front of one door sat a bored looking guard, reading a dog eared paperback.

Clinging to the old adage “If it worked once, it will probably work again, Lindsay pushed the cart towards the guard. “I bring you food!” she said, trying her best to smile like the harmless serving girl she was pretending to be.

“YA ne znayu o yede, no vy pritsel dlya bolit glaza” The man said excitedly, jumping to his feet the moment Lindsay got his attention. “Ty takaya malen'kaya veshch' iz bara, ne tak li?” He jabbered away, obviously happy to have someone to talk to and break the monotony. After a minute or so of this Lindsay realized that he was not, as she had hoped, just going to take the food and leave them. Something needed to be done. She glanced toward Blanket Guy, and when she caught his attention she gave him a signal, glancing meaningfully towards his crotch. She felt a little bad at how quickly he paled, but at least he interrupted the guard’s incomprehensible monologue.

“YA nenavizhu preryvat', no my dolzhny idti.”

“O, der'mo, proshu proshcheniya. YA dolzhen byl znat', chto byla prichina, po kotoroy Dmitriy pozvolyal yey begat.”

Whatever her boy had said to the guard worked, he seemed to be practically falling all over himself in a stammering apology.

“YA dumal, on skazal, chto on ne snimayet yeye po chasam do sleduyushchey nedeli. Dumayu, on peredumal. byli li vy pobeditelem rozygrysha proshloy noch'yu?”

When Blanket Guy’s eyes narrowed the guard quickly took over the cart and pushed it towards the door behind the table, giving Blanket Guy a none to subtle wink as the door closed behind him. The guard had obviously caught her signal as well, even if he’d somewhat miss-interpreted what it was about. At least the two of them were now alone.

“Nu, ty khotel vyyti. Tam eto.” Blanket Guy said, pointing to a second of the three doors. “Dok-stantsiya dostavlyayetsya tuda.”

He strolled over and opened the door he had pointed at. Lindsay looked out in dismay. The door opened right onto the dock she remembered from the night they had brought her in, although this was from the opposite end. Gone was the harsh sodium glare of the flood light. Now it was mid day and harsh winter sunlight flooded the dock, now bare of any crates and barrels and anything that would give cover to someone trying to sneak in or out of the place. Which would be okay if it wasn’t for the half dozen guards that were just pulling a prisoner out of the lone truck backed up against the far end of the dock. As they frog marched him towards the doorway where Lindsay was hiding, she felt a hand on her shoulder, and when she whirled around Blanket Guy put a finger to his lips, then motioned for her to follow as he lead the way towards the third as yet unopened door. Without even wondering why the man she’d now twice threatened to turn into a eunuch was trying to help her, she followed him quickly across the room and through the doorway.

The door lead to another stone staircase. This one cold narrow, and when the door was closed behind her, pitch black. She felt a hand on her arm, urging her forward. Carefully her free hand against the rough stone wall to steady herself, she began to feel her way forward. It helped that the steps went upwards at an even, comfortable pace. Eventually, they pushed their way through a broken door at the top into a ruined building.

After the near pitch black of the stairwell, the bright sun streaming through the broken windows was blinding. Blinking rapidly, her eyes quickly adjusted and she could make out where they were. It had once been the vestry of a now ruined cathedral.

Lindsay looked around. The most obvious way out was, well, out. Out of the question, that is. A pile of crumpled wreckage was heaped against the massive main doors of the church, blocking them from opening. Timbers and rock had been piled against all of the side doors. Any windows she could see started an unreachable 5 meters above the ground. Unless there was another way out hidden in the rubble they had reached a dead end.

As they began to search for a way out of the ruined interior Lindsay marveled at the work that had obviously gone into the place. In it’s prime, the church had been impressive, even as Russian Orthodox churches go. How it had survived the Bolshevik purge without being razed to the ground was a question that would remain un-answered, although the communists had obviously helped themselves to the finer furnishings over the years. Gone were any of the fine gilded fixtures and polished woodwork that were the hallmarks of a house of worship. Stripped and bare, the smashed and broken statues of saints, apostles, and other holy figures littered the floor along with massive scraps of twisted metal and rock and the remains of broken furniture. Glittery pieces of broken glass winked in the sunlight. Broken glass that came from the massive stained glass window high in the wall behind them. A massive stained glass window with a very familiar looking hole in it.

With a start Lindsay recognized the hole, and with a feeling of dread turned towards the largest pile of crumpled wreckage that blocked the main doors.

It was a fighter, or what was left of it. Shredded by the impact of slamming into the massive stone wall that formed the front of the building. The shoulders of a leather jacket was just visible through a gap under a piece of twisted aluminum panel. Not wanting to but unable to stop herself, she walked over to the wreck, lifted the panel up, and looked under it.

A grinning skull with blond pigtails stared back at her.

With a gasp, she dropped the panel. It fell heavily, dislodging the skeletal arm in the jacket which slid down the sleeve and towards her. For a brief moment she thought the skeleton was trying to grab her and scuttled backwards in panic, bumping into the Russian, who had come up behind her. When he saw what had startled her, he nodded “Da. Skelety. Odin iz nemetskikh letchikov. Inogda my nakhodim ikh v krushenii. Telo igrokov ne ischezayet. Oni prosto prevrashchayutsya v skelety.”

She shuddered, suddenly now very interested in finding a way out of the church even if it involved climbing up to the roof.

Unfortunately, it looked like the Bolsheviks didn’t want anyone to have easy access to the church, and had piled mounds of rubble against the doors. The only obvious way out was either through the roof, which would require a ladder they didn’t have, or through a window, which had the same problem. Unless they could find a third way out, they would have to go back down and try the loading dock again.

They failed to find another door that wasn’t blocked. Maybe there was another door behind the wreckage, but Lindsay doubted that, and did not really want to investigate. Shuddering, she pulled her confiscated jacket around her a little tighter. Turning back towards the wreckage she bowed her head for a moment in silence, then touched a hand to her forehead. Head. Heart. Shoulder. Shoulder. She crossed herself like she used to every time she’d entered a church, back when she’d gone every week. Like she should have done earlier, she thought, a bit guiltily, when she had realized this was sanctified ground. A habit she’d gotten out of, but one she was seriously thinking of taking up again.

Then she sighed, and started back towards the stairwell and their only exit out of the place.
Blanket Guy stood there for a moment, looking at the wreckage and copying her movements. Then he picked up a piece of metal from the pile and followed her, speaking over the solemn mood she was feeling.

“Ey, ya dumayu, chto eto tot paren', kotoryy zastrelil menya v posledniy raz, kogda ya poletel.”

She stopped and looked at him, no clue what he was talking about.

“Da. Eto ya i Frenk, i Dzhordzh, i Larri. My byli v bombardirovke, i etot paren' vyshel iz oblakov i poluchil vsekh nas.”

She just stared some more. Blanket Guy seemed really pleased about something he’d found, and he showed it to her.

Painted on the twisted aluminum was the cartoon mascot of The Mad Cows.

She was not surprised. The same way the name on the chest of the skeleton’s uniform hadn’t surprised her. Not really. She had known what it would say even as she’d lifted the chunk of wreckage.

“ANDERSON”

“Interesno, kak on okazalsya zdes’.” Blanket Guy went on, “Kogda-nibud', mozhet byt', ya rasskazhu vam istoriyu. Vy, veroyatno, vsegda budete sluzhit' parnyu v etom bare.”

What ever he wanted to talk about Lindsay wasn’t really interested. She was feeling a bit weird-ed out at the recent discovery, and wanted nothing more than to both be alone with her own thoughts right now, and not be alone at all right now. Something that wouldn’t happen until she got out of this place. She turned and started back towards the stairwell. After a moment he dropped the piece of metal with its happy painted picture and followed. They had almost reached the door before he spoke again.

“YA mog by byt' otkrovennym, mademuazel', dlya vas bylo by chudom, chtoby vytashchit' vas otsyuda, i pokhozhe, chto russkiye ob"yavili vne zakona chudesa”

Dmitri hobbled along the downward sloping corridor as fast as his slowly healing knees legs would let him. It was really too soon to be moving about, but he didn’t care. There was only one thought on his mind, and that drove out all others. To catch the little bitch that did this to him.

The serving girl was an idiot to think her pathetic attempt at tying him would work. As soon as she’d taken her attention off him he had started flexing and twisting his wrists. The weak strips had parted easily the moment the door had closed, and he’d crawled his way towards where he’d seen the German Med Kit that ungrateful slut must have used to heal her bruises. There had been plenty of healing salve and bandages left over and he had lost no time in applying that to his knees.

And to what was left of the little pump action 12 gauge he carried between his legs.

That had been the most painful part of the process. He’d almost passed out a couple of times as he peeled the blood soaked cloth of his trousers away from the wound. His prized little Remington was an unrecognizable mess of clotted blood and torn tissue. That little slut had better pray it healed properly, he had vowed. No one, player or NPC, was going to do that to him and get away with it.

With the cool healing gel soothing the pain of the ruins of his personal armory, Dmitri applied more to his knees and then bandaged them. As soon as they would take his weight he went after her.

Ordinarily, the heavy locked door would have stopped him, except for the spare key he kept hidden in the woodwork of one of the tables. It was a matter of a moment to retrieve the key and let him self out.

That faggot from the Goose group, Leon, and a couple of his Butt Buddies were just passing by when he opened the door. Another bunch of queers this game attracted. He had long suspected they were into men the way they all hung out together drinking tea during their breaks on the production line. He wasn’t too surprised when they’d declined to join in on the special in game entertainment he’d been arranging for the real men. They probably spent their off hours drinking tea and swapping make up tips.

The world would be better off without them he had decided, but that didn’t stop him from accosting them in the hallway and commandeering Leon’s pistol and spare clips to replace the one the little cunt had stolen.

The group had also let slip that the little slit and her wimpy boyfriend were headed towards the dungeons. Re-armed, he hobbled along the hall as fast as his crippled legs would carry him. He had no doubt that their destination wasn’t the dungeons. It would be the loading dock. Obviously they were going to try to escape. Too bad, He was going to catch them first, and when he did, the bitch would pay. Both of them would, but the slut most of all.

She wasn’t on the loading dock when he got there. There was a group of guards tormenting a prisoner on the docks. They’d been at if for a little while and would have noticed her, they all swore to that.

Annoyed, he hobbled back inside to question the guard at the dungeon door. Before he got there though, his attention was caught by the third door in the chamber. The one that lead upstairs to the ruined church the catacombs were built under. A door that had been recently opened, judging by the scuff marks in the dirt in front of it. With the grin of a predator that knows he’s about to make an easy kill, he pushed the door open and started up the stairs.

At the top, he stopped just inside the dark doorway and watched in delight, hardly believing what he was seeing. The little cunt and that little traitor Gregory were walking back towards his hiding place.

Greg wasn’t sure how much the girl could understand, but he kept talking. Trying to lighten the mood. The skeleton in the plane seemed to have freaked her out for some reason, so he was trying to find something to distract her. Talk about movies, some one had suggested to him once when he had confessed his awkwardness at small talk. For some reason the only movie with Germans in it he could think of was Casablanca.

“I might as well be frank, mademoiselle,” he quoted, paraphrasing a little “it would take a miracle to get you out of here, and the Russians have outlawed miracles.”
When she didn’t react he went on. “That was a movie reference. Did you ever watch Casablanca? Nice romantic movie. I’ve seen it maybe a dozen times…”

He was leading them back to the stairwell, only to be stopped short when a pistol emerged from the darkness, followed by the grinning face of a man he thought would be dead by now.

“So you like the romantic movies do you?” Dmitri asked casually, pulling the pistol out of Greg’s belt before he could react, then motioning them back into the relatively debris free central area of the church. The wimp wasn’t a threat to him, now that he’d taken his gun. He carefully kept his pistol firmly trained on the only real threat in the room, that bitch from the bar.

“I’m more of an action movie fan myself.” He said casually, “Seagal, Van Damme, Bruce Willis, Schwarzenegger. Eastwood. You like Clint Eastwood?”

He didn’t really wait for an answer, but continued monologing.

“No? Too bad. I think the spaghetti westerns were his best.”

The bitch’s pistol he collected from her waistband as well, then gestured for the two of them to stand where he could see them clearly. A glance at the confiscated weapons surprised him, and he let out a dry laugh. Here the wimp had been strutting around all dangerous looking, and he’d forgotten load a clip in his pistol.

And that gave him an idea.

“You know what I like most about them?” He asked, not really expecting them to answer. “The big gun fight at the end. Always a big gun fight.”

With a grin, Dmitri ejected the bitches clip, then tossed the pistol back to her. She caught it with a confused look on her face.

“And now we’re going to play a little game.” He continued in a conversational tone, tossing the wimp’s pistol back to him as well as he moved to the center of the space between them, keeping them in his sights as he did so. Five meters in front of the bitch he carefully placed a clip on the ground. Moving to the left he did the same in front of Greg. Lastly he backed up. Making sure the gun was carefully trained on them as he did so, he placed a third clip in front of himself. Of course, his was much closer, but that was because of his wounded legs.

“This game,” he said conversationally, “combines speed, skill, luck, and timing. Kind of like the end scene in a Fist Full of Dollars. Combined with the Good, the Bad, and the Ugly. You are familiar with the movies? Too bad. Classic western cinema. I’m going to eject my clip, then we’re going to race to see who can reach the new clips first. Winner shoots the others. Simple, yes?” As he spoke, he pantomimed the actions. Whether the bitch understood or not he didn’t care, he just wanted to give Greg the illusion that he was giving them a chance. He fully intended that they would die. Greg first of course. A belly shot should make it painful and slow. He would get to watch as the bitch got what was coming to her. What that would be he was still deciding, but it too would be slow and painful. For now, he was waiting until he judged the two of them were at the edge of nervousness. Then he ejected his clip, tossed it, and waited for one of them to make a move.

As expected, the wimp was hesitant and unsure, Looking at him like he didn’t want anything to do with this. The girl, however, looked at him coldly, eyeing the distance between the nearest clip and herself. In that moment Dmitri realized that he maybe he had misjudged her. This was not some dim witted piece of bar fluff to be taken lightly. At this realization he tensed his muscles. He was just about to fling himself forward when she raised her empty pistol and pulled the trigger.

Greg started at the sound of the shot. In disbelieve he saw a look of shock that mirrored his own cross Dmitri’s face. Then, as Greg watched, Dmitri’s legs buckled, pitching him face first into the dust where he lay, unmoving and still. The girl casually strolled over, nudging the body with a toe. When there was no response she spat on the corpse.”

“Sie vergessen immer derjenige in der Kammer. Das ist, wie die meisten Pistole Unfälle passieren, Idioten.”

Greg couldn’t believe it. She’d just shot Dmitri again, this time with an empty gun. Who or what she was he didn’t know, but he was beginning to doubt she really needed his help all this time.

This had to be some sort of side quest.

Unmoving, he watched as she collected the clips from the floor, slipping one into her pistol. Then she walked back to where Dmitri lay, and coldly emptied that clip into the corpse.

“Und ficken bleiben tot, Arschloch!”

She headed for the stairwell, reloading her pistol as she went. Almost as an after thought, she tossed the third clip to Greg.

“Ich hoffe bloody gut, dass ich hier einen Fehler mache nein” she said, leading the way into the darkness. “Wenn du leben willst, komm mit mir”

An army truck is not built for comfort, or speed. The stiff seats are lacking enough padding to be anything more than just slightly uncomfortable. Drafts of winter air leak in through gaps and miss matched panels, bringing with them a cold that the heater barely keeps at bay. Sound deadening between the engine and passenger compartment is almost nonexistent. With the cargo area empty the wooden boards of the cargo bed rattle and bang as the truck rattles and groans its way over the frozen road.

Not the best place to have a conversation, but that didn’t stop Greg from trying.

“This reminds me of the truck I used to drive for my Grandpa.” He said over the roar of the heater motor. “Back on the farm. He always said that anyone could drive an automatic but it took a real man to drive stick.”

She was looking at him with a puzzled look on her face.

“Stick. Stick shift. A manual transmission, you know? Not easy to drive, but Gramps insisted we learn. All the kids did. And they loved to drive that truck.” Greg went on. “Driving it was our reward for helping out around the place. We used to haul hay around for the horses and feed for the cattle. That was the reward for helping out. Getting to drive.” He looked at her questioningly. “Did you ever do something like that? Work hard just because you got to do something you loved while doing it?

“Du bist nicht einer jener Menschen, die die ganze Reise zu sprechen, sind Sie?” she said encouragingly.

Truth be told, Greg wasn’t very good at the kind of small talk that a long drive with a pretty girl should be filled with. And yet the last think he wanted her to think was that he was boring, so he babbled away

“Yeah. I loved driving that truck. I actually thought that’s what I would do when I finished school. Drive the big rigs, you know? Travel the open road? See the country?”
He looked at her to gauge her reaction. She didn’t give him one, so he continued.

“Except it turns out nobody wants to hire a kid with no experience unless he has his own rig, you know. And when I finally got hired on if found that the good jobs always get given to the guys that have been around for ages. The new guy only gets the garbage runs the experienced guys won’t touch. I lasted 6 and a half months before I quit. Got a job doing inner city deliveries with USRPS instead. Been doing that for 6 years now. You ever drive truck?”

The girl looked at him as he asked the question “Oh Gott.” She replied “Sie werden den Weg dorthin zu sprechen”.

“Driving delivery is okay. I mean, the people are great for the most part. Not all of them, of course. Some of them are too full of themselves about how important their little packages are. And I had that one guy on my route who would phone in a complaint every time I was late. Even if it was only a minute. And there’s the other drivers. The cars on the road I mean. The drivers. Some of them are real jerks. There is a reason that the world’s most useless job is a toss up between telephone sanitizer and BMW turn signal mechanic.
Still, It’s a great job and I love it, but lately I’ve been thinking I need to do more with my live. Get a career or something. Maybe meet some one and settle down. I mean, a life of gaming and driving truck is great, but I can’t help feel there’s something missing. You know what I mean?”

An inarticulate grunt was her only answer, so he continued to babble.

“Hey, back there in the church. That logo I found, from the wreck. You recognized it, didn’t you?” Of course she didn’t answer, but he continued none the less. “Of course you would. The same picture was hanging over the bar where we found you. That guy was from the same squadron your bar was at, isn’t he? You probably served the guy all the time. You probably know him. Man, I wish I could really talk to you. I have so many questions about him. That guy was probably the greatest pilot I’ve ever seen. Everybody I know has been shot down by him. Did you know he once single handedly shot down my entire squadron? That was back when we still had enough planes for everyone and we would go out on bombing raids. One day we were on a raid and that guy came out of the clouds and handed us our ass’ on a platter. Just tore us apart. Kind of why I’m on guard duty instead of flying.”

He realized she hadn’t said anything lately and looked over at her.

She was leaning back against the seat with her eyes closed. She’d turned the collar of her jacket up and folded her arms across her chest to ward off the chill of the drafty cab.

‘She can’t really be asleep, can she?’ He wondered.

Of course not, you idiot! the part of his brain that hated him said. She’s only pretending so you will stop talking.

The feeling between that part of his brain and Greg was mutual. There are times when Greg would ignore that part of his brain. Times he actually did things and had fun, in spite of what the nay-say in his head said.

This was not one of those times. He shut up.

Lindsay huddled in her stolen jacket, trying to relax. Blanket Guy seemed quite happy babbling away to himself so she closed her eyes and leaned back, tuning him out. In spite of the jacket and the truck’s heater she felt chilled. Too bad she couldn’t sleep, she thought. She’d never been able to sleep in a car. Or anything that moved really. Something about the constant jostling kept her awake, even when she was dead tired. This time she wasn’t really tired, just cold. There was an icy draft on her legs that was extremely uncomfortable. Leaning forward, she felt around under the dash, trying to find where the draft was coming from. To her surprise, she found an open manual air vent. She slid it closed. Instantly the draft stopped and the cab quickly began to warm up. As the cab warmed up she was able to relax a bit. She put her hands behind her head and stretched her back, easing her stiff muscles

“Hey,” she said, suddenly realizing something. “You stopped talking.”

He was staring out the windscreen, of course. “Izvinite, ya znayu, chto vy pytayetes' spat'.” He said, not taking his eyes off the road.

“Yeah, right.” Lindsay said, sitting upright “You probably thought I was trying to sleep. I didn’t mean to be rude. I wasn’t sleeping. I was just trying to keep warm.” Her shirt was loose and gaping open, showing quite a bit more breast than she intended, so she straightened it up and retied the knot as she leaning towards him “Did you know there’s an air vent under the dash?”

Blanket guy kept driving, checking the mirrors and scanning the road. Looking anywhere else but at her.

She laughed a little inside as she realized what was making him uncomfortable. The blush creeping up his neck gave it away. Boys and their fascination with cleavage. Taking pity on him she straightened up and pulled her jacket back in place.

“Yeah, it was blowing cold air on my legs. Now that it’s stopped I’m warm. Too warm. Mind if I turn the heater down?

“My dolzhny byt' tam cherez paru chasov, Yesli my ne stolknemsya s patrulem.” Blanket Guy replied nervously.

Lindsay took this to mean yes, and flipped the heater switch to medium. The blower noise dropped considerably. Almost to the point where it wasn’t noticeable.

They rode in silence for several minutes. Other than them selves, the road was empty.

“Vy znayete, chto nuzhno etomu gruzoviku?” Blanket Guy said suddenly “Radio. Dazhe staryy gruzovik imel radio”

Lindsay looked at him, then at the two way radio mounted on the dash. Why was he wanting the radio all of a sudden.

“Ne dvukhstoronneye radio. Obychnyy. Dlya muzyki.”

Lindsay still didn’t understand. Did he want to listen to see if there was someone pursuing them? If that was what he was really saying it was actually not a bad idea.
