She was awake again, Greg noticed. Not only that, she’d found an open vent under the dash and had closed it, causing the cab to warm up considerably.
Greg mentally chastised himself for not realizing the vent was open. He knew these old trucks had manual vents, it just hadn’t occurred to him to check.

Then again, she still had her gun. If she’d woken up with him fumbling around between her knees she might have gotten the wrong idea and shot him.

With the cab warming up she had let her jacket fall open. The borrowed shirt must have slipped a couple of buttons while she slept. The front gaped open when she yawned and stretched her back. Suddenly Greg felt a warm flush that had very little to do with the truck heater.

“Hallo! Du hast aufgehört zu redden.” She said while adjusting her shirt.

“It’s okay, I didn’t see anything.” Greg lied, looking straight ahead and concentrating on watching the road. “We should be there in an hour or so, unless we run into a patrol.”

“Ich wollte nur warm bleiben.” She leaned towards him “Wusstest du, dass unter dem Armaturenbrett eine Lüftungsöffnung ist?” she asked, tying her shirt tight

Greg swallowed. He was only half listening to what she was saying anyway, torn between desperately wanting to look at the view she was offering, and knowing it was wrong. He was scared half to death he was going to start leering and making her uncomfortable. He needed a distraction.

“You know what this truck needs?” he said suddenly. “A radio. Even that old farm truck had a radio.”

He started tapping on the steering wheel. “I suppose we can improvise by singing.” He wasn’t sure, but she didn’t look impressed.

“Come on.” He said “It’ll give us something to do.”

When she didn’t respond he started singing;

“East bound and I’m loaded up and trucking. We’re going to do what they say can’t be done. We’ve got a long way to go, and a short time to get there, so sit on back and watch old bandit run.”

She just sat there, looking at him.

“Okay,” he said “Don’t know that one? How about this?

Well, I pulled outta Pittsburgh, rolling down that Eastern Sea board. I got my diesel wound up and she's running like a never before. There's a speed trap ahead on the right, but I don't see a cop in sight. Six days on the road and I'm gonna make it home tonight.”

The girl just looked at him like he was crazy. But in a cute way.

“Okay, you suggest one.”

Again with the blank look of incomprehension.

“Any song at all. I’ll join where I can. It will be fun, I promise.”

She looked at him like she was studying his face for clues to what he was saying. Greg was suddenly aware of just how attracted to this girl he was. Not just the physical aspects either. They were a big bonus, no denying that. But there was a real intelligence when he looked into her eyes. She definitely wasn’t stupid. He was really tempted to believe she was a player. But supposedly the only characters available on their server were pilots. They did have overlaps with the “Called to Battle Duty’ server, but that was all for the infantry parts. And why would someone play as a mere waitress? It didn’t make sense that she was a player and yet she was obviously more than an NPC.

She had to be a quest giver. To Greg that was the only answer that made sense. Whoever had programmed her subroutines had exceeded all expectations and knocked the Turing test out of the ballpark. For a few brief moments Greg fantasized that the side quest was to hole up in a remote cottage and wait out the war by teaching her how to speak Russian while she taught him German. Or maybe inventing a language all of their own. It wasn’t until she sat straight up on her own side of the truck that Greg realized he’d been daydreaming. He hoped to God he hadn’t also been drooling like an idiot.

There is a good minute and a half of awkward silence. Singing still seemed like a good idea. But what? Christmas Carols? They were universal. Everybody knew the tunes and the words. But the bleak snow covered landscape about them certainly didn’t inspire a Christmas like mood.

Then Greg suddenly had the perfect song.

After a few minutes they caught their breath. “Everyone knows Bohemian Rhapsody.” He said “Of course, some of the Rhyming was off.”

He was wondering if there was another song they both knew.

To his delight she started singing another one.
“Ich habe einen Wunsch in den Brunnen geworfen. Frag mich nicht, ich werde nie erzählen. Ich schaute auf Sie, als sie fiel. Und jetzt bist du in meinen Weg.”

Greg thought maybe she was singing a folk at first, yet wondered why the tune sounded familiar. Then he realized the song was a staple of ‘Top Teen Pop Tracks’ on the satellite radio he sometimes listened to in his car, when the radio was actually working.

“Ich tausche meine Seele für einen Wunsch Pfennige und Groschen für einen Kuss Ich war nicht für diese Suche Aber jetzt bist du in meinen Weg”
She obviously liked the song, or at least dancing to it. She was rolling her shoulders in time to the song as she sang.
“Ihre starren hielt. Zerrissene Jeans. Haut zeigte. Heiße Nacht. Wind wehte. Wo du denkst wirst du Baby?”
Hey traf ich nur dich. Und das ist doch verrückt. Aber hier meine Nummer ist. So rufen Sie mich vielleicht.

Pop music wasn’t his favorite genre, but he’d heard this one enough times he could almost think of the name.
She was just singing the middle part of the song when suddenly she grabbed his arm and sat bolt upright, staring into the rear view mirror. “Scheiße. Jetzt nicht.”

Greg looked into his own mirror, seeing nothing. Questioningly, he looked at the girl.

“Ein verdammter Messerschmitt. 4 o Uhr Ebene.” She said hurriedly, pointing back over her shoulder.

Messerschmitt? Crap. Enemy fighters. And this stretch of road was the clear of cover, not even a tree. Just low scrub brush for almost a Kilometer in either direction.

Greg did the only thing he could think of doing and started weaving back and forth across the road, trying to make themselves as difficult a target as possible.

“Nicht in einem vorhersagbaren Muster Sie Idioten!” the girl yelled. Reaching over and grabbing the steering wheel and holding it firmly. The truck started to slide sideways. She held it for a second, finally releasing her hold just before the sliding truck could leave the road. Fishtailing, Greg fought to bring it back under control.

“The fuck are you trying to do? Get us killed? Greg shouted

“Zufällige Bewegungen! Zufällige Bewegungen!. Nicht in einem Muster!”

The road ahead of them erupted in flying dirt and snow as the Messherschmidt roared past.

He’d missed.

Fortunately, there only seemed to be one fighter. A lone patrol without a wingman to follow behind and take out the target if he missed. Of course, the missed pass only meant they got to live until the next one, which looked to be in the immediate future as the fighter climbed and started to turn back for another pass. This time he came at them from the front. This time there would be no missing.

Greg slammed on the brakes, throwing open the door and diving to the road when the truck had slowed down enough for them to do so. As he hit the ground he recalled the advice he’d been given during orientation. “The truck is going to be the fighter’s primary target," one of the older drivers had said. "Run at a right angle to the vehicle. The Kraut won’t bother you as long as the truck is there.” Greg shouted this at his passenger as he ran, forgetting she wouldn’t understand a word of it. He ran until he heard the plane roar passed overhead again, then threw himself to the ground, scrabbling under a scrub brush to hide as the small explosions of cannon fire hitting frozen dirt died away. “Go to ground as he’s passing.” The driver had said. "He won’t be able to keep an eye on you and see where you hide."

Flat on the ground there was no man shaped shadow to define himself as a target, and the grey of his uniform blended in with the surrounding dirt and snow. From the air he'd look like another, maybe slightly larger, feature of the terrain. Or so he hoped that was how it worked.

From under the thin cover of scrub Greg looked back at the truck. It had rolled to a stop, and was now a big black motionless target in the middle of the road, miraculously still untouched. He was hoping against hope that the girl had gotten out and was hiding somewhere along the road, yet knowing in his gut that she didn’t have the same information he had. With any luck the self preservation instincts she seemed to be blessed with would make up for that.

Not a chance. To his astonishment she was not huddled under the semi concealing scrub. Instead, she was standing beside the truck and waving her apron as the fighter came in for another pass. For a long moment he could only sit there, staring in shock. Thinking that it was a pretty stupid thing to be doing, even for an AI.

Before he could gather his wits about him and shout a warning, she exploded.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Twice more the German strafed his position, finally managing to hit the truck on the last pass. It was a long time after the noise of the fighter’s engine had faded into the distance that Greg finally crawled out from under the scrub brush he’d taken refuge under. Only to sink to his knees beside what was left of the girl.

For the longest time he just sat there, staring. Unable to fully comprehend what he was seeing at first, he took it in small details, like he was putting together a mental puzzle. Details like her left shoe had been knocked off and was sitting upright half way between her and the truck. That her toenails, visible through the sheer of her stocking, were painted red. That her skirt had hiked up when she fell, so high he could see her garter. That the garter was red and frilly and had a spare clip of bullets tucked into it. That higher up her bare navel looked flat and firm, and had a belly button that was small and cute and, unlike most girls he’d seen pictures of, completely devoid of any piercings or jewelry. That her shirt was still tied in a tight knot just above that cute little navel. That there was very little of her left above the knot of the shirt, and nothing that didn’t look like extra chunky salsa.

After several minutes Greg managed to stop heaving and pushed himself upright, sitting on his heals and scooping up a handful from the skiff of snow on the rock beside him to try and clear the taste of bile still burning the back of his throat. He had a feeling he would never eat tacos again. The shear senselessness of it all weighed on him. One minute she’d been so warm and alive; Sitting beside him laughing and singing as sweet as any angel. The next she was half of a bloody corpse beside a smoldering truck on a war torn roadway. When he finally rose to his feet he felt as cold and numb as the winter surrounding them.

He turned and started to shuffle away, only to stumble on something. It was her arm, the hand still clutching the white apron she’d tried to wave the plane down with. Without thinking, he picked it up and carried it back and placed it next to where the rest of her lay.

Oddly enough that action made him feel, well, not better, but a sense of rightness. A small patch of relief pasted on a welling cloud of grief that threatened to overwhelm him. A purpose that got him moving again.

Looking around, he located and gathered up what other parts of her body he could find. An arm here. A shoulder there. A large lump that turned out to be a bare breast, possibly the same one he had that tantalizing glimpse of earlier; it’s large brown areola and nipple now completely devoid of any sexual appeal what so ever. There were unidentified bits with shards of bone sticking out. And bits without.

Her head he retrieved from the scrub bush that she should have been hiding under. The bush had cushioned the fall, leaving her face oddly clean and unscathed. Not even a scratch marred her features.

He gathered up as much of her as he could find, then started to scrape out a shallow grave in the frozen ground with one of the hubcaps he found lying nearby. After a few minutes he started to curse his stupidity, threw it aside, and rooted around in the smoldering wreck of the truck until he located a proper shovel.

Maybe he was still shell shocked, but the gore wasn’t bothering him all that much now as he arranged the body in the shallow grave, taking care to tuck the skirt modestly under the knees. The jacket she had left in the truck when they had jumped he laid over the ruins of her chest. With the jacket covering the mess, the body almost looked normal, although even with the eyes closed her face still had a trace of that stunned rage that was her undoubtedly her last emotion, frozen into her features at the time of death.

A burial deserved a moment of solemn silence, which Greg gave, kneeling at the head of the grave. Head bowed and eyes closed . Then he crossed himself the way he remembered she had crossed herself. It seemed appropriate.

The sound of an approaching vehicle intruded, and Greg looked up to see an approaching Jeep. Not really a jeep of course, that was an American word. This was a GAZ which was the Russian equivalent, similar looking but with a more rounded nose, Still, Greg couldn’t help but think of it by the American term Jeep. When it stopped three soldiers got out. Infantry by the looks of their uniforms. Two of them accosted Greg while the third checked out the still smoldering truck.

“Looks like you ran into a bit of trouble.” The first said, almost conversationally.

“Yeah,” Greg said. “You could say that. I don’t suppose you’re headed anywhere near Gulag Four, are you?

“The one under St. Athanasius’?” the second soldier said, glancing sideways at the first soldier in a way that made Greg uneasy. “Yeah. Actually, we’re headed there now.”

“You suppose I could get a lift?” Greg said, in spite of his misgivings. It was too cold to walk.

“Sure.” The first soldier said, a bright smile flashing across his lips. The rest of his face didn’t move. “We’d be happy to give a fellow soldier a lift.” Then his eyes narrowed and his face got all serious again. “I just need to see your orders.”

“Orders?” Greg asked with a sinking feeling in his stomach.

“Yeah.” Gone was any trace of a smile on the soldiers face. All business now, he held out his hand. “Traveling papers. Transfer documents. Unit assignment.”

“Umm,” Greg faltered. “I must have left them in the truck.”

“That true, Jack?” The first soldier called, not even looking over his shoulder to the soldier currently ransacking the trucks cab.

“Nothing in here.” the one referred to as Jack called from the door of the truck.

“I had them, Honest.” Greg pleaded. “Maybe I left them on the dash. That’s it. I left them up on the dash and they blew away when we jumped out.”

“I don’t think so.” The soldier said slowly. “As a matter of fact, I don’t think you ever had orders. You see, the last we saw this truck it was headed to St. Athanasius with another captured flyboy destined for the Gulag. Then, it was to head towards Nekchtickovitch to pick up a load of munitions.”

The man’s eyes never left Greg’s as he spoke.

“Except that here it is, halfway back to the front, and empty except for you and that dead hooker.”

She’s not a hooker.” Greg protested. Why did everyone insist on seeing her that way?
“She’s a waitress. She serves beer.” He stated defensively.

“Sure,” the soldier said with a thin smile. “And I’m a butler. And next you’ll probably say that you’re not a deserter."

“I’m not a deserter.”

“Evidence says otherwise.” The man said, drawing his pistol. “Why else would you and your hooker be headed to the front in a stolen truck?”

"She's not a hooker!"

“You are hereby charged with desertion and theft of Military Property. How do you plead?”

“You can’t be serious.”

“I need an official plea for the record.”

“You can’t put me on trial. I didn’t do anything.”

“I’ll take that as not guilty then, shall I?”

“That’s not what I said.” Greg said desperately, looking at the others. They had come up while the first soldier had been talking and were standing with their own guns drawn in a half circle around him.”

“You can’t be serious.”

“Guilty on all the charges.” The first soldier said with a grin.

Too late, Greg turned to run.

Three guns went off simultaneously.

The first soldier watched Greg’s body as it slowly stopped twitching. After a couple of minutes he picked up the shovel. Placing the point of it against Greg’s throat he stomped hard, ignoring the blood that seeped out around the edge. Again he stomped, splattering gore on his pant leg and severing Greg’s spinal column. After adjusting the angle of the shovel he brought his foot down hard one last time, severing what remaining tissue was holding the head on the body. As the head rolled away he used the shovel to scooped it up and carry it over to the jeep, dumping it onto the passenger side floor.

“Hey,” one of the other guards yelled. “I have to sit back there.”

“I called shotgun. Not my problem.” The second called. “Hey, you want we should take the other head too? It’s already off.”

A few minutes later the jeep and its sorry cargo roared off, spinning tires sending a spray of slush and dirt across Greg’s body which lay beside the road where it had fallen.

Eventually, a light snow began to fall, gradually dusting the bodies with a thin coating of white that covered the signs of violence with a pristine veil.

Half an hour later the entire 127th was dressed and gathered a table in a corner of the 104th’s cafeteria, listening as Lindsay told the story of what she’d been up to. Those who hadn’t been woken up by Lindsay’s scream had been roused by those who had. Not one of them seemed to mind too much about being up early, especially Leslie. She was very happy her theory about violent in-game deaths being fatal looked like it had been just dis proven.

By the time Lindsay had reached the part where her and Blanket Guy had stolen the truck the cafeteria had began serving breakfast, so Lindsay loaded up a tray and finished off her story as she worked her way through a mound of her favorite German Apple pancakes, with a side of bacon, eggs, hash browns, toast, and anything else she could get a fork into.

“Holy crap, girl!” Colleen said as Lindsay came back with a second tray piled nearly as high as her first. “Are you eating for two now?”

“With the size of those helpings it’s more like three!” Addison chirped. .

“Hey, I’m starving.” Leslie protested. “I haven’t eaten anything except that bowl of gruel since I was captured. I’m making up for lost calories.”

“I thought you said it was two bowls.” Lorraine said.

“One was half empty, so that doesn’t count. And they were small.”

“Well,” Addison added “If that’s what the Russians eat I’m glad I’m on the German side.”

“I’ve played the Russian side.” the Colonel said, watching Lindsay eat. “Usually they eat as well as we do.” There was a thoughtful look on her face. “Gruel is more like what you’d feed prisoners or captives.”

“Well I certainly qualified as a prisoner!” Lindsay retorted “Locked up in that room with nothing to eat and forced to wait tables.” Her face darkened “And for food that pig of an officer wanted me to…!” Lindsay slammed her fist into the table, causing the plates on the table to jump.

“Sorry,” she apologized, then closed her eyes and took a deep breath to calm down.

“That’s okay” Bev said, wiping the spilled coffee off the table in front of her. “That was right before you shot him, wasn’t it?”

“Yeah, pretty much.” Lindsay admitted, turning back to her stack of pancakes, although her appetite wasn’t the same as it was a minute ago. Still, a girl has got to eat.

“From the sounds of it he got what he deserved.”

That brought a grim smile to Lindsay’s face “Yeah, I guess he did.” She said, looking around for her fork. To her surprise it was stuck handle first into the table top. When had that happened? Lindsay tugged at it, but it was stuck fast.

“Um, could someone get me another fork, please?”

One was tossed her way, which she deftly caught in midair.

“So, yeah.” She continued, a little calmer. “I wouldn’t be surprised if they were all eating bear steaks and beet stew, while all I got was gruel from the soup trolley.”

“A whole soup trolley, just for you?” The Colonel asked thoughtfully.

“Not just for me,” Lindsay said around a mouthful of pancake, “I think Blanket Guy was supposed to be delivering it to the basement. They had a holding cell down there and I caught a glimpse of people in prison uniforms when the guard opened the door.”

“About how big was this trolley?” The Colonel asked.

“About average.” Lindsay said, shrugging. She pointed towards the back of the mess with her new fork. “Same as the ones in the kitchen there.”

“I don’t suppose you saw how much gruel was in the pot?”

“Not really. I remember the pot said 305 Liter on the handle, ‘cause the number struck me as an odd measurement for a liquid. But I’m pretty sure it wasn’t quite full. Come to think of it, there was a tag on the side that said 256 Litry Supa. Probably Russian for 256 liters of supper.”

The Colonel got up and refilled her coffee cup, her expression indicating she was mulling something in her head while she did so. “How many men do you think you could feed with 256 liters’ of soup? She asked eventually.

“I don’t know. 100? 200? Not something I ever thought of.”

“Grampa use to work in a soup kitchen.” Addison piped up. “He often said he could feed 100 men with 5 gallons of soup.”

“That’s not a reference to the loaves and fishes thing is it?” That was Lorraine.

“Loaves and Fishes?” Addison asked, a little confused.

“Yeah.” Colleen said. “Like in the bible when Jesus was trying to feed the multitude and all he had was a basket of fish and a loaf of bread. Although personally I think he might of had a ‘Skip the Dishes’ app on his phone.”

“That makes no sense.” Lorraine replied.

“Yeah,” Addison added “Skip the Dishes is only in North America, so it wouldn't be a bible reference. Anyway, it was an actual thing Grampa used when figuring out how much food to buy. Five gallons for 100 people.”

That’s food for almost 1300 people!”

He’d been looking into the MIA’s like you’d suggested, and according to the figures he’s dug up, there are an astonishing number of players that are listed as MIA even thought they have had more than enough time to make their way back to base. 1256 of them, to be exact.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Three hours later Lindsay was in front of the 83rd’s hangers, squeezing through yet another belly hatch of an HE111 idling on the tarmac. This time it was the flight leaders. As she clambered up to the cockpit she recognized Captain Robert Stone from her jogging group, already at the controls going through the preflight checks.

“Welcome aboard” he said, as Lindsay settled herself onto the bench behind the nose gun. “I hear you are going to guide us to some precise bombing this morning.”

“That’s right” Lindsay said. She was still a little bewildered at the speed of which Colonel Helgameire had put together the raid, but she was determined not to show it.

"I was wondering when you'd get here."

"Sorry for the delay. I had to adjust the settings in the other bombers, and took longer than expected."

“You really think we’ll pull this off?”

“If you and your boys can hold your pattern, and I don’t mess up. Yeah”

“Tower to Maxim 20 leader," the radio crackled "Prepare for takeoff.”

“Roger that, tower. All aircraft, signal ready.”

When all the other pilots had indicated their readiness, Captain Roberts pressed the mike again. “All aircraft, this is flight leader. Pull chocks and prepare for takeoff.”
With that, the Captain opened the throttles and the heavily laden bomber began to bump and bounce as it moved down the runway, closely followed by the eight other aircraft of the flight. Unlike the fighter pilots, the bombers seem to relish taking off in formation.

Once the wheels retracted Captain Roberts made his final transmission. “Tower, this is flight leader. All birds are in the air. Operation Maxim 20 is on it’s way.

“Roger that, flight leader.” The tower responded “Good luck boys.”

“Operation Maxim 20.” Captain Roberts said to Lindsay over the noise of the engines. “What’s that code name mean, anyway?”

“It means,” Lindsay responded “I’ve finally found something about my commanding officer to love.”

Behind his goggles Roberts raised his eyebrows, but didn’t say anything. A lot of the information in the hurried meeting this morning was passed around on a need to know basis, and a lot of stuff was glossed over. He was dying to know what his curvy bombardier was referring to, but didn’t want to distract her from the job. His commander had stressed the importance of the mission, and that somehow the young first lieutenant with the ample assets had a major role to play in pulling it off. He only hoped there would be an opportunity later on to get some answers.

And after that, they both got busy with their own jobs, and, and didn’t speak until long after they were airborne.

“5 Minutes to target” Captain Robert radioed to the rest of the flight when Lindsay signaled him. “Check position and altitude.”

Lindsay had been hunched over her station since they had changed course after takeoff. Unlike the previous flights where she’d taken the time to enjoy the scenery, this time she fretted and fussed, checking and rechecking the settings. Current altitude. Heading. Wind direction both aloft and on the ground. Making small adjustments as she noted discrepancies between the posted reports she was reading and what she could see through the bombsite. Until the watch she had borrowed from the flight stores at the 87th had indicated it was time to give the five minute warning. Now she closed her eyes and breathed deep, trying to calm her nerves. So much was riding on this mission, and now the moment of truth was almost on them. After several moments her nerves steadied so she opened her eyes and looked back into the bombsite. Just like before the control of the big plane was divided between her control station and Captain Stone’s. With him keeping the bomber straight and level, she concentrated on the task of making the small course corrections that would get them over their target.

For this mission she’d been issued her own headset plugged into the radio, and she triggered her throat mic, saying as crisply and precisely as she could “Maxim 20 leader to all ships. Confirm position and altitude.”

Behind her in the other bombers that made up the strike force the pilots confirmed they were right where they were supposed to be. Strung out behind her like three chevrons, one behind the other.

“Confirm fuse delay by the numbers.” she called back, once everyone acknowledged they were in position.

One by one the following bombers radioed back the delay on their bomb fuse, which Lindsay checked off against the clipboard beside her knee.

So far so good. “Confirm radio delay and sync.”

With the radio link in place, all the bomb release triggers were linked to the one in Lindsay’s plane. When she pushed the button, the nine aircraft of the MAXIM 20 strike force would drop their load of bombs.

One by one, each aircraft radioed back that their link was ready. Lindsay dutifully put a check mark on her clipboard beside each aircraft.

She looked back into the bomb sight. Almost there. Wetting her lips with a tongue that was too dry for the job, she gave the command. “Arm bomb release.”

Again the litany of confirmations came back. Behind her pilots flipped the switches linking their bomb release with hers until all were ready. Now all it would take is a press of her finger and 32,400 Kilograms of high explosive in hardened steel casing would rain down on an unsuspecting enemy. Lindsay poised her finger above the button as the cross hairs crept slowly closer to her release point.

Lindsay held her breath, then stabbed her finger down as the cross hairs intersected the release point at last. The plane lurched and shuddered as the payload was released.

“Bombs away” she said into her throat mike, unnecessarily. Behind her she could imagine what was happening on each of the aircraft. The radio beeping as it acknowledged it had received the order to drop. The short preprogrammed delay to allow that aircraft to move into the position that would allow the bombs to hit where they were calculated to do the most damage. Then the shuddering of release as the bombs dropped.

Lindsay imagined all of this, repeated for each of the eight aircraft following. If she’d done her job well the enemy stronghold would be wiped out. If she hadn’t, if she missed, there would be little or no damage. Worse, the Russians would been alerted that the Germans were onto their scheme and would take steps to prevent the success of future raids. With the familiar feeling of butterflies in her gut Lindsay racked the sight backwards, zooming out a little, watching the target and barely breathing as the unseen bombs streaked downward. Focusing on the cliff face and the single truck at the bottom that marked the loading dock, the only part visible of the labyrinth under the mountain where their comrades were being held. For as long as she could she watched it, until her aircraft passed overhead and the view was blocked by the top of the cliff the church was built on.

Still she held her breath.

Then the parking lot at the base of the cliff exploded.

With a sigh Lindsay pulled off her headset. “Maxim 20”, she said to no one in particular. Then she buried her face in her hands.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
Lindsay was sitting at a table with the rest of the 127th. The 104th mess hall was larger than the officers club, so today it was hosting the après bombing party for the combined forces from the mornings raid. In typical Lindsay fashion, she was not saying much of anything. Just letting the jokes and conversation wash over her as usual. Occasionally people would wander by and congratulate her about the job, and she was basking in the attention. Sure, she was proud of the accomplishment. But there was a difference between being justifiably proud of your own achievements, and having a whole bunch of people recognizing that you had done them.

She would have to be careful, she decided. A person could get addicted to that feeling of pride and self confidence. At least it covered that persistent feeling of nagging self doubt that threatened to crawl out from under that rock in the back of her mind, in spite of the large amount of alcohol she had carefully placed on top of it.

That thought depressed her a little, and she was staring at the mouth of her beer bottle wondering why that was so when her mussing was interrupted.

“Hey there, Lieutenant.”

Lindsay looked up. It was Captain Roberts.

“Hey Captain” she replied, maybe a little more cheerfully than she was actually feeling.

“I was hoping to congratulate you on a good job up there today, and maybe buy you the first beer.”

“It’s a little late for that,” Lindsay grinned, waving her bottle, “But you can buy me my fifth if you want.” She tipped back her bottle and drained it. “Or maybe it’s the sixth.”

When she put the empty bottle on the table she was surprised to see the Captain had another one ready for her.

“Planned ahead did you?” She asked.

“Of course, the Captain laughed.” That’s what being a good pilot is all about. Cheers!” he said, tilting his bottle in Lindsay’s direction.

“Cheers.” She laughed, clinking the neck of her bottle against his.

“You look much happier now than when you got off my plane earlier.” He said after a couple of minutes.

“Yeah, sorry about that.” She shrugged “Stress does that to me.”

“Tell me about it.” The Captain said “At first I thought it was because you hit the parking lot instead of the church. But then everyone was on about how successful the raid was. How does that work out?”

One of the things they hadn’t had time for, before the raid, was explaining to everyone exactly what they were trying to accomplish. Lindsay took another swallow and thought her way through the explanation.”

“Okay,” she said “You know the bombs we dropped were deep penetrators, right? That’s why we drop them from so high. So they can gather enough kinetic energy to sink deep into the dirt and rock before they explode. Which is great when used against buried installations. But even the deepest penetrator we have wouldn’t have been able to get through the mountain and reach the lower levels where the prisoners were kept. So what we did was the next best thing.”

“We blew up the parking lot?” the Captain asked “What, so they can’t move the prisoners out?”

“Hardly.” Lindsay laughed “The parking lot was at about the same level as the dungeons, and right at the end of a box canyon. Since we couldn’t hit the target directly, we hit beside it. The bombs I dropped from the three lead aircraft sank really deep into the soft earth under the parking lot and created a huge underground crater. Plus a shock wave that should have also weakened or collapsed any foundation structure. Then the bombs from the second and third wings sheared the face of the mountain off, collapsing it down into the crater hole and turning the impenetrable underground fortress into a collapsed pile of impenetrable rubble. Even if we didn’t get the whole structure anything left should have collapsed on itself from the secondary shock waves.”

Captain Roberts just stood there, gazing in awe. “That’s brilliant!” he finally said.

“Yeah, I know, right?” Lindsay replied. “I stole the idea from the Brits. They called them Earthquake Bombs. They were quite proud of them.” She took another drink from her beer. “Hey, did you know that for years after the war ended they had a live 10,000kg bomb on display outside the RAF base in Lincolnshire. Families would come and look at it, have picnics, take pictures of their kids sitting on it. All with typical British aplomb. Then someone decided it was too dangerous and hauled it off to a field and set it off. The blast could be heard for 60km. You wanna know what they called it?”

“The Captain gave a smile. “Let me guess, they called it a Maxim 20?”

“Nope. They called it Ten Ton Tessie. I would have called it a 10 Double K Kelly myself, you know? Two Ks ‘cause it was 10 kilo kilograms. But maybe that sounds like a marathon runner.”

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
“So what is a Maxim 20?" The Captain asked "Why was that the code name for the mission?”

“Oh that.” Lindsay shrugged and drained the rest of her beer. “It’s number 20 of the 77 highly quotable maxims for successful mercenaries. Something about if you’re not willing to bomb your own position, you’re not going to win.”

“Actually,” a voice interrupted from behind them. “The maxim reads If you’re not willing to shell your own position, you’re not willing to win.”

Lindsay spun around and saluted crisply, or tried to. At least as crisply as the five beers in her would let her. She was relatively successful in her attempt though, if you count that she didn’t blacken her own eye as success. And gave bonus points for not falling off her bench.

“Hey Colonel,” she stammered “I was just putting the quote into a perspective the Captain here could relate to.”

“So I gather. Still, if you’re going to go about quoting Schlock, you might as well get it right.”

“Schlock, eh?” The Captain asked “A brilliant military strategist like that Sun Tsu guy? The one who wrote the art of war?”

“Hardly,” the Colonel said. “Schlock is an anamorphic brown blob who is a character in a relatively popular Web Comic.”

Sometimes, when a person is thinking something is very profound, and then they are told the source was something they totally didn’t expect, that shatters their expectations of what they were thinking they were going to hear and kicks their brain goes into neutral. When that happens sometimes something embarrassing will slip out. Something like “You love your Colonel because of a web comic?”

And sometimes all the conversation in a room just happens to stop just at the right time and allows everybody around you to hear that comment.

Fortunately this was not one of those times, at least in relation to the ambient noise level in the room.

As for the blurted out comment, however.

It turned out the only three people who actually heard it were actively involved in the current conversation.

Had Lindsay been reasonably sober, she would have found herself desperately wished there was at least one fewer person who had heard. Possibly two, if she could push her luck that far.

Especially since one of those persons just mentioned now looked at Lindsay, raising her eyebrows questioningly.

Ordinarily, Lindsay would have cowered, and possibly ran, but today with courage born of, and bolstered by, the beer in her belly, Lindsay decided to brazened it out.

“Of course,” she said, in spite of her ears reddening. “Anyone who can quote the 77 Maxims is obviously a fan of the strip. Like I said. One more thing to love about her.”

To her surprise, the Colonel was smiling at her. “Why, thank you Lindsay. Although I doubt if I can really remember any more than eight or nine of them, and certainly not all of them by number.”

“And yet,” gushed an emboldened Lindsay heedlessly, “Any fan of my favorite space opera deserves the love and admiration of the lowly staff who serve beneath her. Of those who serve and obey and willingly die for her. And that I would do willingly. I would be happy, no, eager, no, honored to die to please my brave commander.”

“Lindsay.” The Colonel said, still smiling, but with her eyes hardening and her voice taking on a dangerous tone. “Are you truly so willing to die? Right now?”

“But of course I am,” Lindsay continued, before catching sight of the Colonels smile. “Well, maybe.” She faltered “Actually, probably not.”

She had layered it on a little thick.

“Then shut up.” the Colonel said in a tone that suggested she might be joking, but did you want take the chance?

“Yes sir. Shutting up now, sir.”

“Hey Lindsay” Colleen said through the open door of the hut Lindsay and Linda had shared the last couple of days. “Final scores are up, if you’re interested.

Lindsay looked up from the carryall she was packing. Why she was bothering to do so was a bit of a mystery to her, after all. It wasn’t like her luggage was going to accompany her back into the real world. Still, she supposed the ritual gave her a bit of closure. One more firm indication that the game was over.

“So how did we do?” she asked, carefully shaking out and folding a blouse she’d never gotten around to wearing.

“None of us qualified the cash prizes, unfortunately. A couple of honorable mentions. Team spirit award for cooperation. One for fewest losses due to enemy action. That sort of thing. You got an honorable mention in the category of most versatile pilot.”

“I don’t suppose that gave me enough points to put me back into the black?”

“Nope,” Colleen said, shaking her head. “Still well in the red.”

That would be all the penalty points she’d racked up when she’d dropped the bombs. 1200 penalty points each for every friendly killed. And because the bombs had released on her command, all the penalties were awarded to her alone. A bit unfair when the pilots on the raid had actually been awarded points for success.

“If it helps at all, the 127th has the dubious distinction of having a pilot with the all time record of penalty points” Colleen continued, as if pressing the point home.

You just don’t come back from a negative score that was well into seven digits.

In spite of the fact that her actions had released over 1000 German airmen and changed the balance of power in the game,

When all the prisoners killed by Lindsay’s bombing raid had re-spawned, the German side was suddenly fully manned and able to take advantage of all the equipment that had stockpiling up. Eager for revenge over their treatment and with the balance of power now heavily shifted to their side, the Germans lost no time in wiping the Russian forces off the map where ever they could find them.

Two days and three missions later, the game was officially over.

All that was left to do was collect the awarded points and pack their stuff.

And say goodbye.

The rest of the 127th was crowded into the small hanger that had become their ad-hoc officers club solely because it was right next to the tool shed Leslie was calling her office. The industrious girls had scrounged what they could to outfit the temporary space; there was an old phonograph and a stack of records in place of the Jukebox. An old washing tub filled with ice sat perched on a couple of saw horses and served to keep the beer cold. Someone had done a half decent job of copying the squadron logo onto a bed sheet to hang on the wall in place the original company mascot. Although a few chairs and benches had been pilfered from the 104th when someone was convinced to look the other way, the tables were still roughly fabricated of shipping pallets on top of parts crates, some of them still containing spare parts.

The rough atmosphere seemed somehow appropriate for the going away party; Adding an atmosphere of spontaneity to the gathering. The few beers rapidly deteriorated into a round of tearful hugs and earnestly vague promises of keeping in touch, and the next thing Lindsay knew she was walking through a doorway in Leslie's office she knew wasn’t there an hour ago.

As she passed the threshold the world dissolved into flecks of colourless shades of drab grey, swirling and coalescing into the washed out image of a room.

Lindsay’s living room.

1543121222221211222122111221122222121221.content:
With a grunt of effort Lindsay pulled off the headset and pushed it aside, rubbing his temples and the sides of his face where the memory foam edging had been pressing.

After the fluid ease of the body he had gotten used to, it took him a couple of minutes to re-acquaint himself with the way his real body worked.

And smelled. The odor was almost overwhelming as he unsteadily disconnected the harness of tubes and wires and climbed unsteadily out of the suspension cradle. A shower was his first priority, he decided, then changed his mind as a wave of dizziness swept over him and he staggered, barely catching himself against a conveniently close wall.

No, he decided. Something to eat first, then a shower.

Groggily, he made his way across the tiny apartment to the kitchen, deciding on the way that prepping a microwave meal was beyond him at the moment, and settling for a can of meal replacement from the fridge.
He downed the first while standing in front of the fridge, then grabbed a second when the first failed to fill the gaping maw of hunger inside him. He was actually on his third by the time he felt energetic enough to pay attention to the recorded voice from the refrigerator; a tiny, cheerful sounding voice that endlessly repeated a cheery good afternoon greeting, and reminding him that he needed to buy milk and eggs, that the tuna casserole was out of date, and also that the refrigerator door was still open.

Pushing the door closed, Lindsay turned and staggered into the tiny bathroom attached to the kitchen to tackle the task of taking a shower.

Just his luck the building hot water was out again. Which meant that his planed fifteen minute cleansing became a mere two minutes of slightly tepid rinsing. Adequate enough to flush away the worst of the dried sweat and crud that was crusted to his skin, but did little to sooth his soul. Still he felt marginally reenergized afterwards, enough to throw a pair of sweats and order a pizza for dinner.

While he waited for it to arrive he turned his attention to cleaning the VR cradle. Cleaning the cradle was a ritual that he had forced on himself early on, and was now an ingrained habit. Even though every component and surface was made of, and treated with, the highest quality anti-bacterial materials available, not a week went by without there being a news article on someone who had developed toxic shock or a septic infection that was being blamed on a dirty VR Rig. Horror stories abounded of people who had to have toes, fingers, legs, and even genitals either partly or completely amputated because of septic bacterial infections.

Cleaning the rig wasn’t an inconvenience, it was a necessity.

Fortunately, the designers made the rig as easy to clean as possible. Armed with a bucket of hot soapy water (boiled on the stove) and a couple of cleaning rags he wiped away the weekends worth of caked on sweat and other stuff, which is what his mind preferred to call the goo that leaked around the joints and valves of the tubes that carried away the body waste. Then he sprayed everything with a specially formulated blend of rubbing alcohol and room deodorizer. Mountain Fresh Breeze this fragrance was called. He usually preferred it over the Lavender Garden he’d bought by accident because it was on sale, and only kept only in the event there was a chance he would have female visitors unexpectedly drop by. That this hadn’t happened yet, and was unlikely to happen in the foreseeable future, was not a factor in his mind.

The pizza arrived as he was putting everything away, so he grabbed a couple of slices, a beer, and settled in front of his terminal to get caught up on the news as he ate.

May as well before you get totally broken in where you’re going,” he gave a bubbling hum at that, his species way of laughing.

You growled in the mask, glad that the sounds of the port around you kept it from reaching anyone else’s ears. He gave another you lecherous look before pointing you up the gangplank. The human said something to the other, too low for you to hear, but the Wir laughed again as he turned to watch the hillocks of your rump retreating towards the ship.

Inside, the ship was in marginally better repair, though the sound of the air filtration system gave you some concern. You were shoved along by another guard – this one a Gevar in what looked to be riot gear – till you came to a cramped cell. Another push caused you to stumble inside, and the door slammed shut behind you. The only light you had was an extremely dim reddish glow, barely enough to see the wall in front of you. You growled as you realized that you were still bound hand and foot, they obviously weren’t even going to let their prisoners get the least bit comfortable. You managed to find the “bed” though it was only a hard metal platform extending out of the wall with no padding of any sort. The way you were restrained meant that you couldn’t lay on your back, and even lying on your side proved tricky, but you made do.

Sometime later, you felt the familiar rumble of a ship lifting off from a planet, eventually followed by the lingering sense of vertigo and nausea that an improperly tuned or maintained void drive jump could cause. You were actually more than a little glad that was all that happened, if the drive was in a really bad condition the ship could be ripped apart or worse. With nothing else to do, you closed your eyes to wait, but quickly opened them again as you heard a sound.

The exact mechanics and spread of VR in everyday life is entirely open to the individual writer, but here's a general basis:

VR has advanced to the point where users are able to be experience full-sensory, convincing, computer-generated worlds. More advanced VR may come equipped with perception dilation technology, which essentially overclocks the brain, allowing hours of simulation

Many variant of VR technology exist, though they can loosely be divided into two groups: anchored and inserted. Anchored is where the user remains in their body, and a computer-brain interface is established, usually via a headset or implanted neural lattice, while the sensations of the artificial world is beamed directly into the brain. the alternative, insertion VR, downloads the mind of the user into the simulation itself. The user's body is left an empty shell, awaiting the mind to be replaced back in the body at the end of the simulation.

Both types come with inherent weaknesses. Anchored V has been known to cause brain damage under high perception dilation, in simulations featuring extremes of sensations, or if the user is unplugged unexpectedly. Though real world motor control is generally suppressed, users may still injure themselves accidentally. In semi-rare cases, the RL body may manifest injuries incurred in simulation.

Insertion VR avoids most of these problems by seperating the mind and body completely - this also allows much greater perception dilation than anchored VR without any risk of melting the brain. The most obvious downside is that the body is left totally vulnerable in the real world and any disruption of the brain-computer link may leave the downloaded user stuck in the simulation until a connection can be reestablished. To reduce these risks, the users body may be Installed with a Bodyguard program, a rudimentary AI that takes care of the users body in RL for the simulation duration.

Perhaps the biggest risk in VR with both types is of the user becoming unable to leave the simulated world. If this happens - usually through user or programming error - the user's body may be at risk of starvation, dehydration, and dying, particularly if perception dilation is not active. Alternatively, if it is active, the mind may experience years or even decades inside. They may even forgot that they are in a simulation and lose their identity completely.

To reduce the risk of this, most simulations have programmed safeguards and means of logging out. Should a timer not be set, many scenarios have an end goal, a mission or mission that when completed will end the game automatically. Should this fail, many simulations come with a carefully concealed 'exit', usually a door, often with a distinguishing feature, which when passed through will return the player to their body. Safety words can be set which end the simulation immediately. Finally, anybody accustomed to the programming language, may use the in-world console to end or at least modify the parameters.

Despite all the risks, virtual reality has become enmeshed in almost all aspects of life. Entertainment, gaming, education, Training sims, teleconferencing, even dating, all have capitalised on the new tech. The virtual sex industry is booming. As is, unfortunately, virtual identity theft.

VIA (Virtual Identity Assistance), the government agency that has come to oversee the use of the technology, lists the following safety guidelines on its website.

1. Users must be aged over 18, and be of robust physical and mental health
2. Never under any circumstances, remove or switch-off a VR headset that is currently in use.
3. Do not enter VR while under the effects of alcohol or other drugs.
4. Have friends keep watch over your body while under VR.
5. Take a fifteen minute break for every hour of play.
6. Do not use equipment calibrated for other users.
7. Do not use the log-in details and/or assumed identity of other users. Users found breaking this will face criminal prosecution under the Identity Protection Act of 2014.

Naturally nobody takes the slightest bit of notice of these guidelines.
